ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 2014-24
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A COMPILATION OF CITY ORDINANCES ENTITLED
THE ENID MUNICIPAL CODE, 2014, AND ESTABLISHING THE SAME; PROVIDING FOR
REPEALER OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER
OF AMENDING AND SUPPLEMENTING SUCH CODE; PROVIDING FOR PUBLISHING THE NAME OF
EACH TITLE AND A SUMMARY OF THEIR CONTENT.
   ORDINANCE
   BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF THE CITY OF ENID,
OKLAHOMA:
   Section I: That the compilation of city ordinances, consisting of titles 1
to 13, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Enid Municipal
Code, 2014," which code shall supersede all general and permanent ordinances of
the city adopted on or before May 7, 2014, to the extent provided in section 2
hereof.
   Section II: That all provisions of such code shall be in full force and
effect from and after the date of this ordinance's publication and all
ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the city adopted on or before
May 6, 2014, and not included in such code or recognized and continued in force
by reference therein, are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of
this code.
   Section III: That the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be
construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a
subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance.
   Section IV: That unless another penalty is expressly provided, a violation
of any provision of such code, or any provisions of any rule or regulation
adopted or issued pursuant thereto, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs and fees as provided by the code.
   Section V: That any and all additions and amendments to such code, when
passed and approved in such form as to indicate the intention of the mayor and
board of commissioners to make the same a part of such code, shall be deemed to
be incorporated in such code so that reference to such code shall be understood
and intended to include such additions and amendments.
   Section VI: That in case of the amendment of any section of such code for
which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in section 4
of this ordinance shall apply to the section as amended.
   Section VII: Any ordinance adopted after May 7, 2014, which amends or refers
to ordinances which have been codified in such code shall be construed as if
they amend or refer to like provisions of such code.
   Section VIII: The continuance in effect of temporary and/or special
ordinances, although omitted from this code, shall not be affected by such
omission therefrom and the adoption of this code shall not repeal or amend any
such ordinance or part of such ordinance omitted therefrom. Among the temporary
and/or special ordinances not repealed or amended by this code are the
following: Ordinances relating to special paving or sewer districts and special
assessments; vacating, opening and dedicating specific streets and alleys;
relating to specific bond issues; annexing territory to or excluding it from
the city; designating or amending land use and/or zoning; relating to grade and
alignment of specific streets; granting railroad use of specific streets and
alleys; naming, or changing the name of, specific streets and alleys; abating
special nuisances; and all other temporary and/or special ordinances.
Ordinances granting franchises shall not be repealed or amended by the adoption
of this code.
   Section IX: That the name of each title and a summary of their contents by
table of contents is to be attached hereto and published with this ordinance.
   Section X: This ordinance and the recodification of this code is authorized
by 11 O.S. §§ 14-101 - 111, as amended.
   Passed and approved by the mayor and board of commissioners on the 6th day
of May, 2014.
   THE CITY OF ENID, OKLAHOMA
                                                      
   William E. Shewey, Mayor             
(SEAL)
ATTEST:
                                                   
Linda Parks, City Clerk
Approved as to Form and Legality
                                                   
Andrea L. Chism, City Attorney

PART A. BASIC CHARTER
PREAMBLE
   We, the people of the City of Enid, Garfield County, Oklahoma, under the
authority of the Constitution of the State of Oklahoma, do ordain and establish
this Charter for the City of Enid.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Section A.1.1. Organization And Name.
   That the inhabitants of the City of Enid, Garfield County, Oklahoma, within
the boundaries hereinafter described and such additional territory as may be
hereafter added thereto, and their successors be and are hereby created and
organized a Municipal Corporation, with perpetual succession, under the style
and name of "The City of Enid", and as such, they and their successors are by
these present organized and created a body politic and corporate, and shall
succeed to, own, possess and control all the books, records, documents, and all
the property, real, personal or mixed, and all the rights, privileges,
franchises, powers and immunities now belonging to and possessed or enjoyed by
the municipal corporation known as "The City of Enid"; that it shall be subject
to and liable for all legal debts, liabilities, judgments, bonds, notes and
other legal obligations for which the present corporation is now or may
hereafter become legally bound; that the corporation hereby created and its
successors, in said corporate name of "The City of Enid," shall have power to
sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, complain, intervene, prosecute and
defend in all courts; and shall have power to make contracts, to take and
acquire property, by purchase or otherwise, necessary for the public good, and
to own, hold, sell, lease, convey or otherwise dispose of any real or personal
property within or outside of the city limits; that it shall have, exercise and
enjoy other and additional powers, rights, privileges, franchises and
immunities as are granted by existing laws or may be granted and conferred by
any other provision hereinafter adopted; that it shall use a corporate seal of
such design as the elective officers hereinafter provided may designate.
Section A.1.2. Boundaries.
   The boundaries and limits of the City of Enid are hereby established, and
are the same as are now prescribed and defined in Ordinance Number 603, as
passed by the Mayor and City Council, together with such additional territory
as may be hereafter annexed.

ARTICLE III. POWERS GENERALLY
Section A.3.1. Police Department.
   The City of Enid shall have power, by ordinance duly passed, to establish
and maintain a city police department, prescribe the duties of policemen, and
regulate their conduct.
Section A.3.2. Regulation Of Amusements.
   To permit, forbid or regulate theatres, balls, dance houses and other public
amusements, and to suppress the same whenever the preservation of order,
tranquility, public safety or good morals may demand.
Section A.3.3. Regulation Of Intoxicating Liquors.
   To prohibit dram shops, drinking saloons and other places where intoxicating
liquors are sold, and to close variety theatres when necessary, expedient or
advisable.
Section A.3.4. Prohibit Bawdy Houses, Etc.
   To prohibit and punish keepers and inmates of bawdy houses and variety
shows; to prevent and suppress assignation houses and houses of ill fame, to
determine such inmates and keepers to be vagrants and to provide for the
punishment of such persons.
Section A.3.5. Regulate Weights And Measures.
   To inspect weights and measures, fix standards of weight and measures, and
to fix the penalties for not using or conforming to the same, and to provide
that inspection fees may be fixed by ordinance.
Section A.3.6. Regulation Of Taverns, Public Transportation, Etc.
   To make all needful and proper regulations concerning keepers of taverns and
other public houses, draymen, horse drivers, omnibus drivers, hack drivers, and
drivers of baggage wagons and vehicles; to establish maximum rates for all
kinds of transportation within the city limits, to prevent extortion, and to
preserve order and prevent noises and confusion in and about the several depots
on the arrival and departure of railway trains, and to provide how and where
hacks and other carriers shall stand or take their positions upon the streets
adjacent or near to said depots, and where they shall stand when receiving or
discharging passengers.
Section A.3.7. Prohibit Gambling.
   To suppress gambling houses, and to punish keepers of gambling houses and
poolrooms, and all persons who play cards or games of chance of any kind, and
to punish persons who sell lottery tickets or who advertise lottery drawings or
schemes and results of drawing of lotteries.
Section A.3.8. Inspect Dairy Products.
   To provide for the inspection of milk, cream, butter and all dairy products
offered for sale, in the City of Enid, and to prescribe the fees to be charged
therefor.
Section A.3.9.Establish And Regulate Public Grounds; Regulation Of Livestock At
Large.
   To establish and regulate public grounds and regulate and restrain and
prohibit the running at large of horses, mules, asses, cattle, sheep, goats,
swine, geese, ducks, chickens and pigeons, and the distraining, impounding and
sale of the same for the cost of the proceedings and the penalty incurred, and
to order their destruction when they cannot be sold, and to impose penalties
upon the owners thereof for the violation of any ordinance regulating or
prohibiting the same.
Section A.3.10. Regulate Dogs.
   To tax, restrain or regulate and prohibit the running at large of dogs, and
to authorize their destruction when at large contrary to ordinances, and to
impose penalties upon the owners or keepers thereof.
Section A.3.11. Regulation Of Hoops, Kites, Bicycles, Etc.
   To prohibit or regulate the rolling of hoops, the flying of kites and the
firing of firecrackers, and use of velocipedes and bicycles, and the use of any
other amusement or practices tending to annoy persons passing upon the streets
or sidewalks, or to frighten horses or teams.
Section A.3.12. Regulate Blowing Of Whistles, Etc.
   To restrain and prohibit the blowing of whistles, horns, crying of goods,
and all other practices and performances tending to the collection of persons
in the streets or sidewalks by auctioneers and others for the purpose of
business, amusement or otherwise.
Section A.3.13. Regulate Solicitation Of Alms.
   To regulate or prohibit mendicants, beggars, or other persons from
soliciting alms, help or other assistance upon the streets or sidewalks of said
city, and prescribe a penalty by fine for a nonobservance thereof.
Section A.3.14. Regulation Of Speed Of Trains.
   To prohibit and regulate the speed of railroad engines or locomotives within
the city limits.
   [Editor's Note: Federal regulation currently preempts municipal regulation
of train speeds.]
Section A.3.15. Prevention Of Trespasses, Breachers Of Peace, Etc.
   To prevent all trespasses and breaches of the peace and good order, assault
and batteries, fighting, quarreling, using abusive, profane or insulting
language, misdemeanor and all disorderly conduct and to punish all persons thus
offending.
Section A.3.16. Prohibit Immoral Shows.
   To prevent and punish the keepers of houses in which loud and immoral
theatrical representations are given, and to adopt summary measures for the
removal or suppression of all such theatrical representations.
Section A.3.17. Require Safe Railroad Tracks.
   To require all steam or street railway companies owning tracks within the
city limits, upon the public streets or highways of said city, to keep their
tracks in a safe condition, and to provide penalties for the nonperformance
thereof.
Section A.3.18. Prohibit Horse Racing.
   To prohibit, prevent and suppress horse racing, immoderate riding or driving
in the streets of said city.
Section A.3.19. Prevent Cruelty To Animals.
   To prevent cruel treatment of animals and to punish the abusers of animals.
Section A.3.20. Require Hitching Of Animals.
   To compel persons to fasten their horses or other animals attached to
vehicles, or otherwise hitched, or standing in the street.
Section A.3.21. Restrain Vagrants, Beggars And Prostitutes.
   To restrain and punish vagrants, mendicants, beggars and prostitutes.
Section A.3.22. Regulate Dangerous Drugs.
   To regulate and control the sale, gift, barter or exchange of cocaine,
opium, morphine and the salts thereof.
Section A.3.23. License, Tax And Regulate--Businesses Generally.
   To license, tax and regulate merchants, commission merchants, hotel and inn
keepers, brokers, money brokers, real estate agents, insurance agents,
insurance brokers, auctioneers, and all other trades, professions, occupations
and callings of every kind.
Section A.3.24. Same--Miscellaneous Businesses And Amusements.
   To license, tax, regulate, prevent or suppress paupers, peddlers, secondhand
dealers, pawnbrokers, and dealers in junk, and keepers of theatrical or other
shows and amusements. To license, tax and regulate theatres, circuses, moving
picture shows and shows of any kind, and the exhibition of natural or
artificial curiosities, menageries and musical exhibitions, and performances,
and to regulate and license or prohibit street parades, pool tables, slot
machines, striking machines, lung testers, doll racks, cane racks.
Section A.3.25. Prohibit Boxing Or Animal Fights.
   To prevent all boxing matches, sparring exhibitions, cock fighting and dog
fighting and punish all persons thus offending.
Section A.3.26. Regulate Or Prohibit Carrying Of Weapons.
   To regulate, control and prohibit the carrying of firearms and other weapons
within the city limits, and to provide and inflict the same punishment therefor
as is now or may hereafter be provided by state law against persons unlawfully
carrying weapons.
Section A.3.27. Provide For Workhouses, Etc., Unable To Pay Fines.
   To provide workhouses for vagrants, vagabonds and disorderly persons who are
unable or refuse to pay fines, or who have been sentenced to fine and
imprisonment or to compel them to work on the streets, alleys and public works,
and make all necessary regulations concerning the same, and to provide, keep
and regulate a city prison.
Section A.3.28. Define And Abate Nuisances.
   To define what shall be nuisances in the city, and within three thousand
feet (3,000') of the corporation lines outside of the city limits and to abate
such nuisances by summary proceedings, and to punish the authors thereof by
penalties, fines and imprisonment.
Section A.3.29. Regulate Construction.
   To regulate and prevent dangerous construction and conditions of chimneys,
fireplaces, hearths, stoves, stove pipes, boilers, and other heating apparatus
and to cause the same to be made safe.
Section A.3.30. Regulate Traffic.
   To regulate the use of automobiles, motorcars, motorcycles or any motor
vehicles, and the speed thereof; to prescribe the proper lighting of same when
used at night; to issue permits for use of such vehicles and to require the
numbering of such vehicles.
Section A.3.31. Regulate Steam Engines And Boilers.
   To control and regulate the location and use of all kinds of steam engines
and steam boilers in the city; and prescribe the qualifications of persons
operating and running the same, and to adopt such rules and regulations in
relation thereto as may be seen best for the public safety and comfort.
Section A.3.32. Regulate Construction And Erection Of Poles.
   To inspect the construction of all buildings in the city and to prescribe
and enforce proper regulations in regard thereto; to regulate and locate or
prohibit the erection of all poles in the city, and cause the same to be
charged, whether telegraph, telephone, electric light or otherwise.
Section A.3.33. Establish City Prison.
   The city shall have power to establish, maintain and regulate a city prison,
or city prisons, workhouses, and other means of punishment for vagrants,
persons convicted of misdemeanors of the city and disorderly persons, houses of
correction and reformatories for youthful criminals.
Section A.3.34. Penalty For Ordinance Violations.
   The City of Enid shall have power to enforce the bylaws and ordinances of
the city, by fine or imprisonment, or both.
   [Amendment approved by the Governor, 7-13-1936]
Section A.3.35. Provide For Commutation Of Fines Or Labor On Streets;
Collection Of Fines.
   The City of Enid may provide by ordinance for the commutation of fines
imposed, or may require labor in a workhouse or on a rock pile, or upon the
public streets, and public highways of the City of Enid, and for the collection
of any fine imposed; execution may be enforced as other executions issued in
civil cases.
Section A.3.36. Power To Enforce Forfeiture Of Franchise.
   Whenever the forfeiture of a franchise, right or privilege granted to any
person, firm or corporation to be exercised as a public utility, as provided in
this charter, the power to enforce such forfeiture shall not be construed to be
in the Board of Commissioners, but such forfeiture shall be finally enforced
only through the decree of a court of competent jurisdiction.
Section A.3.37. Regulate Streets And Grant Franchises.
   The City of Enid shall have power, by ordinance duly passed, to regulate,
operate or control the streets and alleys of said City of Enid, or may confer
by ordinance upon any person or corporation, the franchise, or the right to use
the property of the city, for the purpose of furnishing to the public any
general public service.
Section A.3.38. Power To Own, Etc., Utilities.
   The City of Enid shall have power, by ordinance duly passed, to buy, or
construct, own, maintain and operate a system of waterworks, gas or electric
plants, telephones, streetcars and sewers, or any other public service or
public enterprise.
   [Amendment approved by the Governor, 7-13-1936; Ord. No. 2002-58, §I, 12-17-
2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section A.3.39. Fire Protection Powers.
   The City of Enid shall have power to provide means for the protection
against and the extinguishment of fires and shall provide for the regulation,
maintenance and support of a fire department, may prescribe fire limits,
regulate and prohibit the erection of buildings in said limits, may direct and
prescribe that all buildings within the fire limits shall be constructed of
fireproof material, the kind, character, extent and quality of which buildings
and materials may, by ordinance, be prescribed and fixed. And shall, by
ordinance duly passed, adopt such rules and regulations in relation thereto as
may seem best for the public safety, comfort and protection. And may, by
ordinance, condemn, destroy, remove or cause to be removed, any building or
thing that seems best for the public safety, comfort and protection.
Section A.3.40. Health Powers.
   The City of Enid shall have power, by ordinance duly passed, to regulate and
prescribe such rules and regulations deemed advisable or necessary to protect
the public health, public safety and comfort.
ARTICLE IV. BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
Section A.4.1. General Powers.
   The Board of Commissioners shall be vested with the power, and charged with
the duty, of adopting all laws and ordinances not inconsistent with the
Constitution of this State and the laws thereof touching every subject matter
and subject, within the purview of the local government, instituted by this
charter.
Section A.4.2.
   [Amended by amendment approved by the Governor on October 20, 1913; repealed
by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.3.
   [Amended by amendment approved by the Governor on October 20, 1913; repealed
by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.4. General Financial Powers.
   The Board of Commissioners shall have the management and control of the
finances of the city, except as otherwise herein provided. They shall have the
power to appropriate money and provide for the payment of debts and expenses of
the city; to provide by ordinance for special funds for special purposes, and
to make the same disbursable only for such purposes.
Section A.4.5. Power To Finance Debts, Issue Bonds, Etc.
   The Board of Commissioners shall have the power to fund or refund, as
provided by law, the whole or any part of the existing debts of the city or any
future debt, by acquiring and cancelling the evidence thereof, and to issue
other bonds in lieu thereof, bearing interest at a rate not greater than the
original indebtedness, and to apply the sinking fund belonging to said series
of bonds so refunded, and may pay and retire any bond, by using the sinking
fund therefor.
Section A.4.6.
   [Repealed by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.7. Persons Authorized To Administer Oaths.
   The Mayor and each Commissioner, the Judge of the Police Court and the City
Clerk shall be and they are hereby authorized to administer oaths in all
matters concerning the municipal affairs of the city.
Section A.4.8.
   [Amended by amendment approved by the Governor on October 20, 1913; repealed
by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.9. [Repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on
January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.10. [Repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on
January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.11. [Repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on
January 4, 1947.]
Section A.4.12. Existing Ordinances, Resolutions, Etc.
   All ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations now in force in the city
of Enid, not in conflict herewith, shall remain in full force and effect until
altered, amended or repealed by the board of commissioners; and all questions
arising in administering said city government, not provided for herein, shall
be governed by the state law in such case made and provided. [Ord., 9-27-1909,
eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.4.13. Publication Of Legal Notice; Opening And Advertising For Bids.
   The publication of all legal notices of the city shall be made in some
newspaper which is of general circulation, and must have been of a continuous
publication for a period of at least one year in the city of Enid, and before
letting the contract for the city printing, the board of commissioners shall
cause an advertisement to be published in a daily newspaper of general
circulation in the city of Enid, inviting competitive bids from daily
newspapers published in the city of Enid, for the work to be done, said
advertisement to be published not less than five (5) times; all bids submitted
shall be sealed, and the same shall be opened by the mayor in the presence of
the majority of the board of commissioners and shall remain on file in the
office of the city clerk and be open to public inspection for at least forty
eight (48) hours before any award of said work is made to any competitive
bidder. The board of commissioners shall, in determining the most advantageous
bid for the city, take into consideration the true and actual circulation of
said papers in the city, and shall enter into contract with the party
submitting the lowest secure bid; and if, in the opinion of the board of
commissioners, none of said bids are satisfactory, then the commissioners may
reject all bids and immediately readvertise for bids inviting competition from
both daily and weekly papers published in the city of Enid, and proceed as
before. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
   [Editor's note: The special notice provisions in this section have been
superseded by the adoption of section D.1.18 in 1989 that provides that the
open meeting act is to be followed.]
ARTICLE V. FINANCE
Section A.5.1. Levy Of Ad Valorem Tax.
   The board of commissioners shall, by ordinance or resolution, on or before
the first Tuesday in August in each year, levy an ad valorem tax for all
purposes except as herein otherwise provided, not to exceed the limit provided
by the constitution of the state of Oklahoma, which said levy shall include the
levy for park and library purposes. Said ordinance or resolution shall specify
distinctly the purpose for which said tax is levied, and no tax levied and
collected for one purpose shall ever be diverted to any other purpose. The tax
so levied, when collected, shall be kept in the fund created. [Ord., 9-27-1909,
eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.5.2. Raising Of Revenue To Pay Debt.
   The board of commissioners shall, on or before the first Tuesday in August
of each year, levy sufficient additional revenue to create a sinking fund to be
used first, for the payment of interest coupons as they fall due; second, for
the payment of bonds as they fall due; third, for the payment of such parts of
judgments as such municipality may by law be required to pay; provided, that
said city shall not be required to pay to exceed one-third (1/3) of the
original amount of all judgments now outstanding in any one year. [Ord., 9-27-
1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.5.3. Tax Increases To Finance Construction Of Public Buildings.
   For the purpose of erecting public buildings in said city, the rates of
taxation herein limited may be increased and the rate of such increase and the
purpose for which it is intended shall be submitted to a vote of the people of
such city and the majority of the qualified voters of such city, voting at such
election, shall vote therefor, provided, that such increase shall not exceed
five (5) mills on the dollar of the assessed valuation of the taxable property
of such city. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
   [Editor's note: The limitation imposed in this section has been superseded
by the passage of A.5.11 in 2003.]
Section A.5.4. Limitations On Indebtedness--Generally.
   Said city shall not be allowed to become indebted in any manner, for any
purpose, to an amount exceeding in any year, the income in revenue provided for
such year, without the assent of three-fifths (3/5) of the qualified voters
thereof voting at an election to be held for that purpose nor in cases
requiring such assent, shall any indebtedness be allowed to be incurred to any
amount, including existing indebtedness, in the aggregate, exceeding five
percent (5%) of the value of the taxable property therein, to be ascertained
from the last assessment roll for state and county purposes, previous to the
incurring of such indebtedness; provided, that said city, in incurring any
indebtedness, requiring the assent of the voters as aforesaid, shall, before or
at the time of doing so, provide for the collection of an annual tax,
sufficient to pay the interest on such indebtedness as it falls due, and also
to constitute a sinking fund for the payment of the principal thereof, within
twenty five (25) years from the time of contracting the same. [Ord., 9-27-1909,
eff. 12-20-1909]
   [Editor's note: The limitation imposed in this section has been superseded
by the passage of A.5.11 in 2003.]
Section A.5.5. Same--Election To Authorize Increases.
   Said city may, by a majority vote of the qualified voters, voting at an
election to be held for that purpose, be allowed to become indebted in a larger
amount than that specified in section A.5.4, for the purpose of purchasing or
conducting public utilities or for the repairing of the same, to be owned
exclusively by said city; provided, that in the incurring of any such
indebtedness, requiring the assent of the voters aforesaid, said city shall
have the power to provide for, and at or before the time for incurring such
indebtedness, shall provide for collection of an annual tax, in addition to
other taxes provided for by this charter, sufficient to pay the interest on
such indebtedness as it falls due, and also to constitute a sinking fund for
the payment of the principal thereof, within twenty five (25) years from the
time of contracting the same. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
   [Editor's note: The limitation imposed in this section has been superseded
by the passage of A.5.11 in 2003.]
Section A.5.6. Authority To Issue Bonds.
   Said city, in addition to the authority hereinbefore given, shall have the
authority to issue bonds in lieu of any bond now outstanding against the said
city; provided, that said bonds shall not draw to exceed interest greater than
that which is allowed pursuant to state law, and shall be exchanged at not less
than par, and accrued interest on the outstanding bonds, and when so issued and
exchanged, such outstanding bonds shall be taken up and cancelled. [Ord. 85-8 §
1, approved at referendum 4-2-1985]
Section A.5.7. Prohibited Interests Of City Officials In Loans.
   The receiving directly, or indirectly by any officer of said city, of any
interest, profit or prerequisites, arising from the use or loan of public funds
in his hands, or to be raised through his agency for city purposes, shall be
deemed sufficient cause to forfeit his office and the person so receiving shall
then and there forfeit his office and be disqualified to hold office. [Ord., 9-
27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.5.8. Certification And Collection Of Tax Levies And Assessments.
   The various levies provided by this article and all other taxes and
assessments provided in this charter, except license and poll taxes, shall be
certified by the city clerk to the county clerk of Garfield County, to be by
said county clerk placed on the tax rolls for collection, subject to the same
penalty and collected by the county treasurer as other taxes are collected by
the county treasurer, as is provided by law for the collection of taxes, and
paid by him to the city treasurer, and such payment shall include all penalties
collected on such city taxes. The entire amount of all city levies shall be
placed upon the tax rolls as one levy, to be known as "city levy". [Ord., 9-27-
1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.5.9. Payment Of Tax Collections By County To City.
   The county treasurer shall, on January 15, May 15, July 15, and November 15,
of each year, and oftener if required by the board of commissioners, pay over
to the city treasurer, all monies and evidence of indebtedness, collected and
payable to this city, which shall include all penalties collected on city taxes
and assessments, and render a full itemized statement thereof to the board of
commissioners and the county treasurer shall duplicate receipts from the city
treasurer for the same, and file one of said receipts with the county clerk and
the city clerk shall enter in a book for that purpose, and under the proper
head, all amounts for which receipts are given. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-
1909]
Section A.5.10. Minimum Interest To Be Paid By Depositories.
   The city treasurer, under the immediate direction of the mayor and board of
commissioners, shall require every bank with which he makes a deposit of the
city's funds, to pay not less than two percent (2%) interest on the average
daily or monthly balance of all money in said bank or banks, belonging to said
city, such interest to become a part of the fund on deposit and the said city
treasurer shall not keep any money in any bank that will not make such
allowance as aforesaid. [Ord. 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.5.11. General Indebtedness.
   The city shall be allowed to become indebted in the manner, amount, and
subject to the restrictions provided by the constitution and the laws of the
state of Oklahoma as amended from time to time. This charter provision shall
supersede all local rules, ordinances, and charter provisions regarding the
manner, amount, and restrictions governing the indebtedness of the city. [Ord.
2002-56 §I, 12-17-2002, approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
ARTICLE VI. POLICE COURT
Section A.6.1. Judicial Powers Vested.
   The judicial power of the city shall be vested in a Police Court.
Section A.6.2. General Jurisdiction.
   The Police Court shall have exclusive jurisdiction of the criminal
proceedings for a violation of any city ordinance, and of all civil actions and
proceedings arising out of a violation of such ordinances and for the
collection of any license required by any ordinance, except such actions and
proceedings as fall within the jurisdiction of other courts under the
provisions of the Constitution of this State.
Section A.6.3. Jurisdiction Over Specific Offenses.
   The Police Court shall also have exclusive jurisdiction of the following
offenses committed within the city (except when prosecuted by indictment or
information): 1) petty larceny; 2) assault and battery; 3) breaches of the
peace, riot, committing willful injury to property and all misdemeanors
punishable by fine or imprisonment in the county jail, or by both; 4)
proceedings respecting vagrants, lewd or disorderly persons; and all other
petty offenses and misdemeanors committed within the city embraced in its
ordinances or by the laws of the State of which the Police Court has
jurisdiction.
Section A.6.4. Disposition Of Fines.
   All fines, penalties and forfeitures collected by said Police Court shall be
the property of the city, and shall be immediately deposited with the City
Treasurer for the use of said city.
Section A.6.5. Dockets, Records, Etc.
   The city shall furnish the necessary dockets, and all blanks and other books
and papers and stationery in the transaction of the business of said Police
Court. A complete record of all cases shall be entered in the docket of said
court.
Section A.6.6. Hours Of Operation.
   The Police Court shall always be open for the transaction of business,
except on Sunday.
ARTICLE VII. ELECTIONS
Section A.7.1.
   [Repealed by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.7.2.
   [Amended by amendment approved by the Governor on October 20, 1913; repealed
by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.7.3.
   [Repealed by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.7.4.
   [Repealed by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.7.5.
   [Repealed by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.7.6. Board Of Education.
   The Board of Education of the City of Enid shall consist of seven (7)
members, one member to be nominated from each ward and territory attached to
said ward for school purposes, and one member to be nominated from the school
district at large in the manner provided by law and the City Charter. All
candidates shall be voted on at large by the qualified electors of said school
district in the manner provided by law and the City Charter.
   The term of office of each member shall be for a period of four (4) years
beginning the first Monday in May after the election, or until his successor
has been elected and qualified; provided, that in the election hereinafter
provided for on the first Tuesday in April, 1935, the term of the three (3)
members of said Board elected at said election receiving the lowest number of
votes therein shall be for a period of two (2) years beginning the first Monday
in May, 1935, or until their successors have been elected and qualified.
   An election shall be held on the First Tuesday in April, 1935, and
biennially thereafter as provided by law and the City Charter, for the election
of Board members whose terms expire on the first Monday in May of the year of
the election.
   The City and School District shall each bear one-half (1/2) the expense of
an election held for both city and school officers or for both city and school
purposes. The city shall pay the entire expense of any election held for City
Officers or city purposes only, and the Board of Education shall pay the entire
expense of any election for school officers or for school purposes only.
   Qualified electors residing in the territory outside the limits of the City
of Enid but within the school district shall be entitled to vote at all school
elections in the ward and precinct adjacent to the outlying territory in which
said elector resides.
   [Amendment approved by the Governor, 8-29-1933]
Section A.7.7. Recall.
   The holder of any elective office may be removed at any time by the electors
qualified to vote for a successor of such incumbent. The procedure to effect
the removal of an incumbent of an elective office shall be as follows: A
petition signed by electors entitled to vote for a successor to the incumbent
sought to be removed, equal in number to at least thirty (30) per centum of the
vote of those that voted in the particular ward for commissioners if the recall
is for a commissioner or thirty (30) per centum of all those who voted for the
office of the Mayor if the recall is for the Mayor at the last preceding
general municipal election, demanding an election of a successor of the person
sought to be removed shall be filed with the City Clerk, which petition shall
contain a general statement of the grounds and charges for which the removal is
sought. The signatures to the petition need not all be appended to one paper,
but each signer shall add to his signature his place of residence, giving the
street and number. One of the signers of each such paper shall make oath before
an officer competent to administer oaths that the statements therein made are
true as he believes, and that each signature to the paper appended is the
genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be. Within ten (10)
days from the date of filing such petition the City Clerk shall examine and
from the voters' register ascertain whether or not said petition is signed by
the requisite number of qualified electors, and, if necessary, the Council
shall allow him extra help for that purpose; and he shall attach to said
petition his certificate, showing the result of said examination. If by the
Clerk's certificate the petition is shown to be insufficient, it may be amended
within ten (10) days from the date of said certificate. The Clerk shall, within
ten (10) days after such amendment, make like examination of the amended
petition, and if his certificate shall show the same to be insufficient, it
shall be returned to the person filing the same without prejudice, however, to
the filing of a new petition to the same effect. If the petition shall be
deemed to be sufficient, the Clerk shall submit the same to the Mayor and
Commissioners without delay. If the petition shall be found to be sufficient,
the Council shall order and fix a date for holding the said election, not less
than thirty (30) days nor more than forty (40) days from the date of the
Clerk's certificate to the Mayor and Commissioners that a sufficient petition
is filed.
   The Mayor and Commissioners shall make, or cause to be made, publication of
notice and all arrangements for holding such election, and the same shall be
conducted, returned and the result thereof declared, in all respects as are
other city elections. The successor of an officer so removed shall hold office
during the unexpired term of his predecessor. Any person sought to be removed
may be a candidate to succeed himself, and unless he requests otherwise in
writing, the Clerk shall place his name on the official ballot without
nomination. In any such removal election, the candidate receiving the highest
number of votes shall be declared elected. At such election if some other
person than the incumbent receives the highest number of votes the incumbent
shall thereupon be deemed removed from the office upon qualification of his
successor. In case the party who receives the highest number of votes shall
fail to qualify, within ten (10) days after receiving notification of election,
the office shall be deemed vacant. If the incumbent receives the highest number
of votes, he shall continue in office. The same method of removal shall be
cumulative and additional to the methods heretofore provided by law.
   No recall petition shall be filed against any officer until he has actually
held his office for at least six (6) months.
   [Ord. No. 2002-51, §I, 12-17-2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
   [Editor's Note: A recall election for a commissioner would be a ward
election while a recall election of mayor would be citywide.]
ARTICLE VIII. GENERAL PROVISIONS
Section A.8.1. Unauthorized Diversion Of Funds.
   Any Commissioner who shall divert the money from the proper fund to which it
belongs, except pursuant to a resolution or ordinance passed by the Board of
Commissioners, duly authorizing the same or shall be instrumental in doing so
or who shall transfer the same from one fund to the other or who shall be the
cause directly or indirectly of having same diverted or transferred from the
fund to which it rightfully belongs, except pursuant to a resolution or
ordinance authorizing the same and duly passed by the Board of Commissioners
shall be deemed guilty of malfeasance of office and shall be removed from
office and shall be punished as the law requires. Provided, however, that if
there shall remain in any fund, at the end of the current year, any portion
thereof which has not been needed and has not been expended for the purpose for
which it was created, that then and in that event the Board of Commissioners
are hereby authorized the transfer of said fund to any fund of the City of Enid
to be properly and lawfully expended for the needs of said city and this
provision shall apply to any unexpended balance theretofore remaining in any
fund, as well as to any such balance hereafter arising.
   [Amendment approved by the Governor, 10-20-1913]
Section A.8.2.
   [Repealed by amendment approved by the Governor on October 20, 1913.]
Section A.8.3. Poll Tax Authorized.
   The City of Enid shall have the power and the Board of Commissioners of said
city are hereby vested with the power and duty, to levy and annually collect a
poll tax, not exceeding two dollars ($2.00) in cash, from each able-bodied male
citizen between the ages of twenty one (21) and fifty (50) years; when such
action is authorized, the City Clerk shall make and certify a list of those
liable to pay the same and deliver such list to the Commissioner of Finance and
Revenue, to be by him collected and properly accounted.
   [Editor's Note: This section is unconstitutional and is not enforced.]
Section A.8.4. Bonds From Contractors.
   The Board of Commissioners shall require good and sufficient bonds from all
contractors, with at least two (2) good and sufficient sureties, who shall be
residents of the State of Oklahoma. No nonresidents of the State shall ever be
received sureties on any bond payable to the City of Enid, except such Guaranty
Companies as are authorized to make bonds in the State of Oklahoma and that may
be satisfactory to the Board of Commissioners. When bondsmen are not residents
of Garfield County, such proof of their solvency may be required as the Board
of Commissioners may deem necessary.
Section A.8.5. General Provisions Relative To Contracts.
   No contracts shall be entered into by the Board of Commissioners until after
an appropriation has been made therefor, nor in excess of the amount
appropriated, and all contracts shall be made upon specification, no contract
shall be binding upon the city unless it has been signed by the Mayor and
countersigned by the City Clerk, and the expenses thereof charged to the proper
fund, liable for the payment of the same, and whenever the contracts charged to
any fund equals the appropriation made therefor, no further contracts shall be
signed by the Mayor or City Clerk, the payment of which would come from such
fund.
Section A.8.6. Bids Required For Certain Contracts.
   All contracts of whatever character, pertaining to public improvements, or
maintenance of public property of said city, involving an outlay of as much as
five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be based upon specifications to be
prepared and submitted to and approved by the Board of Commissioners, and after
approval by the Board of Commissioners, advertisement for the proposed work or
matter embraced in said proposed contract shall be made, inviting competitive
bids for the work to be done, which advertisement shall be published in a daily
newspaper, not less than five (5) times and all bids submitted shall be sealed,
and shall be opened by the Mayor in the presence of a majority of the Board of
Commissioners, and shall remain on file in the office of the City Clerk, and be
open to public inspection for at least forty eight (48) hours before any award
of said work made to any competitive bidder. Said newspaper to be of general
circulation and to have been published for a period not less than one year in
said City of Enid.
   [Editor's Note:Section 1 of Ord. No. 91-05, adopted Jan. 15, 1991, added §
19 to Art. 1 of Pt. D of this charter relative to the Public Competitive
Bidding Act of 1974. The city has advised that "the pertinent conflicting part
of §A.8.6 is effectively repealed by the adoption of this amendment [Ord. No.
91-05]." See § D.1.19 for further information.]
Section A.8.7. Exemptions From Special Assessments.
   No property of any kind, churches, schools or otherwise, shall be exempt
from any of the special assessments authorized by this charter, or the laws of
the State of Oklahoma for local improvements.
Section A.8.8. Service Of Legal Process.
   All legal process against the city shall be served upon the Mayor, or Mayor
Pro Tempore.
Section A.8.9. City Property Not Subject To Execution.
   The property, real and personal, belonging to said city, shall not be liable
to be sold or appropriated under any writ of execution or cost bill, or other
force sale, nor shall the funds belonging to said city in the hands of any
person be liable to garnishment for any debt it may owe, or funds it shall have
due any person, nor shall said city be required to answer to any writ of
garnishment on any account whatsoever.
Section A.8.10. Illegal Purchase Of Votes, Office, Etc.
   No officer or employee of said city shall give or promise to give to any
other person, any portion of his compensation or any money or valuable thing or
promise of employment to any person, in consideration of having been, or being
nominated, appointed, voted for, or elected to any office or employment, and if
any such promise of gift be made, the person making or accepting such gift or
promise shall forfeit his office or employment and be debarred and disqualified
from being elected, appointed, or employed in the service of said city.
Section A.8.11. Unauthorized Acceptance Of Gifts, Salaries, Etc., By City
Officers; Conflicts Of Interest.
   Any officer of said city who shall, while in office, accept any donation or
gratuity in money or other valuable thing, either directly or indirectly from
any person or corporation dealing with the city or any subordinate or employee,
or from any candidate or applicant for any position as employee or subordinate
under him, shall forfeit his office and be forever debarred and disqualified
from holding any position in the service of the city.
   Neither Mayor nor any member of the Board of Commissioners, nor any elective
or appointive employee of the city, shall be directly or indirectly in the
employ of any person, company, or corporation holding or seeking to hold any
franchise of the City of Enid, or shall receive, directly or indirectly, any
wages, commission, gift or favor, or payment from any such franchise holder;
and a violation of this section shall ipso facto render vacant the position
held by the person so violating it, and shall be punished as bribery.
   No member of the Board of Commissioners or any other officer of said city
shall be directly or indirectly financially interested in any work, business or
contract, the expenses, price or consideration of which is paid from the City
Treasury, or by any assessment levied by ordinance or resolution of the Board
of Commissioners; nor be surety of any person having any contract work or
business with the city for the performance of which security may be required,
nor be the surety on the official bond of any officer of the city. Contracts in
violation of said provision shall be void.
Section A.8.12. Liability For Illegal Payments.
   Every officer who shall approve, allow, or pay any demand on the Treasury
not authorized by law, or by this charter, shall be liable to said city
individually and on his official bond for the amount of the demand so illegally
approved, allowed or paid.
Section A.8.13. Public Inspection Of Books And Records.
   All books and records in every office and department except warrants in the
Police Department, unexecuted, shall be open to the inspection of any citizen
at any time during business hours.
   [Editor's Note: Repealed by passage of Part D, Article 1, Section 18 in
1989.]
Section A.8.14. Reports Of Contract Violations By City Officers And Employees.
   It shall be the official duty of every officer or person in the employ or
service of said city, when it shall come to his knowledge that any contract or
agreement with said city or with any officer has been or is about to be
violated by the other contracting party, forthwith to report to the Mayor and
Board of Commissioners all facts and information in his possession concerning
such matter, and a failure to do so shall forfeit his office and remove the
officer and employee therefrom.
Section A.8.15. Taxpayer Suits To Enjoin Improper Expenditures.
   Any person who is a taxpayer of said city may maintain an action in the
proper court to restrain the execution of any illegal, unauthorized or
fraudulent contract of said city, or prevent paying any illegal, unauthorized
or fraudulent contract or agreement on behalf of said city and to restrain any
disbursing officer of said city from paying any illegal, unauthorized or
fraudulent bills, claims or demands against said city, or any salary or
compensation of any person in its administrative services, whose appointment
has not been made in pursuance with the provisions of law the regulations in
force thereunder, and in case of any such illegal, unauthorized or fraudulent
bills, claims or demand or any such salary or compensation which has been paid,
such citizen may maintain an action in the name of said city against the
officer and his bondsmen, from making such payment, and the party receiving the
same, or either, to recover the amount so paid, and such amount, after
deducting all expenses of the action, shall be paid into the City Treasury. In
case said taxpayer is not successful in such action, he shall pay all costs. In
no event shall the city ever be liable for the payment of such costs.
Section A.8.16. Appeals From Police Court.
   The defendant shall have the right to appeal in all cases from the Police
Court to the County Court of Garfield County.
Section A.8.17. Elections Generally.
   All elections for the approval of bond issues, the granting of franchises
and the levying of special taxes, wherein such matters shall be submitted to a
vote of the taxpayers of the city, shall be held at the general or special
election in said City of Enid. The elections held to elect members of the
School Board, Mayor and Commissioners shall be the only elections in said city
which shall be denominated general elections.
Section A.8.18.
   [Repealed by Amendment No. 7, approved by the Governor on January 4, 1947.]
Section A.8.19. Writs, Subpoenas, Service.
   All writs, subpoenas, or other processes issuing out of the Police Court
shall run in the name of the City of Enid, and may be executed and served by
the Chief of Police or his deputies, or policemen of said city or by private
process servers. Provided, that the city shall never be made liable for the
costs in any proceeding in the Police Court; and provided further, a law
enforcement officer of the municipality or county sheriff may serve an arrest
warrant issued by the municipal court any place within the state.
   [Ord. No. 91-08, § I, 2-5-1991 approved at referendum April 2, 1991; Ord.
No. 2002-57, §I, 12-17-2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section A.8.20. Board Of Health Authorized.
   The Board of Commissioners are hereby authorized and required to create a
Board of Health for the City of Enid, said Board shall consist of three (3)
members, one of whom shall be a reputable physician, and shall as elsewhere
provided, and their duties and powers shall be as defined by law.
Section A.8.21. Power Over Streets.
   The City of Enid shall have and exercise such general powers over its
streets, alleys and public property, and make provisions relating thereto as
are now provided by law or as may be hereafter provided by ordinance.
Section A.8.22. Library Board Of Directors--Required.
   All public reading rooms and public libraries shall be under the management
and care of a Board of Directors composed of six (6) members, chosen from the
citizens of the City of Enid at large, and shall be appointed as elsewhere
provided in this charter.
Section A.8.23. Same--Terms Of Office.
   Within thirty (30) days after the election of the Board of Commissioners
provided for in this charter, said Board of Directors shall be appointed as
follows: Two (2) members who shall hold office until the first Monday in May,
1911. Two (2) members who shall hold office until the first Monday in May,
1912, and two (2) members who shall hold office until the first Monday in May,
1913, and the six (6) members so appointed shall constitute the Board of
Library Directors. The term of office shall be three (3) years. At the
expiration of the term of office of each of the aforesaid directors, his
successors in office shall be appointed to serve for a term of three (3) years,
and until his successor in office has been appointed and qualified. And
annually thereafter there shall be appointed, on or before the first Monday in
May, two (2) directors to take the place of the retiring director on said
Board.
Section A.8.24. Same--Officers And Claims.
   Said directors shall immediately after appointment meet and organize by
electing one of their number as president, and another as vice president, and
another as secretary of the Board, and thereafter such officers of the Board
shall be chosen on the second Monday in May of each year.
   Proper vouchers shall be rendered against the said board of directors for
all expenditures, duly verified, as all claims against cities of the first
class, and when certified by the president of and secretary of said board of
directors to be correct, the board of commissioners shall allow the same and
order the same to be paid out of the library fund of said city as other
obligations against the city are paid. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
Section A.8.25. Same--Powers.
   Said board of directors shall have all the authority and power, and shall
perform all of the duties and requirements, provided in chapter seventy- one
(71) section fifty-eight sixty-four (5864) to section fifty-eight seventy-
three (5873) inclusive, of the statutes of Oklahoma, and the same are adopted
and made a part of this charter, save that where the same reads "the mayor and
city council" it shall be construed to mean the "mayor and commissioners"
elected under this charter, and except as otherwise provided in this charter.
[Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
   [Editor's note: The court in City of Enid v. Board of Directors of Enid &
Garfield County Public Library, CJ-2008-327, found that this section was
repealed in 1947 with the adoption of part D of the charter pursuant to section
D.3.1.]
Section A.8.26. [Repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on
January 4, 1947.]
Section A.8.27. [Repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on
January 4, 1947.]
Section A.8.28. [Amended by amendment approved by the governor on October 20,
1913; repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on January 4,
1947.]
Section A.8.29. [Repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on
January 4, 1947.]
Section A.8.30. [Amended by amendment approved by the governor on October 20,
1913; repealed by amendment no. 7, approved by the governor on January 4,
1947.]
Section A.8.31. Applicability Of State Constitution.
   The provisions of this charter shall be subject to the provisions of the
constitution of the state of Oklahoma. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-1909]
[ARTICLE IX.] SCHEDULE
   In order that no inconvenience or injury may result from the change in the
form of government which now exists in the city of Enid, to the form of
government which shall exist and be in operation in such city under the
foregoing charter, it is hereby provided and declared:
   First: That no existing right, action, suit, proceeding, claim or contract
shall be affected by such change in the form of government but all shall
continue as if no change in the form of government had taken place.
   Second: That the foregoing charter and the municipal government thereby
created shall remain in abeyance, after its adoption and approval as provided
in the constitution and laws of this state, until after the first election and
qualification of the officers, which by the provisions of said charter, are
required to be elected, and the present mayor and city council of said city of
Enid shall, until after said first election, continue to possess and exercise
the powers and duties imposed on them by law. [Ord., 9-27-1909, eff. 12-20-
1909]
PART B. FIRE DEPARTMENT CIVIL SERVICE AMENDMENT*
   [*Editor's note: This part contains the charter amendment creating a civil
service system for the fire department, approved by the governor on May 9,
1930. Such amendment did not create specific sections of the basic charter,
hence its inclusion as part B.]
ARTICLE I. COMMISSION
Section B.1.1. Generally.
   There is hereby created for the purpose of carrying into effect and
enforcing the provisions of the civil service laws of the fire department of
the city of Enid, Oklahoma, as hereinafter set forth and specified, and for the
purpose of ascertaining the merit and fitness of all persons seeking positions
in the said fire department to which these laws shall apply, a fire department
civil service commission composed of five (5) citizens of the city of Enid, one
of whom shall be a member of the Enid fire department and who shall act as the
secretary of this commission, such commission to be designated as appointed by
the mayor and commissioners of the city of Enid and to be known as the fire
department civil service commission of the city of Enid, and not more than
three (3) of said civil service commission shall hold any other public office
except the secretary, who may be an officer of the fire department in
accordance with the specifications of this amendment.
   The members of the Civil Service Commission shall be appointed for a term of
six (6) years, and until their successors shall have been appointed and
qualified. In the event a vacancy, for any reason, shall occur in said Civil
Service Commission, the Secretary of such Commission shall immediately notify
the Mayor and City Commissioners of such vacancy, and said Mayor and City
Commissioners shall, within thirty (30) days thereafter, appoint another
citizen of the City of Enid, who shall hold office during such unexpired term;
provided, that in any event, the Mayor and City Commissioners shall fill, by
appointment, any vacancy occurring in the Civil Service Commission within
thirty (30) days after actual notice of such vacancy shall have been brought to
the attention of said Mayor and City Commissioners.
   [Ord. No. 2002-53, §1, 12-17-2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section B.1.2. Functions And Secretary.
   (a)It shall be the duty of such Civil Service Commission to enforce all
rules for the Classification of the officers, places, and employments in the
Fire Department Service of the City of Enid, and for the appointments and
promotions therein and examinations thereof.
   (b)Subject to the direction of the Civil Service Commission, the Secretary
shall have charge of all matters pertaining to examinations called for under
these rules, ascertain the merit and fitness of the candidates for admission
into the civil service of the city with respect to such candidate's character,
knowledge, and ability for this particular branch of service and to estimate
and determine the relative excellence and standing of the persons examined, and
to certify the same in such manner and form as may be prescribed.
   The Secretary of the Civil Service Commission shall keep minutes of the
Commission's proceedings and all necessary records of applicants, their
examinations and standing, and keep a complete record of all persons employed
in the Fire Department and record all appointments, promotions, transfers,
dismissals, resignations and changes of any kind therein. He shall also see
that the rules and regulations are complied with and bring all cases of
infraction of these rules to the attention of the Civil Service Commission.
ARTICLE II. ORGANIZATION OF FIRE DEPARTMENT
 
Section B.2.1. Rank Of Officers And Firemen.
   (a) The Officers of the Fire Department of the City of Enid shall be ranked
in the following manner:
   The Chief shall be first in rank and the other officers shall occupy
relative positions as follows:
   The Assistant Chief shall rank next below the Chief.
   The rank of Secretary shall be next below that of Chief in his department.
   The rank of Fire Marshal shall be next below that of Chief in his
department.
   The rank of Assistant Fire Marshal shall be next below that of Fire Marshal
of his department.
   The Master Mechanic shall rank next below that of Chief in his department.
   The rank of Assistant Mechanic shall rank next below that of Master Mechanic
in his department.
   The Training Officer shall rank next below that of Chief in his department.
   The rank of Deputy Chief shall be next below that of Assistant Chief.
   The Captains shall rank next below the Deputy Chiefs in their departments.
   The Lieutenants shall rank next below the Captains in their departments.
   Should the Chief or any officer of the Fire Department be dismissed from any
position on account of unfitness for the discharge of his duties under said
position and not for any cause authorizing his entire dismissal from the
service, he shall be restored to the rank and grade held by him prior to this
appointment. In case of the absence, disability or death of the Chief, said
position shall be filled from the eligibility list hereinafter mentioned.
   (b)The firemen of the Fire Department of the City of Enid shall be ranked in
the following manner:
   The Drivers shall rank next below the Lieutenants in their departments.
   The Firefighters shall rank next below the Drivers in their departments.
   [Ord. No. 89-15, § II, 2-7-1989 approved at referendum April 4, 1989]
Section B.2.2. Qualifications, Appointments And Duties.
   The City of Enid shall maintain a fire force consisting of the Fire Chief
and such other officers and firemen as may be provided by ordinance. Members of
such Fire Department, including the Chief and his assistants, shall be
appointed from the list of eligibles prepared by the Civil Service Commission
in accordance with the rules and regulations prescribed herein; provided,
however, that in case of a riot, conflagration or emergency, the governing
body, or the Chief of the Fire Department of the City of Enid may make
temporary appointments to remain in force during the continuation of such
emergency; such appointees need not be in the classified service.
   The Fire Department shall be under the control and direction of the Chief of
such department, who shall be an experienced fireman. The Fire Chief shall have
exclusive control of the stationing and transfer of all firemen and other
officers and employees constituting the fire force under such rules and
regulations as are herein established. The Fire Chief in charge shall each day
furnish the Secretary of the Civil Service Commission a written statement
designating all members of the Fire Department who are sick or injured and the
Secretary shall keep a complete record thereof.
ARTICLE III. ELIGIBILITY FOR SERVICE
Section B.3.1. Personal Qualifications.
   (a)No person shall be admitted to examination for any position in the Fire
Department Service who is not a citizen of the United States and who has not
been an actual resident of the City of Enid for at least three (3) years next
preceding the date of examination.
   [Editor's Note: The residency requirement is unconstitutional and is not
enforced.]
   (b)No person will be admitted to examination who is less than eighteen (18)
years of age or more than thirty-five (35) years of age at the date of his
examination. This rule shall be waived in the case of men already in the
service of this Fire Department and who have served ninety (90) consecutive
days immediately preceding the adoption of these rules.
   [Ord. No. 2002-52, §I, 12-17-2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section B.3.2. Original Appointments.
   In all other cases, the original appointments to the uniformed force of said
Fire Department shall be made to the lowest grade of said service and
advancement to the highest grade shall be by promotion in accordance with the
provisions of these rules. Every applicant, in addition to other requirements,
shall comply with the following regulations and specifications.
   He shall be not less than five (5) feet, eight (8) inches in height (in bare
feet), and his weight and circumference of chest must be within the following
table and must be physically qualified to sustain the labors and exposures of
the Fire Department as determined by the medical examiner or physical examiner
appointed by the Civil Service Commission for the purposes of making official
examinations:
SCHEDULE

5 feet 9 inches  150 pounds     190 pounds     351/2 inches
5 feet 10 inches 155 pounds     195 pounds     36 inches
5 feet 11 inches 160 pounds     200 pounds     37 inches
6 feet           165 pounds     210 pounds     371/2 inches
