   Provided, however, the following modifications of the chest measurement
required in this schedule may be allowed:
(1)To an applicant whose height is between five feet nine inches (5'9") and six
feet (6'), a reduction of one inch or any fraction thereof.
(2)To an applicant whose height is six feet (6') or over, a reduction of one
and one-half inches (11/2") or any fraction thereof. And provided further, that
in all cases the applicant shall have a chest expansion of three inches (3") or
more; and there shall be a difference of at least two inches (2") between
forced and full respiration; and provided the limitations of this section shall
not apply to men who have served ninety (90) or more consecutive days
immediately preceding the adoption of this amendment.
   [Editor's Note: All but the first sentence of this section is
unconstitutional and is not enforced.]
ARTICLE IV. APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION TO SERVICE
Section B.4.1. Generally.
   (a)Applications for admission to examination shall be made on forms
prescribed by the Civil Service Commission, such forms to be furnished by said
Commission to all applicants for examination, and to require such information
and certifications, of persons acquainted with the applicant, as said
Commission may require. All applications must be filled out and verified in the
handwriting of the applicant.
   (b)A good moral character is of paramount importance, and is an essential
qualification in determining an applicant's right to examination. Proof at any
time produced to the Civil Service Commission, of an applicant's bad character
or dissolute habits, or of any criminal or disgraceful act committed by him, or
of dismissal for good cause from the public service, shall be deemed sufficient
grounds for the rejection of such applicant, either before or after
examination, and for removal from the register of eligibles.
   (c)A false statement knowingly made by any person in an application for
examination, connivance at or with any false representation or statement made
in any certificate which may accompany such application, or complicity in any
fraud touching the same, shall be regarded as good cause for exclusion from the
examination, or from the register of eligibles, or for removal or discharge
during probation, or thereafter; but no person shall be removed from a register
of eligibles, or from the service, under this section, until an opportunity has
been given him to be publicly heard before the Civil Service Commission, on
written charges, and after due notice, as hereinafter provided for the hearing
of charges before said Civil Service Commission. And a record shall be kept of
the findings of said Commission, showing the vote thereon and the reasons
therefor.
   (d)Applications and accompanying certificates will be filed in the office of
the Civil Service Commission, and will not be returned to the applicant.
   (e)Defective applications shall be returned and an opportunity given for
correction, except when the defects therein disqualify the applicant under
these regulations.
   (f)The Civil Service Commission may limit the number of applicants to be
examined, according to the needs of the service, and in such cases applicants
shall be admitted to examination in the order in which their applications have
been filed in due form.
Section B.4.2.Special Requirements In Mechanical Engineering And Electrical
Service.
   In the Mechanical Engineering and Electrical Service the applicant shall be
required to produce, in addition to the other qualifications in this Article
enumerated, a certificate from some competent person or persons in the same
trade or occupation, of the applicant's ability to do the special kind of work
in which he desires to be employed, and, in the case of mechanics, that the
applicant has served not less than three (3) years at his respective trade.
 
ARTICLE V. EXAMINATIONS
Section B.5.1. Character Of Examination.
   All examinations shall be impartial, public, competitive, and practical in
their character, and shall relate to those matters which will fairly test the
relative capacity of the persons examined to discharge the duties of the
positions to which they seek appointment, and shall include tests of physical
qualifications and health, and, when appropriate, of manual skill. No questions
in any examination shall relate to political or religious opinion or
affiliation.
Section B.5.2. Time, Place, And Notice.
   Examinations shall be held at such times and places as the Civil Service
Commission may designate, and two (2) weeks' notice, in writing thereof shall
be given to all eligible applicants.
Section B.5.3. Subjects For Examination And Relative Importance Thereof.
   The subjects in examinations for the Official Service, and the relative
importance of each subject, shall be designated from time to time by the Civil
Service Commission. The subjects may include special tests as to manual skill,
or technical or scientific knowledge.
Section B.5.4. Physical Examinations.
   Physical examinations shall be made by physicians designated by the Civil
Service Commission. The result of such examinations shall be certified in forms
furnished by the Civil Service Commission.
   [Ord. No. 89-14, § II, 2-7-1989 approved at referendum April 4, 1989]
Section B.5.5. Secrecy Regarding Identity Of Applicants.
   All examinations shall be conducted so that no examination paper will
disclose the name or identity of any applicant until all the examination answer
sheets shall have been graded. Any applicant in any examination who places any
identification mark upon his examination sheet shall be deprived of all
benefits under such examination.
Section B.5.6. Explanation Of Questions.
   All necessary explanations of examination questions shall be made to the
whole class. No question shall be explained to any individual applicant.
Section B.5.7. Penalty For Withdrawal From Examination.
   Any applicant who withdraws from any examination or fails to complete the
entire examination after filling out his identification card and receiving
copies of the questions shall be considered as having failed in said
examination. The reason for such failure shall be stated on his record card.
Section B.5.8. Leaving Room During Examination.
   During the examination no applicant will be permitted to leave the room in
which the examination is being conducted, except in case of extreme necessity
and then only after having handed in his papers on one subject and prior to his
having received the questions in the next subject.
Section B.5.9. Time Limit For Examination.
   The time limit prescribed for each examination, and for any special subject
of examination, shall be announced before the examination. Such examination
shall begin when all announcements have been made and questions distributed. No
variation of time limitation shall be allowed any applicant during any
particular examination.
Section B.5.10. Grading.
   (a) Each member of Examining Board (composed of the Civil Service
Commission) shall place the grade he gives the applicant, on each subject, on a
separate blank and at the end of the grading, the three (3) grades on said
subject shall be averaged; this average shall be the final grade in said
subject. The Civil Service Commission shall establish a uniform method for
arriving at grades in all subjects; and each competitor or applicant shall be
uniformly graded on a scale of one hundred (100), according to the general
average determined by the markings, and the name of no competitor, who fails to
attain a general average of seventy per centum (70%) of complete proficiency in
the subjects of the examination, taken as a whole, shall be entered on the
register of eligibles for the Service.
   (b) In marking the subject of experience the grade shall be given upon the
answers contained in the application blank, subject to the general regulations
contained in subdivision (a) of article V, section 10, of this amendment.
Section B.5.11. Fraud In Examination.
   Any person who shall at any examination or in any document signed or
furnished by him in connection with any examination, by himself or in co-
operation with one or more persons, make any false representation regarding
himself or any of the applicants, or by impersonating any other person, or by
allowing any other person to impersonate him, or who uses or aids anyone in
using any information surreptitiously obtained, or who uses or aids another in
using any memoranda whereby an advantage is obtained over other competitors at
such examination shall be excluded from the examination, and his name shall be
stricken from any eligible list upon which it may appear; provided, this
penalty shall not be imposed until after the accused has been given the
opportunity to be heard, in his defense, in the manner prescribed in article IX
of this amendment, insofar as said procedure is applicable hereto.
Section B.5.12. Notice Of Standing.
   Within a reasonable time after the completion of an examination, each
applicant shall be notified of the general average he has attained on
examination.
Section B.5.13. Re-Examination.
   No person who has failed to pass an examination shall be re-examined within
six (6) months from the date of such failure. An applicant who has passed an
examination and been enrolled upon the register of eligibles shall not be again
examined until one year from the date of such enrollment, and then only upon
withdrawal of his name from the register of eligibles and upon the filing of a
new application.
Section B.5.14. Review Of Examination Papers.
   No examination papers and no examination shall be subject to review by any
person after the posting of the eligible list, except that the Civil Service
Commission may correct mistakes committed by an examiner on the unanimous
consent of such Civil Service Commission; provided, however, that no such
correction shall be made after one year from the date of the posting of the
eligible register in which the mistake occurred; and provided further, that no
person who has been certified from said eligible register shall be disturbed
because of such correction.
ARTICLE VI. REGISTER OF ELIGIBLES
Section B.6.1. Enrollment.
   The Civil Service Commission shall prepare and keep a book, to be known as
the "Register of Eligibles," in which shall be enrolled the names of all
persons who are eligible to appointment or to promotion in the Fire Department
under the proper classes, divisions, and grades. All applicants for any
position in the Fire Department who participated in a competitive examination,
and attained on such examination a general average standing of seventy per
centum (70%), or over, and who are otherwise eligible, shall take rank and be
enrolled upon the register, as candidates for appointment to the position for
which they were examined, in the order of their relative excellence as
determined by examination, without reference to priority of time of
examination.
Section B.6.2. Striking Names From Register.
   The Civil Service Commission may strike the names of candidates from the
Register of Eligibles after they have remained thereon more than one year from
the date of their enrollment, without prejudice to the right of such candidate
or candidates to again make application in an effort to attain a higher state
of proficiency in such examination.
ARTICLE VII. FILLING VACANCIES
Section B.7.1. Requisition And Certification.
   When a vacancy is to be filled in the Fire Department, the appointing
officer shall make a requisition, upon a form prescribed by the Civil Service
Commission for the certification to him of the names of eligibles. The
appointing officer shall notify the Civil Service Commission of each position
to be filled separately. The Civil Service Commission shall, unless the place
is to be filled by reinstatement, certify to the appointing officer the name
and address of the candidate standing the highest upon the register for the
class, division or grade to which said position belongs, and such person shall
be appointed.
Section B.7.2. Waiver Of Certification Or Reinstatement.
   An eligible who has been certified or tendered reinstatement may waive said
certification or reinstatement, upon giving reasons satisfactory to the Civil
Service Commission, without losing his place upon the register. If the reason
assigned is not satisfactory to the Civil Service Commission, or the eligible
refuses to accept an appointment tendered, his name shall be removed from the
eligible register. All waivers must be filed with the Civil Service Commission
within five (5) days from the date of certification. In the absence of such
waiver the name of the eligible next in order is certified in his place. If,
within thirty (30) days from the date of certification, the eligible so removed
furnishes to the Civil Service Commission good and sufficient reason for his
failure to report, he may be restored to the eligible list. But in the absence
of any such sufficient reason, his separation at the expiration of said thirty
(30) days shall be final.
Section B.7.3. Method Of Reinstatement.
   Subject to the provisions of article VII, and the general provisions,
appearing in article X hereof, when a vacancy occurs in any department of the
Fire Department Service, the Civil Service Commission shall, before any new
certificate is made from an eligible register, reinstate in the same class,
division and grade in which he was formerly employed. Any person who has been
examined and appointed under these rules, and who has been temporarily
separated from the Fire Department Service, and the seniority of service of
such appointee shall be governed by the date of his original appointment.
Section B.7.4. Filling Of Vacancies.
   Vacancies in the Fire Department Service, if not filled by the promotion as
herein otherwise provided, shall be filled by requisition and certification as
provided in this amendment. The appointee shall be on probation for a period of
twelve (12) months. At the end of this period, if the conduct and capacity of
the person appointed has been satisfactory, the appointment shall be deemed
complete.
   [Ord. No. 89-13, § II, 2-7-1989 approved at referendum April 4, 1989]
Section B.7.5. Discharge During Probationary Period.
   If any appointee shall, during said probation period, be found incompetent
or otherwise disqualified for the performance of the duties of the position he
is filling; the Chief of the Fire Department, by and with the consent of the
Civil Service Commission, may discharge said appointee upon assigning in
writing to the Civil Service Commission the reasons therefor.
Section B.7.6. Temporary Appointments.
   To prevent the stoppage of public business, or to meet extraordinary
exigencies, the Chief of the Fire Department may, with the approval of the
Civil Service Commission, make temporary appointments to remain in force not to
exceed sixty (60) days, and only until a regular appointment can be made in
accordance with the procedure otherwise provided herein.
Section B.7.7. Removal From City [County].
   Removal of the residence from the County of Garfield, shall be the cause for
the discharge of any person in the Fire Department Service.
   [Ord. No. 85-6, § 1, approved at referendum, 4-2-1985]
Section B.7.8. Restoration Of Probationer.
   Should the work for which a probationer has been certified prove temporary,
and his services be discontinued, without fault or delinquency on his part,
before his time of probation is completed, his name shall be restored to its
proper position upon the Register of Eligibles, and the time he has served
shall be credited to him on his probationary period.
Section B.7.9. Assignment Of Duty.
   Any person appointed to, or promoted in, the Fire Department Service, shall
be required to perform the duties of the position to which he has been
appointed or promoted.
Section B.7.10. Outside Employment.
   No employee of the Fire Department shall engage in any outside occupation
which shall interfere with the response to a call for emergency, when he is off
duty.
ARTICLE VIII. PROMOTIONS
Section B.8.1. Method.
   Promotions in the Fire Department Service shall be made on the basis of
seniority in service and examination. All examinations for promotion shall be
competitive among such members of the next lower grade or rank, as desire to
submit themselves to such examination; provided, however, that captains or
officers of higher rank shall be eligible to take examinations for any rank
higher than that in which they may be at the time of taking such examination.
Section B.8.2. Time Of Service.
   No person shall be examined for promotion for any grade in the Fire
Department unless he has served at least two (2) years in the next lower grade,
except captains and officers of higher rank, who shall, after having passed an
examination showing proper proficiency, be eligible for promotion to any rank.
Section B.8.3. Method Of Examination.
   The method of examination and the rules governing the same shall be the same
as herein provided for applicants for original appointment.
Section B.8.4. Charter Examination.
   Examinations for promotions shall be of the same general character as herein
provided for applicants for original appointment. Length of previous service
and the efficiency of the applicant therein shall be given due consideration.
In ascertaining such efficiency, the record of the applicant as to conduct
shown in the department in which he has served shall be considered.
Section B.8.5. Grading Of Examinations.
   Each competitor shall be graded on a scale of one hundred (100), according
to the general average determined by the markings, and no competitor who fails
to attain a general average of seventy per centum (70%) of complete proficiency
in the subject of the examination, taken as a whole, shall be deemed eligible
for promotion.
Section B.8.6. Priority Of Certification.
   In certifying from the registers for promotion, when two (2) or more
eligibles have the same general average, preference in certification shall be
given in order of seniority of service.
Section B.8.7. Making Of Certification.
   Upon requisition of the Chief of the Fire Department, the Civil Service
Commission shall certify the name of the person standing highest on the
promotion eligible register, and the Chief of the Fire Department shall appoint
said person to the position; provided, however, that no person shall be
certified from a promotion list who has for one year next preceding the date of
the certification, separated himself from the service of the Fire Department,
or who has been removed therefrom upon charges brought and established as
provided in this amendment.
ARTICLE IX. REMOVAL FROM SERVICE
Section B.9.1. Generally.
   Charges against any person holding an office or place of employment in the
Fire Department Service of the City of Enid, may be filed by the Chief or head
of the department in which the person against whom such charges are made is
employed, or by any other person. Such charges shall be investigated by or
before the Civil Service Commission. All charges must be in writing, signed and
duly verified by the person making the same. No member of the Fire Department
can be dismissed from service until proven guilty of charges previously
brought, in the manner hereinafter provided.
Section B.9.2. Hearing.
   The Civil Service Commission shall cause notice in writing, together with a
copy of all charges to be considered, to be personally served upon the accused
or to be mailed to him at his address as shown by the records in the office of
the Civil Service Commission, such notice to state the time, which shall not be
less than ten (10) days after the serving or mailing of such notice, and place
at which such charges will be investigated. The accused shall be given an
opportunity for a public hearing in his defense at such investigation.
Section B.9.3. Findings And Decision.
   The findings and decision of the Civil Service Commission shall be certified
to the Chief of the Fire Department and shall be forthwith enforced by him.
Section B.9.4. Suspension.
   The Chief of the Fire Department may, for good cause, suspend a subordinate
for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. In such case he must forthwith
notify the Civil Service Commission in writing of the suspension and the reason
therefor.
Section B.9.5. Political Activity.
   No person in the Fire Department Service of the City of Enid shall take any
part in any political campaign, in the interest of any candidate, save to
exercise his right of franchise. And any member of said Fire Department, who,
having been given an opportunity to be duly heard as in this act provided,
shall be found to have violated any portion of this rule will be dismissed from
the service.
   [Editor's Note: This section is illegal pursuant to 11 Oklahoma Statutes
§22-101.1 and is not enforced.]
ARTICLE X. GENERAL PROVISIONS
Section B.10.1. Reports, Lists, Etc.
   (a) If any office or place of employment is created or abolished, or the
compensation attached thereto altered, the officer or board making such change
shall immediately report the same in writing, to the Civil Service Commission.
   (b) A list, to be known as the Civil List of the Fire Department of the City
of Enid shall be kept in the office of the Civil Service Commission, and shall
contain the name of every person employed in, or receiving compensation from,
the Fire Department. The list shall show, respecting every officer and
employee, the title of office, or position, the length of time the incumbent or
employee has held the same, the salary or compensation thereto attached, the
length of time the incumbent or employee has been in the service of the Fire
Department of the City of Enid, and the place in the service he has filled.
   (c) No payment in compensation for services rendered, after the taking
effect of this amendment, can be made by the City of Enid, or any of its
officers, to a person holding a position in the Fire Department Service, until
it appears either that he was employed in such position at least ninety (90)
consecutive days, immediately preceding the adoption of this amendment, or that
he has been employed under the provisions of this act.
Section B.10.2. Resignations.
   Any officer or employee in the Fire Department Service who tenders his
resignation to his superior officer shall not, after said resignation has been
accepted by the Chief of the Fire Department and reported to the Civil Service
Commission, be allowed to withdraw said resignation or be reinstated, unless
the application for such withdrawal is made within thirty (30) days after the
receipt of said report and then only upon the recommendation of the Chief of
the Fire Department and the consent of the Civil Service Commission.
Section B.10.3. Unauthorized Absences.
   Any officer or employee in the Fire Department Service of this city, who
shall absent himself from a duty for a period of ten (10) days without
permission in writing from the Chief of the Fire Department, shall be
considered as having abandoned his employment and as having separated himself
from the service of the Fire Department. Such officer or employee may, within
thirty (30) days after such separation, make an application in writing to the
Civil Service Commission for reinstatement, and the Civil Service Commission
shall thereupon give him a hearing and may grant said reinstatement, if it
deems the same to be for the interest of the service. If said application for
reinstatement be refused the separation shall be final, subject to the right of
appeal from the rulings of the Civil Service Commission as hereinafter
provided.
Section B.10.4. Leave Of Absence And Reinstatement.
   (a)Leave of absence without pay may be granted by the Chief of the Fire
Department with the consent of the Civil Service Commission, for the following
causes:
(1)That an officer or employee may enter upon a course of study, or engage in
an investigation, calculated to improve the quality of his service.
(2)If such officer or employee has some reason which, in the judgment of the
Chief of the Fire Department and the Civil Service Commission, is sufficient to
constitute good reason for granting such leave of absence.
(3)By the Civil Service Commission, to those eligible, upon the request of the
Chief of the Fire Department for a period of thirty (30) days, or more, not to
exceed six (6) months, except in the case of an employee desiring to attend an
institution of higher learning, in which case the time limit shall be one year.
   (b)Positions so vacated shall be filled either for the duration of the leave
by substitution from the head of the eligible list, when an eligible qualified
to do the work is available; or by temporary appointment.
   (c)Leave of absence will not be granted during the probationary period, or
within ninety (90) days from the reinstatement of a former employee except on
account of illness.
   (d)A vacation of fifteen (15) days, with full pay, shall be granted each
year to every member of the Enid fire department, who has been in said service
for a period of one full year.
   (e) Sickness, disability, death, and retirement from duty shall be governed
by the Oklahoma Statutes in such case made and provided, and by the general
laws of the state of Oklahoma applicable to the firemen's relief and pension
fund. [Ord., 5-9-1930]
Section B.10.5. Meetings Of Civil Service Commission.
   Meetings of the civil service commission shall be held at the office of said
commission, when called by the president, or any two (2) members, or by the
mayor of the city of Enid. Written notice of the date, time, and object of the
meeting shall be mailed to each other member by the secretary, at least two (2)
days prior to the meeting. A majority of the civil service commission shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. [Ord., 5-9-1930]
   [Editor's note: These notice provisions have been superseded by the passage
of D.1.18 in 1989, that provides that the notice requirements of the open
meeting act are followed.]
Section B.10.6. Eligibility Of Civil Service Commission Members For
Examinations; Appointment Of Successors.
   If at any time any member of the civil service commission, created by this
amendment, shall desire to submit to any examination relative to admission to
the fire department service or promotion therein, such member shall make known
to the commission his intention to take such examination and shall resign from
said commission, wholly severing all connection therewith, prior to the date of
the examination in which said member of the commission proposes to compete. It
shall be the duty of the mayor and commissioners of the city of Enid to appoint
a successor to said resigning commissioner immediately upon the acceptance of
such resignation, said successor to be appointed, qualify, and assume his
duties on the civil service commission prior to any preparation made by the
civil service commission with reference to the examination heretofore
mentioned. [Ord., 5-9-1930]
Section B.10.7. Reduction In Force.
   In the event it becomes necessary to discontinue the services of any officer
or member of the fire department, because of congested conditions in the
service, or for any other cause not involving any fault or dereliction of such
officer or member justifying his removal for cause under the terms of this
amendment, seniority shall prevail. [Ord., 5-9-1930]
Section B.10.8. Financial Support Of Civil Service Commission.
   Appropriation And Expense: The mayor and commissioners of the city of Enid
are hereby authorized and directed to make appropriations necessary for the
payment of such expenses as may be incurred by the civil service commission in
putting into execution and continuing in effect, the provisions of this
amendment. [Ord., 5-9-1930]
ARTICLE XI. APPEALS
Section B.11.1. Generally.
   An appeal from any final action, decision, ruling, judgment or order of the
civil service commission may be taken to the district court of Garfield County,
state of Oklahoma, by any person or persons, any taxpayer, officer, department,
board or bureau of the city of Enid, Oklahoma, jointly or severally aggrieved
by filing with the secretary of the civil service commission, within thirty
(30) days, a notice of appeal, which notice shall specify the grounds of such
appeal. Upon filing of the notice of appeal as herein provided, the secretary
of the civil service commission shall forthwith transmit to the court clerk of
the said district court the original, or certified copies, of all the papers
constituting the record in the case, together with the order, decision or
ruling of the civil service commission. Such case shall be heard and tried de
novo in the district court. [Ord., 5-9-1930]
PART C. AMENDMENT NO. 6
POLICE DEPARTMENT CIVIL SERVICE AMENDMENT*
   [*Editor's note: This part contains the charter amendment creating a civil
service system for the police department, being amendment no. 6, approved by
the governor on April 19, 1937. Such amendment did not create specific sections
of the basic charter, hence its inclusion as part C.]
ARTICLE I. COMMISSION
Section C.1.1. Generally.
   There is hereby created for the purpose of carrying into effect and
enforcing the provisions of the civil service laws of the Department of Police
of the City of Enid, Oklahoma, as hereinafter set forth and specified, and for
the purpose of ascertaining the merit and fitness of all persons seeking
positions in the said Department of Police to which these laws shall apply, a
Department of Police Civil Service Commission composed of five (5) citizens of
the City of Enid, Oklahoma, all of whom shall serve without compensation
therefor and one of whom shall be a member of the Enid Department of Police and
who shall act as Secretary of this Commission, such commission to be designated
and appointed by the Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Enid, and to be
known as the Department of Police Civil Service Commission of the City of Enid,
Oklahoma, and not more than three (3) of said Civil Service Commissioners shall
hold any other office except the Secretary, who may be an officer of the
Department of Police, in accordance with the specifications of the amendment.
   Within thirty (30) days after this amendment shall become effective, the
Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Enid, Oklahoma, shall appoint the
members of such Civil Service Commission, one of whom shall serve for a period
of one year, one for a period of two (2) years, one for a period of three (3)
years, one for a period of four (4) years, and one for a period of five (5)
years, said terms of office to be computed from the date this amendment becomes
effective, all members to take office as soon as they have been appointed and
qualified. Thereafter, the members of the Civil Service Commission shall be
appointed for a term of five (5) years, and until their successors shall have
been appointed and qualified.
   In the event a vacancy, for any reason, shall occur in said Civil Service
Commission, the Secretary of such Commission shall immediately notify the Mayor
and City Commissioners of such vacancy, and said Mayor and City Commissioners
shall, within thirty (30) days thereafter, appoint another citizen of the City
of Enid, Oklahoma, who shall hold office during such unexpired term; provided,
in any event, that the Mayor and City Commissioners shall fill, by appointment,
any vacancy occurring within the Civil Service Commission within thirty (30)
days after actual notice of such vacancy shall have been brought to the
attention of said Mayor and City Commissioners.
Section C.1.2. Functions And Secretary.
   (a)It shall be the duty of such Civil Service Commission to enforce all
rules for the qualification of the officers, places, and employments in the
Department of Police Service of the City of Enid, Oklahoma, and for the
appointments and promotions therein, and the examination thereof.
   It shall be the duty of such Civil Service Commission, as soon as
practicable within sixty (60) days after their appointment and qualification,
to cause to be given an examination, in accordance with the provisions therefor
herein, of all applicants for offices, places, and employments in the
Department of Police, requiring all officers and employees of said Department
at the time of such examination to compete with any and all other applicants
whose applications for admission to the Service may be by the Civil Service
Commission accepted.
   (b)Subject to the direction of the Civil Service Commission, the Secretary
shall have charge of all matters pertaining to examinations called for under
these rules to ascertain the merit and fitness of the candidates for admission
into the Department of Police Service of the City of Enid, Oklahoma, with
respect to such candidate's character, knowledge, and ability for the
particular class of service, and to estimate and determine the relative
excellence and standing of the persons examined, and to certify the same in
such manner and form as may be prescribed.
   The Secretary of the Civil Service Commission shall keep minutes of the
Commission's proceedings and all necessary records of applicants, their
examinations and standing, and keep a complete record of all persons employed
in the Department of Police, and record all appointments, promotions,
transfers, dismissals, resignations, and changes of any kind therein.
ARTICLE II. ORGANIZATION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT
Section C.2.1. Rank Of Officers.
   The officers of the Department of Police of the City of Enid shall rank in
the following manner:
   The Chief shall be first in rank.
   Other officers shall be ranked in accordance with the rules and regulations
promulgated for use in the Department of Police.
   Should the Chief, or any officer of the Department of Police, be dismissed
from any position on account of unfitness for the discharge of his duties under
said position, and not for any cause authorizing his entire dismissal from the
service, he shall be restored to the rank and grade held by him prior to his
appointment. In case of the absence, disability, or death of the Chief or any
other officer, said position shall be filled from the eligibility list
hereinafter mentioned.
   [Ord. No. 2002-54, §I, 12-17-2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section C.2.2. Qualifications, Appointments, And Duties.
   The City of Enid shall maintain a Police Department consisting of the Chief
of Police and such other officers and patrolmen as may be provided by
ordinance. Members of the Department of Police, including the Chief and his
assistants, shall be appointed from the list of eligibles prepared by the Civil
Service Commission, in accordance with the rules and regulations prescribed
herein; provided, however, that in case of an emergency the Chief of the
Department of Police of the City of Enid may make temporary appointments, to
remain in force during the continuation of such emergency. Such appointees need
not be in the classified service.
   The Department of Police shall be under the control and direction of the
Chief of Police. The Chief of Police shall have exclusive control of the
stationing and transfer of all officers and patrolmen constituting the Police
Force, under such rules and regulations as are established. The Chief of Police
shall each day furnish the Secretary of the Civil Service Commission a written
statement designating all members of the Department of Police who are sick or
injured, and the Secretary of the Civil Service Commission shall keep a
complete record thereof.
ARTICLE III. ELIGIBILITY FOR SERVICE
Section C.3.1. Personal Qualifications.
   (a)No person shall be admitted to examination for any position in the
Department of Police who is not a citizen of the United States and who has not
been an actual resident of the City of Enid for at least three (3) years next
preceding the date of examination.
   [Editor's Note: The residency requirement is unconstitutional and is not
enforced.]
   (b)No person will be admitted to examination who is less than twenty one
(21) years of age, or more than forty five (45), at the time of his
examination. This rule shall be waived in the case of men already in the
service of the Department, and who have served ninety (90) consecutive days
immediately preceding the adoption of these rules. This rule may be waived at
the discretion of the Civil Service Commission, in unusual or extraordinary
cases.
Section C.3.2. Original Appointments.
   In all other cases, the original appointments to positions in the Department
shall be made to the lowest grade of service, and advancements to the highest
grade shall be by promotion in accordance with the provisions of these rules.
Every applicant, in addition to other requirements, shall comply with the
following regulations and specifications
   He shall be not less than five feet six inches (5'6") in height (in bare
feet), and his weight and circumference of chest must be within the following
table, and he must be physically qualified to sustain the labors and exposures
of the Police Department.
 
Height           Minimum Weight Maximum Weight Min. Circ. Of Chest Quiescent
5 feet 6 inches  135 pounds     175 pounds     34 inches
5 feet 7 inches  140 pounds     180 pounds     341/2 inches
5 feet 8 inches  145 pounds     185 pounds     35 inches
5 feet 9 inches  150 pounds     190 pounds     351/2 inches
5 feet 10 inches 155 pounds     195 pounds     36 inches
5 feet 11 inches 160 pounds     200 pounds     37 inches
6 feet           165 pounds     210 pounds     371/2 inches
6 feet 1 inch    170 pounds     215 pounds     38 inches

   Provided, however, that the following modifications of the chest measurement
required in this schedule may be allowed:
(1)To an applicant whose height is between five feet nine inches (5'9") and six
feet (6'), a reduction of one inch (1") or any fraction thereof.
(2)To an applicant whose height is six feet (6') or over, a reduction of one
and one-half inches (11/2") or any fraction thereof. And provided further, that
in all cases the applicant shall have a chest expansion of three inches (3") or
more; and there shall be a difference of at least two inches (2") between
forced and full respiration; and provided, that the limitations of this section
shall not apply to men who have served ninety (90) or more consecutive days
immediately preceding the adoption of this amendment.
   [Editor's Note: All but the first sentence of this section is
unconstitutional and is not enforced.]
ARTICLE IV. APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION TO SERVICE
Section C.4.1. Generally.
   (a)Applications for admission to examination shall be made on forms to be
furnished by said Commission to all applicants for examination, and to require
such information and certifications of persons acquainted with applicant as
said Commission may require. All applications must be filled out and certified
in the handwriting of the applicant.
   (b)A good moral character is of paramount importance, and is an essential
qualification in determining an applicant's right to examination. Proof at any
time produced to the Civil Service Commission of an applicant's bad character
or dissolute habits, or of any criminal or disgraceful act committed by him, or
of dismissal for good cause from the public service, shall be deemed sufficient
grounds for the rejection of such applicant, either before or after
examination, and for removal from the register of eligibles.
   (c)A false statement knowingly made by any person in an application for
examination, connivance at or with any false representation or statement made
in any certificate which may accompany such application, or complicity in any
fraud touching the same, shall be regarded as good cause for exclusion from the
examination, or from the register of eligibles, or for removal or discharge
during probation, or thereafter; but no person shall be removed from a register
of eligibles, or from the service, under this section, until an opportunity has
been given him to be publicly heard before the Civil Service Commission, on
written charges, and after due notice, as hereinafter provided for the hearing
of charges before said Civil Service Commission. And a record shall be kept of
the findings of said Commission, showing the vote thereon and the reasons
therefor.
   (d)Applications and accompanying certificates will be filed in the office of
the Civil Service Commission, and will not be returned to the applicant.
   (e)Defective applications shall be returned and an opportunity given for
correction, except when the defects therein disqualify the applicant under
these regulations.
   (f)The Civil Service Commission may limit the number of applicants to be
examined according to the needs of the service, and in such cases applicants
shall be admitted to examination in the order in which their applications have
been filed in due form.
   [Editor's Note:The section number (and catchline) has been furnished by the
editor.]
ARTICLE V. EXAMINATION
Section C.5.1. Character Of Examination.
   All examinations shall be impartial, public, competitive, and practical in
their character, and shall relate to those matters which will fairly test the
relative capacity of the persons examined to discharge the duties of the
positions to which they seek appointment, and shall include tests of physical
qualifications and health. No questions in any examination shall relate to
political or religious opinion or affiliation.
Section C.5.2. Time, Place, And Notice.
   Examinations shall be held at such times and places as the Civil Service
Commission may designate, and two (2) weeks' notice, in writing thereof, shall
be given to all eligible applicants.
Section C.5.3. Subjects For Examination And Relative Importance Thereof.
   The subjects in examinations for the Service, and the relative importance of
each subject, shall be designated from time to time by the Civil Service
Commission. The subjects may include special tests as to technical or
scientific knowledge.
Section C.5.4. Physical Examinations.
   Physical examinations shall be made by physicians designated by the Civil
Service Commission.
   [Ord. No. 89-12, § II, 2-7-1989 approved at referendum April 4, 1989]
Section C.5.5. Secrecy Regarding Identity Of Applicants.
   All examinations shall be conducted so that no examination paper will
disclose the name or identity of any applicant until all the examination answer
sheets shall have been graded. Any applicant in any examination who places any
identification mark upon his examination shall be deprived of all benefits
under such examination.
Section C.5.6. Explanation Of Questions.
   All necessary explanations of examination questions shall be made to the
whole class. No question shall be explained to any individual applicant.
Section C.5.7. Penalty For Withdrawal From Examination.
   Any applicant who withdraws from any examination or fails to complete the
entire examination after filling out his identification card and receiving
copies of the questions shall be considered as having failed in said
examination. The reason for such failure shall be stated on his record card.
Section C.5.8. Leaving Room During Examination.
   During the examination, no applicant will be permitted to leave the room in
which the examination is being conducted, except in case of extreme necessity
and then only after having handed in his papers on one subject and prior to his
having received the questions in the next subject.
Section C.5.9. Time Limit For Examination.
   The time limit prescribed for each examination, and for any special subject
of examination, shall be announced before the examination. Such examination
shall begin when all announcements have been made and questions distributed. No
variation of time limitation shall be allowed any applicant during any
particular examination.
Section C.5.10. Grading.
   (a)Each member of the Examining Board (composed of the Civil Service
Commission) shall place the grade he gives the applicant, on each subject, on a
separate blank, and at the end of the grading the three (3) grades on said
subject shall be averaged; this average shall be the final grade in said
subject. The Civil Service Commission shall establish a uniform method for
arriving at grades in all subjects; and each competitor or applicant shall be
uniformly graded on a scale of one hundred (100), according to the general
average determined by the markings, and the name of no competitor, who fails to
attain a general average of seventy per centum (70%) of complete proficiency in
the subjects of the examination, taken as a whole, shall be entered on the
register of eligibles for the Service.
   (b)In marking the subject of experience, the grade shall be given upon the
answers contained in the application blank, subject to the general regulations
contained in subdivision (a) of article V, section 10, of this amendment.
Section C.5.11. Fraud In Examination.
   Any person who shall, at any examination or in any document signed or
furnished by him in connection with any examination, by himself or in co-
operation with one or more persons, make any false representation regarding
himself or by allowing any other person to impersonate him, or who uses or aids
anyone in using any information surreptitiously obtained, or who uses or aids
another in using any memoranda whereby an advantage is obtained over other
competitors at such examination, shall be excluded from the examination, and
his name shall be stricken from any eligible list upon which it may appear;
provided, this penalty shall not be imposed until after the accused has been
given the opportunity to be heard, in his defense, in the matter prescribed in
article IX of this amendment, insofar as said procedure is applicable hereto.
Section C.5.12. Notice Of Standing.
   Within a reasonable time after the completion of an examination, each
applicant shall be notified of the general average he has attained on
examination.
Section C.5.13. Re-Examination.
   No person who has failed to pass an examination shall be re-examined within
six (6) months from the date of such failure. An applicant who has passed an
examination and been enrolled upon the register of eligibles, shall not be
again examined until one year from the date of such enrollment, and then only
upon withdrawal of his name from the register of eligibles and upon the filing
of a new application.
Section C.5.14. Review Of Examination Papers.
   No examination papers and no examination shall be subject to review by any
person after the posting of the eligible list, except that the Civil Service
Commission may correct mistakes committed by an examiner on the unanimous
consent of such Civil Service Commission; provided, however, that no such
correction shall be made after one year from the date of the posting of the
eligible register in which the mistake occurred; and provided further, that no
person who has been certified from said eligible register shall be disturbed
because of such correction.
ARTICLE VI. REGISTER OF ELIGIBLES
Section C.6.1. Enrollment.
   The Civil Service Commission shall prepare and keep a book, to be known as
the "Register of Eligibles," in which shall be enrolled the names of all
persons who are eligible to appointment or to promotion in the Department of
Police under the proper classes, divisions, and grades. All applicants for any
position in the Department of Police who participated in a competitive
examination, and attained on such examination a general average standing of
seventy per centum (70%), or over, and who are otherwise eligible, shall take
rank and be enrolled upon the register as candidates for appointment to the
position for which they were examined, in the order of their relative
excellence as determined by examination, without reference to priority of time
of examination.
Section C.6.2. Striking Names From Register.
   The Civil Service Commission may strike the names of candidates from the
Register of Eligibles after they have remained thereon more than one year from
the date of their enrollment, without prejudice to the right of such candidate
or candidates to again make application in an effort to attain a higher state
of proficiency in such examination.
ARTICLE VII. FILLING VACANCIES
Section C.7.1. Requisition And Certification.
   When a vacancy is to be filled in the Department of Police, the appointing
officer shall make a requisition, upon a form prescribed by the Civil Service
Commission for the certification to him of the names of eligibles. The
appointing officer shall notify the Civil Service Commission of each position
to be filled separately. The Civil Service Commission shall, unless the place
is to be filled by reinstatement, certify to the appointing officer the name
and address of the candidate standing highest upon the register for the class,
division, or grade to which said position belongs, and such person shall be
appointed.
Section C.7.2. Waiver Of Certification Or Reinstatement.
   An eligible who has been certified or tendered reinstatement may waive said
certification or reinstatement, upon giving reasons satisfactory to the Civil
Service Commission, without losing his place upon the register. If the reason
assigned is not satisfactory to the Civil Service Commission, or the eligible
refuses to accept an appointment tendered, his name shall be removed from the
eligible register. All waivers must be filed with the Civil Service Commission
within five (5) days from the date of certification. In the absence of such
waiver, the name of the eligible next in order is certified in his place. If,
within thirty (30) days from the date of certification, the eligible so removed
furnishes to the Civil Service Commission good and sufficient reason for his
failure to report, he may be restored to the eligible list. But in the absence
of any such sufficient reason, his separation at the expiration of said thirty
(30) days shall be final.
Section C.7.3. Method Of Reinstatement.
   Subject to the provisions of article VII, and the general provisions
appearing in article X hereof, when a vacancy occurs in any department of the
Department of Police Service, the Civil Service Commission shall, before any
new certificate is made from an eligible register, reinstate in the same class,
division, and grade in which he was formerly employed, any person who has been
examined and appointed under these rules, and who has been temporarily
separated from the Department of Police Service, and the seniority of service
of such appointee shall be governed by the date of his original appointment.
Section C.7.4. Filling Of Vacancies.
   Vacancies in the Department of Police Service, if not filled by promotion as
herein otherwise provided, shall be filled by requisition and certification, as
provided in this amendment. The appointee shall be on probation for a period of
twelve (12) months. At the end of this period, if the conduct and capacity of
the person appointed has been satisfactory, the appointment shall be deemed
complete.
   [Ord. No. 89-11, § II, 2-7-1989 approved at referendum April 4, 1989]
Section C.7.5. Discharge During Probationary Period.
   If any appointee shall, during said probation period, be found incompetent,
or otherwise disqualified, for the performance of the duties of the position he
is filling, the Chief of the Department of Police, by and with the consent of
the Civil Service Commission, may discharge said appointee upon assigning in
writing to the Civil Service Commission the reasons therefor.
Section C.7.6. Temporary Appointments.
   To prevent the stoppage of public business, or to meet extraordinary
exigencies, the Chief of the Department of Police may, with the approval of the
Civil Service Commission, make temporary appointments to remain in force not to
exceed sixty (60) days, and only until a regular appointment can be made in
accordance with the procedure otherwise provided herein.
Section C.7.7. Removal From County.
   Removal of residence from the County of Garfield shall be cause for the
discharge of any person in the Department of Police Service.
Section C.7.8. Restoration Of Probationer.
   Should the work for which a probationer has been certified prove temporary,
and his services be discontinued, without fault or delinquency on his part,
before his time of probation is completed, his name shall be restored to its
proper position upon the Register of Eligibles, and the time he has served
shall be credited to him on his probationary period.
Section C.7.9. Assignment Of Duty.
   Any person appointed to, or promoted in, the Department of Police Service
shall be required to perform the duties of the position to which he has been
appointed or promoted.
Section C.7.10. Outside Employment.
   No employee of the Department of Police shall engage in any outside
occupation which shall interfere with the response to a call for emergency 
when he is off duty.
ARTICLE VIII. PROMOTIONS
Section C.8.1. Method.
   Promotions in the Department of Police Service shall be made on the basis of
seniority in service and examination. All examinations for promotion shall be
competitive among such members of the next lower grade, or rank, as desire to
submit themselves to such examination; provided, however, that sergeants or
officers of higher rank shall be eligible to take examinations for any rank
higher than that in which they may be at the time of taking such examination.
Section C.8.2. Time Of Service.
   No patrol officer shall be examined for promotion for any grade in the
Department of Police until he has served at least four (4) years in the next
lower grade, and no sergeant shall be examined for promotion for any grade in
the department until he has served at least two (2) years in the next lower
grade. Captains and the rank immediately below captain and officers of higher
rank, after having passed an examination showing proper proficiency, are
eligible for promotion to any rank.
   [Ord. No. 2002-55, §I, 12-17-2002 approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section C.8.3. Method Of Examination.
   The method of examination and the rules governing the same shall be the same
as herein provided for applicants for original appointment.
Section C.8.4. Character Of Examination.
   Examinations for promotions shall be of the same general character as herein
provided for applicants for original appointment. Length of previous service,
and the efficiency of the applicant therein, shall be given due consideration.
In ascertaining such efficiency, the record of the applicant as to conduct
shown in the department in which he has served shall be considered.
Section C.8.5. Grading Of Examination.
   Each competitor shall be graded on a scale of one hundred (100), according
to the general average determined by the markings, and no competitor who fails
to attain a general average of seventy per centum (70%) of complete proficiency
in the subjects of the examination, taken as a whole, shall be deemed eligible
for promotion. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.8.6. Priority Of Certification.
   In certifying from the registers for promotion, when two (2) or more
eligibles have the same general average, preference in certification shall be
given in order of seniority of service. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.8.7. Making Of Certification.
   Upon requisition of the chief of the department of police, the civil service
commission shall certify the name of the person standing highest on the
promotion eligible register, and the chief of the department of police shall
appoint said person to the position; provided, however, that no person shall be
certified from a promotion list who has for one year next preceding the date of
the certification, separated himself from the service of the department of
police, or who has been removed therefrom upon charges brought and established
as provided in this amendment. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
ARTICLE IX. REMOVAL FROM SERVICE
Section C.9.1. Generally.
   Charges against any person holding an office or place of employment in the
department of police service of the city of Enid may be filed by the chief or
head of the department in which the person against whom such charges are made
is employed, or by any other person.
   Such charge shall be investigated by or before the civil service commission.
All charges must be in writing, signed and duly verified by the person making
the same. No member of the department of police can be dismissed from service
until proven guilty of charges previously brought, in the manner hereinafter
provided. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.9.2. Hearing.
   The civil service commission shall cause notice, in writing, together with a
copy of all charges to be considered, to be personally served upon the accused,
or to be mailed to him at his address as shown by the records in the office of
the civil service commission, such notice to state the time, which shall not be
less than ten (10) days after the serving or mailing of such notice, and place
at which such charges will be investigated. The accused shall be given an
opportunity for a public hearing in his defense at such investigation. [Ord.,
4-19-1937]
Section C.9.3. Findings And Decision.
   The findings and decision of the civil service commission shall be certified
to the chief of the department of police, and shall be forthwith enforced by
him. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.9.4. Suspension.
   The chief of the department of police may, for good cause, suspend a
subordinate for a period of not to exceed thirty (30) days. In such case he
must forthwith notify the civil service commission in writing of the suspension
and the reason therefor. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.9.5. Political Activity.
   No person in the department of police service of the city of Enid, Oklahoma,
shall take any part in any political campaign, in the interest of any
candidate, save to exercise his right of franchise; and any member of said
department of police who, having been given an opportunity to be duly heard, as
in this act provided, shall be found to have violated any portion of this rule,
will be dismissed from the service. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
   [Editor's note: This section is illegal pursuant to 11 Oklahoma Statutes
section 22-101.1 and is not enforced.]
Section C.9.6. Specific Grounds For Discipline, And Authorized Punishments.
   The following shall be deemed specific cause for the suspension, under
charges, of any member of the department of police:
1.Intoxication while on or off active duty.
2.Being a user of intoxicating liquor to excess.
3.Being engaged directly or indirectly as a vendor of intoxicating liquor.
4.Willful disobedience of any order lawfully issued to him by a superior
officer in the department of police.
5.Incompetency to perform the duties of his office.
6.Conviction of any crime, or misdemeanor, against the laws of the United
States or the laws of the state of Oklahoma, or conviction of any violation of
a lawful ordinance of the city of Enid.
7.Habitually contracting debts which he is unable or unwilling to pay, or
refusing, without reasonable excuse, to discharge his lawful obligations.
8.Conduct unbecoming to an officer, patrolman, or gentleman.
9.Conduct subversive to the good order and discipline of the department of the
police.
10.Willfully or continually violating any of the rules or regulations of the
department of police.
   The civil service commission, after a fair and impartial hearing, shall, if
the party under charges is found guilty, order any of the following actions
taken:
(1)Fine of not to exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00).
(2)Loss of vacation days; or suspension from duty, for not to exceed sixty (60)
days, without pay.
(3)Reduction in rank of office.
(4)Discharge from service. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
   [Editor's note: The section number and catchline for the above section has
been editorially supplied; such section appeared after section 5 in the charter
compilation published in the city's 1973 code under the caption "specified
rules." Additionally, the specific causes for suspension, i.e., items "1"
through "10" above were designated in such charter compilation as sections 1--
10.]
ARTICLE X. GENERAL PROVISIONS
 
Section C.10.1. Reports, Lists, Etc.
   (a)If any office or place of employment is created or abolished, or the
compensation attached thereto altered, the officer or board making such change
shall immediately report the same in writing to the civil service commission.
   (b)A list, to be known as the civil list of the department of police of the
city of Enid, Oklahoma, shall be kept in the office of the civil service
commission, and shall contain the name of every person employed in, or
receiving compensation from, the department of police. The list shall show,
respecting every officer and employee: the title of office, or position, the
length of time the incumbent or employee has held the same, the salary or
compensation thereto attached, the length of time the incumbent or employee has
been in the service of the department of police of the city of Enid, and the
place in the service he has filled.
   (c)No payment in compensation of services rendered, after the taking effect
of this amendment, can be made by the city of Enid, or any of its officers, to
a person holding a position in the department of police service, until it
appears either that he was employed in such position at least ninety (90)
consecutive days, immediately preceding the adoption of this amendment, or that
he has been employed under the provisions of this act. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.10.2. Resignations.
   Any officer or employee in the department of police service who tenders his
resignation to his superior officer shall not, after said resignation has been
accepted by the chief of the department of police and reported to the civil
service commission, be allowed to withdraw said resignation or be reinstated,
unless the application for such withdrawal is made within thirty (30) days
after the receipt of said report, and then only upon the recommendation of the
chief of the department of police and the consent of the civil service
commission. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.10.3. Unauthorized Absences.
   Any officer or employee of the department of police service of this city,
who shall absent himself from duty for a period of ten (10) days without
permission in writing from the chief of the department of police, shall be
considered as having abandoned his employment and as having separated himself
from the service of the department of police. Such officer or employee may,
within thirty (30) days after such separation, make an application in writing
to the civil service commission for reinstatement, and the civil service
commission shall thereupon give him a hearing and may grant said reinstatement,
if it deems the same to be for the interest of the service. If said application
for reinstatement be refused, the separation shall be final, subject to the
right of appeal from the rulings of the civil service commission, as
hereinafter provided. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.10.4. Leave Of Absence And Reinstatement.
   (a)Leave of absence without pay may be granted by the chief of the
department with the consent of the civil service commission, for the following
causes:
(1)That an officer or employee may enter upon a course of study, or engage in
an investigation, calculated to improve the quality of his service.
(2)If such officer or employee has some reason which, in the judgment of the
chief of the department of police, and the civil service commission, is
sufficient to constitute good reason for granting such leave of absence.
(3)By the civil service commission, to those eligible, upon the request of the
chief of the department of police, for a period of thirty (30) days, or more,
not to exceed six (6) months, except in the case of an employee desiring to
attend an institution of higher learning, in which case the time limit shall be
one year.
   (b)Positions so vacated shall be filled either for the duration of the
leave, by substitution from the head of the eligible list, when an eligible
qualified to do the work is available; or by temporary appointment.
   (c)Leave of absence will not be granted during the probationary period, or
within ninety (90) days from the reinstatement of a former employee, except on
account of illness.
   (d)A vacation of fifteen (15) days, with full pay, shall be granted each
year to every member of the Enid department of police, who has been in said
service for a period of one full year. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.10.5. Meetings Of The Civil Service Commission.
   Meetings of the civil service commission shall be held at the office of said
commission, when called by the president, or any two (2) members, or by the
mayor of the city of Enid. Written notice of the date, time, and object of the
meeting shall be mailed to each other member by the secretary, at least two (2)
days prior to the meeting. A majority of the civil service commission shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
   [Editor's note: These notice provisions have been superseded by the adoption
of D.1.18 in 1989 that provides that the notice requirements of the open
meeting act are followed.]
Section C.10.6. Eligibility Of Civil Service Commission Members For
Examinations; Appointment Of Successors.
   If, at any time, any member of the civil service commission created by this
amendment shall desire to submit to any examination relative to admission to
the department of police service, or promotion therein, such member shall make
known to the commission his intention to take such examination and shall resign
from said commission, wholly severing all connection therewith, prior to the
date of the examination in which said member of the commission proposes to
compete. It shall be the duty of the mayor and commissioners of the city of
Enid to appoint a successor to said resigning commissioner immediately upon the
acceptance of such resignation, said successor to be appointed, qualify, and
assume his duties on the civil service commission prior to any preparation made
by the civil service commission with reference to the examination heretofore
mentioned. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.10.7. Reduction In Force.
   In the event it becomes necessary to discontinue the services of any officer
or member of the department of police, because of congested conditions in the
service, or for any other cause not involving any fault or dereliction of such
officer or member justifying his removal for cause under the terms of this
amendment, seniority shall prevail. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
Section C.10.8. Financial Support Of Civil Service Commission.
   The mayor and commissioners of the city of Enid are hereby authorized and
directed to make appropriations necessary for the payment of such expenses as
may be incurred by the civil service commission in putting into execution and
continuing in effect the provisions of this amendment. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
ARTICLE XI. APPEALS
Section C.11.1. Generally.
   An appeal from any final action, decision, ruling, judgment, or order of the
civil service commission may be taken to the district court of Garfield County,
state of Oklahoma, by any person or persons, any taxpayer, officer, department,
board or bureau of the city of Enid, Oklahoma, jointly or severally aggrieved,
by filing with the secretary of the civil service commission, within thirty
(30) days, a notice of appeal, which notice shall specify the grounds of such
appeal. Upon filing of the notice of appeal as herein provided, the secretary
of the civil service commission shall forthwith transmit to the court clerk of
the said district court the original, or certified copies, of all the papers
constituting the record in the case, together with the order, decision or
ruling of the civil service commission. Such case shall be heard and tried de
novo in the district court. [Ord., 4-19-1937]
PART D. AMENDMENT NO. 7
CITY MANAGER FORM OF GOVERNMENT*
   [*Editor's note: This part contains charter amendment no. 7, approved by the
governor on January 4, 1947. Such amendment did not create specific sections of
the basic charter, hence its inclusion as part D.]
ARTICLE I. OFFICERS
Section D.1.1. Rules Of Construction.
   Whenever in the constitution of the state of Oklahoma, or the laws thereof,
or in the present ordinances of the city of Enid, hereby continued in force,
reference is made to the "mayor" or to the "chief executive officer" of the
city, such reference shall be deemed made to the mayor under the new form of
government under this amendment; and whenever in the said constitution, laws or
ordinances, reference is made to the "city board" or to the "mayor and
council," or to the "mayor and councilman," or to the "legislative body" of the
city, such reference shall be deemed made to the board of commissioners of the
city. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.2. Composition Of Mayor And Board Of Commissioners.
   The board of commissioners of the city of Enid shall consist of one
commissioner from each ward as now constituted, and shall  be candidates from
and elected by their respective wards.  Each commissioner shall be a resident
citizen of the ward from which he is a candidate at the time of his candidacy
and election. The mayor and board of commissioners shall constitute the
governing body of the city.  The mayor shall be a candidate at large and
elected at large. [Amendment approved by the governor, 10-28-1993]
Section D.1.3. Qualifications For Mayor And Commissioners.
   Any elector of the state of Oklahoma, twenty five (25) years of age, and who
at the time of the election shall be, and for the two (2) years next preceding
such election shall have been, a resident in good faith of the city of Enid,
shall be qualified for the office of mayor or commissioner. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.4. Commissioners; How Elected And Term Of Office.
   The commissioners elected under this amended charter from the respective
wards of the city shall serve for a term of four (4) years, beginning on the
first Monday in May following their election, and until their successors are
elected and have qualified. Each commissioner shall give bond to the city in
the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned upon the faithful
performance of his duties, and the premium on such bond shall be paid by the
city. All such bonds shall be executed by a reliable surety company duly
authorized to do business in Oklahoma and approved by the county treasurer of
Garfield County. No person shall be eligible to serve as commissioner, mayor or
as an elective official of the city of Enid for more than eight (8) years in
succession; provided, however, that no time served by appointment or election
to fill a vacancy in an unexpired term shall be considered as a part of said
eight (8) years. [Amendment approved by the governor, 5-1-1961; Ord. 2002-50
§I, 12-17-2002, approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section D.1.5. Mayor; How Chosen And Term Of Office.
   The mayor shall be elected at large and shall serve as mayor beginning on
the first Monday in May following his election, for the term of four (4) years,
and until his successor is elected and qualified. [Ord. 2002-50 §I, 12-17-2002,
approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section D.1.6. Filling Of Vacancies.
   Vacancies in the office of mayor and commissioners shall be filled by the
board of commissioners until the next general municipal election at which time
the electors of the city must elect some person to fill the unexpired term, but
any vacancies from recall election shall be filled in the manner provided in
such cases; provided further, that a residence change of any commissioner from
the ward in which he was elected shall constitute vacancy in such office.
[Amendment approved by the governor, 7-7-1955; Ord. 2002-50 §I, 12-17-2002,
approved at referendum March 4, 2003]
Section D.1.7. Legislative Authority; Voting; Veto; Minutes; Emergency
Measures.
   All legislative authority is hereby vested in the mayor and board of
commissioners. The mayor and commissioners will each have one vote on the
board; and the mayor shall have no veto power, but shall forthwith, without
discretion, approve all ordinances and resolutions adopted by a majority vote
of the board of commissioners. All ordinances and resolutions shall be entered
in the minutes, and no ordinance or resolution shall become operative until
thirty (30) days after its passage, approval, and publication except in cases
of emergency measures; and no such emergency measure shall become immediately
operative unless it shall state in a separate section the reason why it is
necessary that it should become immediately operative, and the question of
emergency shall be ruled upon separately and approved by the affirmative vote
of not less than five (5) members of the mayor and board of commissioners; and
emergency measures so adopted and approved shall take effect and be in force
from and after their passage, approval, and publication. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.8. Meetings; Notice; Quorum; Compensation.
   The board of commissioners shall hold at least one public meeting in each
month at the city hall at an hour to be designated by resolution, and such
special or adjourned meetings as may be called. Such special meetings of the
board of commissioners may be called by the mayor, or by any two (2) of the
commissioners, or by the city manager, upon twelve (12) hours' written notice
to each member of the board, and the city manager, served personally on each,
or left at his residence in the city, with some member of his family not less
than fifteen (15) years of age; provided, that the appearance of any member of
the board at any such special meeting of the board, shall be a waiver of such
notice. All meetings of the board of commissioners shall be public, and a
journal of the proceedings kept by the city clerk, and any citizen shall have
access to the minutes of the meetings and all records of the city's business.
The city manager shall attend all meetings of the board and may take part in
the discussion, but shall have no vote on the board of commissioners. A
majority of the board shall constitute a quorum and the mayor shall preside at
the meetings. In case he is absent, the board may elect from their number an
acting mayor for the period of such absence. The mayor and each commissioner
shall serve without compensation for their services. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
   [Editor's note: These notice provisions have been superseded by the adoption
of D.1.18 in 1989 that provides that the open meeting act shall be followed.]
Section D.1.9. Appointments By Mayor And Commissioners.
   The mayor and commissioners shall select and employ a city auditor or
auditors, either on part time, contract, or full time basis as they may deem
necessary, who shall work with the city manager in the preparation of his
financial reports, estimates and budgets, and who shall make such additional
audits and reports as the board may require. Such auditor or auditors may be
discharged only by a majority vote of the mayor and the board of commissioners.
They shall be paid such compensation as may be determined by the mayor and the
board.
   The mayor and commissioners shall appoint the city attorney and the members
of all boards and commissions; provided, however, that no person shall serve
more than one term in succession as a member of any civil service commission
after the adoption of this section. [Amendment approved by the governor, 7-7-
1955]
Section D.1.10. Oath Of Office.
   Officers of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of their
respective offices, take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by the
constitution of the state of Oklahoma, and file the same in the office of the
city clerk. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.11. Continuation In Office.
   All officers and employees not holding office under the civil service
provisions of the charter and its amendments of the city of Enid, shall hold
their respective offices without change of compensation until the officers
provided in this amended charter are elected and qualified under the amended
charter, at which time their respective terms of office or appointments, as the
case may be, shall end; except that appointive employees may continue to hold
office until their successors are appointed as provided herein. [Ord., 1-4-
1947]
Section D.1.12. City Manager; Appointment; Qualifications; Removal; Hearing.
   The mayor and commissioners elected under this amendment to the charter
shall qualify as such respectively on the second Monday after their election,
and immediately after they have qualified, the commissioners shall convene and
proceed to employ and appoint a city manager, who shall be the administrative
head of the municipal government. The city manager so employed shall be
appointed without regard to his political belief, and may or may not be a
resident of the city of Enid when appointed, but shall reside in the city of
Enid during his term of office. He shall hold office at the will of the board
of commissioners, and be subject to removal by majority vote of the board at
any time. Provided however, that at least thirty (30) days before such removal
shall become effective, the board shall, by a majority vote of its members,
adopt a preliminary resolution stating the reason for his removal. The manager
may reply in writing and may request a public hearing, which shall be held not
earlier than twenty (20) days nor less than thirty (30) days after the filing
of such request. After such public hearing, if one be requested, and after full
consideration, the board by majority vote of its members may adopt a final
resolution of removal. By the preliminary resolution the board may suspend the
manager from duty, but shall in any case cause to be paid him forthwith any
unpaid balance of his salary up to, and including, the date of his removal.
[Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.13. Powers And Duties Of City Manager.
   The powers and duties of the city manager shall be:
   (a)To prepare and submit to the board of commissioners the annual budget.
   (b)He shall see to the faithful execution of all laws and ordinances of the
city and state.
   (c)He shall appoint all officers, boards, commissions, and employees of the
city of Enid, whose appointment is not specifically reserved to the mayor and
the board of commissioners by this amendment, except the municipal judge, who
shall be appointed as provided by law, and except those civil service
employees, whose selection is otherwise provided by the civil service
provisions of the city charter. No person, however, shall be eligible to serve
as a member of any civil service commission who holds any other public office,
except that the secretary of such commission may be an officer of the
department coming under the supervision of such commission. Provided, however,
that no person shall hold an appointive position or employment in the pay of
the city, under civil service or otherwise, who is related by blood or marriage
within the third degree to either of the commissioners, mayor or to the city
manager; provided, further that this nepotism restriction shall not apply to
any person within the prohibited degree who has held an appointive position or
employment in the pay of the city for two (2) years or more prior to the taking
of office of any commissioner, mayor or city manager to whom said person is
related within the prohibited degree.
