   (d)He shall have power to dismiss any officer or employee appointed by him
when in his judgment the interest of city service so requires, except as
otherwise provided by the civil service provision of the city charter.
   (e)He shall direct and control the several officers and departments of the
city administration, except where otherwise provided in this charter.
   (f)He shall attend all meetings of the board of commissioners and may take
part in the discussion, but shall have no vote.
   (g)He shall keep the board of commissioners advised of all the needs of the
city and shall recommend suitable measures for adoption.
   (h)He shall see to it that the city lives within its budget.
   (i)He shall perform all such other duties as may be imposed upon him by
charter or by ordinance. [Amendment approved by the governor, 7-7-1955]
   [Editor's note: Section 1 of ord. 91-07, adopted February 5, 1991, added §
20 to art. 1 of pt. D relative to nepotism. The city has advised that "the
pertinent conflicting part of § 13(c) [herein] is effectively repealed by the
adoption of this amendment [ord. 91-07]". See § D.1.20 for further
information.]
Section D.1.14. Salary Of City Manager.
   The city manager shall receive such salary as may be agreed upon and fixed
by the mayor and board of commissioners. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.15. Appointment And Removal Procedure; Penalty.
   Neither the mayor nor any commissioner shall recommend any appointment or
removal to be made by the manager except upon request of the manager; and
except for the purpose of inquiry the board and its members shall deal with the
administrative service solely through the city manager, and neither the mayor,
the board, nor any member thereof, shall give orders to any subordinate of the
city manager, either publicly or privately. The mayor or any board member
violating the provisions of this section, or voting for a resolution or
ordinance in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and
upon conviction thereof shall cease to be a member of the board of
commissioners. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.16. City Manager's Bond; Financial Reports.
   The city manager shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties,
enter into an undertaking, with the city, secured by some reliable surety
company, in the penal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), and in such
additional sum and undertaking as the board may from time to time in their
discretion, require, said undertaking or undertakings to be approved by the
board of commissioners, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of his office and for faithfully accounting for and paying over to said
city of Enid all city funds received or collected by him. The said city manager
shall require any appointive officer or employee of the city whose duties
involve the handling of city money, to give bond to the city, secured by some
reliable surety company, and approved by the board of commissioners, in such
amounts as the board may deem necessary for the faithful performance of all
duties of and the accounting for and payments by such appointive officer or
employee of all city funds received by him. The premium for all bonds required
and authorized under this section shall be paid out of the funds of the city.
The city manager shall make a quarterly report in writing to the city
commissioners, or more frequently if requested, covering the receipt and
disbursement of funds and proceedings of the affairs of the city, and a
condensed quarterly report which said quarterly report shall be immediately
published in some newspaper of general circulation in the city and shall be
preserved among the records of the city. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.1.17. Park Board.
   There shall be a board of park commissioners consisting of three (3) members
to be appointed by the city manager who shall hold their positions during the
pleasure of said city manager; and except as herein otherwise provided and
until the commissioners shall otherwise provide by ordinance, the rights,
powers and duties of said board of park commissioners shall be as now declared
and defined by the laws of the state of Oklahoma, as now existing or hereafter
enacted, relative to park boards in cities of the first class. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
   [Editor's Note: The mayor and board of commissioners has passed an ordinance
superseding the park board referenced in this section. The park board is
appointed by the city council. See title 7, chapter 2, article A of the Enid
municipal code.]
Section D.1.18. Oklahoma Open Meeting Act And Oklahoma Open Records Act Govern.
   The city and all of its boards, commissions, agencies, authorities and
public trusts shall be governed by the Oklahoma open meeting act (Oklahoma
Statutes title 25, section 301 et seq.) and the Oklahoma open records act
(Oklahoma Statutes title 51, section 24A.1 et seq.), and as said statutes may
be hereinafter amended. These acts shall supersede all local rules, ordinances
and charter provisions providing for any different standard or regulation.
[Ord. 89-9 § II, 2-7-1989, approved at referendum April 4, 1989]
Section D.1.19. Public Competitive Bidding Act Of 1974.
   All public construction contracts made for the purpose of making any public
improvements or constructing any public building or making repairs to same, and
all contracts pertaining to the maintenance of public property shall be let and
awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, by free and open competitive bidding
after solicitation for sealed bids, in strict accordance with all the
provisions of the state of Oklahoma's public competitive bidding act of 1974
(title 61 Oklahoma Statutes, section 101 et seq.) and as said statutes may be
hereinafter amended. This act shall supersede all local rules, ordinances and
charter provisions providing for any different standard or regulation. [Ord.
91-05 § I, 1-15-1991, approved at referendum April 2, 1991]
Section D.1.20. Nepotism.
   No elected or appointed official or other authority of the municipal
government shall appoint or elect any person related by affinity or
consanguinity within the third degree to any governing body member or to
himself or, in the case of a plural authority, to any one of its members to any
office or position of profit in the municipal government. The provisions of
this section shall not prohibit an officer or employee already in the service
of the municipality from continuing such service or from promotion therein.
This act shall supersede all local rules, ordinances and charter provisions
providing for any different standard or regulation. [Ord. 91-07 § I, 2-5-1991,
approved at referendum April 2, 1991]
ARTICLE II. ELECTIONS
Section D.2.1. Election Board.
   All elections for mayor and commissioners shall be conducted by the
regularly lawfully constituted election board of Garfield County, Oklahoma.
[Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.2.2. Time Of Election.
   On the first Tuesday in February in the year 2007 and each four (4) years
thereafter, and on the first Tuesday in February in the year 2009 and each four
(4) years thereafter, there shall be held a general election conducted at the
regular voting places within the city of Enid, for the election of those
elected officials whose terms of office expire in said year or years under the
provisions of this charter. [Ord. 2004-44, 12-21-2004, eff. 3-1-2005]
Section D.2.3. Determination Of Name Of Candidate; Required Information.
   The method of determining the name of a candidate entitled to be placed upon
the official ballot at said election mentioned in section 2 of this article,
for the office of mayor, or members of the board of commissioners of the city
of Enid, shall be as follows: Candidates may have their names printed on the
ballot as a candidate for an office to be filled under the provisions of this
charter at any city election held for the purpose of electing the officers
mentioned in this amendment, by filing with the county election board a
statement signed by him stating his name as he desires it to appear on the
ballot in the general election, the name of the office for which he is a
candidate, together with his street address. If a candidate for the office of
commissioner, he shall state that he is now a resident of the ward which he
seeks to represent on said board, and has been a resident of the city of Enid
for two (2) years next preceding date of filing said statement. In case of a
candidate for mayor, in addition to stating the name of the office for which he
is a candidate, together with his name and street address, said statement shall
contain a paragraph in which the candidate shall assert that he is now and has
been for two (2) years next preceding the date of filing said statement, a
resident in good faith of the city of Enid, Oklahoma. Said statement in the
case of candidate for mayor and commissioner, when so signed shall be filed
with the secretary of the Garfield County election board no earlier than 8:00
A.M. on the first Monday in December of the year preceding the municipal
general election and no later than 5:00 P.M. on the next succeeding Wednesday.
[When a candidate's name is presented as provided herein, it shall be placed on
the official ballot for said election mentioned in section 2 of this article.]
When such candidate is unopposed, his name shall not appear on the ballot and a
certificate of election shall be issued him. [Ord. 2004-44, 12-21-2004, eff. 3-
1-2005]
Section D.2.4. Ballots; Requirements.
   The Garfield County election board shall prepare the ballots for said
election and such ballots shall contain no emblems, devices, parts or signs
which would in any manner indicate to which political party any candidate
belongs. Said ballot shall be strictly nonpartisan.
   The day after the closing of the filing period for candidates, and the day
after the general election if a runoff election is necessary, the secretary of
the Garfield County election board shall prepare numbered lots in an amount
reflecting the number of candidates for each office and every candidate for
each respective office shall select a numbered lot which shall determine the
order of that candidate's name on the ballot. [Ord. 83-7, approved at
referendum 4-5-1983; Ord. 91-02 § I, 1-15-1991, approved at referendum April 2,
1991]
Section D.2.5. Conduct Of Elections; Certificate Of Election.
   In addition to the preparation of said ballot the said Garfield County
election board shall conduct said election in all respects as other elections
provided for by the general laws and constitution of the state of Oklahoma. A
certificate of each candidate's vote shall be made as in such laws provided;
the ballot boxes shall be sealed as therein provided, and said ballot and
ballot boxes shall be disposed of as provided by the general election laws of
the state. Said election board shall cause to be issued to the successful
candidate or candidates, that is to say the candidates for commissioner from
each ward receiving the largest number of votes for the office for which he is
a candidate, and the candidate for mayor receiving the largest number of votes
for the office for which he is a candidate, proper certificates or certificate
of election; provided, however, if no candidate receives more than fifty
percent (50%) of the votes cast in the general election, a runoff election
between the two (2) candidates with the highest number of votes shall be
conducted on the first Tuesday in April of that year. [Ord. 91-02 § I, 1-15-
1991, approved at referendum April 2, 1991]
Section D.2.6. Applicable Laws.
   All provisions of the general election laws of the state of Oklahoma, where
applicable, and except where the same would be in conflict with the provisions
herein made, shall apply to all municipal elections held in the  city of Enid.
[Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.2.7. Alternative Laws.
   In the event that the foregoing provisions or any of them should be for any
reason held void or for any reason shall become inoperative, then the election
laws of the state of Oklahoma shall govern all elections for municipal officers
within the city of Enid insofar as said special provisions fail. [Ord., 1-4-
1947]
Section D.2.8. Certain Actions Prohibited.
   It shall be unlawful for any candidate for office or any officer or employee
of the city to give or promise to give to any person or persons, directly or
indirectly, any office, position, employment, benefit, or anything of value for
the purpose of influencing or obtaining support, political or otherwise, aid or
vote of any person or persons; the doing of any of which things shall be
grounds for removal from office of such officer, employee or candidate if
elected. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.2.9. Petitions And Filing Fees.
   A declaration of candidacy must be accompanied by a petition supporting a
candidate's filing signed by five percent (5%) of the registered voters
eligible to vote for a candidate in the general election wherein the
candidate's name would appear on the ballot, as reflected by the latest January
15th registration report; or by a cashier's check or certified check in the
amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) filed with the secretary of the county
election board.
   Said check shall be forfeited to the election board and proceeds therefrom
shall be used by said board to defray election expenses unless the candidate is
unopposed in the general election, becomes a candidate in the runoff election,
or receives more than fifteen percent (15%) of the votes cast for the office
for which he is a candidate at the first election wherein his name appears on a
ballot, in which case said check shall be returned to the candidate
immediately. [Ord. 91-06 § I, 1-15-1991, approved at referendum April 2, 1991]
ARTICLE III. REPEAL OF CHARTER PROVISIONS
Section D.3.1. Repealed Sections.
   Article II, sections 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9; article IV, sections 2, 3, 6, 8,
9, 10, 11; article VII, sections 1, 2, 3, 4, 5; article VIII, sections 18, 26,
27, 28, 29, 30 of the charter of Enid, and all articles, sections, and
provisions of the said charter, amendments thereto, and ordinances, of the city
of Enid, to the extent only that any provision thereof is in conflict with this
amendment, are hereby repealed. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
Section D.3.2. Effective Date.
   For the preservation of the public peace, health and safety, an emergency is
hereby declared to exist so that this ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from and after its passage, approval and publication. [Ord., 1-4-1947]
PART E. UNION ORGANIZATION AND COLLECTIVE BARGAINING
ARTICLE I. UNION ORGANIZATION AND COLLECTIVE BARGAINING FOR CERTAIN EMPLOYEES
Section E.1.1. Right To Organize And Bargain Collectively.
   In order to protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizenry
by promoting good labor relations, the city of Enid hereby extends the right to
organize and bargain collectively to all non-supervisory, non-management
confidential city employees. All such rights granted by this article, and
ordinances enacted thereunder and procedures and activities used in the
implementation of these rights shall be governed by the laws of the state of
Oklahoma. The city council shall enact ordinances to effectuate the intent and
express provisions of this article. [eff. 11-12-2013]
Section E.1.2. Recognition Of Bargaining Unit.
   The city commissioners shall recognize, subject to the provisions of this
charter and relevant ordinances, a bargaining unit of city employees for the
purpose of bargaining collectively with the city of Enid with respect to wages,
salaries, hours, rates of pay, grievances, working conditions and other terms
and conditions of employment. [eff. 11-12-2013]
Section E.1.3. Strikes Prohibited.
   In order to protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the
citizenry, the right to strike or to engage in any work stoppage or slowdown is
hereby expressly prohibited. "Strike" means, in concerted action with others,
an employee's refusal to report to duty or wilful absence from one's position,
or abstaining in whole or in part from the full, faithful and proper
performance of the duties of employment for the purpose of inducing,
influencing or coercing a change in the conditions, compensation, rights,
privileges or obligations of employment. [eff. 11-12-2013]
 
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Territorial Applicability
1-1-4: Amendments
1-1-5: Supplementation Of Code
1-1-6: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the board of commissioners, this city code is hereby
declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official city code of Enid.
This city code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the ENID MUNICIPAL
CODE 2003 and is hereby published by authority of the mayor and board of
commissioners and shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent
legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-5 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this city code by title in any legal documents. (2003 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The city code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2003 Code)
1-1-3: TERRITORIAL APPLICABILITY:
This code shall refer only to the omission or commission of acts within the
territorial limits of the city and to that territory outside the city over
which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or
charter provisions, or any law. (1994 Code § 1-7)
1-1-4: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending the city code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this city code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this city code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
the city code. (2003 Code)
1-1-5: SUPPLEMENTATION OF CODE:
   A.   Preparation And Printing: By contract or by city personnel, supplements
to this code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by
the mayor and board of commissioners. A supplement to the code shall include
all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the mayor
and board of commissioners or adopted by initiative and referendum during the
period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the code, and
shall also include all amendments to the charter during the period. The pages
of the supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the
code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or
partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have
been inserted, the code will be current through the date of the adoption of the
latest ordinance included in the supplement.
   B.   Exclusion Of Repealed Portions: In preparing a supplement to this code,
all portions of the code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the
code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages.
   C.   Nonsubstantive Changes Authorized: When preparing a supplement to this
code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to
prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances
and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary
to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may:
      1.   Organize the ordinance material into appropriate sections or
subsections;
      2.   Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and
other subsections of the code printed in the supplement, and make changes in
such catchlines, headings and titles;
      3.   Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subsections to be
inserted in the code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change
existing section or other subsection numbers;
      4.   Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to
"this chapter", "this article", "this section", etc., as the case may be, or to
"sections            to           , (inserting section numbers to indicate the
sections of the code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance
incorporated into the code); and
      5.   Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original
meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the code; but, in no case shall the
codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material
included in the supplement or already embodied in the code. (1994 Code § 1-12)
1-1-6: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend, by additions or
deletions, any part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages, or
portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such code in any manner whatsoever
which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby; provided,
that supplementation of this code, as provided for in section
1-1-5 of this chapter, by authorized persons shall be permitted. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Certain Ordinances Not Affected By Code
1-2-3: Provisions As Continuation Of Existing Ordinances
1-2-4: Effect Of Repeal Of Ordinances; Revival
1-2-5: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this city
code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this city code or are
by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the ordinances
enumerated in section
1-2-2 of this chapter. (2003 Code)
1-2-2: CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT AFFECTED BY CODE:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall be construed to
repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following:
   A.   Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the
city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of
the city's indebtedness;
   B.   Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of
taxes or for an annual budget;
   C.   Any ordinance creating specific sewer and paving districts and other
local improvement or special assessment districts or otherwise relating to
specific local improvements and special assessments therefor;
   D.   Any ordinance calling or otherwise relating to specific elections;
   E.   Any ordinance defining, extending or contracting the corporate limits
of the city;
   F.   Any ordinance granting any right or franchise;
   G.   Any ordinance authorizing or approving specific contracts;
   H.   Any ordinance vacating, opening or naming streets or alleys;
   I.   Any ordinance relating to retirement or pension benefits for city
officers and employees; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply
to ordinances dealing exclusively with pensions or retirement for members of
the fire or police departments;
   J.   Any ordinance relating to subdivisions or zoning;
   K.   Any ordinance the purpose of which has been accomplished;
   L.   Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect;
   M.   Any ordinance which is special although permanent in effect. (1994 Code
§ 1-6)
1-2-3: PROVISIONS AS CONTINUATION OF EXISTING ORDINANCES:
The provisions of this code, insofar as they are substantially the same as
ordinance provisions previously adopted by the city relating to the same
subject matter, shall be construed as restatements and continuations thereof
and not as new enactments. (1994 Code § 1-4)
1-2-4: EFFECT OF REPEAL OF ORDINANCES; REVIVAL:
   A.   Effect: Neither the adoption of this code nor the repeal hereby of any
ordinance of the city shall in any manner affect the prosecution for violation
of ordinances, which violations were committed prior to the effective date
hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of any license or penalty at the effective
date due and unpaid under such ordinance, nor be construed as affecting any of
the provisions of such ordinance relating to the collection of any such license
or penalty or the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to
affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof, required to be
posted, filed or deposited pursuant to any ordinance, and all rights and
obligations thereof appertaining shall continue in full force and effect.
   B.   Revival: Whenever any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or
provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to
revive such former ordinance, clause or provision, unless it shall be therein
so expressly provided. (1994 Code § 1-8)
1-2-5: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If a court of competent jurisdiction should hold one or more sections or a part
of a section of this code or of an ordinance passed hereafter invalid, such
holding shall not affect the remainder of the code or ordinance nor the context
in which such section, sections or part of a section so held invalid may
appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part of a section may be
inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the section, sections or part
of a section so held invalid. (1994 Code § 1-13)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Definitions And Rules Of Construction
1-3-2: Titles Of Chapters, Articles And Sections
1-3-3: History Notes
1-3-1: DEFINITIONS AND RULES OF CONSTRUCTION 1 :
In the construction of the city charter, city code and of all ordinances and
resolutions passed by the mayor and board of commissioners, the following
definitions and rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be
inconsistent with the manifest intent of the mayor and board of commissioners:
BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS: The mayor and the board of commissioners of the city.
CHARTER, CITY CHARTER: The charter of the city of Enid.
CITY: The city of Enid, in Garfield County, Oklahoma.
CODE: Reference to "this code" or "the code" shall mean the Enid city code, as
designated in section
1-1-1 of this title.
COMPUTATION OF TIME: The time within which an act is to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day. If the last day is
a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, that day shall not be counted in the
computation.
COUNTY: Garfield County, Oklahoma.
DIRECT OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL INTEREST: Only that interest which would be
prohibited by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 8-113 or as such statute may be
hereinafter amended.
GENDER: A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied
to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males.
GOVERNING BODY: The mayor and board of commissioners of the city.
HEALTH OFFICER 2 : Any authorized representative of the city- county health
department of the city.
HERETOFORE AND HEREAFTER: Whenever the word "heretofore" appears in any
ordinance, it shall be construed to mean any time previous to the day when that
ordinance shall take effect; whenever the word "hereafter" appears, it shall be
construed to mean the time after the ordinance shall take effect.
HIGHWAY: Includes any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square,
bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated
or devoted to public use.
JOINT AUTHORITY: Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more
officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared.
MAINTENANCE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY: For the purposes of section A.8.6 of the city
charter, the term "maintenance of public property" shall mean any maintenance
or repair contract on or for any public improvement, including, but not limited
to, contracts for the maintenance or repair of streets, alleys, sidewalks,
storm sewers, water and sanitary sewer lines and plant facilities. The term
does not include the direct purchases of materials, equipment, or supplies used
by the city to maintain or repair public improvements.
MAY: The word "may" is permissive.
MAYOR: The mayor of the city.
MONTH: A calendar month.
MUST: The word "must" is mandatory.
NONTECHNICAL AND TECHNICAL WORDS: All words and phrases shall be construed and
understood according to the common and approved usage of the language.
Technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar or
appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such
peculiar or appropriate meaning.
NUMBER: Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any
word importing the plural number shall include the singular.
OATH: The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases
in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such
cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm"
and "affirmed."
OFFICERS, DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS, COMMISSIONS: Except as otherwise specifically
provided, whenever any officer, department, board, commission or other agency
is referred to by title alone, such reference shall be construed as if followed
by the words "of the city of Enid, Oklahoma".
OR, AND: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the sense
requires it.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the
entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
PERSON: The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations,
corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as
to individuals. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the word "person",
as applied to partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners or members
thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every specie of property, except real property as
herein defined.
PRECEDING; FOLLOWING: The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next
before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes personal, real and mixed property.
PUBLIC GROUNDS, PUBLIC PROPERTY OR PUBLIC PLACES: Any park or open place
adjacent thereto, any lake or stream, any and every public ground, public
square, public park, street or sidewalk, or other public place within the city.
Public property and the term "public property" shall include any and all
interests in property held by the city.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT: Any beneficial or valuable change or addition, betterment,
enhancement or amelioration of or upon any real property or interest therein,
belonging to a public agency, intended to enhance its value, beauty or utility
or to adapt it to a new or future purpose. The term does not include the direct
purchases of materials, equipment or supplies by a public agency.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes land together with all things attached to the land so
as to become a part thereof and all rights thereto and interest therein.
SHALL; MAY: The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive.
SIDEWALK: Any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of
the roadway, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of
pedestrians.
SIGNATURE OR SUBSCRIPTION: The term "signature" or "subscription" shall include
a mark when a person cannot write.
STATE: The State of Oklahoma.
STATUTORY REFERENCES: Reference to the statutes of the state of Oklahoma means
the statutes as they now are or as they may be amended to be.
STREET: Includes any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place, square,
bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel or causeway in the city, dedicated
or devoted to public use.
TENANT; OCCUPANT: These terms, applied to a building or land, shall include any
person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies the whole or a part
of such building or land, either alone or with others.
TENSE: Words used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well
as the past and present, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.
WRITTEN OR IN WRITING: These terms shall be construed to include any
representations of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise.
YEAR: A calendar year. (1994 Code § 1-5)
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - similar provisions, 25 OS § 1 et seq.
   
2 2. See section
  4-1-1 of this code.
1-3-2: TITLES OF CHAPTERS, ARTICLES AND SECTIONS:
All titles of chapters and articles, and all catchlines of sections and
subsections of this code are unofficial and intended only for convenience in
arrangement and as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the chapters,
articles, sections and subsections. They shall not be deemed to be part of the
contents of the chapters, articles, sections or subsections, nor shall the
titles and catchlines alter the otherwise intended meaning of any provision of
this code. (1994 Code § 1-2)
1-3-3: HISTORY NOTES:
The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this code are not
intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the
source of matter contained in the section. (1994 Code § 1-3)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: Penalties For Violations
1-4-2: Credit Allowed Prisoners
1-4-3: Application Of Provisions
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Penalties Imposed: Whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance of
the City, or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or
agency of the City under authority duly vested in him, or it, any act is
prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a
misdemeanor, or the doing of an act is required, or the failure to do any act
is declared to be unlawful, or an offense or a misdemeanor, the violation of
any such provisions of this Code or any other ordinance of the City or such
rule, regulation or order shall be punished as indicated in the applicable Code
section.
   B.   Absence Of Penalty: In the absence of any penalty being specified in an
applicable Code section, an offense shall be punishable by a fine of two
hundred dollars ($200.00), plus costs.
   C.   Limitation; Compliance With State Statute: The provisions of
subsections A and B of this section notwithstanding, no penalty shall be
greater than that established by Oklahoma Statute for the same offense.
   D.   Separate Offense For Each Day: Except as otherwise provided, every day
any violation of this Code or any other ordinance of the City or any rule,
regulation or order shall continue, shall constitute a separate offense.
   E.   Subsequent Offense: Whenever in this Code, an offense provides an
enhanced punishment for a second or subsequent offense, this language shall be
interpreted to require a conviction of the previous offense prior to the
imposition of the enhanced punishment. A conviction for this section does not
include those offenses for which a person received a deferred sentence and the
charge was later dismissed by the court. (Ord. 2017-28, 12-19-2017)
1-4-2: CREDIT ALLOWED PRISONERS:
Prisoners placed at work shall receive compensation of fifty dollars ($50.00)
per day, and the monies so earned shall be credited to the payment of the fine
imposed. Prisoners who do not work shall be credited twenty five dollars
($25.00) per day toward the payment of the fine imposed. (Ord. 2015-02, 1-6-
2015)
1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this Code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this Code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2003 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the Mayor and Board of Commissioners to impose such fine or penalty on such
officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section
creating the duty. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 5
CITY SEAL
SECTION:
1-5-1: Seal Established; Use
1-5-1: SEAL ESTABLISHED; USE:
   A.   Superscription: The city hereby adopts as a superscription for the
corporate seal of the city, the following: "The City of Enid, State of
Oklahoma, Official Seal".
   B.   Engraving: The seal of the city shall be made of metal in circular
form, and the words, "The City of Enid, State of Oklahoma", shall be engraved
in circular form near the circumference of the face thereof, and inside of the
face the words "Official Seal".
   C.   Use Of Seal: The seal made and engraved pursuant to subsections A and B
of this section shall be the corporate seal of the city and shall be used as
such for the authentication of all documents required to be sealed with the
seal of the city. (1994 Code § 2-1)
CHAPTER 6
WARDS AND ELECTIONS 1
SECTION:
1-6-1: Wards Established
1-6-2: Absentee Ballots
 
Notes
1 1. See also sections A.7.7, and D.2.1 through D.2.9 of the city charter.
1-6-1: WARDS ESTABLISHED 1 :
The location and boundaries of the six (6) wards of the city are located
specifically in accordance with the map and plat attached to ordinance 2002-06,
on file in the office of the city clerk, and are described by boundaries, with
all boundary lines described following the centerline of the streets and
extending to the furthermost point within the corporate limits of the city or
to a further point without the corporate limits of the city, if necessary, to
include any portion of the city within said described ward, further described
as follows:
   A.   Ward One: That portion of southwest Enid, Oklahoma, which lies within

Street; Thence South 1.5 miles to the intersection of the U.P. Railroad Right

the city of Enid, Oklahoma.
   B.   Ward Two: That portion of southcentral Enid, Oklahoma, which lies

the city, or to a further point without the corporate limits of the city, if
necessary, to include any portion of the city within said described ward,
described as follows:
Two separated areas:

Range 6 West, I.M.; Thence North to the intersection of Fox Drive and Cleveland
Street; Thence East to the intersection of Van Buren Street and Fox Drive;

   C.   Ward Three: That portion of southeast Enid, Oklahoma, which lies within

include any portion of the city within said described ward, described as

and 30th Street; Thence South to the southern boundary line limit of the city
of Enid, Oklahoma.
   D.   Ward Four: That portion of northeast Enid, Oklahoma, which lies within
the following described line which line extends to the furthermost limits of
the city, or to a further point without the corporate limits of the city, if
necessary, to include any portion of the city within said described ward,
described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of North Van Buren Street and the Northern
boundary line limit of the city of Enid, Oklahoma; Thence South to the
intersection of Mulberry Avenue and Van Buren Street; Thence Easterly along
Mulberry Avenue to the intersection of Washington Street and Mulberry Avenue;
Thence South to the intersection of Walnut Avenue and Washington Street; Thence
East to the intersection of 30th Street and Walnut Avenue; Thence North to the
intersection of Willow Road and 30th Street; Thence East to the intersection of
Willow Road and the Eastern boundary line limit of the city of Enid, Oklahoma.
   E.   Ward Five: That portion of central Enid, Oklahoma, which lies within
the following described line which extends to the furthermost limits of the
city, or to a further point without the corporate limits of the city, if
necessary, to include any portion of the city within said described ward,
described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of North Van Buren Street and Willow Road; Thence
West to the intersection of Oakwood Road and Willow Road; Thence South to the
intersection of Randolph Avenue and Oakwood Road; Thence East to the
intersection of Cleveland Street and Randolph Avenue; Thence South to the
intersection of Garriott Road and Cleveland Street; Thence East to the
intersection of Garriott Road and U.P. Railroad; Thence Northeasterly to the
intersection of Walnut Avenue and U.P. Railroad; Thence West to the
intersection of Washington Street and Walnut Avenue; Thence North to the
intersection of Mulberry Avenue and Washington Street; Thence Westerly along
Mulberry Avenue to the intersection of Van Buren Street and Mulberry Avenue;
Thence North to the intersection of North Van Buren Street and Willow Road,
said intersection being the point of beginning.
   F.   Ward Six: That portion of northwest Enid, Oklahoma, which lies within
the following described line which line extends to the furthermost limits of
the city, or to a further point without the corporate limits of the city, if
necessary, to include any portion of the city within said described ward,
described as follows:
Beginning at the intersection of North Van Buren Street and the northern
boundary line limit of the city of Enid, Oklahoma; Thence South to the
intersection of Willow Road and Van Buren Street; Thence West to the
intersection of Oakwood Road and Willow Road; Thence South to the intersection
of Chestnut Avenue and Oakwood Road; Thence West to the western boundary line
limit of the city of Enid, Oklahoma.
   (Ord. 2002-06, 3-12-2002; amd. 2003 Code)

1-6-2: ABSENTEE BALLOTS:
Absentee ballots shall be provided in every municipal election. (1994 Code § 2-
9)
CHAPTER 7
LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY
SECTION:
1-7-1: City And Public Trust Authorized
1-7-2: Compliance With Local, State And Federal Regulations
1-7-3: Protection Of Public Health And Safety
1-7-1: CITY AND PUBLIC TRUST AUTHORIZED:
The city of Enid and any public trust with the city as beneficiary are hereby
authorized:
   A.   Support State And National Policies: To endorse and support state and
national policies, legislation and programs which may be beneficial and to
oppose such as may be injurious to the city of Enid. The city or trust may
endorse, support or oppose such policies, legislation and programs by a duly
approved resolution approved by a majority of the public body present at a
regular or special meeting.
   B.   Legislative Liaison: To appoint an employee of the city or trust and/or
contract to provide legislative liaison services with the Oklahoma state
legislature and/or United States congress.
The legislative liaison shall assist the city or appropriate trust in
identifying positive and negative legislative actions affecting the city,
proposing amendments to bills affecting the city, developing legislative
strategies as they relate to the mayor and board of commissioners' goals and
priorities and the long range strategic plan for economic recovery of the city
and perform all other services and duties as set out in the respective job
description of such employee and/or appropriate contract.
   C.   Litigation At District Court Or Appellate Level: To join with other
cities, towns and state and national municipal associations and leagues as a
means for collective action in the exercise of their governmental and
proprietary functions, including, but not limited to, instituting or joining in
litigation at the district court or appellate level. (1994 Code § 2-11)
1-7-2: COMPLIANCE WITH LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATIONS:
   A.   Compliance Required: All duties and activities performed by the mayor
and board of commissioners, trustees of any public trust or legislative liaison
authorized by this chapter shall be in accordance with all local, state and
federal laws and regulations.
   B.   Use Of Public Funds: Public funds may be used to pay necessary and
reasonable salaries, costs and expenses for such activities and services. (1994
Code § 2-11)
1-7-3: PROTECTION OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY:
All actions taken under the terms of this chapter shall be necessary to protect
the public health, public safety and comfort of the citizens of the city. (1994
Code § 2-11)
CHAPTER 8
OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 1
SECTION:
1-8-1: Code Enforcement Division
1-8-2: Meetings Of Commissions, Rules Of Procedure
1-8-3: Members Of Boards And Commissions
 
Notes
  1. See also sections A.4.1 through A.4.13 and part D of the city charter for
1 provisions concerning the mayor and board of commissioners, and the city
  manager, respectively.
1-8-1: CODE ENFORCEMENT DIVISION:
The code enforcement division is hereby created and the building official and
all of his assistants and inspectors shall be authorized to enforce the
provisions of this code which relate to the inspection of buildings and over
which it has authority. The building official and all of his assistants and
inspectors shall have the authority to issue citations to persons who violate
such applicable provisions of this code. (1994 Code § 2-8)
1-8-2: MEETINGS OF COMMISSIONS, RULES OF PROCEDURE:
"Robert's Rules Of Order, Newly Revised", 1981 edition, is hereby established
as the rules of procedure for conducting all meetings of all commissions in the
city; provided, however, the mayor and board of commissioners shall have the
authority to modify these rules by resolution or ordinance. (1994 Code § 2-7)
1-8-3: MEMBERS OF BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS:
   A.   Absence From Meetings:
      1.   Board Of Commissioners And Board Of Trustees Of City Trust
Authorities: Whenever any member of the board of commissioners and/or a board
of trustees of city trust authorities is absent from more than one-half (1/2)
of all meetings of the board of commissioners and/or a board of trustees of
city trust authorities, regular and special, held within any period of four (4)
consecutive months, such member shall thereupon cease to hold such position.
      2.   Other Boards And Commissions Excepting City Trusts: Any member
appointed or confirmed by the city shall cease to hold office whenever:
         a.   That member of a board or commission, that regularly meets on a
monthly or more frequent basis, is absent from more than one-half (1/2) of all
meetings of such board or commission, regular and special, held within any
period of four (4) consecutive months; or
         b.   That member of a board or commission, that meets on call or
regularly meets on less than a monthly basis, is absent from more than one-half
(1/2) of all meetings of such board or commission, regular or special, held
within any period of twelve (12) consecutive months.
   B.   Removal; Notice Of Charges, Hearing And Appeal:
      1.   Causes For Removal: Any member of any board or commission, other
than members of board of trustees of city trust authorities, appointed by the
mayor and board of commissioners, may be removed from office by the mayor and
board of commissioners for any of the following causes:
         a.   Habitual or wilful neglect of duty;
         b.   Gross partiality in office;
         c.   Oppression in office;
         d.   Corruption in office;
         e.   Extortion or wilful overcharge of fees in office;
         f.   Wilful maladministration;
         g.   Habitual drunkenness;
         h.   Failure to produce and account for all public funds and property
in his hands at any settlement or inspection authorized or required by law;
         i.   Violation of any penal statute involving moral turpitude;
         j.   Failure to maintain conditions of office.
      2.   Charges And Hearing: Prior to removal of a member of a city board or
commission for causes other than absence, the member shall have been given
written notice of the charges and be afforded an opportunity to be heard before
the mayor and board of commissioners.
      3.   Appeal: The decision of the mayor and board of commissioners may be
appealed to the district court of Garfield County if filed within thirty (30)
days of the decision of the mayor and board of commissioners. (Ord. 2013-20, 3-
5-2013)
CHAPTER 9
CITY DEPARTMENTS
SECTION:
1-9-1: Convention And Tourism Department
1-9-2: Golf Course Department
1-9-1: CONVENTION AND TOURISM DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Established: There is hereby established a department within the city
entitled the "convention and tourism department".
   B.   Functions:
      1.   The department shall administer and direct, to the extent such
authority has not been delegated by the mayor and board of commissioners to a
third party by contract, all tourism and convention activities of the city.
      2.   This department's duties shall include, but not be limited to:
managing, operating and maintaining the Cherokee Strip Conference Center;
gathering information and ideas; conducting research and developing advertising
and promotional programs and materials to promote the city's image so that the
city will be developed and maintained as a major tourist and convention center.
      3.   The city manager or his designee shall be responsible for the
activities and functions of this department.
   C.   Third Party Contracts: The mayor and board of commissioners may
contract with a third party entity to perform any and all services of this
department including, but not limited to, the management, operation and
advertising of the Cherokee Strip Conference Center. In the event that a third
party contract is used to implement this department, the city manager shall
coordinate all work under the contract so that a smooth and efficient service
is maintained.
   D.   Rules, Regulations And Fees: The mayor and board of commissioners shall
designate rules and regulations concerning the operation of the conference
center, which rules and regulations shall be on file with the city clerk. These
rules and regulations shall be followed in the management of the Cherokee Strip
Conference Center. The fees that are set out in section
2-6C-5 of this code shall be charged for the use of the conference center.
(1994 Code § 2-51)
1-9-2: GOLF COURSE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Established: There is hereby established a department within the city
entitled the "golf course department".
   B.   Functions: The functions and duties of the golf course department shall
be as provided by this code and the city manager. The golf course department
shall have under its supervision, Meadowlake Golf Course, together with all
other golf course facilities which may hereinafter be established and/or which
are owned and managed by the city. The golf course department shall be
supervised and directed by the golf professional, who shall be responsible for
all operations of his department.
   C.   Enid Park And Recreation Board: The city manager may refer golf course
department issues and policies to the Enid park and recreation board for their
consideration and review. Such board shall submit recommendations to the mayor
and board of commissioners concerning the golf course department.
   D.   Rules, Regulations And Fees: The mayor and board of commissioners shall
designate rules and regulations concerning the operation of the golf course,
which rules and regulations shall be on file with the city clerk. These rules
and regulations shall be followed in the management and operation of Meadowlake
Golf Course. The fees that are set out in section
2-6C-4 of this code shall be charged for the use of Meadowlake Golf Course.
(1994 Code § 2-61)
CHAPTER 10
PUBLIC RECORDS
SECTION:
1-10-1: Fees Imposed; Exceptions
1-10-2: Posting Of Fee Schedule
1-10-1: FEES IMPOSED; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Payment Of Fee; Exceptions: Persons desiring copies of ordinances and
other public records of the city shall pay to the director of finance the fee
provided for in section
2-6A-1 of this code. This chapter shall not apply to:
      1.   Complete copies of this code;
      2.   Copies of chapters or similar parts of this code which have been
prepared in booklet form;
      3.   Ordinances which have been prepared in booklet form, provided
another fee has been established for same.
   B.   Search Fee:
      1.   If the request for copies of public records is solely for commercial
purposes or clearly would cause excessive disruption of the public body's
essential functions, then the fee provided in subsection 2-6A-1B of this code
will be charged and paid to recover the direct cost of document search.
      2.   In no case shall a search fee be charged when the release of said
documents is in the public interest, including, but not limited to, release to
the news media, scholars, authors and taxpayers seeking to determine whether
those entrusted with the affairs of the government are honestly, faithfully and
competently performing their duties as public servants. (1994 Code § 2-10)
1-10-2: POSTING OF FEE SCHEDULE:
The city clerk shall post a copy of the fee schedule on the public bulletin
board in the administration building and with the county clerk. (1994 Code § 2-
10)

Notes
1 1. See also sections A.6.1 through A.6.6 of the city charter.
2 2. State law reference - municipal courts generally, 11 OS § 27-101 et seq.
1-11-1: SCOPE:
This chapter shall govern the organization and operation of the municipal
court, not of record, of the city of Enid, as put into operation by resolution
of the city, as authorized by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 27-102. (Ord. 2011-
10, 7-19-2011)
1-11-2: JURISDICTION 1 :
   A.   The municipal court shall have original jurisdiction over both adults
and juveniles to hear and determine all prosecutions wherein a violation of any
ordinance of the city is charged.
   B.   The municipal court shall have no authority to enforce any ordinance
making unlawful an act or omission declared by state statute to be punishable
as a felony; in addition, a municipal ordinance may not impose a penalty
greater than that established by statute for the same offense. (Ord. 2013-16,
3-5-2013)
 
Notes
  3. State law references - general jurisdiction in municipal court, 11 OS § 27-
1 103; no jurisdiction to punish act punishable as felony under statute or impose
  penalty greater than statute for same offense, 11 OS § 14-111C.
1-11-3: GENERAL PROCEDURE:
   A.   Commencement Of Prosecution: Prosecutions shall be commenced in the
municipal court by verified complaint or by verified citation 1 .
   B.   Conflicts And Change Of Venue 2 : No change of venue shall be allowed
from the municipal court. However, should a conflict of interest arise, the
judge shall transfer the cause to another judge of the municipal court.
   C.   City Attorney As Prosecutor 3 : The city attorney or his/her designee
shall be the prosecutor of the municipal court, and shall have full power to
prosecute the violation of any ordinance of the city of Enid in the municipal
court and shall have the power to prosecute and resist appeals and proceedings
in error and review from the municipal court.
   D.   Entry Of Appearance By Counsel: Attorneys who wish to represent a
defendant in the municipal court shall file a written entry of appearance. The
entry shall include the case number, the name and signature of counsel, the
name of the party represented by counsel, the mailing address, telephone and
fax numbers and Oklahoma Bar Association number of the attorney, and the name
of the law firm, if any. A copy of the entry shall be served on the city
attorney.
   E.   Pleadings: A copy of every pleading filed shall be provided by the
filing party to opposing counsel upon filing. Each such pleading shall bear a
certificate of mailing or delivery showing the mode of delivery and the date
sent or delivered.
   F.   Arraignments: An arraignment may be continued or rescheduled by the
court, or the Court Clerk if directed by the court; provided, however, unless
the defendant waives arraignment, the court shall require an arraignment to be
had within a reasonable time after arrest. It shall remain the duty of the
defendant to appear for arraignment unless the citation is satisfied as
provided for in subsection H of this section.
   G.   Interpreter Services: The defendant must notify the court of the need
for interpreter services at least ten (10) days prior to the date the defendant
is scheduled to appear in court. The Municipal Judge shall determine, at the
time of the court appearance, whether or not the defendant is indigent. If the
defendant is not found to be indigent, the actual cost for interpreter services
shall become part of the court costs payable by the defendant. The defendant
may provide his/her own interpreter.
   H.   Payment Of Fine In Lieu Of Appearance: A defendant released upon
personal recognizance may elect to enter a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to
the violation charged at any time before he is required to appear for
arraignment by indicating such plea on the copy of the citation furnished to
him or on a legible copy thereof, together with the date of the plea and his
signature. The defendant shall be responsible for satisfying full payment of
the fine, court costs and fees to the Court Clerk. Payment may be made by
personal, cashier's, traveler's, certified or guaranteed bank check, postal or
commercial money order, or other form of payment approved by the court.
Provided, however, the defendant shall not use currency for payment by mail. If
the defendant has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere as provided for
in this subsection, such plea shall be accepted by the court and the amount of
the fine, court costs and fees shall be as prescribed by Municipal ordinance
for the violation charged. (Ord. 2011-10, 7-19-2011)
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - 11 OS §§ 27-115 and 27-115.1.
2 2. State law reference - 11 OS § 27-105.
3 3. State law reference - 11 OS § 27-108.
1-11-4: MUNICIPAL JUDGES:
   A.   Number And Terms: There shall be one Presiding Municipal Judge and one
Assistant Municipal Judge of the Municipal Court. Their terms shall be two (2)
years, expiring in January in each even numbered year, and thereafter until
they are replaced.
   B.   Duties And Powers:
      1.   In addition to his regular duties as a Municipal Judge, the
Presiding Judge shall:
         a.   Assign cases among the Judges as he deems best.
         b.   Assign duties to the Assistant Municipal Judge in case of his
absence or inability to preside.
         c.   Promulgate uniform rules of court procedure.
         d.   Perform such other acts as required to execute the ordinances and
resolutions of the City, Charter and Statutes of the State of Oklahoma.
      2.   The Municipal Judges shall have power to issue warrants of arrest
upon the filing of written verified complaints. The Municipal Judges shall have
power to issue alias warrants at their discretion, shall issue subpoenas for
all whose testimony may be deemed material as witnesses upon the trial, and
shall enforce the attendance of witnesses, if necessary. The Municipal Judges
shall also have power to administer oaths; and to enforce due obedience to all
orders, rules and judgments made by him.
   C.   Acting Judge: If both the Presiding Judge of the Municipal Court and
the Assistant Municipal Judge are unable to preside over a case, the Mayor may
appoint an Acting Judge as provided for under 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 27-
106. The compensation for the Acting Judge shall be two hundred dollars
($200.00) per hour. (Ord. 2017-29, 12-19-2017)
1-11-5: POWER TO TRY MINORS 1 :
The Municipal Court shall have power to try minors for violations of all City
ordinances, including, but not limited to, driving under the influence of
alcohol or drugs, and as otherwise set forth by State law. (Ord. 2011-10, 7-19-
2011)
 
Notes
1 1. 10A OS § 2-2-103.
1-11-6: CLERK OF MUNICIPAL COURT 1 :
   A.   Monies Paid To Director Of Finance: The Clerk of the Municipal Court
shall pay to the Director of Finance at least on the first and the fifteenth
days of each month all monies so received by him, except such special deposits
or fees to be disbursed by him for special purposes. All monies paid to the
Director of Finance shall be placed in the General Fund of the City, or in such
other fund as the Mayor and Board of Commissioners may direct, and it shall be
used in the operation of the Municipal government in accordance with budgetary
arrangements governing the fund in which it is placed.
   B.   Bond Of Clerk: The Clerk shall give bond as required by law in the sum
of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). (Ord. 2011-10, 7-19-2011)
 
Notes
1 2. 11 OS § 27-109.
1-11-7: VIOLATIONS BUREAU; COMPROMISING VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Bureau Established; Fines Imposed: A Violations Bureau is hereby
established as a division of the Office of the Clerk of the Court, to be
administered by the Clerk, or by subordinates designated by him/her for that
purpose. Persons who are cited for a violation of any offense which carries a
fine of less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) may, prior to the date set for
appearance in court, elect to pay the prescribed fine and all applicable costs
and fees at the Office of the City Clerk in lieu of appearing in court.
   B.   Court Costs And Fees: The Violations Bureau shall collect court costs
and fees, as outlined in section
1-11-8 of this chapter, in every case in which the defendant pleads guilty or
nolo contendere before the Violations Bureau.
   C.   Final Determination: Payment of a fine under this section shall
constitute a final determination of the cause against the defendant. (Ord.
2011-10, 7-19-2011)
1-11-8: COSTS AND FEES 1 :
   A.   Court costs in the amount of thirty dollars ($30.00) plus the fees and
mileage of jurors and witnesses shall be charged and collected by the Clerk of
the Municipal Court in all cases other than those in which the defendant is
acquitted or found not guilty or those which are dismissed upon motion of the
defendant or the City Attorney.
   B.   The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00) for
the initial filing of any bond for the subsequent court appearance of a
defendant, which shall be assessed as an additional court cost to the
defendant. The Court Clerk shall remit funds to a fund of the City that shall
be used to defray the costs of housing Municipal prisoners.
   C.   The Court Clerk shall charge a fee of five dollars ($5.00), which shall
be in addition to and not in substitute for any and all fines and penalties
provided for by this section or Code, upon conviction of any offense, including
traffic offenses, but excluding parking violations. "Conviction", for purposes
of this section, shall mean any final adjudication of guilt and includes any
deferred or suspended sentence. The Court Clerk shall remit funds to a fund of
the City that shall be used to defray the costs of the court's technology.
   D.   The Court Clerk shall assess all required court fees as required by
State law in the manner prescribed by State law. These required State mandated
fees shall be enumerated in the State of Oklahoma Mandated Municipal Court Fees
List which shall be posted at City Hall and be available free of charge at the
City Clerk's Office.
   E.   When a deferred sentence is imposed, the Court Clerk shall charge an
administrative fee of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00), as directed by the
court, in addition to any deferral fee otherwise authorized by law. (Ord. 2017-
21, 9-19-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS § 27-126; 28 OS § 153.3; 20 OS §§ 1313.2 - 1313.4.
1-11-9: ISSUANCE OF SUMMONS AND WARRANT 1 :
   A.   Issuance And Contents Of Summons: Upon the filing of a complaint
charging violation of an ordinance, the Judge, unless he determines to issue a
warrant of arrest, or unless the defendant previously has been issued a
citation or has been arrested and has given bond for appearance, shall issue a
summons, naming the person charged, specifying his address or place of
residence, if known, stating the offense with which he is charged and giving
him notice to answer the charge in the court on a day certain, containing a
provision for the official return of the summons, and including such other
pertinent information as may be necessary.
   B.   Failure To Appear; Issuance Of Warrant: The summons shall be served by
delivering a copy to the defendant personally. If he fails to appear to answer
the summons within the prescribed period, a warrant shall be issued for his
arrest.
   C.   Search Warrant; Arrest Of Individual: Upon proper application, the
Judge is hereby authorized to issue a search warrant if he is satisfied of the
existence of grounds of the application or if there is probable cause to
believe their existence. Such warrant shall be signed by the Judge with his
name of office to the Police Chief, commanding him forthwith to search the
person or place named, for the property specified, and to bring it before the
Magistrate, and also to arrest the person in whose possession the same may be
found, to be dealt with according to law. (Ord. 2011-10, 7-19-2011)
 
Notes
1 2. 11 OS § 27-115.
1-11-10: BAIL BOND PROCEDURE:
   A.   Conditions For Release For Violation: In addition to other provisions
of law for posting bail, any person, whether a resident of this State or a
nonresident, who is arrested by a law enforcement officer solely for a
misdemeanor violation of a Municipal ordinance shall be released by the
arresting officer upon personal recognizance if:
      1.   The arrested person has been issued a valid license to operate a
motor vehicle by Oklahoma, another state jurisdiction within the United States
which is a participant in the nonresident violator compact, or any party
jurisdiction of the nonresident violator compact; or if the arrested person is
charged with an offense that is not a traffic offense and has been issued an
Oklahoma identification card or a United States military identification card;
      2.   The arresting officer is satisfied as to the identity of the
arrested person;
      3.   The arrested person signs a written promise to appear as provided
for on the citation and the officer believes the person will appear;
      4.   The officer believes the person will not cause injury to himself or
others or damage to property if released; and
      5.   The violation does not constitute:
         a.   Driving or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle
while impaired or under the influence of alcohol or other intoxicating
substances; or
         b.   Eluding or attempting to elude a law enforcement officer; or
         c.   Operating a motor vehicle without having been issued a valid
driver's license, or while the license is under suspension, revocation, denial
or cancellation; or
         d.   An arrest based upon an outstanding warrant; or
         e.   An offense against a person as found in title 5, chapter 5,
articles B and C of this Code; or
         f.   A traffic violation coupled with any offense stated in
subsections A5a through A5d of this section.
   B.   Court Appearance: If any person is charged with an offense that carries
jail time they must appear before the court.
   C.   Duties Of Arresting Officer Upon Release Of Arrested Person:
      1.   If the arrested person is eligible for release on personal
recognizance as provided for in subsection A of this section, then the
arresting officer shall:
         a.   Designate the charge;
         b.   Record information from the arrested person's driver's license on
the citation form, including the name, address, date of birth, personal
description, type of driver's license, driver's license number, issuing state,
and expiration date;
         c.   Record the motor vehicle make, model and tag information, if a
vehicle is involved in the offense;
         d.   Record the arraignment date and time on the citation; and
         e.   Permit the arrested person to sign a written promise to appear as
provided for in the citation.
      2.   The arresting officer shall then release the person upon personal
recognizance based upon the signed promise to appear. The citation shall
contain a written notice to the arrested person that release upon personal
recognizance based upon a signed written promise to appear for arraignment is
conditional and that failure to timely appear for arraignment shall result in
the suspension of the arrested person's driver's license in Oklahoma, or in the
nonresident's home state pursuant to the nonresident violator compact.
   D.   Time Of Arraignment: If the arraignment is continued or rescheduled,
the arrested person shall remain on personal recognizance and written promise
to appear until such arraignment, in the same manner and with the same
consequences as if the continued or rescheduled arraignment was entered on the
citation by the arresting officer and signed by the defendant.
   E.   Issuance Of Warrant For Arrest:
      1.   Nontraffic Offenses: If an individual fails to appear after being
issued a citation, a warrant shall be issued and his appearance shall be
compelled.
      2.   Traffic Offenses; Notify State; Recommend Suspension Of Driver's
License:
         a.   If, pursuant to the provisions of subsection
1-11-3H of this chapter, the defendant does not timely elect to enter a plea of
guilty or nolo contendere and fails to timely appear for arraignment, the court
may issue a warrant for the arrest of the defendant. The Municipal Court Clerk,
within one hundred twenty (120) calendar days from the date the citation was
issued by the arresting officer, shall notify the Oklahoma Department of Public
Safety that:
            (1)   The defendant was issued a traffic citation and released upon
personal recognizance after signing a written promise to appear for arraignment
as provided for in the citation;
            (2)   The defendant has failed to appear for arraignment without
good cause shown;
            (3)   The defendant has not posted bail, paid a fine, or made any
other arrangement with the court to satisfy the citation; and
            (4)   The citation has not been satisfied as provided by law.
         b.   Additionally, the Court Clerk shall request the Oklahoma
Department of Public Safety to either suspend the defendant's driver's license
to operate a motor vehicle in this State, or notify the defendant's home state
and request suspension of the defendant's driver's license in accordance with
the provisions of the nonresident violator compact. Such notice and request
shall be on a form approved or furnished by the Department of Public Safety.
      3.   Notification And Request: The Court Clerk shall not process the
notification and request provided for in this subsection if, with respect to
such charges:
         a.   The defendant was arraigned, posted bail, paid a fine, was
jailed, or otherwise settled the case; or
         b.   The defendant was not released upon personal recognizance upon a
signed written promise to appear as provided for in this section; or if
released, was not permitted to remain on such personal recognizance for
arraignment; or
         c.   A period of one hundred twenty (120) calendar days or more has
elapsed from the date the citation was issued by the arresting officer.
   F.   Records; Notification Of Resolution Of Case: The Municipal Court Clerk
shall maintain a record of each request for driver's license suspension
submitted to the Oklahoma Department of Public Safety pursuant to the
provisions of this section. When the court or Court Clerk receives appropriate
bail or payment of the fine and costs, settles the citation, makes other
arrangements with the defendant, or otherwise closes the case, the Court Clerk
shall furnish proof thereof to such defendant, if the defendant personally
appears, or shall mail such proof by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the
defendant at the address noted on the citation or at such other address as is
furnished by the defendant. Additionally, the court or Court Clerk shall notify
the home jurisdiction of the defendant as listed on the citation, if such
jurisdiction is a member of the nonresident violator compact, and shall, in all
other cases, notify said department, of the resolution of the case. The form of
proof and the procedures for notification shall be approved by the Oklahoma
Department of Public Safety. (Ord. 2018-32, 11-20-2018)
1-11-11: EXCEPTIONS; WARRANT ISSUANCE; CUSTODY:
   A.   Issuance Of Warrant: If a person arrested for a violation is released
upon personal recognizance as provided for in section
1-11-10 of this chapter, but subsequently posts bail and thereafter fails to
timely appear as provided for by law, the court may issue a warrant for the
person's arrest and the case shall be processed pursuant to 11 Oklahoma
Statutes section 27-118.
   B.   Arraignment; Person Placed In Custody: If the defendant is not eligible
for release upon personal recognizance as provided for in section
1-11-10 of this chapter, or if eligible but refuses to sign a written promise
to appear, the officer shall deliver the person to the Judge for arraignment
and the Judge shall proceed as otherwise provided for by law. If no Judge is
available, the defendant shall be placed in the custody of the Garfield County
Detention Facility, to be held until a Judge is available or bail is posted.
   C.   Juveniles, Injured Or Disabled Persons:
      1.   Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a juvenile may be held
in custody pursuant to the provisions of this section, but shall be
incarcerated separately from any adult offender. Provided, however, the
arresting officer shall not be required to:
         a.   Place a juvenile into custody as provided for in this section; or
         b.   Place any other offender into custody:
            (1)   Who is injured, disabled, or otherwise incapacitated; or
            (2)   If custodial arrest may require impoundment of a vehicle
containing livestock, perishable cargo, or items requiring special maintenance
or care; or
            (3)   Where extraordinary circumstances exist that make custodial
arrest inappropriate in the judgment of the arresting officer.
      2.   In such cases, the arresting officer may designate the date and time
of arraignment on the citation and release the person. If the person fails to
appear without good cause shown, the court may issue a warrant for the person's
arrest. (Ord. 2011-10, 7-19-2011)
1-11-12: DISHONORED CHECKS OR INSTRUMENTS TENDERED FOR BAIL:
A personal check or other instrument tendered to the Municipal Court Clerk for
bail or for the payment of fine and costs, if dishonored and returned to said
Clerk for any reason other than the lack of proper endorsement, shall
constitute nonpayment of bail or fine, as the case may be, and the court, in
addition to any civil or criminal remedy otherwise provided for by law, may
issue a bench warrant for the arrest of the person named on the citation to
require his appearance on the charge specified. (Ord. 2011-10, 7-19-2011)
1-11-13: ARREST, CITATION AND BAIL 1 :
   A.   Ordinance Violations:
      1.   If a resident of the city of Enid is arrested by a law enforcement
officer, for the violation of any traffic ordinance for which section
1-11-10 of this chapter does not apply, or is arrested for the violation of a
nontraffic ordinance, the officer shall immediately release said person if the
person acknowledges receipt of a citation by signing it. Provided, however, the
arresting officer need not release said person if it reasonably appears to the
officer that the person may cause injury to himself or others or damage to
property if released, that the person will not appear in response to the
citation, or the person is arrested for an offense against a person or
property. If said person fails to appear in response to the citation, a warrant
shall be issued for his arrest and his appearance shall be compelled. If the
arrested resident is not released by being permitted to sign a citation as
herein provided, he shall be admitted to bail either before or after
arraignment, or shall be released on personal recognizance.
      2.   If a nonresident of the city of Enid is arrested by a law
enforcement officer for a violation of any ordinance for which section
1-11-10 of this chapter does not apply, the defendant shall be eligible to be
admitted to bail either before or after arraignment.
      3.   The amount and conditions of bail granted pursuant to the provisions
of subsections A1 and A2 of this section shall be determined by the judge who
shall prescribe rules for the receipt of bail and for the release on personal
recognizance. In the event of arrests at night, emergencies, or when the judge
is not available, a court official, the chief of police or his designated
representative may be authorized by the judge, subject to such conditions as
shall be prescribed by the judge, to accept a temporary cash bond in a
sufficient amount to secure the appearance of the accused. The cash bond shall
not exceed the maximum fine plus court costs for each offense charged. The
court official, chief of police or his designated representative is authorized,
subject to such conditions as shall be prescribed by the judge, to release a
resident of the city of Enid on personal recognizance.
      4.   If the alleged offense is a violation of an ordinance restricting or
regulating the parking of vehicles, including any regulations issued under such
ordinance, and the operator is not present, the police officer shall place on
the vehicle, at a place reasonably likely to come to the notice of the
operator, a citation in writing in form prescribed by the city. The operator of
the vehicle shall be under the same obligation to respond to the citation as if
it has been issued to him personally under subsection A1 of this section.
   B.   Nonpayment Of Fine And Costs:
      1.   If a defendant, upon conviction for a misdemeanor violation of a
municipal traffic offense or after having entered a plea of nolo contendere or
guilty to a misdemeanor violation of a municipal traffic offense, fails to pay
the fine, fees and/or costs, and has been found to have the ability to pay but
has refused to do so, the court or the court clerk, as directed by the court,
may issue a warrant for the arrest of the defendant or issue an order
committing the defendant to jail, and notify the Oklahoma department of public
safety that the defendant has failed to pay the fine and/or costs imposed.
      2.   Additionally, the court clerk shall request the Oklahoma department
of public safety to either suspend the defendant's driver's license to operate
