shall be recorded the time, place or origin, destination, and charges for each
trip to be made.
   G.   Response Time: Every ambulance service shall maintain an emergency
response time of eight (8) minutes fifty nine (59) seconds or less with a
ninety percent (90%) accuracy, calculated monthly. (Ord. 2015-09, 3-3-2015)
3-8-4: VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Vehicle Identification; Business Name On Vehicle: Each ambulance shall
be identified in such a manner as to indicate clearly that the vehicle is used
for ambulance purposes only. The ambulance service operator's business name
shall appear on each side and on the rear of the vehicle in letters of not less
than three inches (3") in height and one-half inch (1/2") in width on a metal
portion of the body. No advertising of any type shall be placed on the vehicle.
   B.   Maintain In Good Operating Condition: License holders shall maintain in
good operating condition and ready for use, all vehicles and equipment which
shall be modern and capable of rendering a satisfactory ambulance service. All
vehicles and equipment must be approved by the licensee's medical director and
shall meet or exceed the requirements as required for licensing by the state of
Oklahoma.
   C.   Inspection: All mechanical, safety and special equipment shall be
subject to inspection at any time by authorized officials. No ambulance that
has been substantially damaged or altered shall be again placed in service
until it has been reinspected. All ambulances shall be subject to the same
statutes and ordinances, and rules and regulations relating to safety and
operating equipment applicable to other motor vehicles in the city.
   D.   Police Department Authority: The police department may conduct vehicle
inspections of all approved ambulance services as often as in their judgment is
warranted to maintain adequate standards, and shall have the right to remove
any ambulance from operation for failure to maintain adequate mechanical
standards of equipment, or for failure to comply with any of the provisions of
this chapter or article A, B or C of this chapter.
   E.   Vehicle/Equipment Delay: Should an ambulance or equipment break down en
route to an emergency or while transporting a patient which results in a delay
of more than fifteen (15) minutes or a change in equipment in order to complete
the call, reporting of such delay shall be required. The report shall be
submitted to the office of the city clerk of the city of Enid within ten (10)
days of such event and shall outline the circumstances and the resolution of
the occurrence. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-5: INSURANCE:
   A.   Insurance Requirements: Every operator shall maintain in full force and
effect, at all times, the following insurance policies:
      1.   General Liability:
         a.   Bodily injury liability: Limits shall be carried in an amount not
less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any claim or to any claimant
who has more than one claim for loss arising out of a single accident or
occurrence; and not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to any
claimant for his claim for any other loss arising out of a single accident or
occurrence; and not less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for any
number of claims arising out of a single accident or occurrence.
         b.   Property damage liability: Limits shall be carried in an amount
not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any claim or to
any claimant who has more than one claim for loss arising out of a single
accident or occurrence; and not less than three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) to any claimant for his claim for any other loss arising out of a
single accident or occurrence; and not less than two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) for any number of claims arising out of a single accident or
occurrence.
      2.   Professional Liability:
         a.   Bodily injury liability: Limits shall be carried in an amount not
less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any claim or to any claimant
who has more than one claim for loss arising out of a single accident or
occurrence; and not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to any
claimant for his claim for any other loss arising out of a single accident or
occurrence; and not less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for any
number of claims arising out of a single accident or occurrence.
         b.   Property damage liability: Limits shall be carried in an amount
not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any claim or to
any claimant who has more than one claim for loss arising out of a single
accident or occurrence; and not less than three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) to any claimant for his claim for any other loss arising out of a
single accident or occurrence; and not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) for any number of claims arising out of a single accident or
occurrence.
      3.   Automobile Liability:
         a.   Liability: Limits shall be carried in an amount of not less than
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to any claimant who has more than one claim
for loss arising out of a single accident or occurrence; and not less than one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to any claimant for his claim for any other
loss arising out of a single accident or occurrence; and not less than one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any number of claims arising out of a
single accident or occurrence.
         b.   Comprehensive and collision loss: Limits shall be carried in an
amount of not less than actual cash value with deductibles of not more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per vehicle.
         c.   Medical payments: Limits shall be carried in an amount of not
less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to any claimant who has
more than one claim for loss arising out of a single accident or occurrence;
and not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) to any claimant
for his claim for any other loss arising out of a single accident or
occurrence.
      4.   Workers' Compensation: Limits shall be carried in an amount not less
than the amount prescribed by the laws of the state of Oklahoma.
      5.   Contractual Liability: If the ambulance service operates a
subscription program, limits shall be carried in an amount not less than the
actual amount collected from the sale of such subscriptions.
      6.   Umbrella: An additional one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) umbrella
policy must be provided.
   B.   Carriers: The insurance policies shall be executed by an insurance or
indemnity carrier authorized to do business in the state of Oklahoma.
   C.   Notice Of Cancellation: All such certificates of insurance shall
provide for a thirty (30) day cancellation notice to the city clerk.
   D.   Proof Of Insurance: The operator shall submit to the city clerk
annually, or upon any change in insurance, certificates of insurance. (Ord.
2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-6: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Schedule Of Rates; Notify City Of Rate Change: Every person authorized
under this chapter to operate one or more ambulances shall file with the
finance department a schedule of the cash rates which will be charged for the
transportation of persons in ambulances; notice of any change in such cash
rates shall be given to the mayor and board of commissioners in writing at
least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such change. (Ord. 2015-
06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-7: PERSONNEL STAFFING:
   A.   Emergency Calls:
      1.   Driver: Each ambulance shall have a driver who shall assist in
attending to a patient and/or preparing an ambulance patient for transport. The
driver shall not also be the attendant.
      2.   Attendant: Each ambulance shall have, in addition to its driver, an
EMT/paramedic attendant who shall attend to the patient and shall remain with
the ambulance patient being transported.
   B.   Nonemergency/Transport Calls:
      1.   Driver: Each ambulance shall have a driver who shall assist in
attending to a patient and/or preparing an ambulance patient for transport. The
driver shall not also be the attendant.
      2.   Attendant: Each ambulance shall have, in addition to its driver, an
attendant who shall attend to the patient and shall remain with the ambulance
patient being transported.
   C.   Dispatcher: Every operator shall, at all times, have stationed at his
central place of business, a person who shall be required to promptly answer
all calls for service, promptly dispatch ambulances, and be generally
responsible for the conduct of the ambulance service. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-8: 911 DISPATCHING PROCEDURE:
   A.   More Than One Licensee; Preference: When the dispatcher receives an
emergency call for an ambulance, he shall authorize and dispatch an approved
ambulance service. If there is more than one ambulance service, the police
dispatcher shall use the call distribution method approved by resolution of the
mayor and board of commissioners. If there is more than one licensed ambulance
service and the caller prefers to use a particular ambulance service, the
police dispatcher shall authorize and dispatch that ambulance service.
   B.   Private Sick Call: If an ambulance service operator receives a private
sick call which is of an emergency nature and desires to answer such call as an
emergency call, the operator shall report to the police dispatcher such call.
The police dispatcher shall then clear such ambulance service to answer such
private sick call. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-9: USE OF EMERGENCY WARNING DEVICES:
   A.   Use Of Red Lights And Siren: An ambulance may respond, after receiving
a call from a private citizen, or from the city, state or county dispatcher, to
a call using red lights and siren.
   B.   Emergencies: After an ambulance has responded to a call and arrived at
the point of pick up, no ambulance shall proceed to the hospital or other
destination with the use of such emergency warning equipment, except in the
case of emergency. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-10: CENTRAL PLACE OF BUSINESS; TELEPHONE NUMBER:
Each operator shall maintain a central place of business within the city limits
of Enid, at which place he shall provide a properly listed telephone for
receiving all calls for ambulance service. Every operator shall keep on file
with the city of Enid the business address and telephone number where the
operator may be reached at all times. The operator shall keep the business
records and daily manifests required by this chapter at the central place of
business where all such records and manifests shall be readily accessible for
examination by the finance department, the mayor and board of commissioners, or
their authorized agents.
   A.   Daily Manifests: Every operator shall retain and preserve all daily
manifests for at least six (6) months.
   B.   Business Records: Every operator shall keep accurate records of
receipts from operations, and such other operating information as may be
required by the mayor and board of commissioners. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-11: TERMINATION OF SERVICE:
If an operator determines that termination of service is necessary, the
operator shall give ninety (90) days' written notice to the city clerk and
shall be required to continue to furnish the service authorized by the license
until:
   A.   All prepaid ambulance service contracts have expired; or
   B.   The operator shows proof to the city clerk that a pro rata part of the
premium for prepaid ambulance service contracts has been returned to the
customer(s). (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8-12: AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH A SOLE PROVIDER SYSTEM:
To safeguard the public health and well being and facilitate the prompt
dispatch of appropriately equipped and staffed ambulances when needed to
protect life and health, the mayor and board of commissioners may, pursuant to
63 Oklahoma Statutes section 1-2515, after competitive bidding, establish a
sole provider system for stretcher aid van and/or ambulance service transports.
(Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
CHAPTER 8
AMBULANCES
ARTICLE A.  AMBULANCE SERVICE BUSINESS LICENSE
SECTION:
3-8A-1: License Required; Eligibility
3-8A-2: Application Form; Contents; Fee
3-8A-3: Investigation
3-8A-4: Public Hearing
3-8A-5: Issuance
3-8A-6: Expiration; Renewal And Late Fees
3-8A-7: Prohibited Conduct
3-8A-8: Suspension; Revocation
3-8A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; ELIGIBILITY:
   A.   License Required:
      1.   Requirement: No person shall operate any ambulance service within
the city without first obtaining an ambulance business license issued pursuant
to the provisions of this article.
      2.   Exception: The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
         a.   An ambulance picking up a patient on sick calls only in the city,
and delivering the patient to a destination outside the city, nor shall it
apply to an ambulance picking up a patient outside the city and delivering the
patient to a destination within the city.
         b.   An ambulance rendering assistance during any catastrophe or major
emergency when the licensee(s) authorized to operate in the city are
insufficient in number or inadequate during such catastrophe or major
emergency, as determined by the city manager or his designee.
         c.   Any ambulance operating within the city solely for the purpose of
a drill or training exercise.
         d.   Any ambulance rendering requested assistance to a licensed
ambulance service in cases of disaster or major emergency pursuant to
provisions of a "mutual aid agreement" approved by the city commission.
   B.   Eligibility: Applicants must, at a minimum, be:
      1.   Licensed as an ambulance service by the state of Oklahoma at the
paramedic life support level of care.
      2.   Financially able to render safe and comfortable transportation of
patients.
      3.   Financially able to maintain and/or replace vehicles and equipment
as needed.
      4.   Of good moral character and have a reputation as a law abiding
citizen. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8A-2: APPLICATION FORM; CONTENTS; FEE:
Every application for a license shall be in writing, signed and sworn to by the
applicant, and shall be filed with the city clerk. The application shall be on
a form provided by the city clerk and shall contain the following:
   A.   If the applicant is an individual, the name, age and address of the
applicant; if a partnership, the business name of the partnership and the name,
age and address of each partner; if a corporation, the names and addresses of
its principal officers and the names and addresses of all directors thereof.
   B.   Whether the applicant has previously been licensed as an ambulance
service, and if so, when and by what state or city and whether such license or
registration has been revoked or suspended, and if so, the date of and reason
for such revocation or suspension.
   C.   The names under which the applicant has engaged, does engage and
proposes to engage in ambulance service.
   D.   The class of transportation service which the applicant desires to
furnish; number of vehicles; a brief description of the kind and type of
vehicle; passenger capacity of the vehicle; arrangement; and size and gross
weight thereof; model, vehicle identification number, and state license number.
   E.   The names and qualifications of each attendant, driver or dispatcher
employed, or to be employed, in providing ambulance service.
   F.   A description of the applicant's training and orientation program for
attendants, drivers and dispatchers.
   G.   The names and addresses of at least three (3) residents of the city as
references. If the applicant provides service in any other jurisdiction, a
letter of reference from the chief executive officer or the highest elected
official of that jurisdiction regarding the applicant's qualifications and
service within the jurisdiction should be provided.
   H.   Copies of insurance policies, as required by section
3-8-5 of this chapter.
   I.   A list of the rates and charges as required by section
3-8-6 of this chapter.
   J.   The color(s) and design to be used on the exterior of the vehicle.
   K.   Applicant's current financial statement.
   L.   Proof that the ambulance service is licensed by the Oklahoma department
of health at the emergency medical services/paramedic level of service.
   M.   The address of the central place of business within the city limits of
Enid, as well as the location where vehicles, equipment and personnel will be
based within the city limits of Enid.
   N.   Ambulance license fee as set out in section
2-6B-4 of this code. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8A-3: INVESTIGATION:
Upon receipt of an application for a license, the mayor and board of
commissioners shall cause an investigation to be made of the character and
reputation of the applicant as a law abiding citizen and the ability of the
applicant to render safe and comfortable transportation service and to maintain
or replace the equipment for such service, the financial responsibility of the
applicant to maintain insurance for the payment of personal injury, death and
property damage claims, and other pertinent facts which the mayor and board of
commissioners may deem relevant in determining the fitness of the applicant to
assume the occupation of an operator. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8A-4: PUBLIC HEARING:
   A.   Public Hearing; Notice: Upon completion of its investigation, the mayor
and board of commissioners shall schedule a public hearing on the application.
The mayor and board of commissioners shall give to a license applicant and to
all current license holders, notice of any public hearing by the mayor and
board of commissioners affecting licenses at least ten (10) days prior to the
date of the public hearing, and such notice shall be furnished by certified
mail. At the time and place specified in the notice, the mayor and board of
commissioners shall accord all persons attending an opportunity to be heard.
Following the public hearing, or at a subsequent meeting called for such
purpose, the mayor and board of commissioners shall make its determination,
taking into consideration all matters brought to its attention regarding the
qualifications of the applicant, including, but not limited to, the business
reputation of the applicant, the financial responsibility of the applicant, the
number, kind, type, age and mileage of the vehicles to be operated by the
applicant, the cash rates proposed to be charged, whether the public is, at the
time, adequately served, the quality of ambulance service in Enid, and other
factors affecting the public convenience and necessity or that the mayor and
board of commissioners deem relevant.
   B.   Required Findings: Notwithstanding the foregoing, the mayor and board
of commissioners shall not cause a license to be issued unless it finds that:
1) the applicant meets the required qualifications and criteria; and 2) the
public convenience and necessity require the proposed emergency medical service
for which the application has been submitted; and 3) that the proposed service
would not adversely affect total emergency medical service to the people of the
city, the financial integrity of the system and the current provider, nor the
overall quality thereof. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8A-5: ISSUANCE:
The ambulance business license, if approved by the mayor and board of
commissioners, shall be issued by the city clerk. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8A-6: EXPIRATION; RENEWAL AND LATE FEES:
   A.   The ambulance business license is valid for one year and is
nontransferable. Operators may renew their licenses annually upon application
as set out in section
3-8A-2 of this article and payment of the fee set out in section
2-6B-4 of this code.
   B.   Operators shall be required to pay a late fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) per month plus the annual license fee to renew an expired ambulance
business license. Expired licenses may be renewed during the three (3) months
immediately following the expiration of said license.
   C.   Operators who have allowed their ambulance business license to expire
in excess of three (3) months will not be allowed to renew their license, but
shall be allowed to apply for a new ambulance business license. (Ord. 2015-06,
2-3-2015)
3-8A-7: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
Ambulance service shall not:
   A.   Fail or neglect to render the full service authorized by his license.
   B.   Employ an operator that has been convicted of a felony or any criminal
offense involving moral turpitude.
   C.   Obtain a license by an application in which any material fact was
omitted or stated falsely.
   D.   Permit its motor vehicle(s) to be operated in violation of any law.
   E.   Fail to comply with or wilfully or knowingly violate any of the
provisions of this chapter or article.
   F.   Give or allow a rebate, commission or any reduced rate discount not
provided for in the rates established and prescribed herein.
   G.   Induce or seek to induce a change or destination to or from a hospital
or other place specified by the person hiring the ambulance.
   H.   Employ any person who has been guilty of negligence in the operation of
its service.
   I.   Recommend or give favor or advantage to any hospital or mortuary
operating in the city.
   J.   Allow its insurance to be canceled, withdrawn or terminated.
   K.   Allow its vehicle or equipment to become damaged, deteriorated or
unclean to the extent that it is, in the judgment of the police department or
the mayor and board of commissioners, unfit for public use. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-
2015)
3-8A-8: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION:
   A.   Proceedings; Investigation; Notice: An ambulance business license may
be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or article.
Proceedings for revocation or suspension of a license shall be undertaken by
the mayor and board of commissioners in the same manner as proceedings for
issuance of a license. All complaints shall be referred to the mayor and board
of commissioners, who shall cause an investigation to be made. Prior to any
action for suspension or revocation of a license, the city clerk shall give ten
(10) days' notice thereof by certified mail to the operator holding the
license, that the same will be considered at the next regular meeting of the
mayor and board of commissioners, provided the date of such meeting shall not
be less than ten (10) days from the date of the notice. The mayor and board of
commissioners shall thereupon undertake to consider the complaint and either
revoke, suspend, or alter the license or dismiss the complaint. (Ord. 2015-06,
2-3-2015)
ARTICLE B.  AMBULANCE VEHICLE PERMITS
SECTION:
3-8B-1: Permit Required
3-8B-2: Application Form; Contents; Fee
3-8B-3: Inspection
3-8B-4: Issuance
3-8B-5: Expiration And Renewal
3-8B-6: Suspension; Revocation
3-8B-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   Requirement: No person shall use, drive, or operate any ambulance
within the city without first obtaining an ambulance vehicle permit for such
ambulance issued pursuant to the provisions of this article.
   B.   Exception: The provisions of subsection A of this section shall not
apply to an ambulance picking up a patient on sick calls only in the city, and
delivering the patient to a destination outside the city, nor shall it apply to
an ambulance picking up a patient outside the city and delivering the patient
to a destination within the city. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8B-2: APPLICATION FORM; CONTENTS; FEE:
Every application for an ambulance vehicle permit shall be in writing, signed
and sworn to by the applicant, and shall be filed with the city clerk. A
separate application shall be filed for each ambulance which may be operated in
the city. The application shall be on a form provided by the city clerk and
shall contain the following:
   A.   Name and address of the ambulance service.
   B.   Name and address of the operator.
   C.   License number of the vehicle.
   D.   Make, model and year of the vehicle.
   E.   Motor number.
   F.   Vehicle identification number.
   G.   Serial number.
   H.   State ambulance license number.
   I.   Passenger capacity.
   J.   Photo(s) of the vehicle.
   K.   Copies of insurance policies, as required by section
3-8-5 of this chapter.
   L.   Ambulance vehicle permit fee as set out in section
2-6B-4 of this code. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8B-3: INSPECTION:
   A.   All mechanical, safety and special equipment shall be subject to
inspection at any time by authorized officials. No ambulance that has been
substantially damaged or altered shall be again placed in service until it has
been reinspected. All ambulances shall be subject to the same statutes and
ordinances, and rules and regulations relating to safety and operating
equipment applicable to other motor vehicles in the city.
   B.   The police department may conduct vehicle inspections of all approved
ambulance services as often as in their judgment is warranted to maintain
adequate standards, and shall have the right to remove any ambulance from
operation for failure to maintain adequate mechanical standards of equipment,
or for failure to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter and this
article. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8B-4: ISSUANCE:
If the vehicle meets the minimum requirements of this chapter and article, the
city clerk shall issue the permit. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8B-5: EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL:
   A.   Ambulance vehicle permits are valid for one year and are
nontransferable. Operators may renew their ambulance vehicle permits annually
upon application as set out in section
3-8B-2 of this article and payment of the fee set out in section
2-6B-4 of this code.
   B.   Operators shall be required to pay a late fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
per month, or any part thereof, plus the annual permit fee to renew an expired
ambulance vehicle permit. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8B-6: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION:
If any motor vehicle for which a permit has been issued shall become unsafe for
operation, or if its body or interior facilities shall be so damaged,
deteriorated or unclean as to render the vehicle unfit for public use, the
permit therefor may be suspended until the vehicle shall be made safe for
operation and its body shall be repaired and painted, and its interior
facilities shall be reconditioned or replaced, as required by this chapter, or
if, in the opinion of the police chief, suspension of the permit will not
result in the vehicle being made fit for public use, the police chief may
revoke the permit. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
ARTICLE C.  DRIVERS AND ATTENDANTS
SECTION:
3-8C-1: License Required; Eligibility
3-8C-2: Application Form; Contents; Fee
3-8C-3: Investigation; Report Required
3-8C-4: Issuance Of License And Identification Card
3-8C-5: Expiration; Renewal; Late Fees
3-8C-6: Prohibited Conduct
3-8C-7: Suspension; Revocation
3-8C-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; ELIGIBILITY:
   A.   License Required:
      1.   Requirement: No person shall drive, manage, or control an ambulance
on any street in the city, or attend or render first aid to a passenger in such
ambulance without first obtaining a license issued pursuant to the provisions
of this article.
      2.   Exception: The provisions of subsection A1 of this section shall not
apply to an ambulance picking up a patient on sick calls only in the city, and
delivering the patient to a destination outside the city, nor shall it apply to
an ambulance picking up a patient outside the city and delivering the patient
to a destination within the city.
   B.   Eligibility:
      1.   Applicants for an ambulance driver license must, at a minimum:
         a.   Be licensed as an emergency medical technician/basic (or higher
level of care) by the state of Oklahoma.
         b.   Be of good moral character and have a reputation as a law abiding
citizen.
         c.   Have a valid Oklahoma driver's license appropriate for the
vehicle being driven.
         d.   Have successfully completed an emergency vehicle operator course
or refresher course approved by the Oklahoma department of health within the
last two (2) years.
         e.   Be able to speak, read, and write the English language.
         f.   Be at least eighteen (18) years of age.
         g.   Have a satisfactory criminal record, including no convictions of
felonies, offenses involving moral turpitude, offenses involving violence or
offenses involving the use or possession of or trafficking in any illegal drug.
      2.   Applicants for an attendant license must, at a minimum, be:
         a.   Licensed as an emergency medical technician/intermediate (or
higher level of care) by the state of Oklahoma.
         b.   Of good moral character and have a reputation as a law abiding
citizen.
         c.   Be able to speak, read, and write the English language.
         d.   Be at least eighteen (18) years of age.
         e.   Have a satisfactory criminal record, including no convictions of
felonies, offenses involving moral turpitude, offenses involving violence or
offenses involving the use or possession of or trafficking in any illegal drug.
(Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8C-2: APPLICATION FORM; CONTENTS; FEE:
Every application for a license shall be in writing, signed and sworn to by the
applicant, and shall be filed with the city clerk. The application shall be on
a form provided by the city clerk and shall contain the following:
   A.   Name, sex, age, and address of the applicant.
   B.   Name and address of employing ambulance service.
   C.   The names and addresses of at least three (3) residents of the city as
references.
   D.   Whether applicant has previously been licensed as an attendant or
driver, and if so, when and by what state or city, whether such license or
registration has been revoked or suspended, and if so, the date of and reason
for such revocation or suspension.
   E.   Information regarding criminal offenses and traffic violations,
including violation, date of violation, final disposition and jurisdiction.
   F.   Copy of Oklahoma driver's license.
   G.   If applicant will be an attendant, proof that applicant is licensed by
the state of Oklahoma as an emergency medical technician/intermediate (or
higher level of care).
   H.   If applicant will be a driver, proof that applicant is licensed by the
state of Oklahoma as an emergency medical technician/basic.
   I.   If applicant will be a driver, proof that applicant has successfully
completed an emergency vehicle operator course or refresher course approved by
the Oklahoma department of health within the last two (2) years.
   J.   Ambulance attendant or ambulance driver license fee as set out in
section
2-6B-4 of this code. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8C-3: INVESTIGATION; REPORT REQUIRED:
   A.   Investigation: Upon receipt of an application for a license, the mayor
and board of commissioners shall cause an investigation to be made of the
character and reputation of the applicant as a law abiding citizen.
   B.   Report Required; Fingerprinting: The character, reputation, and
pertinent knowledge of each applicant for registration as a driver or attendant
shall be investigated and a report of such investigation containing any facts
relevant to the character and reputation of the applicant shall be placed on
file with the police department. The fingerprints and photographs of each
applicant shall be obtained and placed on file with the police department.
(Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8C-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE AND IDENTIFICATION CARD:
   A.   Issuance; Form Of ID Card:
      1.   If the police chief finds the applicant for registration pursuant to
this article to be a fit and proper person to operate and drive an ambulance
according to the standards set forth in this article and in Oklahoma law, or to
attend to patients according to the standards set forth in this article and in
Oklahoma law, he shall so certify to the city clerk, who shall issue to the
applicant either an ambulance attendant's license or an ambulance driver's
license and a driver's identification card.
      2.   The identification card shall be of a form prescribed by the
director of finance and shall contain a picture of the driver affixed in such a
manner that another picture cannot be substituted therefor without detection,
the driver's name, license number, card number, and the expiration date of the
license. The card shall have a space on the reverse side for entering
violations and fines. The color of the license shall be changed each license
year.
   B.   Display Card In Vehicle: Every driver and attendant licensee under this
article shall display such card in his vehicle in such a manner as to be
readily visible at all times. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8C-5: EXPIRATION; RENEWAL; LATE FEES:
   A.   Ambulance attendant and ambulance driver licenses are valid for one
year and are nontransferable. Attendants and drivers may renew their licenses
annually upon application set out in section
3-8C-2 of this article and payment of the fee set out in section
2-6B-4 of this code.
   B.   Attendants and drivers shall be required to pay a late fee of ten
dollars ($10.00) per month, or any part thereof, plus the annual license fee to
renew an expired license. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8C-6: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
Attendants and drivers shall not:
   A.   Refuse, without good cause, to promptly transport or attend to any sick
or injured person after responding to a call.
   B.   Demand or receive compensation other than that established and
prescribed herein or fail to give a receipt for monies received.
   C.   Continue in employment after conviction of a felony or any criminal
offense involving moral turpitude, any criminal offense involving violence, or
any criminal offense involving the possession of or trafficking in illegal
drugs.
   D.   Obtain a license by an application in which any material fact was
omitted or stated falsely.
   E.   Operate an ambulance in violation of any law.
   F.   Fail to wear the appropriate uniform and to keep his/her person clean
and presentable when on duty.
   G.   Use abusive or obscene language, or fail to conduct him/herself in a
professional manner.
   H.   Release a patient until he/she is assured that some responsible person
is available to receive such patient.
   I.   Use a siren or flashing red light unless on an emergency call.
   J.   Disobey the lawful orders of a police officer.
   K.   Smoke while on duty.
   L.   Fail to comply with or wilfully or knowingly violate any of the
provisions of this chapter or article.
   M.   Give or allow a rebate, commission or any reduced rate discount not
provided for in the established rate.
   N.   Induce or seek to induce a change or destination to or from a hospital
or other place specified by the person hiring the ambulance.
   O.   Induce, or seek to induce, any person engaging an ambulance, to
patronize or retain the services of any hospital, convalescent home, doctor,
mortuary, cemetery, attorney, private accident investigator, nurse, or any
person that could benefit financially as a result of the inducement.
   P.   Act negligently in the operation of an ambulance or in the treatment of
a patient.
   Q.   Recommend or give favor or advantage to any hospital or mortuary
operating in the city.
   R.   Operate a vehicle or equipment which has become damaged, deteriorated
or unclean to the extent that it is, in the judgment of the police department,
the mayor and board of commissioners or the medical director, unfit for public
use.
   S.   Allow another to use his/her license or identification card.
   T.   Make or attempt to make any change or erasure to a license or
identification card. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
3-8C-7: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION:
   A.   Proceedings; Investigation; Notice: An ambulance attendant or ambulance
driver license may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or
article or upon a third traffic violation while operating an ambulance.
Proceedings for revocation or suspension of a license shall be undertaken by
the mayor and board of commissioners. All complaints shall be referred to the
mayor and board of commissioners, who shall cause an investigation to be made.
Prior to any action for suspension or revocation of a license, the city clerk
shall give ten (10) days' notice thereof by certified mail to the license
holder (and to his/her employer), that the same will be considered at the next
regular meeting of the mayor and board of commissioners, provided the date of
such meeting shall not be less than ten (10) days from the date of the notice.
The mayor and board of commissioners shall thereupon undertake to consider the
complaint and either revoke, suspend, or alter the license or dismiss the
complaint. (Ord. 2015-06, 2-3-2015)
CHAPTER 9
PUBLIC CONVEYANCE VEHICLES 1
SECTION:
3-9-0: Purpose
3-9-1: Definitions
3-9-2: Public Conveyance Permit Required
3-9-3: Application For License
3-9-4: License Fee
3-9-5: Transfer Of License
3-9-6: Display Of License
3-9-7: Liability Insurance
3-9-8: Indemnity Bond In Lieu Of Insurance
3-9-9: Issuance; Public Hearing On Convenience And Necessity
3-9-10: Vehicle Requirements
3-9-11: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - general authority to regulate taxicabs, 11 OS § 22-
  118.
3-9-0: PURPOSE:
The mayor and the board of commissioners find that it is in the best interest
of the city of Enid to provide the following rules and regulations for public
conveyance in order to promote the health, safety, and welfare of the people.
(Ord. 2009-24, 10-6-2009)
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
BUS: Means and includes any vehicle used in transporting and conveying
passengers for hire over a regular route in the city or from a particular
terminus or station to another terminus or station and having seating capacity
for not less than nine (9) adult persons in each vehicle.
CONVEYANCE: A means of transport.
FOR HIRE VEHICLES: Means and includes a vehicle that is available to the public
which provides transportation for passengers for a fee.
LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY: A city, state, or federal agency responsible for
enforcing laws.
MAJOR TRAFFIC VIOLATION: A moving traffic violation which endangers the health,
safety, and welfare of other drivers, pedestrians, or the general public.
MANIFEST: A daily record prepared by a public conveyance vehicle driver of all
trips made by the driver showing time and place of origin, destination, number
of passengers, and the amount of fare of each trip.
PUBLIC: Means and includes members of the community or surrounding communities.
PUBLIC CONVEYANCE VEHICLE: Means and includes bus, van, taxicab, and any other
vehicle that provides transportation for passengers and is available to the
public.
RATE CARD: A card for display in each public transportation vehicle which
contains the rates of fare then in force.
STREETS: Means and includes any street, alley, avenue, lane, court or public
place in the city.
TAXICAB: Any vehicle engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire
and not operated on a fixed route.
TAXIMETER: A meter instrument or device attached to a taxicab which accurately
measures the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based.
(Ord. 2009-24, 10-6-2009)
3-9-2: PUBLIC CONVEYANCE PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person, either as owner, principal, agent, employee, lessee or licensee,
shall operate or permit to be operated on upon the streets of the city of Enid
any public conveyance vehicle without first having procured a public conveyance
permit from the city of Enid and complying with the provisions of this chapter.
   A.   Exceptions:
      1.   Any vehicle owned and operated by the city of Enid.
      2.   Any vehicle owned and operated by the Enid public transportation
authority.
      3.   Any vehicle owned and operated by a public trust having the city of
Enid as its sole beneficiary.
      4.   Any vehicle owned and operated by a company operating under a state
or federal contract while it is actually being operated pursuant to such
contract. Proof that the vehicle is being operated under such contract shall be
provided upon request.
      5.   Any trip that originates from outside the boundaries of the city of
Enid, whether such trip is one way or round trip. (Ord. 2009-24, 10-6-2009)
3-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The written application for the license required by this chapter, verified by
the applicant or his duly authorized agent, shall be on a form provided by the
city and shall contain the following information, and such other necessary and
appropriate information as may be required:
   A.   Full name and address of the applicant, and his permanent business
location; if a partnership, the names and addresses of all the partners; if a
corporation, the names and addresses of the officers and directors.
   B.   A complete description of each public conveyance vehicle, including the
make, model, condition and year of construction, the length of time the public
conveyance vehicle has been in use, the current number of miles the public
conveyance vehicle has traveled, the number of years the applicant proposes to
keep the public conveyance vehicle in service and the prospective number of
miles that remain in the service life of the public conveyance vehicle.
   C.   The trade name under which applicant does or proposes to do business;
and the color or distinctive design of the body, if any, of each public
conveyance vehicle proposed to be used.
   D.   Whether or not the public conveyance vehicle is equipped with safety
glass in all doors, partitions, windows and windshield.
   E.   Whether or not property damage insurance and public liability insurance
in the amount established by section
3-9-7 of this chapter has been secured to cover each vehicle proposed to be
used.
   F.   A written statement of the rates proposed to be charged, showing
maximum rates by distance.
   G.   The applicant's estimates of proposed ridership and any other data
supporting the financial feasibility of the applicant's proposed rates and the
demand for public conveyance.
   H.   The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all
unpaid judgments against the applicant, and the nature of the transactions or
actions giving rise to the judgments.
   I.   The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers.
   J.   Any facts which the applicant believes tend to prove that public
convenience and necessity require the granting of a license. (1994 Code § 27.5-
32)
3-9-4: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Payment Of Fee: No license shall be issued pursuant to this chapter
until the applicant shall have paid to the city an annual fee in the amount
provided for in subsection 2-6B-13A of this code. The license renewal date
shall be the anniversary date of issuance.
   B.   Additional Fee; Nonrefundable: The license fee shall be in addition to
any fee required by the laws of the state. No refund shall be made for any
reason; and no license shall be issued at any time for a shorter period of time
than six (6) months. (1994 Code § 27.5-36)
3-9-5: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
No license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be sold, assigned, mortgaged,
or otherwise transferred by the person to whom issued, except with the approval
of the mayor and board of commissioners. (1994 Code § 27.5-37)
3-9-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
A license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be at all times, while the
public conveyance vehicle is being used or offered for use to be hired by the
public, kept in a conspicuous place in the public conveyance vehicle itself.
(1994 Code § 27.5-38)
3-9-7: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
   A.   Certificate Of Insurance Required; An applicant for the license
required by this chapter must file a certificate of insurance with the director
of finance. No certificate of convenience and necessity, franchise, license,
permit, or other privilege or authority shall be issued to or continued in any
person, which authorizes such person to engage in the business of operating
public conveyance vehicles unless such person first files with the director of
finance a certificate of an insurance carrier authorized to do business in the
state certifying that there is in effect a policy of liability insurance
insuring the owner and operator of the public conveyance vehicle business, his
agents, and employees while in the performance of their duties.
   B.   Insurance Amounts: The policy shall insure against loss from any
liability imposed by law for damages, including damages for care and loss of
service because of bodily injury to or death of any person and injury to or
destruction of property caused by accidents arising out of the ownership, use
or operation of such public conveyance vehicles. The minimum limits (exclusive
of interest and cost) with respect to each such public conveyance vehicle shall
be as follows: one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) because of bodily
injury to or death of one person, two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00)
because of bodily injury to or death of two (2) or more persons in any one
accident, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) because of injury to or
destruction of property of others in any one accident.
   C.   Liability Of Insurance Company: The policy shall provide that the
insurance company agrees to pay any final judgment for personal injuries,
including death resulting therefrom, or damages to property caused by any and
all motor vehicles operated by the insured, pursuant to the public conveyance
vehicle license issued by the city within the limits set forth in the policy.
The insurance company shall further agree that upon its failure to pay any
final judgment, the judgment creditors may maintain any action in any court of
competent jurisdiction to compel payment. Nothing contained in the policy or
any endorsement thereon, nor the violation of any of the provisions thereof by
the insured, shall relieve the company from liability hereunder or from the
payment of such judgment. The policy shall also provide that neither insolvency
nor bankruptcy of the insured shall relieve the insurance company from the
payment of any claim or judgment.
   D.   Notify City Of Cancellation: The policy shall provide that it may not
be cancelled until after ten (10) days' written notice to the director of
finance and that the cancellation of any policy shall in no way affect or
terminate any liability arising prior to the effective date of the
cancellation. If the owner or company fails within the ten (10) days to provide
another policy of like kind, then the license and all permits issued
thereunder, as provided for in this chapter, shall terminate and be of no
effect. (1994 Code § 27.5-33)
3-9-8: INDEMNITY BOND IN LIEU OF INSURANCE:
The mayor and board of commissioners may, in its discretion, allow a person
engaged in the public conveyance vehicle business, in lieu of a certificate of
insurance, to deposit and maintain throughout the term of the license, with the
director of finance, a bond with corporate surety which is authorized to do
business in the state. The bond shall run to the city and be conditioned as
provided in section
3-9-7 of this chapter for liability insurance for public conveyance vehicles.
All of the provisions required in a liability insurance policy shall be
contained in the bond. (1994 Code § 27.5-33.1)
3-9-9: ISSUANCE; PUBLIC HEARING ON CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY:
   A.   Hearing; Notice:
      1.   Upon the filing of the application for a license required by this
chapter with the director of finance, the matter of the hearing of said
application shall be brought before the mayor and board of commissioners within
a reasonable time thereafter, at which time the applicant shall show by proper
proof the convenience and necessity for such license.
      2.   Notice in writing at least seven (7) days prior to the date of such
hearing shall first be given to all persons engaged in the public conveyance
vehicle business and operating under a city license, by mail at their business
addresses on file in the city clerk's office, of the time and place of the
hearing, at which hearing they shall have an opportunity to be heard, as to the
necessity and convenience of another public conveyance vehicle service. Notice
of such hearing shall also be published in two (2) issues of the official
newspaper of the city before the hearing, and the applicant shall pay the cost
thereof in advance to the city.
   B.   Items Of Consideration: In determining the necessity and convenience
for such license, in addition to the application requirements set forth in
section
3-9-3 of this chapter, the mayor and board of commissioners shall take into
consideration:
      1.   Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require such
proposed or additional public conveyance vehicle service within the city.
      2.   The financial responsibility of the applicant and the likelihood of
the proposed service being permanent, responsible and satisfactory.
      3.   The number, kind, type and condition of equipment, including, but
not limited to, the year, make, model, and service life of the public
conveyance vehicle.
      4.   The schedule of rates proposed to be charged.
      5.   The number of public conveyance vehicles now operating in the city
and the increased traffic congestion and demand for increased parking space
upon the streets of the city which may result, and whether the safe use of the
streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved.
      6.   The character, experience and responsibility of the applicant.
      7.   Any such other relevant facts as the mayor and board of
commissioners may deem advisable and necessary.
   C.   Approval: If, at the time of the public hearing, there are no persons
currently engaged in the public conveyance vehicle business and operating under
a city license, the mayor and board of commissioners may approve licenses to
any qualified applicants proving and establishing that the demands of public
convenience and necessary require such proposed public conveyance vehicle
service.
   D.   Order For Issuance: If the mayor and board of commissioners determine
there is a necessity and convenience for such license pursuant to subsection B
of this section, an order shall be entered in the minutes to that effect and
directing that a license be issued to said applicant, upon the filing of an
approved bond or insurance hereinbefore described and upon the payment of the
required license fee. (1994 Code § 27.5-34)
3-9-10: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
No public conveyance vehicle shall be licensed unless it shall comply with the
following specifications and requirements:
   A.   Display Of Rate Card: Every public conveyance vehicle shall be equipped
with a frame for the proper display of the owner's fare rate card and the
driver's license card. The card relating to the fare to be charged shall be so
placed that it can be plainly seen by the passenger riding in such public
conveyance vehicle. It shall state clearly the rate of fare to be charged. If
the fare to be charged is based upon a mileage basis, it shall so state and
shall give the schedule of rates; if the fare to be charged is based upon the
carrying of passengers within certain locations, bounded by streets, it shall
so state, and shall state the rate to be charged for the carrying of passengers
through each district. The type used for the printing of the rates of fare
shall be of sufficient size so that it can be clearly read at a distance of
five feet (5').
   B.   Door Handle Inside Vehicle: Every public conveyance vehicle shall have
a knob or handle upon the side of the doors thereof, by which the doors may be
easily opened from the inside. (1994 Code § 27.5-35)
3-9-11: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Grounds For Suspension: A license issued pursuant to this chapter may
be suspended or revoked by the mayor and board of commissioners if the holder
has:
      1.   Violated any of the provisions of this chapter;
      2.   Discontinued operations for more than ten (10) days;
      3.   Violated any provisions of this code or the laws of the United
States or the state, the violation of which reflects unfavorably on the fitness
of the holder to offer public transportation;
      4.   Made any false or misleading statements or caused such to be made in
the application for or in connection with securing the issuance of the license;
      5.   Employed any driver not duly licensed with the city as a driver or
allowed any driver that does not have a current valid driver's license with the
state that allows the driver to drive public conveyance vehicles;
      6.   Violated, or if any of his operators have violated, the provisions
of section 3-9B-6A of this chapter.
   B.   Notice; Hearing: Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be
given ten (10) days' written notice of the proposed action to be taken and
shall have an opportunity to be heard before the mayor and board of
commissioners. (1994 Code § 27.5-39)
CHAPTER 9
PUBLIC CONVEYANCE VEHICLES
ARTICLE A.  OPERATIONAL RULES AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
3-9A-1: Rates And Charges Generally (Rep. by Ord. 2013-54, 12-3-2013)
3-9A-2: Ownership Of Equipment; Responsibility Of License Holder
3-9A-3: Vehicle Requirements; Inspection
3-9A-4: Identification Of Vehicles
3-9A-5: Taximeters
3-9A-6: Individual Service Required
3-9A-7: Receipts Rendered To Passengers
3-9A-8: Refusal Of Passenger To Pay Legal Fare
3-9A-9: Overall Service Required
3-9A-10: Manifests
3-9A-11: Records And Reports
3-9A-1: RATES AND CHARGES GENERALLY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2013-54, 12-3-2013)
3-9A-2: OWNERSHIP OF EQUIPMENT; RESPONSIBILITY OF LICENSE HOLDER:
Ownership of all public conveyance vehicles licensed under this chapter shall
be at the option of the holder of the license, and may be company owned, leased
or independently owned. The license holder, however, shall be responsible for
all public conveyance vehicles operating under its license, and any violation
by an operator of a public conveyance vehicle, whether company owned, leased or
independently owned, of a condition to be kept by the license holder shall be
deemed a violation by the license holder. (1994 Code § 27.5-52)
3-9A-3: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS; INSPECTION:
   A.   Inspection By City Central Garage: Prior to the use and operation of
any public conveyance vehicle under the provisions of this article, the public
conveyance vehicle shall be thoroughly examined and inspected by the city
central garage in accordance with the rules and regulations prescribed by this
section. When the inspecting officer finds that a public conveyance vehicle has
met the standards established herein, he shall so report such findings to the
director of finance.
   B.   Ensure Compliance: Every public conveyance vehicle operating under this
article must be inspected semiannually by the city central garage and at the
request of the police chief or his designee or after an accident where the
public conveyance vehicle was taken out of service. These inspections are to
ensure the continued maintenance of safe operating conditions. Upon such
inspection, if it is found that the public conveyance vehicle operating under
this article does not meet the requirements established herein, the chief of
police shall cause the public conveyance vehicle to be suspended from service
until such time as the public conveyance vehicle has been made to comply with
the standards of this article.
   C.   Repairs Following Accident: When any public conveyance vehicle licensed
under this article has been involved in a reportable accident, and if the
public conveyance vehicle is taken out of service, such public conveyance
vehicle shall not be put back into service until repaired. It is the primary
responsibility of the owner to make necessary repairs before the public
conveyance vehicle is returned to service.
   D.   Cleanliness; Good Condition: Every public conveyance vehicle licensed
under this article shall be kept clean and the upholstery shall be kept in good
repair.
   E.   Compliance With City Standards; Checklist: All vehicles to be licensed
and used as public conveyance vehicles shall meet the standards set out in the
city central garage's checklist which shall be available at the city clerk's
office. These standards may change periodically and the checklist will be so
revised. Any new checklists will be mailed to city licensees and will be
available in the city clerk's office thirty (30) days prior to the changes
becoming effective. (1994 Code § 27.5-52.1)
3-9A-4: IDENTIFICATION OF VEHICLES:
Every person owning and operating a public conveyance vehicle shall identify
each public conveyance vehicle by a distinct color scheme or other method of
painting or lettering which shall include a number assigned to each vehicle by
the license holder. The number shall be painted on each side and on the rear
exterior of each public conveyance vehicle. No other number, except the
assigned number, shall be painted on any public conveyance vehicle; provided,
however, that the telephone number of the public conveyance vehicle company may
be painted thereon. The name of the owner or the trade name under which he does
business shall be painted on each side of the public conveyance vehicle. The
said assigned number on the sides and rear of the public conveyance vehicle
shall be no less than four inches (4") in height. No other advertising or signs
shall be printed on, or carried on, the exterior of the public conveyance
vehicle, except upon the back or top of the public conveyance vehicle. (1994
Code § 27.5-53)
3-9A-5: TAXIMETERS:
   A.   Requirement: No person shall operate or permit a public conveyance
vehicle, except a bus owned or controlled by said person, to be operated as a
public conveyance vehicle upon the streets of the city if a rate other than a
flat rate is to be charged unless the public conveyance vehicle is equipped
with a taximeter for determining the fare for the use of the public conveyance
vehicle.
   B.   Visible To Passengers: Taximeter shall be fastened in front of and
visible to passengers at all times. After sundown, the face of the taximeter
shall be illuminated. The taximeter shall be calibrated to record the fare
accurately. The public conveyance vehicle driver shall not activate the meter
until the passenger has entered the public conveyance vehicle. The driver shall
deactivate the meter at the termination of each trip.
   C.   Inspection: The taximeter shall be subject to annual inspection by the
city garage, at the request of the police chief or by his designee, and after
an accident where the vehicle was taken out of service. The inspector is hereby
authorized, either on complaint of any person or without such complaint, to
inspect any meter and, upon discovery of any inaccuracy therein, to notify the
person operating the public conveyance vehicle to cease operation. The public
conveyance vehicle shall be kept off the streets until the taximeter is
repaired and in the required working condition and not be put back into service
until inspected and approved by the city central garage inspector. (1994 Code §
27.5-54)
3-9A-6: INDIVIDUAL SERVICE REQUIRED:
Individual service shall be accorded the person or persons first employing a
public conveyance vehicle, except a bus, at the rate of fare designated by the
rate card or schedule of rates posted in the public conveyance vehicle. No
driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in the public conveyance
vehicle unless the person or persons first employing the public conveyance
vehicle shall consent to the acceptance of additional passengers. (1994 Code §
27.5-55)
3-9A-7: RECEIPTS RENDERED TO PASSENGERS:
The driver of any public conveyance vehicle licensed under this chapter 9
shall, upon request by the passenger, render to the passenger a receipt for the
amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or a specially
prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the owner and the name and
identification number of the driver. (1994 Code § 27.5-56)
3-9A-8: REFUSAL OF PASSENGER TO PAY LEGAL FARE:
No person shall refuse to pay the legal fare of any of the public conveyance
vehicles mentioned in this article after having hired the public conveyance
vehicle. No person shall hire any such "public conveyance vehicle" defined in
section
3-9-1 of this chapter with the intent to defraud the person from whom it is
hired of the value of the service. (1994 Code § 27.5-57)
3-9A-9: OVERALL SERVICE REQUIRED:
   A.   Central Place Of Business; Dispatching Calls:
      1.   All persons engaged in the public conveyance vehicle business,
except the business of operating buses, in the city operating under the
provisions of this article shall render an overall service to the public
desiring to use public conveyance vehicles.
      2.   Holders of licenses shall maintain a central place of business which
is kept open twenty four (24) hours a day for the purpose of receiving calls
and dispatching public conveyance vehicles. They shall answer all calls
received by them for service inside the city as soon as they can do so, and if
the services cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall then
notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be
answered and give the reason therefor.
   B.   Failure To Accept Calls: Any license holder who refuses to accept a
call anywhere in the city at any time when said holder has available public
conveyance vehicles, or who shall fail or refuse to give overall service, shall
be deemed in violation of this article and the license granted to the holder
shall be revoked at the discretion of the mayor and board of commissioners.
   C.   Notice Of Intent To Reduce Hours; Hearing: If the license holder, for
any reason, believes that twenty four (24) hour service is infeasible, he shall
file with the director of finance a written notice of intent to reduce hours of
service. The notice shall state with specificity the hours to which the license
holder intends to reduce service and the reasons therefor. Within two (2) weeks
of the filing of such notice, the mayor and board of commissioners shall hold a
hearing to determine the public convenience and necessity of the proposed
reduction. Notice of the hearing, including the notice of intent to reduce
service, shall be published in two (2) issues of the official newspaper of the
city before the hearing and the applicant shall pay the cost thereof in advance
to the city. Service shall not be reduced except in accordance with a plan
approved by the mayor and board of commissioners. If the mayor and board of
commissioners finds that the public convenience and necessity will not be
adversely affected by a reduction in the hours of service, the hours of service
shall be reduced and the license holder shall provide such service; if the
mayor and board of commissioners finds that the public convenience and
necessity will be adversely affected, the license holder shall continue to
provide twenty four (24) hour service. Any subsequent failure to provide said
services shall be grounds for the revocation of the license. (1994 Code § 27.5-
58)
3-9A-10: MANIFESTS:
   A.   Recording Of Trips: Every public conveyance vehicle driver shall
maintain a daily manifest upon which is recorded all trips made each day,
showing time and place of origin and destination of the trip and amount of
fare. All completed manifests shall be returned to the owner by the driver at
the conclusion of his tour of duty. The forms for each manifest shall be
furnished to the driver by the owner and shall be of a character approved by
the director of finance.
   B.   Preserve Manifests: Every license holder shall preserve all public
conveyance vehicle drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least the calendar
year next preceding the current calendar year, and said manifests shall be
available to the director of finance and to the mayor and board of
commissioners at all times. (1994 Code § 27.5-59)
3-9A-11: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Records Of Receipts, Expenditures: Every license holder shall keep
accurate records of receipts from operations, operating and other expenses,
capital expenditures, and such other operating information as may be required
by the city.
   B.   Records Kept On Each Vehicle: Every license holder shall keep a
permanent record on every public conveyance vehicle, giving the exact time it
is in service, the name and license number of the driver in charge thereof, the
time and location of the public conveyance vehicle while out of the service,
and if the public conveyance vehicle is in the possession of any person other
than the licensee while not in service, the name and address of any such
person, together with the reason therefor.
   C.   Accessible For Examination By City: Every holder shall maintain the
records containing such information and other data required by this section at
a place readily accessible for examination by the city. (1994 Code § 27.5-60)
ARTICLE B.  DRIVERS' LICENSES
SECTION:
3-9B-1: License Required
3-9B-2: Application For License
3-9B-3: Investigation, Examination And Fingerprinting
3-9B-4: Fee, Term And Renewal
3-9B-5: Form Of License
3-9B-6: Revocation Of License
3-9B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall act as a driver of a public conveyance vehicle without a
driver's license issued by the city. (1994 Code § 27.5-76)
3-9B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for the license required by this article shall be made on such
forms as may be prescribed, and shall contain:
   A.   The name, date of birth, social security number, sex, weight, height,
color of eyes and hair of the applicant, his residence or address and length of
residence in the city and places of residence and employment during the past
three (3) years.
   B.   Whether or not the applicant is now or has been heretofore licensed as
a chauffeur or public conveyance vehicle driver and, if so, when and by what
state and whether such license has been revoked or suspended and the date of
any revocation or suspension.
   C.   The name of the person by whom applicant is employed.
   D.   The experience the applicant has had in driving public conveyance
vehicles.
   E.   Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or
misdemeanor with particulars of each conviction.
   F.   Two (2) recent photographs, not more than thirty (30) days old, of
himself; the photographs to be not less than two and one- fourth inches by
three inches (21/4" x 3"). One of the photographs shall be attached to the copy
of the application filed in the police department and one shall be attached to
the original application filed with the city. Such photographs shall be of full
view face type and shall be permanent prints made from negatives. Any
photographs not sufficient for identification purposes shall be rejected.
   G.   The applicant's driver's license number with the state of Oklahoma
which authorizes such person to drive a public conveyance vehicle. (1994 Code §
27.5-77; amd. 2003 Code)
3-9B-3: INVESTIGATION, EXAMINATION AND FINGERPRINTING:
   A.   Investigation; Past Actions Considered: The city shall cause an
investigation to be made of the facts set forth in the application for the
license required by this article and shall not approve the issuance of a
license to any person whose general reputation for integrity and
responsibility, or whose previous record as a law violator is such as to render
the applicant unfit for such occupation. If applicant has been convicted of a
misdemeanor or felony within the ten (10) years prior to the application which
involves violence, moral turpitude, drugs or alcohol related conduct involving
a motor vehicle, such applicant will be considered unfit for such occupation.
   B.   Denial Of License; Time Limit To Reapply: If the city finds the
applicant unfit by reason of his previous record as a law violator or by reason
of his general reputation for integrity or responsibility and disapproves of
the application, the applicant shall not be eligible to apply for a public
conveyance vehicle driver's license until six (6) months thereafter.
   C.   Fingerprinting: The city shall fingerprint every applicant, taking the
finger impressions on three (3) separate fingerprint cards and shall
immediately submit one set of fingerprint cards to the Oklahoma state bureau of
investigation and the federal bureau of investigation, with remaining sets
retained in the police files of the city.
   D.   Application: The application shall be submitted to the city in
triplicate. (Ord. 2005-23.5, 10-4-2005, eff. 12-1-2005)
3-9B-4: FEE, TERM AND RENEWAL:
   A.   Fee: Every driver who makes application for and obtains a license as a
driver of a public conveyance vehicle shall be required to pay the city the fee
established in subsection 2-6B-13C of this code.
   B.   License Term; Renewal: The license shall expire each year on the
anniversary date of its issuance. The driver shall be required to obtain a
public conveyance vehicle driver's license annually upon the payment of said
fee. An additional application and investigation shall be required for a
renewal public conveyance vehicle driver's license each year. A new set of
photographs not less than thirty (30) days old shall be furnished to the city
for each renewal of the public conveyance vehicle driver's license.
   C.   Fee Nonrefundable: No refund shall be made for any reason and no public
conveyance vehicle driver's license fee shall be prorated. (1994 Code § 27.5-
79)
3-9B-5: FORM OF LICENSE:
   A.   License Card Described: The public conveyance vehicle driver's license
shall be of a form prescribed by the city and shall contain a picture of the
public conveyance vehicle driver affixed in such a manner that another picture
cannot be substituted therefor without detection. The public conveyance vehicle
driver's name, license number and the expiration date of the public conveyance
vehicle driver's license shall be placed on said card, which card shall have
space on the reverse side for violations and offenses. The color of the license
card shall be changed each license year.
   B.   Display Of License: The public conveyance vehicle driver's license
shall be conspicuously displayed in the public conveyance vehicle so that the
entire public conveyance vehicle driver's license is visible from the rear seat
and the only public conveyance vehicle driver's license that is displayed shall
be the one belonging to the driver who is on duty at that time. The public
conveyance vehicle driver's license shall be enclosed in a frame with a glass
or a transparent front and shall be illuminated so as to be clearly discernible
to and readable by the passengers in the rear seat at any time.
   C.   License Nontransferable: No public conveyance vehicle driver's license
shall be transferable.
   D.   Lost License; Issuance Of Duplicate; Fee: In case of loss of a public
conveyance vehicle driver's license, and upon proper proof and showing thereof,
the city may issue, upon payment of the fee established in subsection 2-6B-13D
of this code a duplicate public conveyance vehicle driver's license plainly
marked "duplicate", which fact shall be certified to the police department.
(1994 Code § 27.5-80)
3-9B-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Grounds For Revocation: A public conveyance vehicle driver's license
shall be revoked by the chief of police for any of the following reasons:
      1.   For permitting any other persons to use his public conveyance
vehicle driver's license.
      2.   For obliterating or erasing any official entry on his public
conveyance vehicle driver's license.
      3.   For failure to maintain a valid driver's license with the state of
Oklahoma which qualifies the driver to drive a public conveyance vehicle.
      4.   Upon conviction of any of the following charges: a) driving while
impaired; b) driving under the influence; and c) reckless driving.
   B.   Seizure Of License; Reapplication:
      1.   Whenever a public conveyance vehicle driver's license is revoked,
the chief of police shall take up the public conveyance vehicle driver's
license and forward it to the city, together with a reason for such revocation.
      2.   No person whose public conveyance vehicle driver's license has been
revoked shall be able to obtain a public conveyance vehicle driver's license
until one year from the date of such revocation.
   C.   Right To Appeal: In case of the revocation of the public conveyance
vehicle driver's license, the driver shall have the right to appeal to the
mayor and board of commissioners whose decision thereon shall be final.
   D.   Supplementary Provisions: The provisions of this section are
supplementary to all other penalties. (1994 Code § 27.5-81)
ARTICLE C.  LIMOUSINES
SECTION:
3-9C-1: Definition
3-9C-2: Licensing And Other Requirements
3-9C-1: DEFINITION:
"Limousine" shall mean and include any vehicle classified as a limousine by the
factory producing such vehicle, which transports passengers for hire and whose
owner charges for such services based on the time the vehicle is rented and not
by a taximeter or the length of the trip. "Limousine service" does not include
service normally and customarily performed by a bus or taxicab. (1994 Code §
27.5-91)
3-9C-2: LICENSING AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Required; Fee: No person, either as owner, principal, agent,
employee, lessee or licensee, shall operate or permit to be operated upon the
streets of the city any limousine without first having procured a license from
the city and paid the fee as set out in subsection 2-6B-13E of this code.
   B.   Compliance With Requirements: Any person licensed pursuant to this
article shall comply with and fulfill the requirements of the following
sections as if fully set out:
   
3-9-3, application for license
   
3-9-5, transfer of license
   
3-9-6, display of license
   
3-9-7, liability insurance
   
3-9-11, suspension or revocation of license
   
3-9A-2, ownership of equipment, responsibility of license holder
   
3-9A-3, vehicle requirements, inspection
No person shall violate the subsections listed above.
   C.   Driver's License: No person shall act as a driver of a limousine
without a driver's license issued by the city. Limousine licenses shall comply
with and be regulated by the requirements of article B of this chapter.
   D.   License Issuance: Upon proper application and compliance with this
section, the city clerk shall issue the licenses required by this article.
(1994 Code § 27.5-92)
ARTICLE D.  AIRPORT SHUTTLE
SECTION:
3-9D-1: Service Created
3-9D-2: Airport Shuttle Fee
3-9D-1: SERVICE CREATED:
There is hereby created an airport shuttle service to transport persons to and
from Enid Woodring municipal airport. (1994 Code § 27.5-100)
3-9D-2: AIRPORT SHUTTLE FEE:
There is hereby fixed and established a fee for the use of the airport shuttle
in the amount provided for in subsection 2-6C-1C of this code. (1994 Code §
27.5-101)
CHAPTER 10
SALVAGE YARDS AND IMPOUND LOTS
SECTION:
3-10-1: Definitions
3-10-2: License Required; Fee; Compliance
3-10-3: Layout Plan
3-10-4: Fences And Walls
3-10-5: General Arrangement
3-10-6: Sales Office
3-10-7: Receiving Yard
3-10-8: Density Of Vehicles
3-10-9: Weeds And Rank Vegetation
3-10-10: Fire Road
3-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
IMPOUND LOT: Any yard, premises, or tract of land upon which impounded vehicles
are stored.
IMPOUNDED VEHICLES: Any vehicle which has been towed or otherwise moved to an
impound lot.
NONOPERATING VEHICLE: Any vehicle the certificate of title to which has been
canceled, or which has been wholly or partially dismantled or is kept for the
purpose of dismantling, selling, wrecking or using parts therefrom, or which is
in such a condition that it will not operate and is not intended to be made
operational as a motor vehicle.
SALVAGE: Any nonoperating motor vehicle or part thereof.
SALVAGE YARD: Any yard, premises, or tract of land in or upon which salvage is
stored or maintained, for business or commercial use or in connection
therewith. (Ord. 2015-14, 4-7-2015)
3-10-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; COMPLIANCE:
   A.   License Required: No person shall operate or maintain a salvage yard or
impound lot in the city without first obtaining a license therefor.
   B.   Fee; Compliance: The license shall be issued upon payment of a fee in
the amount provided in section
2-6B-16 of this code, and upon proper application being made showing compliance
with this chapter and the zoning ordinances of the city. (Ord. 2015-14, 4-7-
2015)
3-10-3: LAYOUT PLAN:
No person shall carry on, operate, own or maintain a salvage yard or impound
lot unless there has been filed with, and approved by, the code administration
department a salvage yard or impound lot layout plan showing:
   A.   The location and size of area involved.
   B.   All improvements of surrounding property lying within three hundred
feet (300') of the proposed salvage yard or impound lot.
   C.   The location and type of screening.
   D.   The location of storing area and sales office.
   E.   The location of curb cuts on property.
   F.   The general layout of access or fire roads within the salvage yard or
impound lot. (Ord. 2015-14, 4-7-2015)
3-10-4: FENCES AND WALLS:
No person shall carry on, operate, own, maintain, or conduct a salvage yard or
impound lot unless:
   A.   Conditions And Requirements: The establishment is carried on,
maintained or conducted entirely inside an enclosed building or buildings, or
upon premises with a fence that is at least six feet (6') high, of solid wood,
masonry or other opaque screening on the following sides or portions thereof:
      1.   Any side which adjoins or abuts a street or property zoned for
residential use. Property separated from the salvage yard or impound lot by
only a street, alley, easement or public way shall be considered as abutting or
adjoining said salvage yard or impound lot.
      2.   Any side to which there is an unrestricted view from any street.
      3.   That portion of a side not abutting or adjoining a street which is
within thirty feet (30') of any street, or property line abutting the street.
   B.   Maintenance: Fences and walls shall be maintained in a neat,
substantial, safe condition, without advertising thereon. (Ord. 2015-14, 4-7-
2015)
3-10-5: GENERAL ARRANGEMENT:
No person shall carry on, operate, own, maintain or conduct a salvage yard or
impound lot unless the salvage or impounded vehicles located in or on said
premises shall be so arranged that reasonable inspection or access on all parts
of the premises can be had at any time by the proper fire, health, police and
building officials. (Ord. 2015-14, 4-7-2015)
3-10-6: SALES OFFICE:
No person shall carry on, operate, own, maintain or conduct a salvage yard or
impound lot unless it is provided with a sales or office building on the
property to be used in conjunction with the operation. (Ord. 2015-14, 4-7-2015)
3-10-7: RECEIVING YARD:
No person shall carry on, operate, own, maintain or conduct a salvage yard or
impound lot unless it is provided with a receiving area for automobiles prior
to storing, which shall be maintained in a minimum size of one thousand eight
hundred (1,800) square feet per acre of salvage yard or impound lot. (Ord.
2015-14, 4-7-2015)
3-10-8: DENSITY OF VEHICLES:
No person shall carry on, operate, own, maintain or conduct a salvage yard or
