6-11-4: USE OF CRASH HELMET 1 :
No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall operate or ride upon any
motorcycle, motor driven cycle or motorized scooter unless such person is
wearing a crash helmet of a type which complies with standards established by
49 CFR section 571.218. (Ord. 2004-28, 9-7-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - 47 OS § 12-609.
6-11-5: RESTRICTION ON MOTORIZED SCOOTERS:
No person shall operate a motorized scooter on any roadway with a posted speed
limit of greater than twenty five (25) miles per hour. (Ord. 2004-28, 9-7-2004)
6-11-6: TRAFFIC LAWS APPLICABLE TO MOTORIZED SCOOTERS; EXCEPTIONS:
Every person riding a motorized scooter upon a roadway shall be granted all of
the rights and be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a
vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to
vehicles or by the traffic ordinances applicable to the driver of a vehicle,
except as to special regulations in this chapter and those provisions of laws
and ordinances which by their nature can have no application. (Ord. 2004-28, 9-
7-2004)
CHAPTER 12
VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT
SECTION:
6-12-1: Purpose
6-12-2: Authority To Impound
6-12-3: Arrest And Detention Of Driver
6-12-4: Impoundment Of Illegally Parked Vehicles
6-12-5: Recovered Stolen Vehicles
6-12-6: Vehicles Whose Owner Is Unascertainable
6-12-7: Place Of Impoundment
6-12-8: Duration Of Impoundment
6-12-9: Notification Of Owner
6-12-10: Payment Of Removal Costs And Storage
6-12-11: Right Of Redemption Of Vehicle
6-12-12: Release Of Vehicle To Other Than Registered Owner
6-12-13: Special Liens
6-12-1: PURPOSE:
The impoundment of vehicles under authority of the provisions of this chapter
shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for protection of the public
peace, safety, and welfare, and the safeguarding of property, and shall be used
generally for the prevention and removal of traffic hazards, prevention and
abatement of public nuisance arising from traffic law violations, protection of
the public rights in the use of city streets and thoroughfares from
obstructions placed and left in derogation of those rights, and for
safeguarding and protecting recovered stolen vehicles. (1994 Code § 20-96)
6-12-2: AUTHORITY TO IMPOUND:
Members of the police department are hereby authorized, within the limits set
forth in this chapter, to impound vehicles under the circumstances hereinafter
enumerated. No impoundment shall be valid unless made under order of an
authorized police officer and in strict adherence with the procedures required
in this chapter. (1994 Code § 20-97)
6-12-3: ARREST AND DETENTION OF DRIVER:
Whenever the driver or person in charge of any vehicle is placed under arrest
and taken into custody and detained by police under circumstances which leave,
or will leave, a vehicle unattended on any street or highway, alleyway, or any
public property, or on any private property designated for public use, or any
other private property without the property owner's consent, the vehicle may be
impounded. (1994 Code § 20-101)
6-12-4: IMPOUNDMENT OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   Fire Lane: Any vehicle found to be parked in any fire lane or other
access roadway as defined in the international fire code 1  may be impounded.
   B.   Disabled Vehicles: A disabled vehicle upon a street or highway may be
impounded under the following circumstances:
      1.   If left unattended and improperly parked on a street or highway;
      2.   If left unattended longer than forty eight (48) hours on the
shoulder of any highway;
      3.   If the person in charge of the vehicle is physically incapacitated
to such extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal.
   C.   Bridge: An unattended vehicle left upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway
or within the structure of a grade separation may be impounded.
   D.   Traffic Hazard Or Obstruction 2 : A vehicle left unattended upon any
street, alley or thoroughfare and so parked illegally as to constitute a
definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic shall be
impounded.
   E.   Road Construction Or Improvement Locations:
      1.   When the city plans to construct or improve any street, alley or
right of way upon which a car or cars are legally parked, the city shall
install a sign to be conspicuously posted at two (2) locations upon, at or near
such street, alley or right of way. Such notice shall state: "Street -
Construction - Improvement, All Vehicles Must Be Removed Immediately!" Such
notice shall be given at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the commencement
of any construction or improvement activities.
      2.   Any vehicle which remains upon any street, alley or right of way at
the commencement of any such construction or improvement activities shall be
determined to be parked illegally and shall constitute a traffic hazard, and
shall be impounded.
   F.   Derelict Vehicles:
      1.   When any derelict vehicle is discovered by the police department to
have been parked upon any street in the city for a period of seventy two (72)
hours, the police department is authorized to impound the vehicle, and if the
owner of the vehicle may be ascertained by reasonable diligence, the owner
shall be notified of the action by the police department.
      2.   When any derelict vehicle is discovered by the police department to
have been parked upon any airport property belonging to the city for a period
of forty eight (48) hours, the police department is authorized to impound the
vehicle, and if the owner of the vehicle may be ascertained by reasonable
diligence, the owner shall be notified of the action by the police department.
      3.   For the purposes of this chapter, a "derelict vehicle" shall be
defined as:
         a.   Abandoned;
         b.   Interfering with the normal flow of traffic;
         c.   Interfering with the use of private property;
         d.   Neglected; or
         e.   Inoperable.
   G.   Private Property:
      1.   An unattended vehicle found to be in violation of section
6-6-9 of this title may be impounded when the required complaint has been
properly made and filed as provided in this subsection.
      2.   If a violation of the provisions of section
6-6-9 of this title occurs, the owner or legal occupant who complains shall
sign a complaint against the person parking the vehicle on the owner's or legal
occupant's property, or if the identity of the person parking the vehicle is
unknown, then the complaint may be filed against the registered owner of the
vehicle. The complaint shall be verified and shall allege that the complaining
party is the owner or legal occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is
parked or standing.
      3.   Upon filing of the complaint by the property owner or legal
occupant, and if there appears to be proper cause to believe the provisions of
section
6-6-9 of this title have been violated, the police department shall cause the
vehicle to be impounded from the property and placed in storage.
   H.   Parked Over Water Meters:
      1.   Any vehicle parked in such a way as to obstruct ready access to a
city water meter shall be impounded after notice has been given.
      2.   Notice shall be given as follows:
         a.   Notice of the offense and one hour advance notice of impoundment
and an opportunity to move the vehicle shall be given to the owner or person in
charge of the illegally parked vehicle if such person is present.
         b.   If the vehicle owner or person in charge of the vehicle is not
present, notice of the offense and impoundment shall be left on the vehicle at
least twelve (12) hours in advance of impoundment.
   I.   Parked In/Upon Stormwater Drainage Facilities Or Easements:
      1.   Any vehicle parked in, over, or upon stormwater drainage facilities
or easements shall be impounded after notice has been given.
      2.   Notice shall be given as follows:
         a.   Notice of the offense and one hour advance notice of impoundment
and an opportunity to move the vehicle shall be given to the owner or person in
charge of the illegally parked vehicle if such person is present.
         b.   If the vehicle owner or person in charge of the vehicle is not
present, notice of the offense and impoundment shall be left on the vehicle at
least twelve (12) hours in advance of impoundment.
   J.   Prohibited Zone: Any unattended vehicle parked at the street curbing of
any zone where parking is prohibited and where official signs are in place
giving notice thereof in violation of the prohibition may be impounded.
   K.   Blocking Fire Exits Or Hydrants: Any vehicle illegally parked in such a
manner that it blocks a fire escape ladder, device or exit or blocks ready
access to a fire hydrant shall be impounded.
   L.   Intersection: Any unattended vehicle illegally parked in any street
intersection shall be impounded. A disabled vehicle in an intersection, with
the person in charge of the vehicle being present, shall be moved out of the
intersection and to the nearest available legal parking space at the street
curbing.
   M.   Handicapped Parking Spaces: Any vehicle parked in a parking space which
is clearly marked for handicap parking, whether on public or private property,
which vehicle does not have a clearly visible state or city authorized handicap
sticker may be impounded and the owner and/or operator may be cited for
violations pursuant to section
6-6-7 of this title. (Ord. 2015-20, 5-4-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 9, chapter 10 of this code.
2 2. State law reference - removal of vehicles constituting traffic obstruction
  authorized, 47 OS § 11-1002(b).
6-12-5: RECOVERED STOLEN VEHICLES:
   A.   Notice To Owner Of Place Of Retention: Whenever a stolen vehicle is
located by police and the registered owner cannot be found within a reasonable
time not exceeding one hour, or cannot be determined from the registration
papers or other identifying media in the vehicle or from records or information
available from reports of stolen cars, the vehicle may be removed to the
nearest authorized place for holding impounded vehicles and the registered
owner of the vehicle shall be notified of the location of the place for holding
impounded vehicles as soon as possible by the police department.
   B.   Removal By Owner Or Impoundment By City: If the registered owner is
identified, located and notified of the recovery of the stolen vehicle, the
owner shall be given the right to make his own arrangement for the removal of
the vehicle within the period of one hour from the time he is actually notified
of its recovery, and if the owner is unable or unwilling to effect the removal
within the time specified, the vehicle may be impounded. (1994 Code § 20-111)
6-12-6: VEHICLES WHOSE OWNER IS UNASCERTAINABLE:
Any vehicle may be impounded by the police if the owner is unascertainable at
the time and pursuant to other procedures set forth in this chapter. (1994 Code
§ 20-112)
6-12-7: PLACE OF IMPOUNDMENT:
Every vehicle that is impounded under the provisions of this chapter shall be
removed to the nearest garage or place of safekeeping designated by the mayor
and board of commissioners and to no other place. (1994 Code § 20-113)
6-12-8: DURATION OF IMPOUNDMENT:
   A.   Written Order For Release: Except as otherwise provided, any vehicle
impounded under the authority of this chapter shall be stored and held safely
until a written order for its release, signed by an authorized police officer,
has been issued.
   B.   Payment Of Impoundment Costs: The order of release shall be conditioned
upon the payment by the person to whom the release is issued of all impoundment
costs and accrued storage charges assessed against the vehicle.
   C.   Fines And Costs Paid In Full: No order of release of an impounded
vehicle shall be issued until all fines and costs due the city because of all
violations involving the vehicle have been paid. (1994 Code § 20-114)
6-12-9: NOTIFICATION OF OWNER:
The manager or authorized agent of the place holding impounded vehicles where
vehicle has been rightfully impounded shall promptly ascertain the name and
address of the owner of the vehicle and, if reasonably possible, notify him of
the vehicle location. (1994 Code § 20-115)
6-12-10: PAYMENT OF REMOVAL COSTS AND STORAGE:
The owner of a motor vehicle which is in violation of this chapter or the owner
of any vehicle which shall have been lawfully removed from any highway or other
public property may regain possession of the vehicle upon payment of the
reasonable cost of removal and storage of such vehicle. (1994 Code § 20-116)
6-12-11: RIGHT OF REDEMPTION OF VEHICLE:
Presentation of the order of release at the place of impoundment, together with
payment or tender of payment of all impoundment costs and accrued storage
charges due, shall entitle the person presenting the release to obtain
possession of the impounded vehicle. (1994 Code § 20-117)
6-12-12: RELEASE OF VEHICLE TO OTHER THAN REGISTERED OWNER:
   A.   Authority Of Police Chief: The chief of police, subject to the
provisions of this chapter, is hereby authorized to release, to one other than
the registered owner, vehicles which have been impounded by the police
department.
   B.   Lien Holder, Proof Required: A lien holder claiming an interest in an
impounded vehicle shall submit to the chief of police proof of compliance with
the following requirements by written instruments or other suitable documents:
      1.   Proof of interest;
      2.   An agreement to save and hold harmless the city, its officers, and
employees;
      3.   Proof of financial responsibility showing the net worth of the party
seeking the vehicle to be in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), or
a surety bond in an amount no less than double the value of the vehicle sought
to be released.
   C.   Other Party, Proof Required: Any other party claiming an interest in an
impounded vehicle shall submit to the chief of police proof of compliance with
the following requirements by written instruments or other suitable documents:
      1.   Proof of interest; and
      2.   Order of replevin. (1994 Code § 20-118)
6-12-13: SPECIAL LIENS:
   A.   Lien For Compensation: Every person lawfully in possession of an
impounded vehicle shall have a special lien thereon for the compensation due
him from the owner of such impounded vehicle for all expenses incurred.
   B.   Foreclosure Of Lien: Said lien may be foreclosed by a sale of such
abandoned vehicle upon giving notice and in the manner following. The notice
shall contain:
      1.   The name of the party bringing action and the name of the owner or
any person claiming any interest therein.
      2.   A full description of the vehicle, giving all available information
as to the make, serial number, license tag with year and the state from which
the tag was issued.
      3.   A full statement of all the facts.
      4.   The amount of the claim, giving a full description of the work,
labor, storage or any other costs involved.
      5.   The date, time and place of the sale.
      6.   The notice shall be posted in three (3) public places in the county
in which the vehicle is to be sold at least ten (10) days before the time
specified therein for such sale, and a copy of said notice shall be mailed to
the registered owner as recorded in the office of the Oklahoma tax commission,
the director of finance, and any other person claiming any interest in the
motor vehicle, at their last known mailing address, by registered mail on the
same date of posting said notice.
   C.   Sale Of Vehicle; Disposition Of Funds:
      1.   Proceedings for such sale shall not be commenced until ten (10) days
after said lien has accrued. After this ten (10) day period, but before sale,
the said registered owner of the vehicle shall have a right to contest the
impoundment in the municipal court.
      2.   A return of such sale shall be made at the time of sale and shall
contain a statement as to proof of posting and mailing of the notice of sale of
abandoned vehicle.
      3.   Any funds remaining after the payment of the lien and costs incurred
therein shall be remitted to the owner, if such owner is known, and if such
owner or the address of such owner is not known, to the director of finance to
be deposited in the general fund of the city. (1994 Code § 20-119)
CHAPTER 13
LOW SPEED ELECTRICAL VEHICLES, GOLF CARTS, MINIBIKES, ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES AND
MOBILITY DEVICES
SECTION:
6-13-1: Low Speed Electrical Vehicles Limitations
6-13-2: Use Of Golf Carts Or Go-Carts Prohibited
6-13-3: Limitations On Use Of Minibikes
6-13-4: Use Of All-Terrain Vehicles
6-13-5: Electric Personal Assistive Mobility Devices
6-13-1: LOW SPEED ELECTRICAL VEHICLES LIMITATIONS:
No person shall operate any low speed electrical vehicle on any street or
highway with a posted speed greater than thirty five (35) miles per hour.
However, a low speed electrical vehicle may cross a street or highway with a
posted speed greater than thirty five (35) miles per hour. (Ord. 2004-28, 9-7-
2004)
6-13-2: USE OF GOLF CARTS OR GO-CARTS PROHIBITED 1 :
Golf carts or go-carts shall not be operated on the streets and highways. (Ord.
2004-28, 9-7-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS §§ 11-1116, 1151.2.
6-13-3: LIMITATIONS ON USE OF MINIBIKES 1 :
   A.   Minibikes shall be prohibited from operating on the streets and
highways, except:
      1.   Minibikes may be ridden in parades;
      2.   Minibikes operated for food vendor services may be operated on
streets with a speed limit of thirty (30) miles per hour or less if the
minibike is registered in accordance with 47 Oklahoma Statutes section 1151(E).
   B.   All minibikes offered for sale shall bear the following notice to
customers:
This machine is not manufactured or sold for operation on the public streets or
highways. Since it is not provided with equipment required by state law for
street or highway use, all persons are cautioned that any operation of this
vehicle upon a public street or highway will be in violation of the motor
vehicle laws of this state and will subject violator to arrest.
   (Ord. 2004-28, 9-7-2004)
 
Notes
1 2. 47 OS § 11-1116.
6-13-4: USE OF ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES:
All-terrain vehicles shall not be operated on streets and highways except under
the following circumstances:
   A.   An all-terrain vehicle may be driven across a street or highway while
the vehicle is traveling upon a regularly traveled trail and needs to continue
travel from one area of the trail to another. If the vehicle comes to a
complete stop, yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic that constitutes
an immediate hazard, and crosses the street or highway at an angle of
approximately ninety degrees (90°) to the direction of the street or highway.
The operator must have a valid driver's license and it must be driven during
daylight hours. This exception shall not apply to divided highways or streets
with a posted speed limit exceeding thirty five (35) miles per hour in the area
of crossing.
   B.   An all-terrain vehicle may be driven on a street or highway to cross a
railroad track. In that event, the all-terrain vehicle may travel for not more
than three hundred feet (300') on a public street or highway to cross the
track. The operator must have a valid driver's license and it must be driven
during daylight hours. (Ord. 2004-28, 9-7-2004)
6-13-5: ELECTRIC PERSONAL ASSISTIVE MOBILITY DEVICES:
   A.   Registration, License Not Required: Electric personal assistive
mobility devices, as defined in section
6-1-2 of this title, are not required to be registered pursuant to the Oklahoma
Vehicle License and Registration Act and operators are not required to have an
Oklahoma driver license to operate the device.
   B.   Where Operated: Electric personal assistive mobility devices cannot be
operated on the State highways or turnpikes except they may be operated upon
the sidewalks, walking trails, bikeways, and municipal streets of this State.
   C.   Rules For Use: A person operating an electric personal assistive
mobility device shall:
      1.   Obey all speed limits,
      2.   Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and human powered devices at
all times,
      3.   Give an audible signal before overtaking and passing any pedestrian,
and
      4.   Wear or equip the electric personal assistive mobility device with
reflectors and a headlight when operating at night.
   D.   Penalty: The violation of this section shall result in a warning for
the first offense and thereafter the offense carries a maximum fine of ten
dollars ($10.00). Each act of noncompliance shall be considered a separate
offense. (Ord. 2018-19, 6-5-2018)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Obstructing Streets And Sidewalks
7-1-2: Tractors And Machines With Lugs; Planking Required
7-1-3: Snow And Debris Removal From Sidewalks
7-1-4: Closing Public Way Or Easement, Procedure
7-1-5: Installation Of Utility Lines In Public Streets
7-1-6: Sidewalk Partnership Program
7-1-1: OBSTRUCTING STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Obstructions Prohibited; Exemption:
      1.   No person shall in any manner whatsoever obstruct any public street,
alley, parkway, sidewalk, curbing or parking, or direct, place, operate or
maintain any business or any equipment, materials or supplies pertaining
thereto in or upon the same.
      2.   This section shall not apply to outdoor cafes permitted under title
3, chapter 5 of this code.
   B.   Signboards, Structures: No person shall in any manner whatsoever erect
or maintain any sign or signboard, building, structure, billboard, or any
equipment pertaining to any business in or upon any of the public streets,
alleys, boulevards, parkways, sidewalks or curbing; provided, however, nothing
herein shall affect the erection or use of overhead signs in compliance with
the sign ordinances of the city.
   C.   Nuisance Declared: All apparatus, equipment, materials or supplies
pertaining to any business; and all curb gasoline filling stations and pumps;
and all signs, billboards and other structures erected or maintained in
violation of this section are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall
be removed as provided herein.
   D.   Notice To Remove Obstruction:
      1.   The building official shall provide written notice to the owner,
operator, lessee or person maintaining an obstruction upon any of the public
streets, sidewalks, parking or curbs as herein prohibited. The notice shall
require such person to remove the obstruction within three (3) days of the
receipt of said notice.
      2.   Upon the failure of such person to remove the obstruction, the city
shall have the authority to abate said nuisance and remove the same at the
expense of the person maintaining it.
      3.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit any obstruction
or to prevent prosecution for violation of subsection A or B of this section
prior to the giving of such notice. (1994 Code § 30-1; amd. 2003 Code)
7-1-2: TRACTORS AND MACHINES WITH LUGS; PLANKING REQUIRED 1 :
No person shall drive any tractor, apparatus, machine or other equipment having
lugs, grousers, corrugations or other equipment which could damage streets upon
or across any paved street without first placing sufficient planking or other
material on the pavement to protect the same against damage or to fail to
remove such protective material from the pavement after its use. (1994 Code §
30-2)
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - permits for oversize vehicles, 47 OS § 12-405.
7-1-3: SNOW AND DEBRIS REMOVAL FROM SIDEWALKS:
Any person in possession of, or the occupant of, any building or lot shall,
within twelve (12) hours after a snow has fallen, remove all snow from the
sidewalks along the front and sides of said premises or building. Such person
shall also keep the sidewalk clean and free of rubbish, trash and debris. (1994
Code § 30-3)
7-1-4: CLOSING PUBLIC WAY OR EASEMENT, PROCEDURE 1 :
   A.   Notice Of Date And Hearing: Whenever it is desired to close or to
consider the closing to the public use of any public way or easement, the mayor
and board of commissioners shall by motion fix a date for closing or
considering the closing of such way or easement and which date shall afford
sufficient time to give thirty (30) days' notice. Thereupon, the city clerk
shall, more than thirty (30) days prior to such date, mail a notice of such
date and hearing on the proposed closing of a public way or easement, to the
holders of a franchise or others designated by the mayor and board of
commissioners to have a special right or privilege granted by ordinance or
legislative enactment to use the public way or easement. The clerk shall
certify to the mayor and board of commissioners that such notice has been
mailed.
   B.   Fees And Costs: Any private person who requests the city to close a
public way or easement to public use shall provide a list containing the names
and mailing addresses of all owners of property lying within three hundred feet
(300') of the exterior boundary of the subject property, as certified by a
licensed and bonded abstracting company or title insurance company. The
applicant shall also pay to the director of finance at the time of making the
request the fee as provided in subsection 2-6A-7A of this code.
   C.   Refund Of Fee: Should the applicant withdraw his application in
writing, prior to the setting of the hearing by the mayor and board of
commissioners, the fee provided in subsection 2-6A-7A of this code shall be
refunded to said applicant. (1994 Code § 30-4; amd. Ord. 2003-06, 3-18-2003;
2003 Code)
 
Notes
1 2. State law reference - vacating streets and alleys, 11 OS § 42-101 et seq.
7-1-5: INSTALLATION OF UTILITY LINES IN PUBLIC STREETS:
   A.   Approval Required; Application; Fee:
      1.   No person shall install a gas line, oil line, water line, electric
line or any other conduit or conductor either above or below the streets,
roads, highways and alleys within the corporate limits of the city without the
prior approval of the mayor and board of commissioners. Installation should be
as approved by the city engineer and shall meet all the requirements of the
city, including, but not limited to, this code.
      2.   Application for such construction shall be submitted to the city
engineer with an application fee in the amount established in subsection 2-6A-
7B of this code, which shall be paid to the finance director.
   B.   Exemptions: Public utilities licensed or franchised by the city, and
sewer and water service line construction, are exempt from subsection A of this
section. (1994 Code § 30-5)
7-1-6: SIDEWALK PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM:
   A.   Residential Sidewalk Repair Partnership Program: Eligible residential
property owners that desire to install or improve the sidewalks located in the
right of way may apply to the city for partnership funds to be used to make
repairs to the sidewalks.
      1.   To qualify, the property must be located within the city limits and
have or have been developed with sidewalks or the properties on either side of
the subject property have or have been developed with sidewalks. The sidewalk
must be in need of repair or reconstruction due to its condition or because it
does not comply with current sidewalk standards.
      2.   To be accepted into the program, the property owner must be able to
provide fifty percent (50%) of the cost of the repair or reconstruction or be
willing to have fifty percent (50%) of the cost be assessed against the
property to be paid back as provided for by state law as a sidewalk assessment
or as a lien.
      3.   Acceptance is contingent on the availability of matching funds and
priority will be given to applications on the basis of the condition of the
sidewalk, the need, and the scope of the project. Work that will result in a
general improvement to pedestrian access rather than provide only a localized
benefit will be given priority. Landowners are encouraged to consider making an
area wide application where appropriate.
      4.   If a property is accepted into the program, an agreement will be
drawn up between the property owner or owners and the city. If the
circumstances warrant, the city may provide more than a fifty percent (50%)
match if the scope of the project involves more than repair or is coupled with
additional municipal objectives.
   B.   Commercial Sidewalk Partnership Program: Eligible commercial property
owners that desire to install or improve sidewalks in the right of way may
apply to the city for partnership funds to be used to install or improve the
sidewalks.
      1.   To qualify, the property must be the location of an existing
business within city limits which was not required, when developed, to include
sidewalks.
      2.   To be accepted into the program, the property owner must be able to
provide fifty percent (50%) of the cost for the installation or be willing to
have fifty percent (50%) of the cost be assessed against the property to be
paid back as provided for by state law as a sidewalk assessment or as a lien.
      3.   Acceptance is contingent on the availability of matching funds and
priority will be given to applications on the basis of what type of street the
property abuts, the need and the scope of the project. Landowners are
encouraged to consider making an area wide application where appropriate.
      4.   If a property is accepted into the program, an agreement will be
drawn up between the property owner or owners and the city. If the
circumstances warrant, the city may provide more than a fifty percent (50%)
match if the scope of the project is coupled with additional municipal
objectives.
   C.   Ineligibility For Program: A property for which a sidewalk development
fee has previously been paid in lieu of construction of a sidewalk shall be
ineligible for the sidewalk partnership program. (Ord. 2016-03, 2-2-2016)
ARTICLE A.  CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 1
SECTION:
7-1A-1: Definitions
7-1A-2: Street Construction Permit
7-1A-3: Street Concrete Work; Completion Time
7-1A-4: Construction Standards
7-1A-5: Pavement Design And Permitted Uses
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  2-1-4 of this code for bond requirement for street improvements.
7-1A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
CONTRACTOR: Any person who does street concrete work, other than the owner.
OWNER: The owner or person in possession or in control of the property in front
of or adjacent to which street concrete work is being done or contemplated.
STREET CONCRETE WORK: The construction, alteration, repair or removal of any
pavement, curbing, gutter or driveway within any public right of way or
easement. (1994 Code § 30-31)
7-1A-2: STREET CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required; Exceptions:
      1.   Required: No person shall lay, place, construct, alter, repair,
remove or maintain any concrete, asphalt, hard surfacing, pipe, wire, poles,
lines or other material of any kind or do any ditching, excavating or filling
in any street, alley or public easement in the city without first having
obtained a permit from the city engineer. This provision applies to all
persons, including, but not limited to, franchisees and license holders.
      2.   Exceptions: No permit is required:
         a.   When work is done by or for the city.
         b.   For the fencing in of any utility easement or the growing of
shrubs thereon.
   B.   Application For Permit: Application for such permit shall be
accompanied by detailed plans and specifications of the work to be done.
   C.   Permit Fee; Exceptions:
      1.   If the plans and specifications comply with the requirements of this
article, the engineering department shall issue the permit upon payment of a
fee as specified in subsection 2-6A-7C of this code to the director of finance.
      2.   No fee shall be required for:
         a.   Persons authorized to do such work by the state or by a franchise
granted by the city; or
         b.   Work other than street concrete work. (1994 Code § 30-32; amd.
2003 Code)
7-1A-3: STREET CONCRETE WORK; COMPLETION TIME:
No person shall fail to complete or cause to be completed street concrete work
within a reasonable time, according to the plans and specifications submitted
and according to the permit issued therefor and the requirements of this
article. (1994 Code § 30-33)
7-1A-4: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
All work for which a permit is required by the provisions of this article shall
be accomplished as directed by the city engineer. (1994 Code § 30-34)
7-1A-5: PAVEMENT DESIGN AND PERMITTED USES:
All pavement constructed in the city shall be in accordance with the standard
construction specifications of the city and comply with the following; except,
however, that pavement on state and federal designated highways and street
improvements funded by state and federal programs shall be designed and
constructed in accordance with the Oklahoma department of transportation
requirements:
   A.   Type I: Type I pavement shall be designated for collector streets in
residential districts and local streets in commercial districts. Type I
pavement shall be a six inch (6") slab of Portland cement concrete on one-half
inch (1/2") sand cushion and six inch (6") compacted subgrade of suitable
material or six inch (6") compacted stabilized base as directed by the city
engineer. The stabilized base or subgrade shall extend ten inches (10") beyond
the back side of the curb section. The curb design shall be integral six inch
by eight inch (6" x 8") "barrier" type.
   B.   Type II: Type II pavement shall be designated for local streets in
residential districts and shall be a five inch (5") Portland cement concrete
slab with all other requirements of type I the same, except the back of curb
height shall be eleven inches (11").
   C.   Type III: Type III pavement shall be designated for the same service
classification as type I. Type III pavement section shall be two inches (2") of
type C asphaltic concrete surface course and five inches (5") of fine aggregate
bituminous base (FABB) on a six inch (6") compacted subgrade or six inch (6")
compacted stabilized base as directed by the city engineer. The compacted
subgrade or base and one inch (1") of FABB shall extend ten inches (10") beyond
the back side of the curb. The combined curb and gutter section shall be thirty
inches (30") wide with a six inch (6") molded curb section as specified for
type I, back of curb height shall be twelve inches (12").
   D.   Type IV: Type IV pavement shall be designated for the same service
classifications as type II. Type IV pavement section shall be two inches (2")
of type C asphaltic concrete surface course and four inches (4") of FABB. All
other requirements of type IV shall be the same as for type II, except the back
of curb height shall be eleven inches (11").
   E.   Type V:
      1.   Type V pavement is classified as temporary pavement and shall be six
inch (6") soil asphalt stabilized base of suitable aggregate and soil obtained
from approved sources or a combination of existing road bed material and
additional soil from approved sources. This stabilized base can be mixed in
place or produced off site and then manipulated and stabilized in place. The
surface may be a single bituminous chip and seal surface treatment or a slurry
seal treatment. Four inches (4") of fine aggregate bituminous base may be
substituted for the soil asphalt base or four inches (4") of full depth
asphaltic concrete pavement on a compacted subgrade or stabilized base may be
substituted for the soil asphalt base and surface treatment with approval of
the city engineer.
      2.   The intent for application of type V pavement is on street where the
city determines temporary pavement is necessary for the health, safety and
welfare of the community and sufficient funds are not available for
construction of permanent pavement. Type V pavement shall not be approved for
street improvements paid for by assessment of property owners.
   F.   Type VI: Type VI pavement section shall be a minimum of two inches (2")
of compacted aggregate base on a compacted subgrade of suitable material and a
slurry seal surface treatment. The compacted subgrade shall extend ten inches
(10") beyond the back side of the curb section. The requirements for combined
curb and gutter shall be the same as for type IV pavement, except a five inch
(5") roll curb section may be substituted for a barrier curb with approval of
the city and back of curb height shall be eleven inches (11"). Type VI pavement
shall not be approved for public right of way dedicated after the date of
adoption of this article.
   G.   Type VII: Type VII pavement shall be designated for collector streets
in commercial districts and streets other than arterials in industrial
districts. Type VII pavement shall be a minimum of seven inches (7") of
Portland cement concrete slab. The thickness shall be increased if subgrade
conditions and traffic load necessitate such increase as determined by the city
engineer. All other requirements for type VII pavement shall be the same as for
type I, except the back of curb height shall be six inches (6") plus the
thickness of the slab.
   H.   Type VIII:
      1.   Type VIII pavement shall be designated for the same service
classification as type VII. Type VIII pavement section shall be two inches (2")
of type C asphaltic concrete surface course and a minimum of seven inches (7")
of FABB. The thickness of FABB shall be increased if subgrade conditions and
traffic load necessitates such increase as determined by the city engineer. All
other requirements for type VIII pavement shall be the same as for type III,
except a minimum of two inches (2") of FABB shall extend ten inches (10")
beyond the back of curb.
      2.   An equivalent thickness of asphaltic concrete may be substituted for
FABB as determined by Oklahoma department of transportation design procedures,
except a minimum of two inches (2") of FABB shall always be specified.
   I.   Pavement Design For Arterial Street: Pavement sections including curb
and combined curb and gutter shall be designed based on subgrade conditions and
projected traffic loads for a service life of a minimum of thirty (30) years
using Oklahoma department of transportation established procedures for such
design. (1994 Code § 30-35)
ARTICLE B.  LIMITED ACCESS FACILITIES 1
SECTION:
7-1B-1: Definitions
7-1B-2: Improvement Costs
7-1B-3: Arterial Highways
7-1B-4: Auxiliary Service Highways
7-1B-5: Limited Access Facilities, Streets Designated
7-1B-6: Comprehensive Street Plan
7-1B-7: Use Of Limited Access Facilities, Regulations
7-1B-8: Zoning Ordinances Not Affected
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - control of access to highways, 69 OS § 1301 et seq.
7-1B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following definitions shall apply:
ARTERIAL HIGHWAY: A street or highway especially designed for through traffic,
entrance into which at intersections may be limited by requiring all entering
vehicles to be brought to a complete stop, and the mayor and board of
commissioners having jurisdiction thereover may otherwise protect the right of
way of vehicles thereon.
AUXILIARY SERVICE HIGHWAY: A street or highway especially designed to furnish
access to a limited access highway or to an arterial highway.
EXPRESSWAY: A divided arterial highway.
FRONTAGE ROAD: A road constructed adjacent and parallel to, but separated from,
the highway and connected thereto at least at each end for service to abutting
property and for control of access.
LIMITED ACCESS FACILITY: Shall include limited access highways, expressways,
arterial highways, frontage roads and the auxiliary service highway.
LIMITED ACCESS HIGHWAY: An arterial street or highway especially designed for
through traffic, and over, from or to which neither owners nor occupants of
abutting lands nor other persons have any right or easement of access, light,
air or view.
PARKWAY: Any street, highway or limited access facility from which trucks,
buses, and other commercial vehicles are, or may be, excluded.
PUBLIC ROAD: A road constructed to connect other public roads or streets, but
not connected to the highway. (1994 Code § 30-16)
7-1B-2: IMPROVEMENT COSTS 1 :
A system of limited access facilities consisting of the streets and parts of
streets hereinafter described is hereby established, and in recognition of the
general use of the streets and avenues therein included and of the wear and
tear and destruction of the grading, drainage, pavement and improvements
thereof by general traffic, the straightening, widening, draining, paving,
repaving, resurfacing, curbing, guttering and maintaining of the limited access
facilities are hereby declared to be improvements of a general nature and to
the extent that the costs thereof exceed the benefits to the abutting property,
such costs are declared to be costs of improvements of a general nature for the
benefit of the entire city. (1994 Code § 30-17)
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - power of city to declare limited access facility, 69
  OS § 1331.

All streets designated in this article as auxiliary service highways and
arterial highways are hereby declared to be limited access facilities and
public utilities, in accordance with the provisions of 69 Oklahoma Statutes
sections 1301 through 1331, and sections 1401 through 1403, inclusive. (1994
Code § 30-20)
7-1B-6: COMPREHENSIVE STREET PLAN:
The streets designated in this article as auxiliary service highways and
arterial highways are designated as a necessary part of a comprehensive plan
for a system of streets or highways for the adequate movement of traffic in,
out, through or around the city. (1994 Code § 30-21)
7-1B-7: USE OF LIMITED ACCESS FACILITIES, REGULATIONS:
Use of the limited access facilities shall be regulated and controlled by the
traffic ordinances of the city. (1994 Code § 30-22)
7-1B-8: ZONING ORDINANCES NOT AFFECTED:
Nothing in this article shall be deemed or construed to affect any of the
zoning ordinances of the city. (1994 Code § 30-23)
CHAPTER 2
PARKS AND RECREATION
SECTION:
7-2-1: Hours
7-2-2: Use Of Amplifying Equipment; Permit
7-2-3: Glass Containers Prohibited
7-2-4: Prohibited Behavior
7-2-5: Violation; Penalty
7-2-1: HOURS:
   A.   Hours Parks Open To Public: City parks shall be open daily to the
public on the following schedule:
      1.   Between six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M.
of any one day from April 1 to November 1.
      2.   From one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise to one-half (1/2) hour after
sunset of any one day from November 1 to April 1.
   B.   Occupancy Prohibited During Closing Hours: It shall be unlawful for any
person, other than city personnel conducting city business therein, to occupy
or be present in city parks during any hours the parks are not open to the
public.
   C.   Exceptions:
      1.   Baseball fields, softball fields, football fields and soccer fields
within the city parks, including the spectator and parking areas of said
fields, are excluded from the above closing hours while said fields are being
used for team playing of baseball, softball, football or soccer. This exception
is extended only to teams organized by sports organizations that have filed
with the city an approved schedule of proposed use of the fields.
      2.   Tennis courts within city parks are excluded from the above closing
hours while the courts are being used for playing tennis. (1994 Code § 24-1)
7-2-2: USE OF AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT; PERMIT:
   A.   Definition: As used in this section, the term "amplifying equipment"
shall mean any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice,
music or any other sound. It shall not include standard automobile radios when
used and heard only by the occupants of the vehicle in which the radio is
installed, or warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles, or horns or
other warning devices used only for traffic safety purposes.
   B.   Permit Required: No person, other than law enforcement officers or
authorized governmental agencies, shall install, use or operate any amplifying
equipment in a fixed or movable position or mounted upon any sound truck for
the purposes of giving instructions, directions, talks, addresses, lectures, or
transmitting music to any person or assemblage of persons in any public park of
the city without having first obtained a permit therefor from the director of
finance.
   C.   Application For Permit; Fee:
      1.   The application for such a permit shall contain the name and address
of the applicant, kind and type of equipment proposed to be used, the manner in
which it will be operated and the purpose or purposes for the operation of the
same, and such other information as shall be required by the city clerk. A
permit shall be issued to the applicant upon the payment of the permit fee.
      2.   The permit fee for the use or operation of any amplifying equipment
in the parks of the city shall be as provided in section
2-6A-5 of this code.
   D.   Disturbing Others: No person shall use any amplifying equipment in such
a manner as to disturb other persons in the park or on adjacent property. (1994
Code § 24-2)
7-2-3: GLASS CONTAINERS PROHIBITED:
No person shall be permitted to carry into or possess any glass container
within any municipal park. (1994 Code § 24-3)
7-2-4: PROHIBITED BEHAVIOR:
No person shall smoke tobacco products, including, but not limited to,
cigarette, bidi, kretek, cigar, cigarillo, little cigar, pipe, tobacco rock or
tobacco stone, in any public park. (Ord. 2014-22, 5-6-2014)
7-2-5: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   A violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine of not less
than ten dollars ($10.00) plus costs, nor more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) plus costs. (Ord. 2014-22, 5-6-2014)
ARTICLE A.  PARK AND RECREATION BOARD 1
SECTION:
7-2A-1: Board Created; Members; Terms
7-2A-2: Powers And Duties
7-2A-3: Meetings
 
Notes
1 1. See section D.1.17 of the city charter.
7-2A-1: BOARD CREATED; MEMBERS; TERMS:
There is hereby created a board to be known as the Enid park and recreation
board. The park and recreation board shall consist of a total of eight (8)
members, seven (7) members to be appointed by the mayor and board of
commissioners, and one member of the board of commissioners to be appointed by
the mayor. The members of the park and recreation board shall hold office for a
term of three (3) years or until their successors are appointed and qualified.
Members of the park and recreation board may serve two (2) terms in succession.
(Ord. 2013-23, 3-19-2013)
7-2A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The powers and duties of the park and recreation board shall be as follows:
   A.   To advise and assist the city in the planning of all parks owned and
operated by the city;
   B.   To advise with and recommend plans for the development of parks;
   C.   To advise with the city in its overall coordination of the park
programs; to inform and instruct the public on matters involving the city
parks; and
   D.   To promote the use of parks both by individual initiative and
recreational programs, as appropriate. (1994 Code § 24-18)
7-2A-3: MEETINGS:
The park and recreation board shall meet at such times as is agreed by the
members thereof, and shall have the authority to make its own rules and
regulations for the purpose of conducting its business and meeting. (1994 Code
§ 24-19)
CHAPTER 3
FISHING, LAKE USE AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT
SECTION:
7-3-1: Definitions
7-3-2: Chief Ranger (Rep. by Ord. 2004-42, 11-16-2004)
7-3-3: State License; Hours
7-3-4: Special Events; Permit And Fee (Rep. by Ord. 2011-03, 3-1-2011)
7-3-5: Fishing Requirements And Restrictions
7-3-6: Boats And Flotation Devices
7-3-7: Swimming, Scuba Diving, Ice Skating
7-3-8: Government Springs Park (Rep. by Ord. 2004-42, 11-16-2004)
7-3-9: City Waterworks
7-3-10: Domestic Waterfowl
7-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words are defined as follows:
BODY OF WATER: Ponds, lakes, creeks, and springs.
CITY OPERATED RESERVATION: Any naturally occurring or manmade body of water
owned or maintained by the city, and any park or interest in land owned or
maintained by the city which contains or is appurtenant to a natural or manmade
body of water.
FISHERMAN'S FLOAT: Any device designed to keep a fisherman afloat in an upright
position in the water, ordinarily consisting of a protectively covered circular
tube, of inflated rubber or styrofoam, with a saddle type seat, in which the
fisherman is seated while wearing watertight rubber waders.
LENGTH LIMIT: The total length of a fish measured from the tip of the snout to
the end of the tail, with fish flat on a ruler, mouth closed and tail lobes
pressed together. (1994 Code § 24-100)
7-3-2: CHIEF RANGER:
(Rep. by Ord. 2004-42, 11-16-2004)
7-3-3: STATE LICENSE; HOURS:
   A.   State License: No person shall fish upon any city operated reservation,
unless such person has a current state fishing license as provided by Oklahoma
Statutes or proof of exemption therefrom.
   B.   Hours: No person shall fish in any city operated reservation, except
during posted park hours or at such other times as further restricted by any
ordinance, rule or regulation. (1994 Code § 24-101)
7-3-4: SPECIAL EVENTS; PERMIT AND FEE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2011-03, 3-1-2011)
7-3-5: FISHING REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Type Of Fishing Equipment Permitted; Licensing: The following
restrictions shall apply on city owned and/or operated reservations:
      1.   Except as provided in the Oklahoma wildlife conservation code, no
person shall fish, pursue, harass, catch, kill, take in any manner, use, have
in possession, sell or transport all or any portion of fish without having
first procured an Oklahoma fishing license.
      2.   Fishing is limited to not more than three (3) rods and reels per
person, with no more than three (3) hooks per line (treble hooks are considered
1 hook). No other fishing methods are allowed.
      3.   No snagging, seining, netting, cast netting or noodling (hand
fishing) allowed.
      4.   All black bass caught must be released (returned to the water)
immediately after being taken; no harvest is allowed.
      5.   Channel catfish and blue catfish have a combined daily bag limit of
six (6); no size limits apply.
      6.   Crappie have a thirty seven (37) fish bag limit.
      7.   Flathead catfish have a ten (10) fish bag limit; minimum length
limit of twenty inches (20").
      8.   Trout have a bag limit of two (2) per person per day; no size limit
applies.
      9.   Harvest of all other species must comply with state regulations as
outlined in OAC title 800:10-1.
      10.   No person shall deposit unused bait of any character, including,
but not limited to, minnows, small fish, worms, flesh of animals or any other
deleterious matter which might decay, in the waters of any city owned and/or
operated reservation or upon the lands adjacent thereto.
      11.   No game fish from any city owned and/or operated reservations shall
be used as bait. For the purposes of this section, game fish shall be as
defined in the Oklahoma wildlife conservation code. (Ord. 2011-03, 3-1-2011)
7-3-6: BOATS AND FLOTATION DEVICES:
   A.   Operation Of Boats: Nonmotorized boats only may be operated on the city
operated reservations at Crosslin Park, Government Springs Park and Meadowlake
Park.
      1.   Age Restriction: No person under the age of twelve (12) may operate
any craft on city operated reservations. They may be a passenger of someone
aged sixteen (16) or older with parent/guardian permission.
      2.   Boat Size: Boats must be less than fourteen feet (14') in length.
      3.   Safety Requirements:
         a.   Personal flotation device or PFD (life jacket).
         b.   All boats must carry one wearable USCG approved PFD for each
person on board.
         c.   All passengers twelve (12) years and younger on boats must wear a
United States coast guard approved PFD whenever the vessel is underway.
         d.   Life jackets must:
            (1)   Be United States coast guard (USCG) approved,
            (2)   Be in good and serviceable condition, and
            (3)   Must be of suitable size for the intended person, and
approved for the activity.
      4.   Boating Hours: Boating hours are from sunrise to sundown. At no
point shall anyone operate any craft on city operated reservations outside of
daylight hours.
   B.   Fishing From Floats: It shall be unlawful for any person to fish from a
fisherman's float in any city operated reservation.
   C.   Violations:
      1.   A violation of any subsection of this section is subject to a fine
of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus costs for each violation.
      2.   Any person convicted of a violation shall be trespassed from boating
on city operated reservations. (Ord. 2013-42, 11-19-2013)
7-3-7: SWIMMING, SCUBA DIVING, ICE SKATING:
   A.   Swimming And Bathing: No person shall swim or bathe in any of the
waters of any city operated reservation.
   B.   Wading: No person shall wade in any city operated reservation unless it
is incidental to a lawful boat launching or boat retrieval.
   C.   Scuba Diving: No person shall engage in any skin or scuba diving in any
city operated reservation, except with the express permission of the city or
during an emergency situation or salvage operation.
   D.   Ice Skating, Sledding: No person shall ice skate or sled on or over any
of the waters of any city operated reservation. (1994 Code § 24-106)
7-3-8: GOVERNMENT SPRINGS PARK:
(Rep. by Ord. 2004-42, 11-16-2004)
7-3-9: CITY WATERWORKS:
Persons shall be permitted to operate a boat at the city operated reservation
located at the city service center, but only for the purpose of testing boats
and motors. The operation of such boats at the city operated reservation
located at the city service center shall be governed by the laws of the state.
(1994 Code § 24-108)
7-3-10: DOMESTIC WATERFOWL:
   A.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful to release domestic waterfowl on any
city property.
   B.   Violation: A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine,
or fee in lieu of fine, in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus
court costs and fees. (Ord. 2011-03, 3-1-2011)
CHAPTER 4
AVIATION; AIRPORT
SECTION:
7-4-1: Aviation Board
7-4-2: Landing Fees
7-4-3: Rental And Gasoline Storage Charges
7-4-1: AVIATION BOARD:
   A.   Created: There is hereby created a board to be known and designated as
the "aviation board of the city of Enid".
   B.   Appointment; Terms; Compensation:
      1.   The aviation board shall be composed of seven (7) residents to be
appointed by the city manager and approved by the mayor and board of
commissioners.
      2.   The term of each member of the aviation board shall be three (3)
years, with their terms expiring in March of the applicable year, and any
vacancy shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment for the
remainder of the term.
      3.   Members of the board shall serve without pay.
      4.   No member shall serve more than two (2) terms in succession.
However, partial terms shall not be considered in determining the term limit.
   C.   Officers And Meetings:
      1.   The aviation board shall each year elect a chairman and a vice
chairman from among its members.
      2.   A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business.
      3.   The board shall meet at such times as it may determine or upon the
call of the chairman.
      4.   It may adopt any necessary rules and regulations for conducting its
own business.
   D.   Functions:
      1.   The aviation board shall serve as an advisory body in the control
and supervision of the municipal airport.
      2.   The board shall conduct studies for the betterment of aviation
generally and shall report, advise and make such recommendations to the city
manager and the mayor and board of commissioners as it may determine wise from
time to time. (Ord. 2008-07, 2-21-2008)
7-4-2: LANDING FEES:
There is hereby levied a fee as provided in subsection 2-6C-1A of this code,
per scheduled landing at Woodring municipal airport. The charge shall be paid
monthly within twenty (20) days after being billed by the city, and if not paid
within twenty (20) days, a penalty fee as provided in subsection 2-6C-1A of
this code shall be added. (1994 Code § 6-16)
7-4-3: RENTAL AND GASOLINE STORAGE CHARGES:
   A.   Fees And Charges: There shall be levied and charged the fees as
provided in subsection 2-6C-1B of this code for ground rental for fixed base
operations, ground rental for hangars, hangar space fees and gasoline flowage
charges at Woodring municipal airport.
   B.   Monthly Payments: All ground and hangar rentals shall be paid monthly
in advance and the flowage charges shall be paid monthly based on the preceding
months flowage. (1994 Code § 6-17)
CHAPTER 5
RAILROADS
SECTION:
7-5-1: Railroad Crossings
7-5-2: Paving And Street Improvements
7-5-1: RAILROAD CROSSINGS 1 :
   A.   Warning Bells At Crossing: No person controlling, managing or operating
any railroad or line of railroad passing through or into the city shall cause
or permit its train engines or cars to cross any street without giving notice
of its approach by continually ringing the bell for a distance of not less than
two hundred feet (200') from the street crossing until the engine shall have
passed over the street.
   B.   Blocking Railroad Crossings:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any conductor to permit any railroad train,
car or engine to remain stationary or standing for longer than the space of
fifteen (15) minutes on any street crossed by a railroad track, or to obstruct
in anywise any street crossing for a longer time than fifteen (15) minutes.
      2.   Subsection B1 of this section shall not apply in those instances
where a road, street or public way is blocked as a result of a derailment,
wreck or mechanical failure which renders the train, car or engine totally
incapable of operation. (1994 Code §§ 28-2, 28-3)
 
Notes
1 1. State law reference - authority to regulate railroad crossings, 11 OS § 22-
  119.
7-5-2: PAVING AND STREET IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Duties Of Railways 1 :
      1.   When a railway occupies any portion of a street with its tracks
running in the general direction of the street, either on or adjacent thereto,
the railway company shall improve the space between its tracks, and two feet
(2') on either side thereof, in the same manner that the remainder of the
street is to be improved, or with such other material as the city may require.
      2.   Where any railway company occupies an alley with its track or
tracks, the company shall be required to improve, gutter, drain, grade or pave,
chat or gravel such alley in the manner that may be required by the ordinances
of the city. Where any railway company crosses any street that is being or has
been paved, the mayor and board of commissioners may require the railway
company to pave so much of the street as may be occupied by its track or tracks
and two feet (2') on each side, and when more than one track crosses the street
within a distance of one hundred feet (100'), measuring from inside rail to
inside rail, the railway company shall grade, gutter, drain, curb, pave, chat
or gravel, or improve between its tracks in the same manner as the city may be
improving or has improved the other portion of the street.
   B.   Noncompliance By Railway; Improvements By City; Lien 2 :
      1.   If the owners of the railway shall fail or refuse to comply with any
order of the city to make such improvements by paving, chatting, graveling,
macadamizing, or building sidewalks as the city directs, or to repair such
paving, graveling, macadamizing or building sidewalks, such work may be done by
the city. The cost and expense of such work done by the city may be charged
against the railway company and may be collected in the district court in the
county in which the improvements have been made, by action at law, in the name
of the city against the railway company. In any such action at law, it shall be
sufficient to declare generally for work or labor done, or material furnished
on the particular street, avenue, alley or highway so improved.
      2.   In addition to the remedy provided in this subsection B for
collection of costs and expenses, the city or anyone authorized by it to do the
work, shall be entitled to a lien upon the property of the railway company.
Such lien shall exist for the full amount of the cost and expense against the
property of the railway company adjacent or contiguous to the improvement or
improvements so made. The lien may be enforced against the property of the
railway company by action in the district court in the county in which the
improvements have been made. In any action to enforce the lien, it shall be
sufficient to declare generally that the lien exists for the amount of the cost
and expense of the work and labor done or material furnished on the particular
improvement. (1994 Code §§ 28-4, 28-5)
 
Notes
1 2. State law reference - similar provisions, 11 OS § 36-116.
2 1. State law reference - similar provisions, 11 OS § 36-118.
CHAPTER 6
PARADES; SPECIAL EVENTS 1

CHAPTER 7
TREES
SECTION:
7-7-1: Definitions
7-7-2: Removal Of Dead Or Diseased Trees; Trimming Trees
7-7-3: Public Tree Care; City Authority
7-7-4: Planting, Distance From Curb And Sidewalk
7-7-5: Sight Distance At Intersections; Obstructing Hydrants
7-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
ARBORIST: Any person who trims, prunes or cuts trees for hire or otherwise
serves as a specialist in the care and maintenance of individual trees.
PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any property within the curb line of the streets as defined
more specifically in 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 36-106.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any real property, including parks, streets or highways, that
is owned by the City or held by it in trust for the benefit of the public.
PUBLIC TREES: All trees, shrubs, bushes and other woody vegetation for which
any portion of the trunk is located on public property. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-
2003)
7-7-2: REMOVAL OF DEAD OR DISEASED TREES; TRIMMING TREES:
   A.   Trimming Or Removal:
      1.   Property owners shall trim trees so as not to obstruct the passage
of pedestrians on sidewalks (no limbs below 8 feet), nor vehicles traveling on
streets (no limbs below 14 feet) and alleys (no limbs below 12 feet).
      2.   The City shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or
diseased trees or the trimming of live trees on private property within the
City, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor
insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within
the City.
   B.   Notice; Abatement: The City Code Office will notify in writing the
owners of trees specified in subsection A of this section. The trimming or
removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within thirty (30)
days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to
comply with such provisions, the City shall have the authority to remove such
trees and charge the cost of the work to said owners.
   C.   Violation: The violations of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus costs, unless the person charged
has been previously convicted once under this section or any of the following
sections of this Code:
4-3-2,
4-4-2,
4-5-8,
4-6-8,
8-4-7, and
9-9-2 in the last five (5) years, then a violation of this section shall be
punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus costs. (Ord.
2018-25, 9-6-2018)
7-7-3: PUBLIC TREE CARE; CITY AUTHORITY:
   A.   The City shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove
trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues,
lanes, squares or public grounds as may be necessary to ensure public safety or
to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds.
   B.   The City may remove, cause or order to be removed, any tree or part
thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is
injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other
public improvements or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other
pest. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-2003)
7-7-4: PLANTING, DISTANCE FROM CURB AND SIDEWALK:
Street trees may not be planted closer than four feet (4') from any street curb
without approval from the City Engineer, nor shall any trees be planted closer
than eight feet (8') from the street curb of major arterials without approval
of the City Engineer. For the purpose of this section, the "edge of the paved
portion of a street" shall be defined as the street curb. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-
2003)
7-7-5: SIGHT DISTANCE AT INTERSECTIONS; OBSTRUCTING HYDRANTS:
   A.   Sight Distance 1 : No street tree shall be allowed to create a sight
distance restriction, as defined in the City's traffic control policies, of
uncontrolled intersections within the City.
   B.   Obstructing Hydrants: All fireplugs within the City shall be free from
any and all obstructions which render them inaccessible to fire protection
equipment and personnel. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  11-13-5B of this Code.
ARTICLE A.  TREE BOARD AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY PLAN
SECTION:
7-7A-1: Purpose
7-7A-2: Tree Board Established
7-7A-3: Community Forestry Plan
7-7A-4: Annual Work Plan And Implementation
7-7A-5: Tree Species
7-7A-6: Scope Of Duties
7-7A-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this article to promote and protect the public health,
safety and general welfare by creating a tree board and providing for the
development of a community forestry plan to address the planting, maintenance
and removal of public trees and shrubs within the city of Enid in order to
promote, maintain and improve the urban forest resource of the city of Enid.
It is not the intent of this article for the city to assume responsibility for
trees planted in the right of way by adjacent property owners. (Ord. 2003-24,
12-16-2003)
7-7A-2: TREE BOARD ESTABLISHED:
   A.   There is hereby created and established a tree board for the city of
Enid. It will consist of five (5) members. The members shall include:
A city manager designee;
Four (4) at large residents appointed by the mayor and board of commissioners.
All members will serve without compensation.
   B.   The at large members shall serve three (3) year terms. Members may
serve two (2) terms in succession.
   C.   At any meeting of the tree board, a quorum shall consist of half of the
total members.
   D.   Meetings shall be held at least quarterly and as deemed necessary by
the tree board.
   E.   The board shall elect a chairman from among its members and the term of
chairman shall be one year with eligibility for reelection for no more than
three (3) consecutive terms. (Ord. 2007-13, 7-17-2007)
7-7A-3: COMMUNITY FORESTRY PLAN:
It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study, investigate, counsel
and develop and/or update periodically a written plan for the care,
preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of public
trees and shrubs. Such a plan shall incorporate an inventory of the existing
trees on major rights of way, parks and other public property. Upon approval
and adoption of the recommended plan by the city commission, it shall
constitute the official community forestry plan. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-2003)
7-7A-4: ANNUAL WORK PLAN AND IMPLEMENTATION:
   A.   The duties of the tree board shall be to report and recommend to the
city commission an annual work plan to implement the community forestry plan.
The annual work plan shall outline activities planned for the coming year
including, but not limited to, the following:
      1.   Annually review and update a tree plan for the community by the end
of the first quarter;
      2.   Coordinate tree related activities;
      3.   Conduct an Arbor Day ceremony;
      4.   Provide tree information to the community;
      5.   Maintain a suitable and an unsuitable tree list for the community;
      6.   Maintain a list of licensed arborists;
      7.   Recognize groups and individuals completing tree projects;
      8.   Coordinate publicity concerning trees and tree programs;
      9.   Plan fundraisers and coordinate donations of trees or money to
purchase trees;
      10.   Develop rules and regulations for considerations by the city
commission pertaining to a tree program; and
      11.   Perform other tree related duties.
   B.   The work plan shall also include what is to be done, who is to do it
and how the proposed work will be funded. Upon approval of the annual work plan
by the city commission, the tree board will have the responsibility of carrying
out the annual work plan. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-2003)
7-7A-5: TREE SPECIES:
The tree board shall develop and maintain a list of suitable trees for planting
along streets in three (3) size classes: small, medium and large. A list of
trees not suitable for planting shall also be created. No species other than
those included on the list of suitable trees may be planted as public trees
without prior approval of the tree board. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-2003)
7-7A-6: SCOPE OF DUTIES:
This article is applicable to trees located within street rights of way,
utility easements, drainage easements, public parks and on other public
property within the city except property owned by schools or any branch of
county, state, or federal government. (Ord. 2003-24, 12-16-2003)
CHAPTER 8
AIRPORT ZONING
SECTION:
7-8-1: Short Title
7-8-2: Definitions
7-8-3: Enforcement And Administration
7-8-4: Board Of Adjustment
7-8-5: Airport Zones
7-8-6: Airport Zone Height Limitations
7-8-7: Use Restriction
7-8-8: Nonconforming Uses
7-8-9: Permit And Variance Requirements
7-8-10: Appeals
7-8-11: Judicial Review
7-8-12: Penalties
7-8-13: Nonaviation Use Of Airport Hangars
7-8-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the ENID WOODRING REGIONAL
AIRPORT ZONING ORDINANCE. (Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires:
AIRPORT: Enid Woodring Regional Airport.
AIRPORT ELEVATION: One thousand one hundred sixty seven feet (1,167') above
mean sea level.
APPROACH SURFACE: A surface longitudinally centered on the extended runway
centerline, and extending outward and upward from the end of the primary
surface at the same slope as the approach zone height limitation slope set
forth in section
7-8-6 of this chapter. In plan the perimeter of the approach surface coincides
with the perimeter of the approach zone.
APPROACH, TRANSITIONAL, HORIZONTAL, AND CONICAL ZONES: These zones are as set
forth in section
7-8-5 of this chapter.
BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT: The zoning board of adjustment presently existing as
appointed by the mayor and board of commissioners and appointed by the joint
airport zoning board, as provided in 3 Oklahoma Statutes section 110.
CONICAL SURFACE: A surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of
the horizontal surface at a slope of twenty to one (20:1) for a horizontal
distance of four thousand feet (4,000').
HAZARD TO AIR NAVIGATION: An obstruction determined to have a substantial
adverse effect on the safe and efficient utilization of navigable airspace.
HEIGHT: For the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth
in this chapter and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level
elevation unless otherwise specified.
HORIZONTAL SURFACE: A horizontal plane one hundred fifty feet (150') above the
established airport elevation, the perimeter of which in plan coincides with
the perimeter of the horizontal zones.
JOINT AIRPORT ZONING BOARD: A board consisting of two (2) members appointed by
the city, two (2) members appointed by the county, with a chairman elected by a
majority of the four (4) members so appointed, authorized by 3 Oklahoma
Statutes sections 101 through 115.
LARGER THAN UTILITY RUNWAY: A runway that is constructed for and intended to be
used by propeller driven aircraft of greater than twelve thousand five hundred
(12,500) pounds' maximum gross weight and jet powered aircraft.
NONCONFORMING USE: Any preexisting structure, object of natural growth, or use
of land, which is inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter or an
amendment thereto.
NONPRECISION INSTRUMENT RUNWAY: A runway having an existing instrument approach
procedure utilizing air navigation facilities with only horizontal guidance, or
area type navigation equipment, for which a straight in nonprecision instrument
approach procedure has been approved or planned.
OBSTRUCTION: Any structure, growth, or other object, including a mobile object,
which exceeds a limiting height set forth in section
7-8-6 of this chapter.
PERSON: An individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association,
joint stock association or government entity; including a trustee, a receiver,
an assignee, or a similar representative of any of them.
PRECISION INSTRUMENT RUNWAY: A runway having an existing instrument approach
procedure utilizing an instrument landing system (AS) or a precision approach
radar (PAR). It also means a runway for which a precision approach system is
planned and is so indicated on an approved airport layout plan or any other
planning document.
PRIMARY SURFACE: A surface longitudinally centered on a runway. When the runway
has a specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface extends two hundred
feet (200') beyond each end of that runway. The width of the primary surface is
set forth in section
7-8-5 of this chapter. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the
same as the elevation of the nearest point on the runway centerline.
RUNWAY: A defined area on an airport prepared for landing and take off of
aircraft along its length.
STRUCTURE: An object, including a mobile object, constructed or installed by
man, including, but without limitation, buildings, towers, cranes, smokestacks,
earth formation, and overhead transmission lines.
TRANSITIONAL SURFACES: These surfaces extend outward at ninety degree (90°)
angles to the runway centerline and the runway centerline extended at a slope
of seven feet (7') horizontally for each foot vertically from the sides of the
primary and approach surfaces to where they intersect the horizontal and
conical surfaces. Transitional surfaces for those portions of the precision
approach surfaces, which project through and beyond the limits of the conical
surface, extend a distance of five thousand feet (5,000') measured horizontally
from the edge of the approach surface and at ninety degree (90°) angles to the
extended runway centerline.
TREE: Any object of natural growth.
UTILITY RUNWAY: A runway that is constructed for, and intended to be used by,
propeller driven aircraft of twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds'
maximum gross weight and less.
VISUAL RUNWAY: A runway intended solely for the operation of aircraft using
visual approach procedures. (Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-3: ENFORCEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Enforcement Officials; Process Applications:
      1.   The code administration department of the city or its successor
shall enforce and administer these regulations.
      2.   Applications for permits and variances shall be made to such
department upon a form published for that purpose. The chairman of the joint
airport zoning board and the code administrator of the city shall collaborate
to create the application form or forms.
   B.   Separate From Board Of Adjustment: The code administration department
shall hear and decide issuance or not of all permits, but it shall not have nor
exercise any of the powers delegated to the board of adjustment. (Ord. 2002-05,
3-12-2002)
7-8-4: BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT:
   A.   Powers: A board of adjustment shall have and exercise the following
powers:
      1.   To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or
determination made by the joint airport zoning board or the administering
agency in the enforcement of this chapter;
      2.   To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this chapter
upon which such board of adjustment under such regulations may be required to
pass; and
      3.   To hear and decide specific variances.
   B.   Continuance Of Existing Board: The existing zoning board of adjustment
of the city, duly appointed by the mayor and board of commissioners, is
designated and appointed to exercise the powers set out above according to its
procedures and otherwise act as the board of adjustment for this chapter. (Ord.
2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-5: AIRPORT ZONES:
In order to carry out the provision of this chapter, there are created and
established certain zones which include all of the land lying beneath the
approach surfaces, transitional surfaces, horizontal surfaces, and conical
surfaces as they apply to Enid- Woodring Regional Airport. Such zones are shown
on the airport airspace drawing of Enid-Woodring Regional Airport consisting of
two (2) sheets, prepared by Barnard Dunkelberg and Company, Inc., dated
October, 1992, which is attached to ordinance 2002-05, on file in the office of
the city clerk, and made a part hereof by reference. An area located in more
than one of the following zones is considered to be only in the zone with the
more restrictive height limitation. The various zones are established and
defined as follows:
   A.   Precision Instrument Runway Approach Zone: The inner edge of this
approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is one
thousand feet (1,000') wide. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a
width of sixteen thousand feet (16,000') at a horizontal distance of fifty
thousand feet (50,000') from the primary surface. Its centerline is the
continuation of the centerline of the runway.
   B.   Runway Larger Than Utility With Visibility Minimum Greater Than Three-
Fourths Mile Nonprecision Instrument Approach Zone: The inner edge of this
approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is either
five hundred feet (500') or one thousand feet (1,000') wide, depending on the
type of approach zone on the opposite end of the runway. The approach zone
expands outward uniformly to a width of three thousand five hundred feet
(3,500') at a horizontal distance of ten thousand feet (10,000') from the
primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the centerline of the
runway.
   C.   Runway Larger Than Utility With Visual Approach Zone: The inner edge of
this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is five
hundred feet (500') wide. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a
width of one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') at a horizontal distance of
five thousand feet (5,000') from the primary surface. Its centerline is the
continuation of the centerline of the runway.
   D.   Transition Zones: Transition zones are hereby established adjacent to
each instrument and noninstrument runway and approach zone as indicated on the
zoning maps.
   E.   Horizontal Zones: Horizontal zones are hereby established by swinging
arcs of five thousand feet (5,000') radii for all noninstrument runways and ten
thousand feet (10,000') for all instrument runways from the center of each end
