of the primary surface of each runway and connecting the adjacent arcs by
drawing lines tangent to those arcs. The horizontal zone does not include the
approach and transitional zones.
   F.   Conical Zone For Instrument And Noninstrument Runway: The conical zone
for instrument and noninstrument runway is hereby established as the area that
commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom
a horizontal distance of four thousand feet (4,000'). The conical zone does not
include the instrument and noninstrument approach zones and transition zones
and horizontal zones. (Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002; amd. 2003 Code)
7-8-6: AIRPORT ZONE HEIGHT LIMITATIONS:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no structure shall be erected,
altered, or maintained, and no tree shall be allowed to grow in any zone
created by this chapter to a height in excess of the applicable height herein
established for such zone. Such applicable height limitations are established
for each of the zones in question as follows:
   A.   Precision Instrument Runway Approach Zone: Slopes fifty feet (50')
outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation
as the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of ten thousand
feet (10,000') along the extended runway centerline; thence slopes upward forty
feet (40') horizontally for each foot vertically to an additional horizontal
distance of forty thousand feet (40,000') along the extended runway centerline.
   B.   Runway Larger Than Utility With Visibility Minimum Greater Than Three-
Fourths Mile Nonprecision Instrument Approach Zone: Slopes thirty four feet
(34') outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of, and at the same
elevation as, the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of ten
thousand feet (10,000') along the extended runway centerline.
   C.   Runway Larger Than Utility With Visual Approach Zone: Slopes twenty
feet (20') outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of, and at the
same elevation as, the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance
of five thousand feet (5,000') along the extended runway centerline.
   D.   Transition Zone: Slopes seven feet (7') outward for each foot upward
beginning at the sides of, and at the same elevation as, the primary surface,
and extending to a height of one hundred fifty feet (150') above the airport
elevation. In addition to the foregoing, there are established height limits
sloping seven feet (7') outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of,
and at the same elevation as, the approach surface, and extending to where they
intersect the conical surface. Further, where the precision instrument runway
approach zone projects through and beyond the conical zone, there are
established height limits sloping seven feet (7') outward for each foot upward
beginning at the sides of, and at the same elevation as, the approach surface,
and extending a horizontal distance of five thousand feet (5,000') from the
edge of the instrument approach zone measured at right angles to the extended
runway centerline.
   E.   Horizontal Zone: Established at one hundred fifty feet (150') above the
established airport elevation.
   F.   Conical Zone: Slopes twenty feet (20') outward for each foot upward
beginning at the periphery of the horizontal and at one hundred fifty feet
(150') above the airport elevation and extending to a height of three hundred
fifty feet (350') above the airport elevation.
   G.   Excepted Height Limitation: Nothing in this order shall be construed as
prohibiting the construction or maintenance of any structure, or growth of any
tree to a height up to fifty feet (50') above the surface of the land. (Ord.
2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-7: USE RESTRICTION:
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, no use may be made of
land or water within any zone established by this chapter in such a manner as
to create electrical interference with navigational signals or radio
communications between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for pilots
to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes
of pilots using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport,
create bird strike hazards, or otherwise in any way endanger or interfere with
the landing, takeoff, or maneuvering of aircraft intending to use the airport.
(Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-8: NONCONFORMING USES:
   A.   Regulations Not Retroactive:
      1.   The regulations prescribed in this chapter shall not be construed to
require the removal, lowering, or other change or alteration of any structure
or tree not conforming to the regulations as of the effective date of this
chapter, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of a nonconforming use.
      2.   Nothing contained herein shall require any change in the
construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or
alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of this chapter, and
is diligently prosecuted.
   B.   Marking And Lighting: Notwithstanding the preceding provision of this
section, the owner of any existing nonconforming structure or tree is hereby
required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such
markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the joint airport zoning
board to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport
the presence of such airport obstruction. Such markers and lights shall be
installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the city. (Ord. 2002-05,
3-12-2002)
7-8-9: PERMIT AND VARIANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Future Uses:
      1.   Except as specifically provided in subsections A1a, A1b, and A1c of
this section, no material change shall be made in the use of land, no structure
shall be erected or otherwise established, and no tree shall be planted in any
zone created unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted.
Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit
is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether
the resulting use, structure, or tree would conform to the regulations herein
prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be
granted. No permit for a use inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter
shall be granted unless a variance has been approved in accordance with
subsection D of this section.
         a.   In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and
conical zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than
seventy five feet (75') of vertical height above the ground, except when,
because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, such tree or
structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zones.
         b.   In areas lying within the limits of the approach zones but at a
horizontal distance of not less than four thousand two hundred feet (4,200')
from each end of the runway, no permit shall be required for any tree or
structure less than seventy five feet (75') of vertical height above the
ground, except when such tree or structure would extend above the height limit
prescribed for such approach zones.
         c.   In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones
beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zones, no permit shall be required for
any tree or structure less than seventy five feet (75') of vertical height
above the ground, except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land
contour, or topographic features, would extend above the height limit
prescribed for such transition zones.
      2.   Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be
construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction or alteration
of any structure, or growth of any tree in excess of any of the height limits
established by this chapter, except as set forth in subsection
7-8-6G of this chapter.
   B.   Existing Uses: No permit shall be granted that would allow the
establishment or creation of an obstruction or permit a nonconforming use,
structure, or tree to become a greater hazard to air navigation than it was on
the effective date of this chapter or any amendments thereto, or than it is
when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all
applications for such a permit shall be granted.
   C.   Nonconforming Uses Abandoned Or Destroyed: Whenever the joint airport
zoning board determines that a nonconforming tree or structure has been
abandoned or more than eighty percent (80%) torn down, physically deteriorated,
or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree
to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning
regulations.
   D.   Variances:
      1.   Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any
structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use property, not in accordance
with the regulations prescribed in this chapter, may apply to the board of
adjustment for a variance. The application for a variance from such regulations
shall be accompanied by a determination from the federal aviation
administration as to the effect of the proposal on the operation of air
navigation facilities and the safe, efficient use of navigable airspace. Such
variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that literal application or
enforcement of the regulations will result in unnecessary hardship and relief
granted will not be contrary to the public interest, will not create a hazard
to air navigation, will do substantial justice, and will be in accordance with
the spirit of this chapter.
      2.   Additionally, no application for variance to the requirements of
this chapter may be considered by the board of adjustment unless a copy of the
application has been furnished to the joint airport zoning board for advice as
to the aeronautical effects of the variance. If the joint airport zoning board
does not respond to the application within thirty (30) days after receipt, the
board of adjustment may act on its own to grant or deny said application.
   E.   Obstructions; Marking And Lighting: Any permit or variance granted may,
if such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this chapter
and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the
owner of the structure or tree in question to install, operate, and maintain,
at the owner's expense, such markings and lights as may be necessary. If deemed
proper by the board of adjustment, this condition may be modified to require
the owner to permit the city, at its own expense, to install, operate, and
maintain the necessary markings and lights. (Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-10: APPEALS:
   A.   Right To Appeal: Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any
decision of the administering agency or the joint airport zoning board made in
the administration of this chapter may appeal to the board of adjustment.
   B.   Filing Notice Of Appeal: All appeals hereunder must be taken within a
reasonable time as provided by the rules of the board of adjustment and by
filing with the administering agency and the joint airport zoning board a
notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The joint airport zoning board
or the administering agency shall forthwith transmit to the board of adjustment
all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was
taken.
   C.   Stay Of Proceedings; Exception: An appeal shall stay all proceedings in
furtherance of the action appealed from unless the administering agency or the
joint airport zoning board certifies to the board of adjustment, after the
notice of appeal has been filed with it, that, by reason of the facts stated in
the certificate, a stay would, in the opinion of the administering agency or
the joint airport zoning board, cause imminent peril to life or property. In
such case, proceedings shall not be stayed except by order of the board of
adjustment on notice to the administering agency and the joint airport zoning
board, and on due cause shown.
   D.   Action In Timely Manner: The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable
time for hearing appeals, give public notice and due notice to the parties in
interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any
party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney.
   E.   Board Decision: The board of adjustment may, in conforming with the
provisions of this chapter, reverse or affirm in whole or in part, or modify
the order, requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and may make
such order, requirement, decision, or determination as may be appropriate under
the circumstances. (Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-11: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the board of
adjustment, may appeal to the district court as provided in Oklahoma Statutes.
(Ord. 2002-05, 3-12-2002)
7-8-12: PENALTIES:
Each violation of this chapter or of any regulation, order, or ruling
promulgated hereunder shall constitute a class A offense; and each day a
violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2002-
05, 3-12-2002; amd. 2003 Code)
7-8-13: NONAVIATION USE OF AIRPORT HANGARS:
   A.   Designated Hangar Series: T-hangars in the 46 series shall be set aside
for nonaviation storage use. Only T-hangars in this series shall be used for
nonaviation storage.
   B.   Rental Rates: Rental rates of T-hangars in the 46 series shall be as
set forth in section
2-6C-1 of this code.
   C.   Appropriate Use: Property stored on the premises must be appropriate
for airport activities and if personal property stored is found to be
hazardous, threatening, annoying, dangerous to others, or otherwise
inappropriate, the lessor shall have the right to require the removal of such
property. Property shall not be used for any unlawful purpose or for any
purpose that may constitute a nuisance. Items prohibited from the premises
include, but are not limited to, the following: animals (alive or dead,
including taxidermied); feed, grain, food, plants, and other attractants;
firearms, weapons, and ammunition; flammable, combustible, toxic, corrosive,
and otherwise hazardous items, chemicals or liquids; explosives to include
fireworks; tires, medical supplies, and pressurized materials including oxygen
tanks.
   D.   Violation: A violation of this section will result in a criminal
penalty of one hundred four dollars ($104.00) a day in addition to costs and
fees. (Ord. 2013-40, 10-1-2013)
CHAPTER 9
COMMUNITY ANTENNA TELEVISION SYSTEMS
SECTION:
7-9-1: Definitions
7-9-2: Effect Of Preemption; Federal And State Law
7-9-3: Responsibility For Continuing Administration
7-9-4: Obligations Of City
7-9-5: Nonliability Of City
7-9-6: Offenses
7-9-7: Failure Of City To Enforce Chapter
7-9-8: Acts Of God
7-9-9: Noncompliance By Licensee Or City; Amendments Considered
7-9-10: Notices Issued To Licensee And City
7-9-11: Waiver Of Right Of Licensee
7-9-12: Remedies Cumulative
7-9-13: Compliance With Applicable Law
7-9-14: Time Of The Essence To Agreement
7-9-15: Descriptive Headings Of Sections
7-9-16: Choice Of Law; Venue; Attorney Fees
7-9-17: Nondiscrimination
7-9-18: New License And Amendments Not Overlapping
7-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
abbreviations shall have the meanings given herein. Terms not defined below
shall have the same meaning as in the cable act, the 1992 cable act, or in FCC
regulations. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present
tense include the future tense; words in the plural number include the singular
number; and words in the singular number include the plural number:
AFFILIATE: An entity which owns or controls, is owned or controlled by, or is
under common ownership with the licensee.
BASIC CABLE SERVICE: Any service tier which includes the retransmission of
local television broadcast signals and includes public, educational and
government access channels or as otherwise provided by federal statutes.
CABLE ACT: The cable communications policy act of 1984, as amended.
CABLE ACT OF 1992: The cable television consumer protection and competition act
of 1992.
CABLE SERVICE: Means: a) The one-way transmission to subscribers of video
programming or other programming service; and b) subscriber interaction, if
any, which is required for the selection of such video programming or any other
lawful communication service.
CABLE SUBSCRIBER (INCLUDING "SUBSCRIBER"): Any person, whether an individual,
business entity or institution, who pays either monthly, yearly or special
event service charges and, who lawfully receives any of basic cable, pay cable,
pay-per-view or other services lawfully provided by the cable system,
regardless of whether such person occupies single-family or multiple-unit
dwellings, hotels or motels, or carries on business or other affairs in
business establishments or institutional premises.
CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEM OR CABLE SYSTEM: An electronic communications system,
consisting of a set of closed transmission paths using antennas, coaxial or
fiber optic cables, wires, microwave facilities or receivers, transmitters,
towers, wave-guides, satellite communication devices and other electronic means
or devices designed and constructed for the purpose of providing cable
services, which includes video and audio programming.
CITY: The city of Enid, in its present incorporated form or in any later
reorganized, consolidated, enlarged or reincorporated form, or its lawful
successor, transferee, or assignee thereof.
FCC: Federal communications commission, or successor governmental entity
thereto.
GROSS RECEIPTS: Any revenue derived directly or indirectly by the licensee, its
affiliates, subsidiaries, or received by the licensee from the operation of the
cable system in the city in the service area; provided, however, all revenues
shall include, but not be limited to, basic cable service monthly fees, pay-
cable service fees, pay-per-view service fees, installation and reconnection
fees, leased channel and local advertising fees; provided, however, that gross
revenue shall not include: a) any sales, excise or other taxes which are
imposed directly on any cable service subscriber by any governmental unit or
agency and which are collected by the licensee on behalf of said government
unit or agency (without limitation, the license fee is not such a tax); and b)
any revenues reported by the licensee but which in fact constitute bad debt;
except that "gross revenues" shall include all recoveries of such bad debt.
LICENSE: The rights and privileges given pursuant to this chapter to conduct
and operate a cable system in the city.
LICENSEE: The person, corporation or entity to whom a CATV license has been
issued by the city.
OTHER LAWFUL SERVICE: Any service other than cable service provided through
electric or electronic signals or which utilizes any facility or equipment of
the cable system.
PERSON: An individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust
corporation, or governmental entity.
PUBLIC WAYS: The surface of, and the space above and below, any public street,
highway, freeway, bridge, land path, alley, court, boulevard, sidewalk,
parkway, way, lane, public way, drive, circle, or other public right of way,
including, but not limited to, public easement, dedicated strip, or public
rights of way now or hereafter held by the city and dedicated for compatible
uses that, within its proper use and meaning, and consistent with the terms,
conditions and provisions pursuant to which the same was created or dedicated,
properly is used by the licensee for the purpose of installing, maintaining and
operating the cable system. "Public way" shall also mean any easement now or
hereafter held by the city within the service area for the purpose of public
travel, or for utility or public service use dedicated for compatible uses, and
shall include other easements or rights of way as shall within their proper use
and meaning and consistent with the terms, conditions and provisions pursuant
to which the same was created or dedicated, properly is used by the licensee
for the purpose of installing, maintaining or operating the cable system.
REBUILD: The reconstruction and upgrade, as required by section
7-9B-1 of this chapter, of the cable system existing in the service area
utilizing fiber optic cable and technology which is the state of the art as of
the date of the approval of this license.
SERVICE AREA: The present municipal boundaries of the city and shall include
any additions thereto by annexation or other legal means.
STATE OF THE ART: The most current technology which is economically feasible,
has been performance tested and is commonly accepted by industry standards for
cable television systems of comparable size.
VIDEO PROGRAMMING: Programming provided by, or generally considered comparable
to programming provided by, a television broadcast station. (1994 Code § 9-1)
7-9-2: EFFECT OF PREEMPTION; FEDERAL AND STATE LAW:
The licensee and the City must comply with all applicable provisions of Federal
and State law. If the City's ability to enforce any licensing provision is
preempted, then the provision shall be deemed preempted, but only to the extent
and for the period the preemption is required by law. If, as a result of a
change in law or otherwise, the provision would again be enforceable, it shall
be enforceable. (1994 Code § 9-72)
7-9-3: RESPONSIBILITY FOR CONTINUING ADMINISTRATION:
The title of the office that has primary responsibility for the continuing
administration of the license and this chapter, is the City Manager. (1994 Code
§ 9-76)
7-9-4: OBLIGATIONS OF CITY:
   A.   Cooperation With Licensee: It being in the public interest for the
licensee to maintain a good relationship with the residents of the City, the
City shall assist and cooperate with the licensee in maintaining such a
relationship.
   B.   Use Of Public Ways, Easements: If it becomes legally or practically
infeasible for the licensee to use certain public ways, particularly public
utility easements, easements across private property, or dedicated utility
strips, then the City shall cooperate with the licensee in obtaining the
necessary authority to cross, use or otherwise employ rights-of-way in
installing and maintaining its system.
   C.   Enforcement: The City shall cause its legal enforcement staff to
cooperate fully in the enforcement, prosecution and conviction of persons found
to have violated the criminal law and all provisions in this chapter applicable
to cable service and the cable system. (1994 Code § 9-77)
7-9-5: NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
A licensee shall have no recourse whatsoever against the City, or its officers,
boards, commissions, agents or employees, for any loss, cost or expense or
damage arising out of any of the provisions or requirements of the licensee or
this chapter, or because of the lawful enforcement thereof by the City, nor for
the City's lack of authority to grant all or any part of the license. (1994
Code § 9-73)
7-9-6: OFFENSES:
   A.   Operating Without License: It shall be unlawful for any person to
install, operate or maintain a cable system within the City without first
obtaining the license required by this chapter.
   B.   Unauthorized Connections To System: It shall be unlawful for any person
to make any unauthorized connection, whether physically, electrically,
acoustically, inductively, or otherwise, with any part of the licensee's cable
system for the purpose of enabling himself or others to receive any signals,
pictures, programs, sounds or any other information or intelligence transmitted
over the licensee's system without the consent of the licensee.
   C.   Injuring Cable Wires, Equipment: It shall be unlawful for any person,
without the consent of the owners, willfully to tamper with, remove, or injure
any cable, wires, or other equipment used for the distribution of signals,
pictures, programs, sounds or any other information or intelligence transmitted
over the licensee's cable system.
   D.   Penalty: A violation of this section shall be punishable by a maximum
fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs. (Ord. 2018-16, 5-22-2018)
7-9-7: FAILURE OF CITY TO ENFORCE CHAPTER:
A licensee shall not be excused from complying with any of the terms or
conditions of this chapter by any failure of the City on any one or more
occasions to insist on or to seek compliance with any such terms or conditions.
(1994 Code § 9-75)
7-9-8: ACTS OF GOD:
The licensee shall not be deemed in default or violation of provisions of this
license where performance was rendered impossible by war or riots, civil
disturbance, tornadoes, floods or other natural catastrophes, or similar events
beyond the licensee's control, and the license shall not be revoked or the
licensee penalized for such violation, provided the licensee takes immediate
and diligent steps to bring itself back into compliance and to comply as soon
as possible with the license under the circumstances without endangering the
health, safety and integrity of the licensee's employees or property, or the
health, safety and integrity of the public, or public or private property.
(1994 Code § 9-78)
7-9-9: NONCOMPLIANCE OF LICENSEE OR CITY; AMENDMENTS CONSIDERED:
If, for any other reason beyond its control, the licensee is unable to comply
with the terms and conditions of this license or chapter, or if the city
determines that there are issues that may be beyond its control to address, and
which ought to be addressed by amendments to this license or chapter, then the
parties shall meet to discuss these issues in good faith and to establish such
reasonable amendments, extensions and other changes to the license requirements
as they agree are appropriate. (1994 Code § 9-79)
7-9-10: NOTICES ISSUED TO LICENSEE AND CITY:
   A.   Issuance Of Notices: Unless otherwise expressly agreed to by the
parties, every notice or response to be served upon the city or the licensee
shall be in writing, and shall be deemed to have been duly given to the
required party five (5) business days after having been posted in a properly
sealed and correctly addressed envelope, postage prepaid, at a post office or
branch thereof regularly maintained by the U.S. postal service.
   B.   Licensee Addresses: The notices or responses to the licensee shall be
addressed as follows:
Suddenlink
General Manager
131 East Maine Avenue
Enid, OK 73701
with a copy to:
Suddenlink
3015 SSE Loop 323
Tyler, TX 75701
   C.   City Address: The notices or responses to the city shall be addressed
as follows:
      City Of Enid
      P.O. Box 1768
      Enid, OK 73702
   (1994 Code § 9-80; amd. Ord. 2010-07, 6-1-2010)
7-9-11: WAIVER OF RIGHT OF LICENSEE:
The failure of the city, upon one or more occasions, to exercise a right or to
require compliance or performance under a license or any other applicable law
shall not be deemed to constitute a waiver of such right or a waiver of
compliance or performance, unless such right has been specifically waived in
writing. (1994 Code § 9-81)
7-9-12: REMEDIES CUMULATIVE:
Except as otherwise expressly provided herein, remedies provided herein are
cumulative and in addition to other rights either party may have at law or
equity or under the license or this chapter. The exercise of one remedy shall
not foreclose the exercise of others, nor shall it relieve either party of its
obligation to comply with any provision of the license and this chapter. (1994
Code § 9-82)
7-9-13: COMPLIANCE WITH APPLICABLE LAW:
The parties shall at all times be subject to, and shall comply with, all
applicable federal and state laws and regulations. (1994 Code § 9-83)
7-9-14: TIME OF THE ESSENCE TO AGREEMENT:
In determining whether the licensee has substantially complied with the license
and this chapter, the parties agree that time is of the essence to the
agreement. (1994 Code § 9-84)
7-9-15: DESCRIPTIVE HEADINGS OF SECTIONS:
The headings set forth herein are descriptive only. (1994 Code § 9-85)
7-9-16: CHOICE OF LAW; VENUE; ATTORNEY FEES:
This agreement shall be governed by the laws of the state of Oklahoma. Any
federal court of competent jurisdiction shall have venue and jurisdiction
exclusively for any action at law or equity which may be instituted to enforce
the terms of this license or chapter. If any legal action is instituted to
enforce any of the terms of this license or chapter, one party's reasonable
attorney fees and all costs of the action, including court costs, expert
witness fees and all other actual expense incurred in the prosecution or
defense of the action, shall be paid by the other party, to the extent the
party prevails. (1994 Code § 9-86)
7-9-17: NONDISCRIMINATION:
The licensee shall not unlawfully discriminate against any person, including in
its provision of services and equipment, on the basis of race, color, religion,
national origin, sex, age, disability or income; or deny service to any group
of potential subscribers because of the income of the residents of the area in
which a group of potential subscribers reside. The licensee shall provide
information concerning the cost and availability of equipment to facilitate the
reception of services by the hearing impaired. (1994 Code § 9-87)
7-9-18: NEW LICENSE AND AMENDMENTS NOT OVERLAPPING:
In that the provisions, terms and requirements of this chapter, with the
exception of the duty to timely upgrade the system in accordance with article B
of this chapter, are effective after the term of the existing license, it is
hereby agreed by the city and the licensee that this new license and amendments
to this chapter hereby made are not construed to be overlapping and are made in
accordance with applicable state and federal law. (1994 Code § 9-88)
ARTICLE A.  LICENSING PROVISIONS; TRANSFER
SECTION:
7-9A-1: License Granted
7-9A-2: Specific Covenants Of Licensee
7-9A-3: Term Of License
7-9A-4: Grant Of Authority; Equal Protection Clause
7-9A-5: Rights Reserved
7-9A-6: Effect Of License On Other Laws And Powers Of City
7-9A-7: Transfer Of Rights And Privileges
7-9A-1: LICENSE GRANTED:
   A.   Grant Of License, Use Of Public Ways: The city hereby grants to the
licensee a nonexclusive license which authorizes the licensee to construct,
operate and maintain a cable television system for the purpose of providing
cable service and other lawful services to subscribers using public ways within
the service area and for that purpose to erect, install, construct, repair,
replace, reconstruct, maintain, or retain in, on, over, under, upon, across, or
along any public way and all extensions thereof and additions thereto, such
poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, pedestals,
amplifiers, appliances, attachments, and other related property or equipment as
may be necessary or appurtenant to the cable system, subject to the provisions
of this chapter and applicable law.
   B.   Operating System Without License Prohibited: No person shall operate a
cable television system within the city or use any streets, alleys or ways of
the city for the purpose of laying, maintaining or operating any cable
television system without having first procured a license from the director of
finance of the city.
   C.   Operating System On Vance Air Force Base: No person shall operate a
cable system on Vance Air Force Base without first obtaining a "license to use
real property and base access" letter from DynCorp local purchase or its
successor. (Ord. 2004-18, 5-4-2004)
7-9A-2: SPECIFIC COVENANTS OF LICENSEE:
The licensee agrees:
   A.   Not to contest the validity of the licensing procedure or any provision
of this chapter, and agrees to pay the cost of defending any litigation,
together with any judgment, reasonable costs and attorney fees incurred,
relating to the award of the license to the licensee or any provision of this
chapter contested by the licensee. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary
contained in this subsection, the licensee shall incur no liability nor
obligation to pay the cost of defending any litigation, together with any
judgment, cost and reasonable attorney fees incurred, relating to any matters
arising from the failure of the city to act upon an application submitted by or
grant a license to another cable television operator.
   B.   By acceptance of the license, the licensee accepts all the terms of the
license and the regulations imposed by this licensing ordinance. (1994 Code §
9-3)
7-9A-3: TERM OF LICENSE:
The license granted pursuant to this chapter shall be for a term of ten (10)
years from and after April 22, 2010, unless otherwise lawfully terminated in
accordance with the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 2010-07, 6-1-2010)
7-9A-4: GRANT OF AUTHORITY; EQUAL PROTECTION CLAUSE:
   A.   Authority: During the term of the license, the licensee is granted the
right and privilege to engage in the business of operating and providing cable
service to any part of the service area, and for that purpose to erect,
install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct, maintain and retain, in,
over, under, upon, across, and along any public street, alley or easement now
laid out or dedicated and all the extensions thereof and additions thereto
within the city, such poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits,
vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments, and other property as
may be necessary and pertinent to a state of the art cable system, and in
addition to use, operate and provide similar facilities or properties rendered
or leased from other persons, including, but not limited to, a public utility
or other licensee licensed or permitted to do business in the city.
   B.   Right Not Exclusive: A license granted under this chapter to operate a
cable system for the purpose of providing cable service and other lawful
services to subscribers in the city and to use and occupy the streets therefor
is not and shall not be deemed to be an exclusive right or permission. The city
expressly reserves the right to grant similar nonexclusive licenses to other
persons to operate cable television systems and to use the streets of the city
therefor within the same or other areas of the city at any time or any period
of time; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to
require the granting of additional licenses if, in the opinion of the mayor and
board of commissioners, it is not in the public interest to do so. In the event
that the city enters into a franchise, permit, license or other agreement of
any kind with any subsequent licensees for the purpose of providing cable
television service to any part of the city which contains terms more favorable
to such licensees in any regard to similar provisions of this chapter, this
chapter shall be deemed amended as of the effective date of the other
franchise, permit, license or other agreement, so as to give any existing
licensees the benefit of any such more favorable terms. (1994 Code § 9-5)
7-9A-5: RIGHTS RESERVED:
By issuing this license, the city reserves its rights under its lawful police
powers. The city, among other things, does not waive any rights it may have
under 47 USC section 552 or any requirements of local law or regulations, as
amended, including zoning codes, codes regarding building permits and fees, or
time or manner of construction, the standard construction specifications
manual, subdivision regulations and the other manuals governing the use of
public ways. Any other fees or charges paid, to the extent they are not by
federal law deemed to be a franchise fee, shall be paid in addition to the
licensing fee required hereunder. (1994 Code § 9-6)
7-9A-6: EFFECT OF LICENSE ON OTHER LAWS AND POWERS OF CITY:
The granting of a license under this chapter shall not relieve the licensee
thereof of any requirements of any ordinance, rule, regulation or specification
of the city now or hereafter lawfully enacted pursuant to its police powers or
any other exercise of the city's governmental and police powers to the full
extent that such powers now or hereafter may be vested in or granted to the
city. (1994 Code § 9-8)
7-9A-7: TRANSFER OF RIGHTS AND PRIVILEGES:
   A.   Consent Required:
      1.   If the licensee shall at any time assign, sell, lease or otherwise
transfer in any manner whatsoever its rights and privileges under this license
to any person, other than an affiliate, such action shall be in writing and a
duly authenticated copy shall be filed with the city. Such action shall not
become effective until the transferee shall have agreed in writing with the
city to become responsible for the full performance of all the conditions,
liabilities, covenants and obligations contained in this license and until such
action shall have been approved by the city, provided such approval shall not
be unreasonably withheld. The city may require evidence that the transferee
possesses the financial, technical and legal capability to perform all of the
conditions, liabilities, covenants and obligations contained in this license.
If the city fails to act upon a proposed transfer within sixty (60) days after
the transferee shall have agreed in writing to become responsible for the full
performance of all of the conditions, liabilities, covenants and obligations of
this license, then such action shall be deemed to have been approved.
      2.   No approval of the city shall be required for a transfer in trust,
by mortgage, by other hypothecation, or by assignment of any rights, title or
interest of licensee in this license or the cable system in order to secure
indebtedness of licensee.
   B.   Securing Debt: Notwithstanding the foregoing, pledges in trust or
mortgages of the assets of the cable system to secure an indebtedness may be
made without the city's prior consent; except that no such arrangement may be
made which would in any respect under any condition prevent the licensee or any
successor from complying with all its obligations under the license or this
chapter, nor may any such arrangement permit a third party to succeed to the
interest of the licensee without the prior consent of the city.
   C.   Prior To Construction: Notwithstanding the above, no transfer shall be
made prior to substantial completion of the cable system construction required
under this license and chapter.
   D.   Effect Of Unlawful Transfer: Any transfer, assignment or change of
control made in violation of this article shall make the license subject to
cancellation.
   E.   Timetable For Consideration: Any request for a transfer shall be deemed
granted unless the city acts upon the request within sixty (60) days of the
date the transferee submits a written request for approval of the transfer, and
transferee and transferor have submitted the information which they may be
required to submit in connection with the transfer. The timetable may be
extended with the consent of the city and either the licensee or transferee.
   F.   Costs: The licensee may require the transferee to bear its reasonable
costs associated with the review of any transfer request, except to an
affiliate. (1994 Code §§ 9-66, 9-67, 9-68, 9-69, 9-70, 9-71)
ARTICLE B.  CABLE SYSTEM FACILITIES, EQUIPMENT AND SERVICES
SECTION:
7-9B-1: Cable System Design
7-9B-2: Cable System Design Review Process
7-9B-3: Initial And Continuing Tests
7-9B-4: Inspections During Construction
7-9B-5: Other Construction Procedures
7-9B-6: Cable System Maintenance
7-9B-7: Cable System Performance
7-9B-8: Cable System Construction, Extension, Area To Serve
7-9B-9: Public, Educational And Governmental Use
7-9B-10: Subscriber Services
7-9B-11: Technology Level Requirements
7-9B-12: Licensee Responsibility For Program Content
7-9B-1: CABLE SYSTEM DESIGN:
   A.   Upgrade System; Fiber Optic Technology: The licensee shall upgrade the
cable system so that the cable system in its entirety uses equipment of high
quality and reliability capable of providing a channel capacity of at least
seventy two (72) channels of analog programming. Fiber optic technology will be
integrated into the cable system in a manner which permits the licensee to take
full advantage of the benefits of that technology, including increased
reliability and improved system performance. The cable system will employ fiber
optics down to nodes of two thousand five hundred (2,500) homes or less and
will reduce active services down to fewer than six (6) per cascade.
   B.   City Right To Locate Equipment: The city shall have the right, at no
cost, to locate equipment upon, and make attachments to, the cable television
system owned by the licensee in connection with city systems. Attachments shall
be installed and maintained in accordance with the requirements of the
electrical code of the city and only after written notice to the licensee. Upon
request by the city, the licensee agrees to construct attachments to the system
for exclusive use by the city, its departments, boards, authorities,
commissions and agencies for governmental purposes, other than the operation of
a cable television system, at the incremental cost of such attachments at the
time of construction. The licensee shall assume no liability or expense in
connection with any city attachment to or use of the cable television system.
City use shall be in such manner as not to interfere with the use and
maintenance of the cable television system by the licensee.
   C.   City Compliance With Licensee: The city, in its use and maintenance of
such equipment and fixtures, shall at all times comply with the rules and
regulations of the licensee in order that there be a minimum danger of contact
or conflict between the equipment and fixtures of the licensee and the
equipment and fixtures used by city.
   D.   Save Harmless Agreement For Licensee: The city shall be solely
responsible and save the licensee harmless for all claims and demands for
damages to persons or property arising out of the use by the city of the cable
system.
   E.   Time Limit For Upgrade And Installations: The upgrade and installations
required under this section shall be completed on or before December 31, 1996.
The city shall grant reasonable extensions of time to complete construction in
particular areas of the city if, prior to the scheduled time for completion,
the licensee shows that, notwithstanding its due diligence, it has been unable
to extend service to a specified area because the acts or omissions of a third
party (not including the licensee's subcontractors or agents) have caused a
delay in construction beyond delays reasonably expected during the course of a
rebuild or upgrade, and the licensee proposes a reasonable alternative deadline
for extension of service to that area. (1994 Code § 9-9)
7-9B-2: CABLE SYSTEM DESIGN REVIEW PROCESS:
   A.   Elements Of Plan: At least thirty (30) days prior to the date that
construction of any required upgrade is scheduled to commence, the licensee
shall make available a detailed cable system design and construction plan,
available for review by the city at the local office of the licensee, which
shall include at least the following elements:
      1.   Design type, trunk and feeder design, number and location of hubs or
nodes.
      2.   Distribution system cable, fiber, equipment to be used.
      3.   Plans for standby power at headend.
      4.   Longer amplifier cascade in system (number of amplifiers, number of
miles, type of cable/fiber).
      5.   Design maps and tree trunk maps for the cable system.
   B.   Design Shown On Maps: The system design will be shown on maps of
industry standard scale using standard symbology, and shall depict all
electronic and physical features of the cable system. (1994 Code § 9-10)
7-9B-3: INITIAL AND CONTINUING TESTS:
The licensee shall perform all tests necessary to demonstrate compliance with
the requirements of 47 CFR 76 subpart K of the FCC rules and regulations. All
tests shall be conducted in accordance with most current publications of
Tektronix, "No Loose Ends", and/or NCTA's "Recommended Practices for
Measurements on Cable Systems". The licensee shall perform at least the
following tests:
   A.   Acceptance Tests:
      1.   The licensee shall perform acceptance tests on the entire system at
the conclusion of the upgrade to demonstrate compliance with 47 CFR 76 subpart
K of the FCC rules and regulations.
      2.   The city has the option of witnessing the tests. The test results
shall be submitted to the city for review. The licensee shall have the
obligation, without further notice from the city, to take corrective action if
any segment is not operating or performing within 47 CFR 76 subpart K of the
FCC rules and regulations.
   B.   Continuing Tests: The licensee and the city will jointly select test
points at various points of the system. The quantity of these test points will
be mutually agreed upon based on what best represents the architecture of the
cable system. The licensee shall perform proof of performance tests at these
locations annually in conjunction with 47 CFR 76 subpart K through the term of
the license, and at other points mutually agreed upon where cable system user
complaints indicate tests are warranted or as required to test all major trunk
lines. The city shall have the option of witnessing the tests. A written report
of the test results shall be filed with city within thirty (30) days of the
test. If a location fails to meet performance specifications as outlined in 47
CFR 76 subpart K, the licensee, without requirement of additional notice or
request from the city, shall take corrective action, retest the locations and
advise the city of the action taken and results achieved. (1994 Code § 9-11)
7-9B-4: INSPECTIONS DURING CONSTRUCTION:
The city may conduct inspections of construction areas and subscriber
installations, including to assure compliance with the applicable laws, codes,
and requirements of this license. The licensee shall be notified of any
violations found during the course of inspections. The licensee must bring
violations into compliance within thirty (30) days of the date it receives
notice, and submit a report to the city describing the steps taken to bring
itself into compliance. Inspection does not relieve the licensee of its
obligation to build in compliance with all provisions of this chapter. (1994
Code § 9-12)
7-9B-5: OTHER CONSTRUCTION PROCEDURES:
The licensee:
   A.   Shall follow a system design and construction plan consistent with its
obligations under this license, use the equipment specified (or substitute
equipment of equivalent or better quality) in such distribution system design
plan and construction plan (except insofar as those plans, if carried out,
would result in construction of a cable system which would not meet
requirements of federal, state or local law; and except for such minor
modifications as are typical in the industry).
   B.   Shall use equipment of good and durable quality.
   C.   Shall make available, within sixty (60) days of implementation of the
upgrade, as built system design maps for the city's review at the local office
of the licensee.
   D.   Shall provide strand maps showing the actual location of additions or
extensions to its lines within sixty (60) days of completion of cable system
construction in any geographic area. (1994 Code § 9-13)
7-9B-6: CABLE SYSTEM MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Interruptions Minimized: The licensee shall, so far as reasonably
possible, schedule maintenance so that activities likely to result in an
interruption of service are performed during periods of minimum subscriber use
of the cable system. The licensee shall make best efforts to minimize
interruptions of service consistent with reasonable and customary upgrade
practices.
   B.   Maintenance Practices: In addition to its other obligations, the
licensee shall use replacement components of good and durable quality, with
characteristics better or equal to replaced equipment.
   C.   Requirements: The licensee and licensee's agent shall:
      1.   Maintain and operate the cable system so as to provide video, audio
and other signals to be delivered with signal strength and quality levels which
meet the parameters as specified by the FCC. The licensee shall construct the
system, rebuild and operate and maintain the cable system in the manner
consistent with all ordinary care and all applicable laws, ordinances,
construction standards, and FCC technical standards. Upon request, the licensee
shall provide the city a report of the results of any FCC required proof or
performance test conducted by the licensee.
      2.   Furnish the best possible signals available under the circumstances
existing at the time, without causing cross modulation in the cable or
interfering with other electrical or electronic systems, and shall provide
quality reception so that both sound and picture are produced free from visible
and audible distortion and ghost images on standard television receivers in
good repair.
      3.   Except where there exists an emergency situation necessitating a
more expedited procedure, the licensee may interrupt service, for the purpose
of repairing or upgrading the cable system, only during the periods of minimum
use, and only after twenty four (24) hours' minimum notice to its subscribers.
      4.   Maintain equipment capable of providing standby battery power for
trunk amplifiers for a minimum period of three (3) hours.
      5.   As a part of the cable system rebuild, provide capacity for
interactive services which may be added to the cable system as such services
become technically and economically feasible.
      6.   Under normal operating conditions, the following standard shall be
met no less than ninety five percent (95%) of the time on an annual basis:
Except when beyond the control of the licensee, the licensee shall respond to
cable service interruptions promptly and in no event later than twenty four
(24) hours.
      7.   Establish procedures for receiving, acting upon and resolving
subscriber complaints, which procedure shall be subject to the approval of the
mayor and board of commissioners of the city.
      8.   Notify the city in writing of any unresolved complaints from
subscribers. The licensee shall promptly investigate any complaints received
from subscribers and take such action as is necessary to provide cable service
to subscribers and to operate the system as required by this chapter. (1994
Code § 9-14)
7-9B-7: CABLE SYSTEM PERFORMANCE:
The city may regulate technical standards for the cable system to the fullest
extent permitted by federal law and regulations, or as same may be hereinafter
amended. Initially, the cable system shall be constructed so as to meet or
exceed the technical standards set forth in 47 CFR section 76.601 et seq. ("FCC
Rules"), as amended, and shall be operated and maintained to satisfy those
standards. (1994 Code § 9-15)
7-9B-8: CABLE SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION, EXTENSION, AREA TO SERVE:
   A.   Extend System Upon Request Of Potential Subscribers: The licensee shall
timely construct the cable system as provided by this chapter, and whenever it
shall receive a request for service from at least five (5) subscribers within
one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) cable feet of its trunk cable, extend
its cable system to said subscribers at no cost to the subscribers for cable
system extension other than the usual connection fees for all subscribers;
provided, that such extension is technically and physically feasible. The one
thousand three hundred twenty feet (1,320') shall be measured in extension
length of licensee's cable required for service located within the public
easement or street and shall not include length of necessary service drop to
subscriber's home or premises. The number of dwellings per street mile shall
also be included in the number necessary to determine whether the extension
complies with this section.
   B.   Refusal Of Service: No person shall be arbitrarily refused cable
service unless the prospective subscriber is more than one hundred fifty feet
(150') from distribution cable to connection of service to subscribers, or
there is a density of less than ten (10) subscribers for one thousand three
hundred twenty feet (1,320') of cable system.
   C.   Construction Of System For Future Service: If technologically and
financially feasible, a licensee shall have constructed its system sufficient
to make its cable service available to substantially all of the residential,
commercial and public buildings within the city, before offering cable services
requiring the use of portions of its CATV system to buildings and structures
located in unincorporated areas outside the city's boundaries.
   D.   Application To Territorial Limits: The license shall apply to the
territorial limits of the city as it now exists or may hereafter be determined.
   E.   Capital Contribution In Aid Of Construction: For areas outside the
distance as provided in subsection A of this section, and where there is a
density of less than five (5) potential subscribers per one thousand three
hundred twenty (1,320) cable bearing strand feet of trunk or distribution
cable, the cable system shall be extended on the basis of a capital
contribution in aid of construction, including actual cost of material and
labor. For the purpose of determining the amount of capital contribution in aid
of construction to be borne by the licensee and subscribers in the area in
which cable service is expanded, the licensee will contribute an amount equal
to the construction and other costs per quarter mile, multiplied by the length
of the extension in quarter miles, multiplied by a fraction whose numerator
equals the actual number of potential subscribers per one thousand three
hundred twenty (1,320) cable bearing strand feet of its trunks or distribution
cable, and whose denominator equals 5. Persons requesting service will bear the
remainder of the construction and other costs on a pro rata basis. The licensee
may require that the estimated payment of the subscriber's share of the capital
contribution in aid of construction be paid in advance. Any excess amounts
collected in advance must be returned to the subscriber.
   F.   New Subdivisions: In addition, the licensee shall extend its cable
system to any new subdivision; provided, however, the licensee shall extend at
the same time as the gas and electric utilities extend.
   G.   Time Limit For Extending Service: Subject to the provisions in this
section, the licensee must extend cable service to any person requesting it
within seven (7) business days of the request where cable service can be
provided by activating or installing a standard drop. Upon completion of the
system upgrade, cable service must be extended to any person requesting it
within five (5) business days of the request where cable service can be
provided by activating or installing a standard drop. Cable service must be
extended within ten (10) business days of the request for a nonstandard
installation. Where an extension of the distribution system is required,
service must be extended within ninety (90) days of the request for an
extension of one-half (1/2) mile or less or, in other cases, within six (6)
months; provided, however, such time limits shall be extended for a sufficient
period of time necessary to obtain any required permits or permission from
third parties.
   H.   Public And Governmental Buildings:
      1.   The licensee shall, within the city, provide a single installation
of its nonpremium cable service at each public building containing offices of
the city government; each public library, fire and police station, public
schools (including the board of education administration building), Zollars
Library, Gantz Center, the administration building of Phillips University, and
the Enid higher education facility.
      2.   Such installation shall be made at such reasonable locations as
shall be requested by the respective units of government or institutions, at
the sole cost and expense of the licensee. Additional installments or
relocation of installations made pursuant to this chapter shall be performed
and charged by the licensee at actual cost. No monthly service charges shall be
made for distribution of the licensee's nonpremium cable service within the
buildings enumerated in this section. (1994 Code § 9-16)
7-9B-9: PUBLIC, EDUCATIONAL AND GOVERNMENTAL USE:
   A.   PEG Channel Capacity:
      1.   Upon completion of the upgrade, the licensee shall set aside three
(3) downstream channels for noncommercial public, educational, or governmental
("PEG") use.
      2.   If the third channel is designated for noncommercial PEG use, but
one year after activation or reactivation a channel is not programmed with
video or text, at least three (3) hours per day, five (5) of seven (7) days a
week, measured over three (3) consecutive calendar months, the under programmed
third channel (or channels) will revert back to the licensee's use until such
time as the remaining channels are programmed with video or text at least four
(4) hours per day, five (5) of seven (7) days a week for three (3) consecutive
months, at which point the channel or channels will be reactivated on request.
The channels reactivated shall be in addition to and not displace, the then
existing services.
   B.   No Charge: The PEG channels shall be available at no charge to users.
   C.   Liability For Obscenity, Defamation, Or Invasion Of Privacy On Access
Channels: Liability for obscenity, defamation, or invasion of privacy on any
access channels shall rest with the person or group of persons utilizing the
access channels.
   D.   Other Programming: When the PEG use channels are not being used to
carry programming provided by other access users, the city or its designee, at
their sole cost and expense, shall have the right to backup PEG programming
with other programming, consistent with promoting public, educational and
governmental use of the channels. This subsection shall not limit the
licensee's rights under 47 USC section 531(d). (1994 Code § 9-17)
7-9B-10: SUBSCRIBER SERVICES:
   A.   Number And Categories: From the completion of the cable system upgrade
as provided for herein, the licensee shall attempt to provide at least the same
number and broad categories of service as are provided as of the effective date
of this chapter, plus three (3) access channels.
   B.   Types Of Programming; Removal Of Programs: The licensee agrees to offer
programming including news, sports, children's and weather. The licensee may,
upon thirty (30) days' notice to the city, rearrange, replace or remove a
particular cable service if: 1) such service is no longer available to the
licensee; or 2) the licensee must pay a higher copyright royalty for the
service that was required when this license was executed and such higher
royalty has not been compensated for through a rate increase or by other means.
   C.   Periodic Community Surveys: Upon request by the city, the licensee
shall develop and conduct community surveys at least three (3) months prior to
each successive periodic review as provided for in section
7-9C-10 of this chapter, and within six (6) months following the completion of
the upgrade as provided for in section
7-9B-1 of this article, to determine the cable related needs and interests of
the subscribers. The licensee shall bear the costs of such surveys. The
licensee shall commission the use of a professional independent third party to
conduct such survey.
   D.   Access Channel Reserved: The commander's access channel (channel 43)
will be reserved. The channel is to be set aside for government use during
periods of actual government use. In no event is this channel to be viewable by
nongovernment subscribers during periods of government use and should not be
broadcast off base to nonair force subscribers. (1994 Code § 9-18)
7-9B-11: TECHNOLOGY LEVEL REQUIREMENTS:
A licensee shall build the latest state of the art cable television system as
is available in similarly sized cities in the state and upgrade its facilities,
equipment and services so that its cable system is as advanced as the current
state of technology in Oklahoma will allow. Provided however, at no time shall
such licensee be required to upgrade its facilities if it demonstrates that
such upgrading would not be financially or technologically feasible or in the
best interest of the city or its subscribers; this limiting condition shall not
apply to the initial rebuild as provided in section
7-9B-1 of this article. (1994 Code § 9-19)
7-9B-12: LICENSEE RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROGRAM CONTENT:
   A.   Authority Of City: During the term of this license, the city may not
prohibit the licensee from providing any program or class of programs over the
cable system. Provided that nothing in this section shall be read to constitute
a waiver by the city of any rights it may have in the enforcement or enactment
of any applicable law regarding obscenity, indecency, libel, slander,
incitement or the like.
   B.   Parental Control Device: Upon request, the licensee shall provide
subscribers with a parental control locking device or digital code capable of
blocking or otherwise preventing a television set from receiving a channel or
audio signal, for which the licensee imposes a separate charge. (1994 Code § 9-
20)
ARTICLE C.  MONITORING PERFORMANCE; REGULATORY AUTHORITY
SECTION:
7-9C-1: Inspection Of Books And Records
7-9C-2: Inspection Of Installations
7-9C-3: Records Maintained
7-9C-4: Reports Prepared
7-9C-5: Documents Provided
7-9C-6: Obligation To Release
7-9C-7: Maps And Plats
7-9C-8: Requests For Information
7-9C-9: Testing
7-9C-10: Periodic Reviews
7-9C-11: Unreasonable Requests
7-9C-1: INSPECTION OF BOOKS AND RECORDS:
The city shall have access at all reasonable hours to all plans, engineering,
accounting, financial, statistical, customer and service records relating to
the enforcement of the city's rights or the licensee's obligations under this
license or applicable law. The documents requested shall be produced upon
reasonable written notice and no later than thirty (30) days after the request
for production. If such requested documents are too voluminous, or for security
reasons cannot be copied and moved, then the licensee may request that the city
inspect them at the licensee's office. The city agrees to treat any information
disclosed by the licensee to it as confidential and only to disclose it to any
employees, representatives, and agents thereof that have a need to know, or in
order to enforce the provisions hereof. The licensee shall not be required to
provide subscriber information in violation of section 631 of the cable act.
Nothing contained herein shall conflict with the city's duties with regard to
public records as provided by the open records act, 51 Oklahoma Statutes
section 24A.1 et seq. (1994 Code § 9-21)
7-9C-2: INSPECTION OF INSTALLATIONS:
Upon reasonable notice and at a reasonably convenient time, and in a manner
which does not unreasonably interfere with the normal business operation of the
licensee or the cable system, the city shall have the right to inspect the
licensee's facilities and equipment and to perform tests as the city deems
necessary to ensure compliance with the terms of the license and this chapter.
The city may inspect the licensee's testing equipment and, in conjunction with
the licensee, use the licensee's testing equipment in making these tests. (1994
Code § 9-22)
7-9C-3: RECORDS MAINTAINED:
   A.   Types Of Records Maintained: In addition to other records that it may
be required to maintain, the licensee shall maintain records of the following:
      1.   Records of outages, indicating date, duration, area, percentage of
subscribers affected, type of outage and cause. The licensee's monthly outage
report, in a form acceptable to the city.
      2.   Records of service calls for repair and maintenance, indicating date
and time service was requested, date of acknowledgment, date and time service
was scheduled (if it was scheduled), the date and time service was provided
(and, if different), and the date and time the problem was solved. The
licensee's service call log, in a form acceptable to the city.
      3.   Records of installation/reconnection and requests for service
extension, indicating date of request, date of acknowledgment, and date and
time service was extended. The installer/technician field log, amended to show
the date and installation/reconnection or extension request is received and
completed, in a form acceptable to the city.
      4.   Records of complaints, indicating date complaint received, nature of
complaint, resolution of complaint, and date of resolution. The combination of
the service call log, verbal complaint log and licensee's file of written
complaints and responses, in forms acceptable to the city.
   B.   Records Available For City Review: The records shall be kept at the
licensee's local office and shall be available for city review and copying
during normal business hours. The parties shall cooperate to amend requirements
under this section so that the city has access to information to evaluate the
licensee's compliance with the license and so that the licensee may amend its
forms as its services evolve. (1994 Code § 9-23)
7-9C-4: REPORTS PREPARED:
The licensee shall provide the following reports:
   A.   Subscribers: An annual report stating subscriber totals for each
category of service, the number of subscribers added and the number
disconnecting.
   B.   System Extensions: An annual report showing the number of system
extensions and the nature of and estimated costs associated with capital
improvements to the system.
   C.   Service Calls: A monthly summary showing the number of service calls
received by type and the percentage of service calls compared to the subscriber
base.
   D.   Outages: An annual summary of the number of outages, number of planned
outages, and the best estimate of the duration of these outages. (1994 Code §
9-24)
7-9C-5: DOCUMENTS PROVIDED:
   A.   Documents Required: Except as otherwise provided, the licensee shall
provide, upon request, the following documents to the city:
      1.   The annual report, if any, of licensee, or each affiliate of
licensee which controls licensee and issues an annual report.
      2.   Copyright filings reflecting the operation of the Enid system.
      3.   FCC forms 325 and 395, or their successor forms, for the Enid
system.
      4.   Any filing made at the FCC, or any state or federal agency regarding
the Enid system, its proof of performance tests, or its RF signal leakage
tests.
      5.   Any request for protection under bankruptcy laws, or any judgment
related to a declaration of bankruptcy. The request shall be provided to the
city on the same date it is filed.
   B.   Notify City Of Investigations Or Criminal Proceedings: Within five (5)
business days of the date any of the following are received on the licensee's
behalf, the following shall be provided to the city: any notice of deficiency,
forfeiture, or other document issued by any state or federal agency instituting
any investigation or civil or criminal proceeding regarding the cable system,
licensee, or any affiliate of licensee, to the extent the same may affect or
bear on operations in Enid. (1994 Code § 9-25)
7-9C-6: OBLIGATION TO RELEASE:
The licensee shall take all reasonable steps required, if any, to provide the
city with all information which must be provided or may be requested pursuant
to this chapter, including, by providing appropriate subscriber privacy
notices. Nothing in this chapter shall be read to require the licensee to
violate 47 USC section 551. (1994 Code § 9-26)
7-9C-7: MAPS AND PLATS:
   A.   Strand Map: The licensee shall prepare, at its sole expense, a strand
map, showing the actual location of its existing poles, wires, cable lines, and
conduits within the city on digital data compatible with auto CAD for the
purposes permitted by this chapter. The map, along with copies of the plans and
specifications for the upgrade of the cable system, shall be filed with the
city engineer within three (3) months of the effective date of this chapter. A
new map will be filed with the city within sixty (60) days of the completion of
any segment of the upgrade. The licensee, upon request of the city, shall make
available for review at the local office of the licensee, a detailed cable
system map.
   B.   Map Of New Facilities: After completion of any segment of the upgrade,
and before the commencement of any new construction of any sort which would
alter the location of licensee's facilities in that segment, the licensee shall
maintain on file a map or maps showing the proposed location of its new
facilities and plans and specifications for construction, subject to the
approval of the city engineer, before construction. Within sixty (60) days of
their completion, the licensee shall file with the city engineer, a complete
and true copy of a map. The licensee shall not be required to file revised
maps, for any segment of the cable system more frequently than once in each
calendar year, once the initial map has been filed with the city. (1994 Code §
9-27)
7-9C-8: REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION:
The licensee shall respond to reasonable written inquiries from the city
concerning the construction, operation, installation, or maintenance of the
cable system, plans for its expansion, or the licensee's financial or legal
status. The licensee shall provide the information requested within thirty (30)
days of request. Requests for extensions of time to respond shall not be
unreasonably denied. (1994 Code § 9-26)
7-9C-9: TESTING:
   A.   Based On Investigation: When, based on investigation, the city has
reasonable questions concerning the reliability or technical quality of the
cable system, the city may require the licensee to perform tests and prepare a
report showing: 1) the nature of the city's question which precipitated the
test; 2) the cable system component or area tested; 3) the equipment and
procedures used; 4) any conclusions drawn from the tests; and 5) other
information pertinent to understanding the test. If the city requires more than
two (2) tests per calendar year under this subsection, and any such additional
test demonstrates that the licensee has substantially complied with the
material provisions hereof, the cost of any additional test(s) shall be borne
by the city.
   B.   Based On Complaints: When, based on multiple subscriber complaints, the
city has questions concerning the reliability or technical quality of the cable
system and when the licensee can provide no satisfactory explanation for such
complaints, the city may require the licensee to perform tests and prepare a
report showing: 1) the nature of the subscriber complaint which precipitated
the test; 2) the system component or area tested; 3) the equipment and
procedures used; 4) any conclusions drawn from the tests; and 5) other
information pertinent to understanding the test. (1994 Code § 9-27)
7-9C-10: PERIODIC REVIEWS:
   A.   Review Of System Service: During the year which commences on the fifth
anniversary of December 31, 1996, and every five (5) years thereafter, the city
may commence a review of the cable system to determine the technological and
economic feasibility of incorporating compression and high definition
technology into the design for the purpose of identifying future cable system
community needs and interests, including channel capacity and customer service,
and reviewing the licensee's performance during the proceeding five (5) year
period; to review customer service standards; to review PEG use channel
capacity; to review licensee's cable system design; and, if the FCC rules and
regulations are eliminated and not replaced, to review such technological
standards as may be necessary.
   B.   Hearings: The city shall conduct public hearings to provide the
licensee and the public the opportunity to comment on the issues which are to
be considered in this five (5) year review, and shall consider whether a change
in the licensing requirements is appropriate to meet the reasonable cable
related needs and interests of the community, considering the costs of meeting
those needs and interests.
   C.   Renegotiation Terms Of Chapter: Upon completion of any five (5) year
review provided for in this section, the licensee and the city shall meet,
confer and, if agreed to by both parties, renegotiate in good faith the terms
and conditions of this licensing chapter relating to the other items as listed
in subsection A of this section. (1994 Code § 9-30)
7-9C-11: UNREASONABLE REQUESTS:
If the licensee believes the information requested under this article is not
related to the city's enforcement or the city's right, or the licensee's
obligations under this license, chapter or applicable law, it may seek
appropriate protection from a court of competent jurisdiction, but may not
refuse to produce such information absent an appropriate order. (1994 Code § 9-
31)
ARTICLE D.  PERFORMANCE GUARANTIES; REMEDIES; TERMINATION
SECTION:
7-9D-1: Bonds Required
7-9D-2: Security Fund
7-9D-3: Noncompliance; Penalties For Damages
7-9D-4: Termination Or Revocation Of License; Reasons
7-9D-5: Procedures For Termination And Forfeiture
7-9D-6: Continuity Of Service; Right To Purchase
7-9D-7: Notification Of Options
7-9D-8: Effect Of Bond Limitations
7-9D-9: Notice Of Termination To City
7-9D-1: BONDS REQUIRED:
   A.   Construction Bond:
      1.   During the period of the cable system upgrade as provided for in
section
7-9B-1 of this chapter, the licensee shall secure a construction bond in favor
of the city in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00),
which shall be available to ensure the completion upgrade and of the licensee's
obligations thereunder.
      2.   A copy of such construction bond shall be supplied to the city, in a
form acceptable to the city attorney, prior to the commencement of the upgrade
or within sixty (60) days of the date of this chapter, whichever comes first.
      3.   The construction bond may be terminated by the licensee only upon
notification to the city that the upgrade has been satisfactorily completed
consistent with the requirements of section
7-9B-1 of this chapter.
   B.   Performance Bond:
      1.   On or before the effective date of this agreement, the licensee
shall supply to the city a performance bond in the amount of ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) to ensure the payment of all sums that the licensee may be
obligated to pay the city from its exercise of any privilege or right herein
granted.
      2.   A "guarantee in lieu of bond" may be provided by guarantor Tele-
Communications, Inc., instead of the performance bond, and such guarantee will
likewise ensure payment up to ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). (1994 Code §
9-32)
7-9D-2: SECURITY FUND:
   A.   City Drawing On Fund; Notify Licensee: During the term of the license,
the licensee shall deposit with the city a security fund in the amount of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00), which shall be provided in cash or in the form of
an irrevocable letter of credit or other instrument acceptable to the city. At
least thirty (30) days prior to drawing on the fund, the city shall provide
written notice to the licensee of the reason it intends to draw on the fund and
the amount of known damages, so that the licensee may take steps to cure any
noncompliance. No funds shall be withdrawn by the city where any such
noncompliance and identified damages resulting from noncompliance are incurred
by the licensee prior to the end of the thirty (30) day period or such extended
period as the city may agree.
   B.   Replenish Fund: The licensee shall replenish the security fund within
ten (10) days of the date of the city mailing the licensee written notice
stating: 1) that money has been withdrawn from the fund; 2) the amount of the
withdrawal; and 3) the reason for the withdrawal. (1994 Code § 9-33)
7-9D-3: NONCOMPLIANCE; PENALTIES FOR DAMAGES:
   A.   Liquidated Damages: Because the licensee's failure to comply with
provisions of this license and chapter will result in injury to the city, and
because it will be difficult to estimate the extent of such injury, in certain
cases the city and licensee hereby agree to the following liquidated damages,
which represent both parties' best estimate of the damages resulting from the
specified injury.
      1.   For failure to substantially complete construction in accordance
with the license: $100.00/day for each day the violation continues;
      2.   For failure to comply with requirements for public, educational, and
government use of system: $100.00/day for each day the violation continues;
      3.   For repeated, wilful, or continuing violation of customer service
standards: $100.00 per violation;
      4.   For all other material violations for which actual damages may not
be ascertainable: $100.00/day for each day the violation continues.
   B.   Payment Of Damages: The payment of any such damages shall not relieve
the licensee of its obligation to comply with the license. The subscriber rates
and charges imposed by the licensee shall not be increased or affected, either
directly or indirectly, by reason of any payment licensee may be required to
make pursuant to this section. (1994 Code § 9-34)
7-9D-4: TERMINATION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; REASONS:
The license shall terminate on December 31, 2011, or may be revoked, for the
following reasons, subject to the provisions of section
7-9D-5 of this article:
   A.   For any wilful violation of any material provision of the license or
this chapter;
   B.   If the licensee is adjudicated bankrupt, or if any other license
required under state or federal law to provide cable service in the city is
revoked;
   C.   For any attempt to evade any material provision of the license or this
chapter, or practicing any fraud or deceit upon cable system subscribers or the
city. (1994 Code § 9-35)
7-9D-5: PROCEDURES FOR TERMINATION AND FORFEITURE:
   A.   Notice To Licensee: The city shall notify the licensee in writing of
the alleged violation which may warrant termination, under section
7-9D-4 of this article, which notice shall:
      1.   Describe the specific alleged violation(s);
      2.   Direct the licensee to correct or to show cause why the alleged
violation(s) should not be corrected; and
      3.   State the time for response which shall be no less than thirty (30)
days from the date licensee receives such written notice.
   B.   Remedial Action: Within the time designated, the licensee must:
      1.   Cure the violation(s) or, in the event the violation(s) cannot be
completely cured within the time period specified, take reasonable steps to
begin to cure, and submit a written response to the city, identifying the
specific steps taken; or
      2.   Contest the assertion of violation(s), describing all facts relevant
to the claim, supported by affidavits and documents.
   C.   Notice Of Hearing In Case Of Default: If the licensee contests the
city's assertion of violation(s), or fails to completely cure the alleged
default, including paying any damages owed, unless waived, the city shall
schedule a hearing to review the alleged default. The city shall cause to be
served upon such licensee, at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date of
such hearing, a written notice of the city's intent to review; specify if
termination is sought as a remedy; and state the time and place of the meeting,
