administrative notice will be mailed to the industrial user. The user must
immediately resample the questionable result and submit the analysis within
thirty (30) days of violation awareness. If the second analysis indicates a
violation has occurred, a notice of violation (NOV) will be issued to said
user.
   C.   Notice Of Violation:
      1.   Whenever the environmental compliance specialist finds that any user
is in violation of this article, the environmental compliance specialist may
serve upon said user a written notice of violation (NOV) by certified mail,
return receipt requested. The user must, within five (5) working days of the
receipt of this notice, submit to the environmental compliance specialist an
explanation of the violation and its intended course of corrective action,
including the estimated date by which corrective action will be completed, and
a plan to prevent further violations. After receipt of this response, the
environmental compliance specialist will periodically inspect and monitor the
corrective action taken by the user. The environmental compliance specialist
may grant reasonable extensions to the deadline date. The financial condition
of the user shall not be considered in establishing deadlines or extensions.
      2.   Submission of this plan in no way relieves the user of liability for
any violations occurring before or after the receipt of the notice of violation
(NOV), nor does this section limit the authority of the city to take any
action, including emergency action, without first issuing a notice of
violation.
      3.   If the user fails to respond to a notice of violation within the
required time period, or if the user fails to complete the corrective action by
the deadline, this failure constitutes a separate violation under this article,
and the city shall use the enforcement response plan to determine the
appropriate response. (1994 Code §§ 34-132.1, 34-132.2, 34-132.3)
8-3H-4: AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES:
   A.   Supporting Evidence: An industrial user who complies with the
notification provisions of section
8-3A-11 of this chapter in a timely manner shall have an affirmative defense to
any enforcement action brought by the city for any noncompliance with this
article or permit issued to the user due to noxious, malodorous or toxic
liquids, gases, vapors, fumes or solids if properly signed operational logs or
other relative evidence shows that: 1) an upset occurred and the user can
identify the causes of the upset; and 2) the facility was being operated in a
prudent and workmanlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and
maintenance procedures.
   B.   Burden Of Proof: In any enforcement proceeding, the industrial user
seeking to establish the occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof.
(1994 Code § 34-133)
8-3H-5: REMEDIES BY USERS; CITY ACTION UPON NONCOMPLIANCE:
   A.   Consent Orders: The environmental compliance specialist is hereby
authorized to enter into consent orders with any user responsible for
noncompliance. Such orders will include the specific action to be taken by the
user to correct the noncompliance within a time period also specified by the
order. Consent orders shall have the same force and effect as administrative
orders issued pursuant to subsections B and C of this section and shall be
judicially enforceable.
   B.   Compliance Schedule:
      1.   If additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance will be
required of the user to meet the pretreatment standards, a compliance schedule
will be developed by the environmental compliance specialist for the user. A
compliance schedule may be made a part of a consent order, an administrative
order or a ruling of the environmental enforcement board. The user shall meet
the shortest schedule by which to provide all such additional pretreatment.
      2.   The completion date in this schedule shall not be later than the
completion date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. The
following conditions shall apply to this schedule:
         a.   The schedule shall contain increments of progress in the form of
dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the
construction and operation or additional pretreatment required for the user to
meet the applicable pretreatment standards.
         b.   No increment referred to in this section shall exceed nine (9)
months.
         c.   No later than fourteen (14) days following each compliance date,
the user shall submit a progress report to the environmental compliance
specialist, and a final report must be submitted within fourteen (14) days from
the final compliance date as well.
         d.   The report should include, at a minimum, whether or not it
complied with the increment of progress to be met on such date. If it did not
comply, the report must contain the date on which it expects to comply with
this increment of progress, the reason for delay, and the steps being taken by
the user to return the construction to the schedule established.
      3.   Compliance schedules may also contain other requirements to address
the noncompliance, including additional self-monitoring, and management
practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants discharged to the
sewer.
      4.   A compliance schedule shall not be a prerequisite for taking any
other action against the user.
   C.   Cease And Desist Orders:
      1.   When the environmental compliance specialist finds that a user is in
violation of this article, or based upon the user's past history, similar
violations are likely to reoccur, the environmental compliance specialist may
issue an order to the user directing it to cease and desist all such
violations. A cease and desist order may require the user to:
         a.   Immediately comply with all requirements; and/or
         b.   Take such appropriate remedial or preventive action as may be
needed to properly address a continuing or threatened violation up to and
including halting operations and/or terminating the discharge.
      2.   Issuance of a cease and desist order shall not be a prerequisite to
taking any other action against the user.
   D.   Cost Recovery: Any user violating any of the provisions of this article
or who causes damage to or otherwise inhibits the POTW, shall be assessed by
the environmental compliance specialist the amount of any expense, loss, or
damage which was proximately caused by such violation or discharge. These costs
may include sampling and monitoring expenses and the cost of any actual damages
incurred by the city or the POTW. The environmental compliance specialist shall
bill the user for the cost incurred by the city for any cleaning, repair, or
replacement work and enforcement costs caused by the violation or discharge.
This bill is in addition to any criminal penalty applicable under this article.
   E.   Emergency Suspension:
      1.   The environmental compliance specialist may immediately suspend a
user's discharge into the POTW and/or wastewater discharge permit whenever such
suspension is necessary in order to stop an actual or threatened discharge
which reasonably appears to present an imminent or substantial endangerment to
the health or welfare of persons, to the environment, or threatens to cause
interference with the POTW, the waters of the state, or threatens to result in
a violation of the city's NPDES permit. Any user notified of a suspension of
its discharge shall immediately stop or eliminate its contribution.
      2.   In the event of a user's failure to immediately comply voluntarily
with the suspension order, the environmental compliance specialist shall take
such steps as deemed necessary, (to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW, the
waters of the state or endangerment to any individuals) to include: revocation
of the permit, termination of discharge or immediate water supply severance.
      3.   A user that is responsible in whole or in part for any discharge
presenting imminent endangerment shall submit a detailed written statement
describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to
prevent any further occurrence to the environmental compliance specialist
within fifteen (15) days of the date of the order of emergency suspension.
      4.   Nothing in this subsection shall be interpreted as requiring a
hearing or formal notice prior to any emergency suspension order.
      5.   The environmental compliance specialist will lift the emergency
suspension when the user has demonstrated that the period of endangerment has
passed.
   F.   Revocation Of Permit: Any user who violates the following conditions is
subject to having their permit revoked:
      1.   Failure of a user to factually report the wastewater constituents
and characteristics of their discharge;
      2.   Failure of the user to report significant changes in operations;
      3.   Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose
of inspection and monitoring;
      4.   Violation of conditions of the permit; or
      5.   Failure to pay cost recovery, administrative penalty, or to perform
specific remedies such as posting performance bonds.
   G.   Termination Of Discharge Into City Sewer System: The wastewater
discharge into the city's sewer system by industrial users may be terminated
for any of the following reasons:
      1.   Falsifying self-monitoring reports concerning wastewater
constituents and characteristics of the discharge.
      2.   Tampering with monitoring equipment.
      3.   Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater
volume, constituents and characteristics prior to the discharge.
      4.   Refusing to allow timely access to the facility, premises, and
records.
      5.   Violation of wastewater discharge permit conditions.
      6.   Failure to meet effluent limitations.
      7.   Failure to pay penalties, fines and/or cost recovery.
      8.   Failure to pay sewer charges.
      9.   Failure to meet compliance schedules.
   H.   Water Supply Severance: Whenever a user has violated the provisions of
this article, orders or wastewater discharge permits, water service to the user
may be severed. Service will only recommence at the user's expense, after the
user has satisfactorily complied with all the requirements assessed against
such user by the city. (1994 Code §§ 34-134.1, 34-134.2, 34-134.3, 34-134.4,
34-134.5, 34-134.6, 34-134.7, 34-134.8)
8-3H-6: APPEALS FROM ORDERS OF CITY; HEARING PROCEDURE:
If said user disputes the appropriateness of the enforcement response of the
environmental compliance specialist, or the validity of the violation, the user
may request an administrative hearing before the public utilities director to
review said order. The request must be in writing and must specify the reasons
for appeal. It must be filed with the city clerk within fifteen (15) days from
receipt of the appealed from order.
   A.   Administrative Hearing:
      1.   Whenever any user causes or contributes to a violation of this
article and the environmental compliance specialist determines that the
appropriate enforcement response includes revocation of a permit, termination
of discharge or water supply severance, and the situation does not rise to the
level of an emergency suspension, the environmental compliance specialist will
issue an order requiring the user to appear before the public utilities
director and show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be
taken.
         a.   Notice shall be served on the user specifying the time and place
for the meeting, the proposed enforcement action and the reason for such
action. The notice of the meeting shall be served personally or by certified
mail, return receipt requested, at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing.
Such notice may be served on any authorized representative of the user.
         b.   Whether or not the user appears as ordered, immediate enforcement
action may be pursued following the hearing date.
         c.   An administrative hearing shall not be a prerequisite for taking
any other action against the user.
      2.   Administrative hearings will also be held when a user appeals an
order of the environmental compliance specialist.
   B.   Appeals From Administrative Hearings:
      1.   If said user disputes the administrative order made by the public
utilities director at an administrative hearing, it may appeal to the
environmental enforcement board by filing a written request with the city clerk
within fifteen (15) days from the administrative hearing. The user must state
in its written request the finding objected to, the reason for said appeal, and
the alternative it seeks.
      2.   Whether the user disputes the appropriateness of the enforcement
response or the validity of the violation, or both, an appeal bond equal to the
amount of any and all monetary penalties assessed, or if none are assessed, in
the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) must accompany said appeal
request.
      3.   Failure to submit a petition for review shall be deemed to be a
waiver of the appeal. (1994 Code §§ 34-135, 34-135.1, 34-135.2)
8-3H-7: PERFORMANCE BOND TO GUARANTEE COMPLIANCE:
   A.   Bond May Be Required: The environmental compliance specialist, public
utilities director, or environmental enforcement board may require the posting
of a performance bond prior to the lifting of a suspension order, reissuing a
wastewater discharge permit, or reconnecting the water supply or sewer service.
   B.   Bond Amount: The bond is to be payable to the city in a sum not to
exceed a value determined by the city to be necessary to achieve consistent
compliance and to protect or restore or repair damage to the POTW caused by
similar violations. (1994 Code § 34-136)
8-3H-8: LEGAL ACTIONS:
   A.   Injunctive Relief And Civil Penalties: Whenever a user has violated a
pretreatment standard or requirement or continues to violate the provisions of
this article, wastewater discharge permits or orders issued hereunder, or any
other pretreatment requirement, the city may seek a temporary or permanent
injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific performance
of the wastewater discharge permit, order, or other requirement imposed by this
article on activities of the industrial user. Such other action as appropriate
for legal and/or equitable relief may also be sought by the city, including any
action for damages, reasonable attorney fees, court costs, and other expenses
associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring
expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred by the city.
   B.   Remedies Nonexclusive: The provisions of this article are not exclusive
remedies. The city reserves the right to take any, all, or any combination of
these actions against a noncompliant user. The city's enforcement responses
will generally be in accordance with the city's enforcement response plan.
However, the city reserves the right to take other action against any user when
the circumstances warrant, to include pursuit of civil litigation in state,
district and/or federal courts for damages, injunctive relief and/or specific
performance. (1994 Code § 34-137)
8-3H-9: CRIMINAL ACTIONS AND PENALTIES:
   A.   Violations: Any user that wilfully or negligently violates any
provision of this article, any orders or wastewater discharge permits issued
hereunder, or any other pretreatment requirement shall, upon conviction, be
guilty of a class D offense, punishable by a fine of not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) per violation per day.
   B.   Allowing Harmful Substances Into POTW: Any user that wilfully or
negligently introduces any substance into the POTW which causes personal injury
or property damage shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a class D offense,
punishable by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
violation per day.
   C.   Falsifying Information:
      1.   No person shall knowingly make any false statements. False
statements include oral communications to city officials and/or statements,
representations or certifications in any application, record, report, plan, or
other documentation filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this
article.
      2.   No person shall knowingly tamper with or knowingly render inaccurate
any monitoring device or method required under this article.
      3.   The violation of this subsection shall be a class D offense,
punishable by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
violation per day.
   D.   Vandalism:
      1.   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently
break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, tamper with, or prevent access to, any
structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the POTW.
      2.   The violation of this subsection shall be a class D offense,
punishable by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per
violation per day.
   E.   Separate Offense For Each Day: Each day on which a violation occurs
shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense.
   F.   Considerations For Assessing Penalty: The penalties will be assessed on
an incremental basis at the sole discretion of the assessor and will take into
consideration the nature of the violation, the good faith of the user, the
compliance history of the user, and the effect of the violation on the POTW or
the waters of the state, as well as any other relevant factors. (1994 Code §
34-138)
CHAPTER 4
SOLID WASTE
SECTION:
8-4-1: Definitions
8-4-2: Mandatory Use Of Service; Exception
8-4-3: Collection Agency
8-4-4: Fees, Billing For Refuse Collection And Container Rental
8-4-5: Precollection Practices
8-4-6: Garbage And Rubbish Containers
8-4-7: Storing Trash
8-4-8: Collection Of Yard Trimmings And Refuse
8-4-9: Residential Solid Waste; Disposition
8-4-10: Removal Of Construction Materials
8-4-11: Use Of Another's Trash Container
8-4-12: Request For Exemption From Use Of Service
8-4-13: Sanitary Landfill; Permit; Fees; Restrictions
8-4-14: Penalty
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall be defined as follows:
ALLEY: A narrow passage or way, not designed to be a street or highway,
intersecting a block or tract of land, and so designated on a plat of record or
established by prescription and used primarily for the accommodation of the
abutting or adjoining property.
AUTHORIZED PRIVATE RECEPTACLE: A litter storage and collection receptacle.
CARRYOUT SERVICE: Service from a point of collection at ground level not more
than seventy five feet (75') from the street from which collection is made and
not obstructed by gates, fences, enclosed porches, garages or similar
enclosures. "Carryout service" shall not include service from alleys.
CHARGING UNIT: A. Each occupied single-family dwelling.
   B.   Each unit designed to be occupied and used by one or more persons for
living and cooking together in a multiple-family dwelling or apartment or
apartment hotel.
   C.   Each licensed lot or space for a mobile home or trailer coach in a
mobile home park or in a trailer court.
   D.   Each commercial establishment or premises other than subsection B or C
of this definition.
COMMERCIAL HANDBILL: Any printed or written matter, any sample or device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or
otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature:
   A.   Which advertises for sale any merchandise, produce, commodity, or
thing; or
   B.   Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial
establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or
indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or
   C.   Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical
performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is
charged for the purpose of private gain or profit.
CURBSIDE SERVICE: Service from a point of collection adjacent to and along the
curb or pavement edge of a paved street or adjacent to, and on the street side
of, a roadside ditch of unimproved streets, from which collection is made;
except however, the container shall not interfere with the free movement of
traffic. "Curbside service" shall not include service from alleys.
DISABLED PERSON: An adult person having a physical impairment which prevents
said individual from meeting the physical requirements for curbside service,
i.e., unable to carry the bags to the street.
GARBAGE: Putrescible, animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and consumption of food.
HOUSEHOLD HAZARDOUS WASTE: Hazardous waste that is used in the home and is
generally of one of these varieties: paints/lacquers, pesticides/herbicides,
automotive products, or household cleaners. Any waste that is flammable,
corrosive, reactive, or toxic will be considered hazardous.
LITTER: "Garbage", "refuse", and "rubbish" as defined herein and all other
waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to
create a danger to public health, safety and welfare.
NEWSPAPER: Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any
newspaper duly entered with the post office department of the United States, in
accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and
recorded with any recording officer as provided by general laws and, in
addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine
regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to
the public.
NONCOMMERCIAL HANDBILL: Printed or written matter, any sample, or device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or
any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of
literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a "commercial handbill"
or "newspaper".
POLYCART: A rollout cart (90 to 105 gallons) used for curbside automated waste
and recycling collection which is made out of stress free molding technology
known as advanced rotational molding.
PRIVATE PREMISES: Any dwelling house, building, or other structure designed or
used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether
inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall
include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox
belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling house, building, or other structure.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other
public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and
buildings.
REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes),
including garbage, rubbish, ashes, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and
solid market and industrial wastes.
RUBBISH: Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin
cans, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
the purpose of vehicular travel.
TRASH: Shall extend to the widest sense of that term, and includes, but without
limitation upon any other meaning, refuse, litter, ashes, leaves, debris,
paper, combustible materials, offal, rubbish, waste, and useless or uncared for
matter of all kinds, whether solid or liquid in form.
TREE TRIMMING: Large, heavy trimmings resulting from pruning or shrub removal
if branches or trunks do not exceed four inches (4") in diameter.
VEHICULAR: Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may
be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon
stationary rails or tracks.
YARD TRIMMINGS: Those materials generated while providing normal maintenance to
the yard area adjacent to a single-family residential unit. This shall include
grass and weed trimmings, leaves and garden wastes, in addition to other items
related to maintenance of other landscaping, but shall not include tree
trimmings, rocks, gravel or dirt. (Ord. 2009-28, 12-1-2009)
8-4-2: MANDATORY USE OF SERVICE; EXCEPTION:
   A.   Use Required: Except as herein otherwise authorized, all noncommercial
refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by
the city, and not by any other person.
   B.   Roll-Off Exemption: The prohibition against collection of refuse by
persons other than the city does not apply to "roll- offs", defined as twenty
(20), thirty (30) or forty (40) cubic yard containers. (1994 Code §§ 34-156,
34-167)
8-4-3: COLLECTION AGENCY:
All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of
by the city under the supervision of the solid waste department, which shall
have the authority to make regulations concerning the days of collection, type
and location of waste containers and such other matters pertaining to the
collection, conveyance and disposal as it shall find necessary, and to change
and modify the same; provided, that such regulations are not contrary to the
provisions of this chapter. (1994 Code § 34-157)
8-4-4: FEES, BILLING FOR REFUSE COLLECTION AND CONTAINER RENTAL:
   A.   Dwelling Units: The monthly fee for collection and disposal of garbage
and rubbish placed in the polycart for curbside service from dwelling units
shall be as provided in section
2-6E-8 of this code. The monthly fee for collection and disposal of garbage and
rubbish placed in the polycart for carryout service from dwelling units shall
be as provided in section
2-6E-8 of this code.
   B.   Additional Dwelling Units: Residential customers may make a request for
the placement of additional polycarts. The monthly fee for the additional
polycarts shall be as provided in section
2-6E-8 of this code. The request for additional polycarts shall be subject to
the following:
      1.   Additional polycarts shall require a minimum placement period of six
(6) months.
      2.   Requests for pick up/removal of additional polycarts during the
minimum placement period shall be subject to a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00)
per additional polycart.
   C.   Commercial Units: The monthly fee for collection and disposal of
garbage and rubbish for charging (commercial) units shall be as established in
section
2-6E-8 of this code.
   D.   Contacts; Variance From Minimum Fee: When commercial refuse
accumulations require collection other than prescribed in subsection C of this
section, the charge for such collections shall be as provided in subsection 2-
6E-8D of this code, and the owner or occupant of the premises requesting this
extra service shall be responsible for the additional charges.
   E.   Container Rental Rates: Appropriate rental rates for city provided
containers shall be determined by the public works department and billed
monthly to the user in addition to monthly collection charges. The rental rate
for containers shared by more than one charging unit will be proportioned by
the number of charging units sharing such container. Said charge shall reflect
the capital and maintenance cost amortized over the life of the container.
   F.   Carryout Service:
      1.   Carryout service shall be provided for the disabled person if such
individual provides certification to the finance director that he/she is the
head of household and provides documentation from a recognized agency (social
security, veterans administration) private insurance company, pension fund or
other disability documentation acceptable to the finance director and further
certifies that no other person or member of the household is physically capable
of placing the container for curbside service and further certifies the address
where the applicant resides. If such documentation is approved by the director
of finance, the applicant will receive carryout service at curbside rates.
      2.   Any person making a false or incorrect certification shall be guilty
of an offense and shall further be liable for the monthly charges for carryout
service for the prior months the person received such service at curbside
rates. Certifications must be renewed on July 1 of each year.
      3.   Carryout service shall not be provided for persons who have not
complied with subsection F1 of this section.
   G.   Curbside Service: Every person occupying or having control of the
occupancy of any private premises located on a regularly established refuse
route shall be presumed to have requested and authorized curbside service and
shall be billed for such service, regardless of whether the service was
provided by the city, unless such person makes a written request for carryout
service from the customer service department on an authorized city form prior
to July 1, 1983, or any subsequent monthly billing cycle, and provides
documentation required by subsection F1 of this section.
   H.   Charging Units: Every person occupying or having control of the
occupancy of any charging units located on a regularly established refuse route
shall notify the customer service department the beginning of such occupancy
and request refuse pick up service; however, the failure of any owner, rental
agent, or occupant of such premises to make such request shall not prevent in
any way, impair or impede the solid waste superintendent from adding the
address of such premises to the proper refuse collection route records
providing said service, enforcing by appropriate action the regulatory measures
herein prescribed, and causing the fee or charge therefor to be paid. Any place
of abode or residence, or any other place or business occupied and/or in
operation shall be prima facie evidence that garbage, refuse and/or trash is
being produced and accumulated in such premises.
   I.   Change In Method Of Collection: No person receiving curbside or
carryout service shall be allowed to change to the alternate method of service
for a period of six (6) months after the initial service is requested or
provided, unless said person relocates to another address. However, the city
manager may exempt persons from this provision based on a physical impairment
arising or when the effective and orderly public service is not substantially
affected by the change. Any change in the method of collection hereinabove
allowed will begin on the first day of the month following the month the change
is requested.
   J.   Billing On Water Statement:
      1.   Refuse collection charges shall be billed on the water statements
and shall become due and payable on the same date and time, at the customer
services department of the city, where water bills are rendered, but shall be
shown as a separate item from the water charge or the sewer service charge.
      2.   The customer service department shall not accept payment for refuse
collection charges without payment of the water bill, nor shall it accept
payment of the water bill without a payment for refuse collection charges,
except where the city has not made city water available to a user of city
refuse collection service; provided, however, that the customer shall have the
right to contest and opportunity to be heard concerning the bill with the
customer service department under this section.
   K.   Delinquency; Penalty; Discontinuance Of Service:
      1.   A customer failing to pay the refuse collection charge within ten
(10) days from the date the charge becomes due shall be charged a late payment
penalty of ten percent (10%) in addition to the regular bill; and if not paid
within thirty (30) days after such refuse collection bill becomes due, such
delinquency shall be cause for immediate discontinuing or disconnecting of the
water connection or refuse collection service or both.
      2.   Penalties, charges and fees shall be paid before either or both the
refuse collection service and water service are reestablished. The stoppage of
services for nonpayment of collection charges shall be in addition to the right
of the city to proceed for the collection of unpaid charges through legal
action. (Ord. 2009-28, 12-1-2009; amd. Ord. 2010-12, 11-16-2010, eff. 1-1-2011)
8-4-5: PRECOLLECTION PRACTICES:
   A.   Garbage And Rubbish: All garbage and rubbish, excluding household
hazardous waste, being placed in containers for collection shall have drained
from it all free liquids and shall be deposited in the polycart(s) provided by
the city of Enid. All hypodermic needles shall be protected by either the
original cap or by the use of cardboard or styrofoam sufficient in size to
completely cover the length of the needle. Broken glass shall be placed in a
box or securely wrapped in sufficient layers of paper to prevent contact during
the trash collection process.
   B.   Tree Trimmings: All tree trimmings, hedge clippings and similar
material shall be cut to lengths not to exceed four feet (4') and separately
tied in bundles not more than two feet (2') thick before being deposited for
collection. Tree trimmings shall not be placed in the polycart. The homeowner
shall notify the city of Enid of the tree trimmings in order to have the refuse
removed. (Ord. 2009-28, 12-1-2009)
8-4-6: GARBAGE AND RUBBISH CONTAINERS:
   A.   Containers Required; Maintenance:
      1.   Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, every person owning,
managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises or any place where garbage
or rubbish accumulates, shall provide and at all times maintain in good order
and repair, on any such premises, a city provided polycart, which shall be used
for the automated waste removal system and shall not be removed from the
premises. It is the resident's responsibility to keep sufficient capacity and
in such sufficient numbers to accommodate and securely keep all the garbage and
rubbish that may accumulate between collections.
      2.   Any polycart that does not conform to the provisions of this chapter
or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or
injure the person collecting the contents thereof shall be replaced with no
cost to the resident.
      3.   Any polycart that is not distributed by the city of Enid will not be
collected.
      4.   The city shall have the authority to refuse collection services for
failure to comply with this chapter.
      5.   All covers or doors shall be kept closed except when depositing
refuse in the container.
      6.   If the container is damaged, the replacement cost of the polycart
shall be determined by the public works department and billed appropriately for
the replacement cost of that container. If the public works department
determines that the owner or resident is not at fault, then the replacement
cost will be engulfed by the public works department.
   B.   Size; Cleanliness:
      1.   Each polycart container shall be provided by the city of Enid and
the contents shall be bagged appropriately.
      2.   All polycart containers shall be kept clean and free from
accumulation of any substance remaining attached to the inside of the container
which would attract or breed flies, mosquitoes or any other biting and/or
stinging insects.
   C.   Plastic Bags:
      1.   Polycart containers shall contain plastic bags securely tied about
the top and of sufficient strength to hold the load when picked up and carried
without supporting the bottom.
      2.   The occupant of the premises shall be responsible for providing
plastic bags of sufficient strength and mil thickness to hold and maintain the
contents of the plastic bag, and the city shall not be responsible for the
cleaning of trash and garbage resulting from torn and/or ruptured bags
regardless of how the tear or rupture occurred.
   D.   Businesses, Mobile Home Parks:
      1.   Unless otherwise exempted by the public works department, business,
industrial, institutional, and mobile home parks shall utilize containers
provided by the city and shall be of sufficient capacity and/or quantity to
fully contain all refuse accumulated between collection periods.
      2.   All covers or doors shall be kept closed except when depositing
refuse in the container.
      3.   Every person utilizing polycart containers provided by the city
shall have a duty to regularly inspect, secure and notify the city of Enid of
any defect in the container which may by its form, use or location reasonably
cause damage to any person.
      4.   The city shall not be liable for any damage or injury to any person
or property based on any user's failure to inspect, secure or notify the city
of Enid of any defect in the container. This requirement may be satisfied by
giving written notice of such defect to the Public Works Department Director or
his designees.
   E.   Multi-Family Dwellings:
      1.   If it is determined by the Public Works Department that there is a
safe location available and there are containers available multi-family
dwellings of three (3) or four (4) charging units that have a common water
meter and/or combined collection billing may utilize containers provided by the
City and shall be of sufficient capacity and/or quantity to fully contain all
refuse accumulated for once a week pick up at the same cost as residential
trash service.
      2.   All covers or doors shall be kept closed except when depositing
refuse in the container.
      3.   Every person utilizing containers provided by the City shall have a
duty to regularly inspect, secure and correct any defect in the container which
may by its form, use or location reasonably cause damage to any person.
      4.   The City shall not be liable for any damage or injury to any person
or property based on any users' failure to inspect, secure or repair any
container. This requirement may be satisfied by giving written notice of such
defect to the Public Works Department Director or his designees. (Ord. 2009-28,
12-1-2009)
8-4-7: STORING TRASH:
   A.   Placement Of Trash In Containers: No person shall place any trash in
any street, alley, or other public place, on any private property, whether
owned by said person or not, except in proper polycart containers for
collection or under express approval granted by the City, nor shall any person
throw or deposit any trash in any stream or other body of water.
   B.   Placement Of Polycart:
      1.   The container shall be placed at the curb no later than seven thirty
o'clock (7:30) A.M. on the collection day.
      2.   The polycart shall be placed at the edge of the resident's property,
next to the street, wheels above the curb, with the handle facing the
resident's home.
      3.   There must be a minimum of ten feet (10') of clearance from other
containers, parked vehicles, street and lampposts, trees, mailboxes, and other
obstructions.
      4.   The resident must remove the container from the curb or street after
it is emptied.
   C.   Unauthorized Accumulations; Nuisance: Any unauthorized accumulation of
trash on any premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is hereby
prohibited.
   D.   Depositing On Public Ways, Occupied Premises: No person shall cast,
place, sweep or deposit anywhere within the City any trash in such a manner
that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk,
alley, sewer, parkway or other public place, or into any occupied premises.
   E.   Violation: The violations of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus costs, unless the person charged
has been previously convicted once under this section or any of the following
sections of this Code:
4-3-2,
4-4-2,
4-5-8,
4-6-8,
7-7-2, and
9-9-2 in the last five (5) years, then a violation of this section shall be
punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus costs. (Ord.
2018-25, 9-6-2018)
8-4-8: COLLECTION OF YARD TRIMMINGS AND REFUSE:
   A.   Yard Trimmings:
      1.   All yard trimmings shall be placed in the weather resistant clear
plastic bags manufactured for the use of yard waste disposal. Said bags shall
be securely tied about the top and of sufficient strength to hold the load when
picked up and carried without supporting the bottom, except in no case shall
such containers, when filled, weigh more than fifty (50) pounds.
      2.   The occupant of the premises shall be responsible for providing the
appropriate clear plastic bags of sufficient strength to hold and maintain the
contents of the bag and the City shall not be responsible for the cleaning of
debris resulting from torn and/or ruptured bags regardless of how the tear or
rupture occurred.
      3.   Yard trimmings shall be placed within ten feet (10') of the curb of
the street from which collection is made or at the edge of the roadway where
there is no curb.
      4.   If the occupant chooses to recycle yard clippings, the occupant may
contact the city of Enid and rent a grass clipping polycart for which the sole
purpose is to collect only grass clippings. If the occupant puts nongrass items
in the recycling grass clipping polycart, the occupant will lose the privileges
of renting and using the recycling grass polycart.
   B.   Refuse:
      1.   Refuse shall be collected at least once a week in residential areas
and more often as directed by the superintendent of the solid waste department,
and shall be collected from commercial establishments as determined by the
superintendent of the solid waste department.
      2.   The superintendent of the solid waste department shall authorize the
collection of a reasonable accumulation of refuse from each residence during a
collection period for the standard charge of the use of one polycart.
Additional charges for additional refuse shall be in accordance with the rates
for additional polycarts. If other refuse is collected, additional charges for
such amounts will be charged at the discretion of the superintendent of the
solid waste department. The superintendent of the solid waste department shall
have the authority to refuse to collect unreasonable amounts or to make an
additional charge for such amounts.
      3.   The removal of any additional refuse may be arranged by contacting
the superintendent of the solid waste department. The items will then be
appropriately removed. These items shall be placed with at least ten feet (10')
clearance from other containers, parked vehicles, street and lampposts, trees,
mailboxes, and other obstructions.
      4.   The removal of wearing material, bedding or other refuse from homes
or other places where highly infectious or contagious diseases have prevailed
should be performed under the supervision and direction of the superintendent
of the solid waste department. Such refuse shall not be placed in polycart
containers for regular collection.
      5.   Highly inflammable or explosive materials shall not be placed in
polycart containers for regular collection.
      6.   Collectors of refuse from outside the city who desire to haul over
the streets of the city shall use a watertight vehicle so operated as to
prevent offensive odors escaping therefrom and refuse from being blown, dropped
or spilled.
      7.   Ownership of refuse materials set out for collection or deposited in
the city landfill shall be vested in the city. (Ord. 2009-28, 12-1-2009)
8-4-9: RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE; DISPOSITION:
When residential refuse accumulations require collection other than prescribed
in section
8-4-4 of this chapter, such as debris, tree limbs, brush or other materials
other than refuse, roofing materials, and other solid waste created by or as a
result of commercial or contractual work done to or on the site of the
residence, the owner or occupant may notify the solid waste department of the
amount and type of waste and request an extra trash pick up. Charges for such
removal services shall be as provided by section
2-6E-8 of this code. (Ord. 2009-28, 12-1-2009)
8-4-10: REMOVAL OF CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS:
   A.   Solid Waste Container Required: Any person, firm or corporation having
secured a building permit from the city shall furnish and place on said
premises, a solid waste container of suitable size and capacity to contain all
debris which will result from said construction activities. The solid waste
container shall be placed on the building site prior to the accumulation of any
construction debris, or when it is deemed appropriate by the code
administrator.
   B.   Location Within Subdivision: Solid waste containers may be permitted to
be located at a designated location within a subdivision for the purpose of
providing service to multiple building sites; provided, that construction
activity does not result in the accumulation of debris at any one building
site.
   C.   Removal Of Debris; Request City Service: As the container is filled,
the person, firm, or corporation having secured the building permit shall cause
said container to be emptied and its contents removed to an approved sanitary
landfill. Upon request, the city shall provide waste disposal services.
   D.   Authority To Waive Requirements: The code administrator may waive the
requirements of subsection A of this section when such construction activity
shall not result in the storage of any debris outside the confines of the
building or structure.
   E.   Containment Of Refuse: No person, firm, or corporation shall permit any
refuse, rubbish, or any other waste materials to blow or be carried from the
premises for which the building permit has been issued. (1994 Code § 34-164.5)
8-4-11: USE OF ANOTHER'S TRASH CONTAINER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use another person's trash container,
whether the container is furnished by the city or by the individual, without
permission of such other person. (1994 Code § 34-165)
8-4-12: REQUEST FOR EXEMPTION FROM USE OF SERVICE:
Any person living in a residence upon which city water or sewer service is not
available, as defined in sections
8-2-2 and
8-3A-5 of this title, may request an exemption from using the city's solid
waste collection service for such residence. Such exemption request shall be
made in writing to the utility billing department. All persons who qualify
under this section shall be exempt from receiving and paying for the city's
solid waste collection service for such residence. (1994 Code § 34-166)
8-4-13: SANITARY LANDFILL; PERMIT; FEES; RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall dump or deposit any rubbish, material
or property of any kind at the sanitary landfill of the city without first
obtaining a permit.
   B.   Refuse Originating Within City: A permit shall be issued for the
depositing of refuse material or property originating within the city, at the
sanitary landfill upon payment of the fees provided in subsection 2-6C-2A of
this code.
   C.   Refuse Originating Outside City: A permit shall be issued for the
depositing of refuse material or property originating outside the city, at the
sanitary landfill, upon payment of the fees provided in subsection 2-6C-2B of
this code.
   D.   Unsecured Loads: An additional fee will be paid by any user entering
the sanitary landfill of the city with a vehicle containing an unsecured load,
as provided in subsection 2-6C-2C of this code. A load is unsecured when
material hauled is susceptible to blowing, dropping, leaking or otherwise
escaping from said vehicles. Particular loads that will be considered
unsecured, unless adequately covered or secured, are:
      1.   Construction and demolition materials or byproducts;
      2.   Yard wastes including tree limbs, brush, grass and leaves;
      3.   Roofing materials; and/or
      4.   Cardboard, paper and other lightweight materials.
      5.   Unsecured trash bags subject to blowing off of a vehicle.
   E.   Yard And Tree Trimmings Originating Within City:
      1.   A waiver on the landfill permit fee for the depositing of loads
containing yard and tree trimmings originating within the city shall be given
to any person furnishing proof of residency within the city, as evidenced by a
current driver's license, a city issued landfill card, or a water bill with a
city of Enid address. This waiver shall not be available when the yard and tree
trimmings were collected by a commercial business.
      2.   Loads containing yard and tree trimmings mixed with trash or other
materials that cannot be processed in the city compost site shall not be
allowed a waiver on the landfill permit fee and shall be charged as provided in
subsection 2-6C-2A of this code.
   F.   Yard And Tree Trimmings Originating Outside City:
      1.   The landfill permit fee for the depositing of loads containing yard
and tree trimmings originating outside the city shall be as provided in
subsection 2-6C-2B of this code.
      2.   Loads containing yard and tree trimmings mixed with trash or other
materials that cannot be processed in the city compost site or loads which
contain refuse material shall be charged as provided in subsection 2-6C-2B of
this code.
   G.   Petroleum Contaminated Soil:
      1.   A permit will not be issued for any petroleum contaminated soil that
originates outside the state of Oklahoma.
      2.   For all petroleum contaminated soil, the generator is responsible
for providing laboratory analysis for benzene, BTEX (benzene, toluene,
ethylbenzene and xylene), TPH (total petroleum hydrocarbons - gas range, diesel
range, or both), and flashpoint. For any site that is suspect of containing
leaded gasoline, the generator is also required to test the soil for lead
content. In addition, any contaminated soil with a benzene concentration above
ten (10) mg/kg, or a lead concentration above five (5) mg/kg, the generator
shall perform a TCLP (toxicity characteristic leaching procedure) analysis. All
testing shall be performed by a laboratory approved by the Oklahoma department
of environmental quality (ODEQ).
      3.   All generators of petroleum contaminated soil will be required to
complete the nonhazardous industrial waste disposal request form provided by
the ODEQ, which shall be submitted to the city for approval thirty (30) days
prior to anticipated delivery. Approval or denial shall be provided to the
generator within fifteen (15) days of the receipt date of the request.
      4.   The generator must present a copy of the approval letter to landfill
personnel upon delivery of the first load of material and every load thereafter
must include a written statement indicating the originating site and the load
number it represents. Any load that is delivered to the landfill that is unable
to provide the required documentation will be rejected.
      5.   The city will deny any request to dispose of petroleum contaminated
soil with a TPH concentration in excess of eighteen thousand (18,000) ppm for
the diesel range, and three thousand six hundred ten (3,610) ppm for the gas
range. The city reserves the right to perform random testing for any
contaminated soil disposed of at the landfill facility. For any composite
sample that is found to be in excess of ten percent (10%) of the upper TPH
limit of the specified range, the generator is responsible for removing the
material within thirty (30) days. For any material that is not removed within
thirty (30) days, the generator will be assessed a fee as provided for in
subsection 2-6C-2E of this code.
      6.   Any petroleum contaminated soil shall be delivered to the landfill
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M.,
Monday through Friday. (Ord. 2012-13, 6-5-2012, eff. 7-15-2012)
8-4-14: PENALTY:
A violation of any provision in this chapter shall be a class A offense. Each
and every day on which a violation shall occur or continues to occur shall be
deemed a separate and distinct offense. Prosecution of such an offense is not
the exclusive remedy or mode of prosecution. (1994 Code § 34-177)
CHAPTER 5
STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM 1
SECTION:
8-5-1: Definitions
8-5-2: Stormwater Utility Service Charge And Exemptions
8-5-3: Collection Of Service Charge
8-5-4: Calculation Of Equivalent Service Unit (ESU)
8-5-5: Stormwater Development Fee
 
Notes
1 1. See title 13, chapter 3 of this code for stormwater management
  regulations.
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, for the purposes of this chapter,
the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given herein:
CITY: The city of Enid.
COMMON BILLED: A billing for water and/or sanitary sewer service for a tract
that is billed to the tract as one bill and not directly to the individual
units of that tract.
EQUIVALENT SERVICE UNIT (ESU): Shall be established at one unit per five
thousand (5,000) square feet of impervious surface or a portion thereof.
INDIVIDUAL BILLED: Where billing for water and/or sanitary sewer services for a
tract is by separate billing to the individual units of that tract.
STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE: The fee levied within the boundaries of the
city for the use of the city's stormwater drainage facilities.
USER: The owner, renter or lessee of a tract of land that drains stormwater to
the stormwater drainage system. (1994 Code § 11-61)
8-5-2: STORMWATER UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE AND EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Charges Established: There is hereby established a stormwater utility
service charge for the city's stormwater drainage system at rates hereinafter
established; provided, however, that the service charge shall not be imposed on
the following types of property:
      1.   City streets, rights of way, parks, and city owned property;
      2.   State of Oklahoma highway rights of way;
      3.   Railroad rights of way;
      4.   Undeveloped land.
   B.   Monthly Rate: The monthly stormwater utility service charge rate shall
be charged and collected as provided for in section
2-6E-9 of this code.
   C.   Application For Reduced Impervious Surface Rate: Any individually
billed single-family residential user may apply for a reduced impervious
surface rate for the user's individually billed single-family unit where the
total impervious surface of the tract associated to the unit is less than one
thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet in area. Application shall be
made to the customer service department on forms provided. Review of
applications shall be made by the engineering department for completeness and
correctness. Upon approval of application for a unit, the stormwater utility
service charge rate for that unit shall be changed to the reduced impervious
surface rate at the next billing cycle. At such time as the impervious surface
area of a unit exceeds one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet, the
standard rate shall apply and the reduced impervious surface rate shall not
apply. (1994 Code § 11-65)
8-5-3: COLLECTION OF SERVICE CHARGE:
   A.   Monthly Charges; Billing; Water Termination For Nonpayment:
      1.   The storm water utility service charges herein established for the
use of the city's storm water drainage system shall be billed to each user
monthly, along with a bill for water or other utility services and such
penalties as are now or may hereafter be established for other utility service
bills. All collecting agencies authorized by the city to accept payment of city
utility bills are hereby directed to advise customers of the provisions of this
section.
      2.   In the event that any person, firm or corporation shall tender as
payment of water service, sewer service, collection of solid waste service and/
or storm water utility service charge for the use of the city's systems an
amount insufficient to pay in full all of the charges so billed, the payment
shall be credited to the account or accounts in accordance with accounting
procedures used by the customer service department for utility bill payments.
      3.   The city shall have the right and privilege of discontinuing any and
all utility service to any premises for insufficient payment.
      4.   In the event that any utility account shall become delinquent, water
services may be terminated by the city until all delinquent charges for the use
of the city's storm water drainage system, collection of solid waste service,
sanitary sewer service and water service shall have been paid in full 1 .
      5.   The provisions for collection provided herein shall be in addition
to any rights or remedies which the city may have under the laws of the state
of Oklahoma.
   B.   Billing For Storm Water Drainage Only: In the case of users of real
estate who are not billed for water, sanitary sewer or collection of solid
waste, the owner of the real estate or agent of the owner shall be billed
monthly for the service charges herein established.
   C.   Saving Clause: The invalidity of any provision, clause or portion of
this section or the invalidity of the application thereof to any person or
circumstance shall not affect the validity of the remainder of this section or
the validity of its application to other persons or circumstances. (1994 Code §
11-66)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  8-1-7 of this title for notice to user before termination of service.
8-5-4: CALCULATION OF EQUIVALENT SERVICE UNIT (ESU):
   A.   Basis For Billing: The equivalent service unit (ESU) shall be
calculated by determination of the amount of impervious surface that exists or
will exist after development of any tract as set out in the definition of
"equivalent service unit (ESU)" in section
8-5-1 of this chapter. The ESU for certain tracts as calculated by, and on file
in, the engineering department of the city shall be the official determination
and shall be used as the basis for billing of the storm water utility service
charge.
   B.   Application For Determination:
      1.   Upon the development of a tract or tracts of land, the owner or user
of same shall make application for a determination of ESU for the tract.
      2.   Application shall include the measured square foot area of the site
being developed, amount of impervious surface to be in place at the time of
full development, location, legal description, name of owner or user of the
tract and address.
      3.   Application shall be made as part of the building or other city
permit application. A building permit shall be required when no other city
permit is applied for.
      4.   Upon determination of the ESU for the tract, it shall be added to
the official list, and billing for the storm water utility service charge shall
begin as set out in this chapter.
   C.   Changes In List: Changes may be made in the official list of ESU from
time to time to add tracts not included, add new developments, or make
corrections or adjustments.
   D.   Appeal Of Determination: Determinations in the official ESU may only be
appealed by the owner or user of the affected tract. Appeals shall be made in
writing to the director and shall include evidence of an error or
miscalculation in the determination. The director shall be given two (2) weeks
to review the application and, finding sufficient evidence, may direct the
official list of ESU to be changed. A finding of insufficient evidence or no
response in the two (2) week period shall be a denial of the appeal. (1994 Code
§ 11-67)
8-5-5: STORMWATER DEVELOPMENT FEE:
See sections
2-6E-10 and
13-3-10 of this code for charges and regulations. (1994 Code § 11-70; amd. 2003
Code)
CHAPTER 6
NATURAL GAS TRANSPORTATION
SECTION:
8-6-1: Definitions
8-6-2: License Required
8-6-3: Fee
8-6-4: Licensing Requirements
8-6-5: Revocation And Penalties
8-6-6: Duties Of Franchisee
8-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
CITY: The city of Enid, Oklahoma, a municipal corporation.
CONSUMER: Any individual person, corporation, company, partnership, firm,
unincorporated association, trust, or public corporation who uses or consumes
natural gas in the city but does not include self-suppliers of natural gas.
FRANCHISEE: Oklahoma Natural Gas Company or any other entity holding a valid
franchise from the city for the transportation, distribution or sale of gas.
LICENSE: The rights and privileges granted by the city manager on behalf of the
city of Enid to a consumer to use the public ways for the transportation of
natural gas as provided by this chapter.
LICENSEE: A consumer granted a license under this chapter.
PIPELINE SYSTEM: A system of works, pipes, pipelines, apparatus, machinery,
structures, appliances and appurtenances located within the public ways
reasonably necessary for the transportation, distribution, or sale of natural
gas.
PUBLIC WAYS: Any street, alley, avenues, boulevard, lane, park, parkway,
sidewalk, driveway, utility easement, right of way, and any other public ways,
places, areas, or grounds within the corporate limits of the city of Enid as
now constituted or may be added hereafter.
SETTLEMENT PRICE: The inside FERC first of the month price for natural gas as
published for the month of delivery in the "Platts Inside FERC Gas Market
Report" publication, under the heading "Prices Of Spot Gas Delivered To
Pipelines", Oneok Gas Transportation, LLC - Oklahoma, or a successor
publication or index.
TRANSPORT GAS: All natural gas transported and/or distributed by the
franchisee, but not sold by the franchisee, through the pipeline system to any
consumer located within the corporate limits of the city of Enid.
VOLUMETRIC RATE: That sum measured in cents per dekatherm "Dth" in accordance
with the provisions of section
8-6-3 of this chapter. The volumetric rate calculation shall be based on the
settlement price for the month of delivery and multiplied by three percent (3%)
to obtain the volumetric rate for that month. (Ord. 2005-22.5, 9-6-2005)
8-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No consumer shall receive or deliver gas within the city pursuant to any
pipeline system installed in the public ways, unless the consumer shall hold a
valid license from the city or the company selling the gas has a franchise with
the city. Such license shall be issued for the purpose of granting the licensee
authority to use the public ways. The city manager is hereby authorized to
issue licenses pursuant to the terms of this chapter and may adopt any
administrative policy or procedures deemed necessary to implement this chapter.
(Ord. 2005-22.5, 9-6-2005)
8-6-3: FEE:
In consideration of the issuance of a license by the city, a licensee shall pay
to franchisee, who shall collect and remit such fee on behalf of the city, a
fee for use of the public ways equal to the then current volumetric rate
multiplied by the number of Dth of transport gas distributed to the licensee
for consumption within the city.
All fees collected by the franchisee shall be monthly remitted to the city on
or before the twenty fifth day of each successive month during the term of the
license. (Ord. 2005-22.5, 9-6-2005)
8-6-4: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Any license issued shall contain the following material terms:
      1.   The licensee shall pay the fee set forth in section
8-6-3 of this chapter to franchisee;
      2.   The licensee shall grant to the city the right to audit at
reasonable times the books and records of the licensee to verify the correct
payment of the fee set forth in section
8-6-3 of this chapter;
      3.   The licensee shall assume conjointly with the franchisee or other
party allowed use of the public ways for pipeline installation the
indemnification terms of the franchise or other agreement insofar as the terms
apply to the licenses. (Ord. 2005-22.5, 9-6-2005)
8-6-5: REVOCATION AND PENALTIES:
   A.   A license shall be revocable by the mayor and board of commissioners at
any time upon a thirty (30) day prior written notice to licensee, with a copy
to the franchisee, for failure to pay fees assessed under section
8-6-3 of this chapter or upon a finding that the licensee or the third party
supplier of natural gas has violated a state or federal law having a reasonable
relationship to its fitness to conduct business.
   B.   Any violation of this chapter shall be an offense. Any consumer
adjudged guilty of violating any section contained in this chapter shall be
punished by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus costs, for each
offense; and each day of a continuing violation shall be deemed a separate
offense. (Ord. 2005-22.5, 9-6-2005)
8-6-6: DUTIES OF FRANCHISEE:
In addition to the duty to collect and distribute the fees as provided in
section
8-6-3 of this chapter, franchisee shall provide a yearly written report to the
city accounting for all volumes of gas transported or distributed through its
distribution system within the corporate limits of the city on behalf of all
licensees. (Ord. 2005-22.5, 9-6-2005)
TITLE 9
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODES AND STANDARDS 1
SECTION:
9-1-1: Building Code Adopted
9-1-2: Amendments To Building Code
9-1-3: The Construction Board Of Appeals
9-1-4: Existing Building Code Adopted
9-1-5: Amendments To Existing Building Code
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS §§ 14-107, 22-113, 43-102.
9-1-1: BUILDING CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption: Pursuant to 59 Oklahoma Statutes section 1000.23, the City of
Enid hereby adopts that certain technical code known as the International
Building Code (IBC), 2015 edition, excluding appendix chapters, as published by
the International Code Council, for the purpose of regulating and governing the
conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures, by
providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other
physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe,
sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of buildings and
structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition of such
structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and the
collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions,
penalties, conditions and terms of said Building Code are hereby referred to,
adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the
additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section
9-1-2 of this chapter.
      1.   Where such code conflicts with other adopted codes, the more
restrictive shall apply.
      2.   Three (3) copies of said adopted code have been and are now on file
in the Office of the City Clerk.
   B.   Violation: No person shall violate any of the provisions of this
chapter or of the publication adopted by or amended in this chapter. A
violation shall be punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00);
unless the person has previously been convicted of a violation of one of the
technical codes within the last three (3) years, then a violation shall be
punishable by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00); or unless the
person has previously been convicted of a violation of one of the technical
codes twice or more within three (3) years, then a violation shall be
punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 2015-42,
11-17-2015)
9-1-2: AMENDMENTS TO BUILDING CODE:
All amendments and modifications to the International Building Code (IBC), 2015
edition, as adopted by the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission, are
hereby adopted by the City of Enid and incorporated as fully as if set out at
length herein. Additional amendments are as follows:
Chapter 1 Scope And Administration is hereby amended in the following respects:
Section 101.1. Insert: the city of Enid.
Section 105.2 Work Exempt From Permit is hereby omitted.
Section 105.8 Contractors Bond Required is hereby created to read as follows:
It shall be the duty of every contractor or builder, who shall make contracts
for the erection or construction or repair of buildings for which a permit is
required, and every contractor or builder making such contracts and subletting
the same or any part thereof, to file with the city a bond in the sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) executed by a surety company, authorized to do
business in the state of Oklahoma, payable to the city, and which shall be
conditioned upon compliance by the principal with all ordinances of the city in
reference to building regulations and buildings. Said bond shall further save
and hold the city harmless from any kind of loss, expense, cost, damage,
action, or liability of any kind whatsoever, including reasonable attorney's
fees which the city may suffer or be recovered from the city by reason of any
loss, damage, or injuries sustained, performed by the principal or his agents,
in the use of the streets, alleys, or public property of the city or by reason
of negligence, failure or refusal of the principal or his agents to erect or
maintain proper safety devices, warning signals or barricades about such work
while it is in the process of construction or repair. The bond shall be
approved by the city attorney.
Section 109.2 Schedule Of Permit Fees. On all buildings, structures or
alterations requiring a building permit, as set forth in section 105, the fee
shall be paid as required at the time of filing application in the amounts
provided for in title 2, chapter 6, article F of the Enid municipal code.
Section 109.4.1 Triple Fees Authorized is hereby created to read as follows:
All fees are tripled if work is started prior to the issuance of any permit.
Existing equipment change outs shall be permitted to start prior to inspection
and issuance of permit. The assessment and/or payment of triple fees shall in
no way prevent further penalty, such as suspension or revocation of a license
and/or permit for excessive repetition of violations.
Section 113.1.1 is hereby created to read as follows: Appointment. There is
hereby established a board to be called the construction board of appeals,
which shall consist of nine (9) members. The board members shall be appointed
by the mayor and board of commissioners.
Section 113.3.1 is hereby created to read as follows: Membership. The
construction board of appeals shall consist of nine (9) members. Such board
shall consist of individuals with knowledge and experience in the technical
codes, such as design professionals, contractors, and building industry
representatives, specifically as follows:
One registered design professional who is a registered architect.
One registered design professional with structural engineering experience, or a
building contractor.
One building contractor, or a member from the building industry.
One registered design professional with electrical engineering experience, or a
licensed electrical contractor.
One licensed electrical contractor, or a licensed electrical journeyman.
One registered design professional with mechanical experience, or a licensed
mechanical contractor.
One licensed mechanical contractor, or a licensed mechanical journeyman.
One registered design professional with plumbing experience, or a licensed
plumbing contractor.
One licensed plumbing contractor, or a licensed plumbing journeyman.
A board member shall not act in a case in which he has a personal or financial
interest.
Section 113.3.2 is hereby created to read as follows: Terms. The terms of
office of the board members shall be for three (3) years. The appointments
shall be made in such a manner that the term of every member shall expire in
March. Vacancies shall be filled for an un-expired term in the manner in which
original appointments are required to be made. No member shall serve more than
two (2) terms in succession; however, partial terms shall not be considered in
determining the term limit. Members are subject to loss of office due to
absences pursuant to section
1-8-3A of the Enid municipal code and removal for cause by the mayor and board
of commissioners consistent with section
1-8-3B of the Enid municipal code.
Section 113.3.3 Quorum And Voting is hereby created to read as follows: A
simple majority of the board shall constitute a quorum. In allowing an
exception to any provision of this or other technical codes, the affirmative
votes of the majority present, but not less than three (3) affirmative votes,
shall be required. In modifying a decision of the code administrator, not less
than three (3) affirmative votes, but not less than a majority of the board,
shall be required.
Section 113.3.4 Secretary Of Board is hereby created to read as follows: The
code administrator shall act as secretary of the board and shall make a
detailed record of all of its proceedings, which shall set forth the reasons
for its decision, the vote of each member, the absence of a member and any
failure of a member to vote.
Section 113.3.5 Powers is hereby created to read as follows: The construction
board of appeals shall have the power, as further defined in 113.4 to hear
appeals of decisions and interpretations of the code administrator and consider
exceptions to only the technical codes found in title 9 of the Enid municipal
code.
Section 113.4 Appeals is hereby created.
Section 113.4.1 Decision Of The Code Administrator is hereby created to read as
follows: The owner of a building, structure or service system, or his duly
authorized agent, may appeal a decision of the code administrator to the
construction board of appeals whenever any one of the following conditions are
claimed to exist:
         a.   The code administrator rejected or refused to approve the mode or
manner of construction proposed to be followed or materials to be used in the
installation or alteration of a building, structure or service system.
         b.   The provisions of this code do not apply to this specific case.
         c.   That an equally good or more desirable form of installation can
be employed in any specific case.
         d.   The true intent and meaning of this code or any of the
regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or incorrectly interpreted.
         e.   Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within ten (10)
days after the decision is rendered by the code administrator. A fee as
provided in section
2-6F-2 of the Enid municipal code shall accompany such notice of appeal.
Section 113.4.2 Special Exceptions is hereby created to read as follows: The
construction board of appeals, when so appealed to and after a hearing, may
allow a special exception to the application of any provision of this or other
technical codes to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement
thereof would do manifest injustice and would be contrary to the spirit and
purpose of this code, the other technical codes or public interest, and also
finds all of the following:
         a.   That special conditions and circumstances exist which are
peculiar to the building, structure or service system involved and which are
not applicable to others.
         b.   That the special conditions and circumstances do not result from
the action or inaction of the applicant.
         c.   That allowing the exception requested will not confer on the
applicant any special privilege that is denied by this code to other buildings,
structures or service system.
         d.   That the exception allowed is the minimum exception that will
make possible the reasonable use of the building, structure, or service system.
         e.   That the allowing of the exception will be in harmony with the
general intent and purpose of this code and will not be detrimental to the
public health, safety and general welfare.
Section 113.4.2.1 Conditions Of The Special Exception is hereby created to read
as follows: In granting the special exception, the board may prescribe a
reasonable time limit within which the special exception required shall be
commenced or completed or both. In addition, the board may prescribe
appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this code. Violation
of the conditions of a special exception shall be deemed a violation of this
code.
Section 113.4.3 Notice Of Appeal is hereby created to read as follows: Notice
of appeal shall be in writing and filed within ten (10) calendar days after the
code administrator renders the decision. Appeals shall be on a form provided by
the code administrator.
Section 113.4.4 Unsafe Or Dangerous Buildings Or Service Systems is hereby
created to read as follows: In the case of a building, structure or service
system, which, in the opinion of the code administrator, is unsafe, unsanitary
or dangerous, the code administrator may, in his order, limit the time for such
appeals to a shorter period.
Section 113.5 Procedures Of The Board is hereby created.
Section 113.5.1 Rules And Regulations is hereby created to read as follows: The
board shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure not
inconsistent with the provisions of this code. The board shall meet on call of
the chairman. The board shall meet within ten (10) calendar days after notice
of appeal has been received.
Section 113.5.2 Decisions is hereby created to read as follows: The
construction board of appeals shall, in every case, reach a decision without
unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Each decision of the board shall also
include the reasons for the decision. If a decision of the board reverses or
modifies a refusal, order or disallowance of the code administrator or allows a
special exception to the application of any provision of this code, the code
administrator shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision.
Every decision shall be promptly filed in writing in the office of the code
administrator and shall be open to public inspection. A certified copy of the
decision shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the applicant and a copy shall
be kept publicly posted in the office of the code administrator for two (2)
weeks after filing. Every decision of the board shall be final; subject however
to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity.
Section 114.4 Violation Penalties. Any person who shall violate any provision
of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or
who shall erect, install, alter or repair a building or structure in violation
of the approved construction documents or direction of the code official, or of
a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00),
unless the person has previously been convicted of a violation of one of the
technical codes within the last three (3) years, then a violation shall be
punishable by a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00); or unless the
person has previously been convicted of a violation of one of the technical
codes twice or more within three (3) years, then a violation shall be
punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00).
Chapter 15 Roof Assemblies And Rooftop Structures is hereby amended to add the
following language:
Section 1507.1.1 Declaration Of Policy is hereby created to read as follows:
The mayor and board of commissioners of the city of Enid has determined that
the use of wood shingles upon a building or structure increase the hazard that
the flames of a nearby fire may spread to that building or structure. Further,
the use of wood shingles may increase insurance rates charged to the owner
because of the susceptibility of said shingles to be damaged as a result of
hailstorm events. Because of these findings, the commission believes that the
citizens of the city of Enid should not be compelled by restrictive covenants
to use wood shingles for their homes, building or other structures and that the
health, safety and welfare of said citizens should be promoted by making such
requirements invalid and unenforceable. The commission is also aware, however,
that developers and residents of subdivision protected by such restrictive
covenants are vitally interested in maintaining the aesthetic value of their
